Notes: supersuperstring

A vernacular prefix added to kinship terms, personal names and personal pronouns, e.g. Mand. ā-mǔ 阿母 ‘mother’ [Han texts], ā-nú  阿奴 ‘younger brother’, ā-shuí  阿誰 ‘who’, ā-nǐ 阿你 ‘you’ (Norman 1988: 113); Yuè-Guǎngzhōu a³³-ma⁵⁵ (Ɂaᶜ¹-maᴬ¹) 阿媽 ‘mother, mama’, a³³-ma²¹ (Ɂaᶜ¹-maᴬ²) 阿雙 ‘grandmother’.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *Ɂa- is a prefix for kinship terms, body parts or nouns in general, depending on the language (STC: 121-123), e.g. WB ə-tʰaŋ ‘thought’ < tʰaŋ ‘think’, ə-pʰuiᴮ ‘grandfather’; WT Ɂa-kʰu ‘uncle, husband’.

Occurs already in Zuǒzhuàn prefixed to the Chǔ dialect word for → hǔ1 虎 ‘tiger’. Unger (Hao-ku 33, 1986) suggests that certain words with MC initial Ɂ-  might be the result of a fusion of this prefix with the following stem (§5.11).

‘Younger brother’ [Jìn Dyn.] (Norman 1988: 113).  ||  [E] For phonological and semantic reasons, this word is prob. not related to rú 孺 *no ‘child’ (under → rú4 懦臑 ‘weak’), nor to → rǔ3 乳 ‘milk’. It may be connec ted to PTB *naːw (STC no. 271): Lushai nauᴴ < nau ‘child, younger brother or sister, younger cousin’ etc., JP kə³¹-nau³³ ‘younger brother / sister’, WT nu-bo ‘man’s younger brother’. The putative OC final *ā cannot be reconciled with PTB *āːw, though; perh. the CH word has been re-etymologized, or only committed to writing after *a > MC o.
‘To pity’ [Shi] is prob. a sound-symbolic word.
‘White-haired, old’ [Shi], possibly related to TB items under → yuè1 月 ‘moon’, but the vowels do not agree.  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋaj (去); MGZY ŋay (去) [ŋaj]

‘To love, to grudge’ [Shi] > Mand. ‘to like, be fond of’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu  SR Ɂaj (去); MGZY ’ay (去) [Ɂaj]; ONW Ɂɑiᶜ   ||  [E] ST: TB-PKaren *ʔai (Matisoff BSOAS 63.3, 2000: 364). Or MK *sʔəəc, *sʔaac ‘to love, pity’ (Shorto 2006 #798a).
‘To lose one’s breath’ [Shi] is a sound-symbolic word (§2.9)

‘Obstruct, hinder’ [Lie].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu  SR ŋaj (去); MGZY ngay (去) [ŋaj]; ONW ŋɑiᶜ   ||  [E] ? ST: WT ’geg(s)-pa, bkag, dgag ‘to hinder, prohibit, shut’ ᛝ ’gag ‘obstruction, stoppage’ (Bodman 1980: 72); PLB *Ɂgak ‘obstruct, block up’. TB voiced stops do occasionally correspond to Chinese initial nasals (§5.12.2). Alternatively, WT could be compared with → gù1 固. CH ài may be related to → yí13 疑 ‘hesitate’.
‘Be calm, peaceful, still, steady, take one’s leisure’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɂɔn (平); PR Ɂan; LR Ɂan; MGZY ’an (平) [Ɂan]; ONW Ɂɑn.

‘To push down with the hand’ [SW], ‘to stop, repress’ [Shi], ‘lay hand on, seize’ [Xun]; ‘stool, tray’ 案 [Zhouli].  ||  [<] exoactive of ān (§4.3), lit. ‘cause to be settled, calmed’.   ||  [C] Boltz (1994: 95ff) includes additional words which are written with this phonetic (GSR 146), such as → ān3 鞍. A parallel stem (§2.5) is → yàn1 宴燕 (Wáng Lì 1982: 543). → yǎn5 偃 is prob. a different etymon.

‘Saddle’ [Guanzi] is cognate to → ān1 安 acc. to Boltz (1994: 95f), lit. ‘seat’. Following the Shìmíng, Pulleyblank has suggested a connection with è 頞 (Ɂat) ‘bridge of the nose’ [Meng] (Boltz 1994: 98).

‘Dumb, silent’ [Mo].    ||  [E] ST *Ɂum: PTB *um ‘hold in the mouth’ (STC: 181) > WT Ɂum ‘a kiss’ (cf. Ɂu ~ Ɂo ‘a kiss’); Lepcha ŭm ‘receive into the mouth without swallowing’, Mikir om ‘mouthful’, Nung im ‘mouthful’ (HST: 95). Perh. also connected with PTB *(m-)uːm (STC: 181 n. 479). → cǎn 噆 is perh. a derivation.
‘Hold in the mouth, put in the mouth’ [GY].   ||  [T] ONW Ɂɑm.   ||  [<] endoactive of ān 喑 (§4.5).
‘Pent up’ [Zhuang].  ||  [<] exopass. of ān 喑 (§4.4), lit. ‘be held back in the mouth’, but the role of MC div. III is not clear (§9.1.2).
‘River bank’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋɔn (去); PR Ɂan; LR Ɂan; MGZY ngan (去) [ŋan]; ONW ŋɑn   ||  [E] ST: WT dŋo ‘shore, bank’.
‘Cliff’ [BI, SW], ‘high river bank’ [Liù shū běnyì 六書本義].

‘River bank’ [Shi].   ||  [<] These are all nouns derived from the stem *ŋaɁ ‘oppose, resist’ (→ yù17 禦), i.e. ‘the thing that resists the river’s flow, keeps the river in its bed’. The voiceless initial in hàn and hǔ denotes a noun referring to a natural object (§5.2.4), the final *-n in hàn and àn marks nouns in general (§6.4.3). The role, if any, of tone C is not clear. For an overview of similar and related words, see under → yà2 御迓訝.
‘A deep black’ [SW].

‘Be dark’ 暗 [Guoyu]; 闇 (also read QY Ɂậmᴮ) [Li] > Mand. ‘dim, gloomy’.   ||  [T] Sin S. SR Ɂam (去); PR Ɂan; MGZY ’am (去) [Ɂam], ONW Ɂɑmᶜ.   ||  [<] perh. exoactive of àn 黯 (§4.3), here noun > verb.   ||  [C] A probable allofam is → yīn5 陰 (so Wáng Lì 1982: 602).

‘(A small-mouthed, large-bellied) earthen jar (for fetching water)’ [Lunheng] > ‘obese, swollen’ [Zhuang]; later 盎 ‘basin, tureen’ (which is large-mouthed).    ||  [E] MK: Khmer ’āṅa /Ɂaaŋ/ ‘a type of large, wide-mouthed earthen jar, cistern, tank’.

‘To cry, clamor’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Perh. cognate to PTB *ŋuw > WT ŋu-ba ‘to weep, roar’, WB ŋui ‘cry, weep’, PL *ŋo¹ ‘cry’ (HST: 60). This identification is somewhat doubtful as the vowels and the meanings are not very close.

‘To fry’ [Zhouli], ‘roast’ [Li].  ||  [E] ST *ŋau: PTB *r-ŋaw (STC no. 270) > WT rŋod-pa, brŋos ‘to parch, roast, fry’; Chepang ŋāw; Mikir arŋu ‘roast, fry’; JP gə³¹-ŋau³³ ‘fry’ (STC: 193; also Bodman 1980: 78).

‘Inside’ (of a realm) [Shi], ‘bay, cove’ was acc. to Guō Pú (ca. 300 AD) a Jiāngnán (southern) word.  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɂaw (去); MGZY ’aw (去) [Ɂaw]; ONW Ɂɑu   ||  [D] This word is still used in Mǐn dialects: Fúzhōu oᶜ¹-tʰauᴬ², Xiàmén uᶜ¹   ||  [E] MK: Viet ao ‘pool, pond’, WrMon ‘o, o ‘cove, small bay’ (Norman 1983: 205).
‘Proud, arrogant’ [Shu]. Etymology not clear.   ||  [T] Sin S. SR ŋaw (去); PR aw; LR aw; MGZY ngaw (去) [ŋaw]

‘Eight’ [OB, Shi].   ||  [T] MTang pär, ONW pät — [D] PMin *pet, K-Méixiàn pat  ||  [E] ST *priat ~ *pret: PTB *b-r-yat (STC no. 163) > WT brgyad (< *bryat); TGTM *³pret, Kanauri *re; PLB *Ɂrit or *Ɂryat > WB hrac; Lushai paᴸ-riatF (Bodman 1980: 73); Bahing ja, Thulung jet; JP mə³¹-tsat⁵⁵ < m-rjat. CH -> Tai: PT *p-: S. pɛɛtᴰ¹ᴸ is obviously a CH loan (otherwise we should find an /r/ in the Tai initial).

‘Python’ [SW, Shanhaijing].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pa (平); MGZY: ba (平) [pa]); ONW pä  ||  [E] ? Kam-Tai: note Lao ŋuuᴬ⁴ kăbaaᴬ³ ‘a kind of viper: Agkistrodon’ (ŋuu ‘snake’, kă- perh. animal prefix) (James Chamberlain ICSTLL 1981). AA-PNB *qb≠àyh ‘snake’.

‘A kind of bamboo from southwest China’ [GY].   ||  [E] The word’s place of origin (SW China) and late appearance suggest that it is a loan from a TB language: PTB *pa [STC no. 44; Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 140] > WT spa ~ sba ‘cane’; WB waᴮ ‘bamboo’; JP kə⁵⁵-wa⁵⁵, wə³¹ ‘bamboo’, Lushai ruaᴴ (rɔF) (< *r-wa) ‘a kind of bamboo’ (HST: 38).
‘Bamboo hedge or fence’ [GY].  ||  [E] PTB: *rpa: Kom ra-pe, Tśiru ra-pa ‘fence’ (Kuki lgs.) [Shafer: IST 29].
‘Scar’ [JY].  ||  [E] ? ST: Perh. related to WT ’bar-’bar ‘uneven, rough, pock-marked’ (Unger Hao-ku  35, 1986: 36).

‘Wild pig, pig’ [Shi].   ||  [E] Bā is assumed to be a ST word related to PTB *pᵂak > WT pʰag; PLB *wak > WB wak; JP waɁ³¹ ‘pig’ (STC no. 43; Matisoff LL 1.2: 2000: 157f). But the OC and TB forms are phonologically not very close. OC medial *r corresponds also to a TB pre-initial, but TB forms for ‘pig’ do not have one, therefore one needs to assume some kind of CH innovation which led to medial *r. An OC open syllable corresponding to TB final -k is not common (§6.9). Alternatively, MK-Wa-Lawa-Bulang *bras ‘wild boar’ is semantically and phonologically close to the OC form. CH -> Miao languages npa⁴, npua⁴ ‘pig’ (Strecker LTBA 10.2, 1987: 51: Benedict, Wáng Fúshì).
‘To expel’ (a person) [Zhouli].  ||  [E] ST: Lushai pɔtᴸ / pɔɁᴸ ‘to pull, pull up, out’. Allofams may include → fā 發 and → fèi6 廢 ‘cast aside’ (if derived from fā).
‘Uprooted’ 沛 [Shi], ‘thinned out’ (trees) 拔 [Shi], ‘uprooted’ figuratively of a person 沛 [Lunyu].   ||  [<] exopass. of bá 犮 *bât (§4.4).
‘To pull up, uproot, be uprooted’ [Yi, Shu].   ||  [<] r-caus. of bá 犮 *bât (§7.5), lit. ‘cause to be uprooted’.

‘Roots of grass’ [Huainan, SW]. SW 377 considers this word related to → fā 發 ‘lift up / out’ and → fá2 伐 ‘to plow’ as the plow exposes the roots of the grass. An allofam may be → bá3 茇 ‘to camp’, and perhaps bá 跋 ‘foot, base’.  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. Comparanda may include TB-JP (n³¹-/niŋ³¹-) pot³¹ ‘root; origin’; or see bá3  茇.
‘To camp on grassland’ [Shi, Zuo].  ||  [E] This is likely a specialized meanings of a MK etymon: MK *kɓat, *ɓat ‘grass’ (Shorto 2006 #1034). Possibly, bá2 茇 ‘roots of grass’ could be related.
‘To trample on (with feet), trudge’ [Shi], ‘foot, base’ (of a torch) [Li]; ‘the end of an arrow’ [Shi]. Possibly related to bá2 茇 ‘roots (of grass)’, but that would be rather strained.

‘A handful’ [Guoyu], ‘grasp’ [Meng].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pa (上);  MGZY: suppl. ba (上) [pa])  ||  [E] ST: WT spar-ba ‘the grasping hand, paw, claw, a handful’ (Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 36). Matisoff (2000: 155f) connects this word with PTB *r-pa-k ‘palm / sole and leaf’. For the r-metathesis, see §7.7.3.  ||  This word may be related to → pá2, bá 耙杷 ‘rake’. Given its TB cognates, it is prob. not related to → fú3 扶 ‘breadth of two fingers’. Wáng Lì (1982: 173) relates this wf to → bǐng2 秉 ‘grasp’.
‘Flat valley’. This word from SW China is a Tai loan: S. paaᴮ¹ < *paᴮ  ‘meadow’ (Li F. 1976: 46; Mei Tsu-lin, AAS 1980).

‘To stop, cease’ (work etc.) tr. [Lun]. Prob. not related to → bì25 畢.  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ba (去); MGZY pay (上) [baj]  ||  [E] ST: WB priᴮ < preᴮ ‘be done, completed’ (CVST 1: 59), perh. also JP pʰraɁ³¹ < pʰrak³¹ ‘to complete’.

‘Be white’ [OB, BI, Shi] always has been a basic color term (Baxter JCLTA 19, 1983), also applied to silver.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR bəj (入); LR bəjɁ; MGZY pay (入) [baj]; ONW bëk  ||  [N] The graph represents an acorn, note the element 白 in the original graphs for → lè 樂 = lì 櫟 ‘oak’ and zào 皂 ‘acorn’. It is not clear why the graph has been selected for ‘white’. (Unger Hao-ku  29, 1984).  ||  [E] ST: Most plausibly, bái is a CH kēxtension (§6.1) of the ST root *bar ‘white’ and thus cognate to → pó3 皤 ‘white’ (so Wáng Lì 1982: 292), hence OC < *bar-k: PTB *pwaːr > Lushai vaarᴴ ‘be white, light’, PKaren *Ɂ(b)wa ‘white’ (Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 145).  ||  Tai: S. pʰiak < *pʰr/l- ? ‘white, albino’ (Li F. 1976: 44) may be a CH loan. <> AA ‘silver’ may be related: Nyah Kur prak, PVM *prak.  ||  Alternatively, note this area word for ‘white’ without medial r which is, however, difficult to reconcile with MC: MK *kɓɔɔk ‘white, gray’ (Shorto 2006 #369a); PTB *bok (?): S. Kuki bok ‘white’, Garo gibok ~ gipok, Dimasa *g-pʰuk.    ||  [C] Possible cognates are → bó1 伯 ‘elder’; → bó2 帛; → pò4 魄, → pò5 霸魄.   ||  (bái2)  白     ||  [D] Min: Fúzhōu paiɁ⁷, Amoy bat⁷ ‘to know’, borrowed from AA: Viet biẽt ‘to know, recognize’, also PMY *p¹ai¹ᴬ ‘to know’ (Norman / Mei 1976: 298).

‘Hundred’ [BI, Shi]. The OB graph is similar to, but not identical with, → bái1 白 ‘white’ (Unger Hao-ku  29, 1984).   ||  [T] Sin S. SR pəj (入), LR pəjɁ; MGZY bay (入) [paj]; ONW pëk.  ||  [E] ST *(p)rya: PTB *r-ya (STC no. 164) > WT brgya < br-ya; Kanauri rā; PLB *hrya, WB əra (inscriptional rya), Lushai zaᴸ-biR < jaɁ/h, Paangkhua razáa < rya. For the final -k, see §6.1. CH -> PTai *p-: Lóngzhōu paakᴰ¹ᴸ is obviously a CH loan (otherwise we should expect an r in the initial and almost certainly an open syllable).

‘To open’ [Guiguzi].   ||  [E] ST *prai: WB praiᴮ ‘to gape, expand, flare’ ᛝ pʰraiᴮ ‘to pull open, make gap’; Chepang pre-Ɂak-sa ‘to separate’ (intr.).  ||  A derivation is → bò3 擘 (pɛk). Possibly related to → zhā 奓 *trai ‘to open’. For an overview of similar items, see the table under → pí7 罷疲. For a listing of similar words and possible allofams, see → lí10 離.

‘To ruin, destroy’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pai, bai (去);  MGZY  bay, pay (去) [paj ~ bɑj]  ||  [E] Etymology not certain, but Tai: S. prap⁴ ‘to subdue, conquer’ is the same etymon and indicates a PCH form *praps > OCM *prâts. (The phonetic → bèi2 貝 is also connected to foreign -p). The direction of borrowing is undetermined, yet Tai is prob. not the ultimate source of CH. More likely, the etymon is a ‘medial r’ causative derivation (§7.5) with the addition of the redundant exoactive final *-s (§4.3). AA is the most likely source of OC: OMon pop /pop/ ‘to give way to’, Khmer -pap /-bɑɑp/ ‘be beaten, subdued, routed’ ᛝ paṁpapa /bɑmbɑɑp/ ‘to crush’ (opposition), ‘break down’ (resistance). (Note that MK has a causative r-infix). <> ST: WT ’brab-pa ‘to beat, scourge (e.g. with thorns), scatter’ (e.g. grain for offering) is semantically somewhat removed.   ||  Alternatively, bài may be derived from → fèi6 廢 ‘reject, fall’; however, fèi6 廢 ᛝ fá 乏 = WT bab ‘fall down’ is semantically different from bài 敗 = AA pap ‘be beaten’, hence we consider these two distinct wfs. Acc. to Wáng Lì (1982: 500) an allofam is → bì10 敝弊斃 ‘worn out’. Pulleyblank (1962: 215) relates this wf to → pí7 罷疲. See → fèi6 廢 for additional comments.
‘To go to ruin, defeat’ [OB, Shi].  ||  [<] endopass. of bài 敗 (paiᶜ) (§4.6).
‘To bend or put together’ (the hands in salute), ‘to salute’ [BI, Shi]. Etymology not clear.

‘Fine rice’ [Shi].  ||  [E] This etymon is close to → lì21 糲 *ras ‘coarse grain’ and its possible cognates, both hail perh. from the some foreign source. This word bài and → mǐ1 米 ‘rice’ can on occasion be connected with the same foreign comparandum. The following items look similar to bài: AA-Kharia pɛɁ, Khmer paj < *paih, *pih ‘rice’, PNB *pʰe ‘husked rice’. Note also TB-Mru rai ‘a species of rice’, Lushai ṭaiF < traih (< *-s) ‘species of early rice’ [Löffler 1966: 132]; the Lushai word has also been associate with WT kʰre ‘millet’ (Sagart ms 2002: 8).

‘To distribute’ [BI, Shu] > ‘spread out, scatter’ [Zuo] > ‘to arrange, classify’ [Meng].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR  pan (平);  MGZY  ban (平) [pan]  ||  [E] ? ST *pral: WT ’pʰral-ba ‘to separate, part’ ᛝ ’bral-ba ‘be separated, lose’, WB praᴮ ‘be divided into several parts, various’, JP pə³¹-ran³¹ ‘be separate, sort out’ (for JP allofams, see → lí 離). In HST: 65, the WT item is associated with → bàn2, biàn  釆, and with → bàn1 半 by Bodman (1980: 147), while Karlgren (1933: 92f) combines all of these into one wf (no. 26-37). <> AA has an alternative comparandum which is semantically closer to OC, even the initial *p- could represent an AA trans. / caus. prefix: Khmer rāla /ríiəl/  intr. ‘to spread, extend, distribute’ ᛝ brāla /príiəl/  tr. ‘to spread’.  ||  A cognate is prob. *(C-)ral → lí10 離 *rai with the occasional ST *-l > OC *-i shift (§8.3). → bān2 斑 is perh. the same word. For an overview over similar items, see lí10 離 and the Table P-1 under → pī3 披.
‘Variegated’ [Li] may either be the s. w. as → bān1 班 ‘scatter’; or may be a derivation from → bó9 駁 ‘mixed colors’. In this case, OCM *prân would derive from earlier *pron.
‘To move, transport’, a post-classical word.    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR  pwɔn (平), PR pɔn, LR  pɔn; cf. 般 MGZY bon (平) [pɔn]
‘Board, plank’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST *par: WT ’pʰar ‘a panel, small plank’ (Bodman 1980: 145; HST: 45). CH -> PTai *p-: S. pɛɛnᶜ¹. For the OC medial *r, see §6.1.
‘Great’ (of demeanor, domain, god) [Shi].  ||  [E] ? ST: WT ’pʰar-ba ‘raised, elevated’ (Bodman 1980: 145; HST: 88). For the OC medial *r, see §6.1.

‘Half’ [Yi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pwɔn (去), PR pɔn, LR pɔn;  MGZY  bon (去) [pɔn]; ONW pɑn  ||  [E] ST *par: WT bar ‘interstice, intermediate space, middle, mean’ (HST: 109) ᛝ WT pʰrag < par-k ‘intermediate space, interstice, interval’ (§6.1); NNaga pʰar ‘divide’ [French 1983: 183]. JP ban ‘division, part’, Bodo pan ‘share, part’ may belong here which CVST I: 4f. relate to → fēn1 分, however. Li F. (1976: 41) also relates Tai: S. panᴬ¹ < *p- ‘to divide into shares’ to fēn. For alternative connections, see → bān1 班.

‘To cleave’ [Zhouli], ‘divide’ 判 [Zuo]; ‘one half, one of two parts’ 片 [Zhuang] > semi-circular pool, shore’ 泮 [Shi], and additional specialized meanings based on ‘half’.   ||  [<] exoactive of bàn (§4.3), perh. caus. aspiration (§5.8.2).
‘Bank between fields, separate from’ [Zuo], ‘to separate from, rebel’ [Lunyu].   ||  [<] endopass. of bàn (§4.6), lit. ‘be separated from’.

‘Discriminate, distinguish’ [Shu].   ||  [<] exopass. of biàn 辨辯 below (§4.3), lit. ‘(cause to) be divided’.  ||  [E] ? ST: This wf may belong to TB-Lushai pʰelᴴ ‘to split, cut in halves’ (medial r does not occur in Lushai after labial initials), and / or to *pral > → bān1 班 (§2.5).
‘Sections of a fruit’  [SW].  ||  [<] exopass. of biàn 辨辯 below (§4.3), lit. ‘what is divided’. → bàn4 瓣 ‘petals’ is perh. the s. w.
‘Divide’ [Zhouli], ‘distinguish, discriminate’ 辨 [Lunyu] (also MC bănᶜ), 辯 [Yi], ‘dispute’ [Meng].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR bjen (上);  MGZY pen (上) [bɛn]; ONW ban
‘To deal with, handle, manage’ [BI, Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR  ban (去);  MGZY  pan (去) [ban]  ||  [E] ST *brel: WT brel-ba ‘be employed, busy, engaged’ (Bodman 1980: 163).

‘Petals of a flower’ is a late word [14th cent. AD]. The MC reading applies to the meaning ‘sections of a fruit’ (under → bàn2, biàn 釆). In the QYS, the rimes ān  and -ăn seem to have been confused on occasion; therefore -ăn could also go back to *-rân.  ||  [E] ‘Petals’ is possibly the same word as bàn 瓣 ‘section of fruit’ (under → bàn2, biàn   釆). Alternatively, it could be the same etymon as → pā 葩 ‘flowers, blossoms’ and prob. related to ‘burn’ → fán5 燔, note the WT word me-tʰog ‘flower’, lit. ‘fire-top’.
‘Country’ [Shi], possibly the same etymon as → fēng1 封 (Wáng Lì 1982: 388).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR paŋ (平); MGZY  bang (平) [paŋ]

‘Board’ [Jinshu].  ||  [E] ST: WT spaŋ ‘board, plank’ (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 48). Superficially, this word looks like a doublet of → bǎn1 板版. The graph also writes a word QYS pɐŋᶜ, LH paŋᶜ ‘oar’ [Chuci].
‘Club, stick’ [Post-Han: Weishu].  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. pʰlɔɔŋᴬ² < *b- ‘club, cudgel’ (Manomaivibool 1975).

‘To wrap, bundle’ [Shu], ‘contain’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR paw (平); MGZY baw (平) [paw]  ||  [E] ST: WT ’pʰur-ba ‘to wrap up, envelop’ (Unger Hao-ku  35, 1986: 36), perh. also Lepcha prók ~ prek ‘wrap up’ [Bodman ICSTLL 1987: 21]. For the r-metathesis, see §7.7.3. This word is often thought to be cognate to → bào1 抱 ‘carry in arms’, but the TB cognates cast doubt on this.

‘Womb’ [Zhuang].  ||  [E] ST: WT pʰru-ma ~ ’pʰru-ma/-ba ‘uterus, placenta’ (Bodman 1980: 142; HST: 161); Löffler (ZDMG 116.1, 1966: 152) adds Mru bur ‘menstruation’. Acc. to Karlgren (1956: 5) this is the s. w. as → bāo1 包 ‘wrap’, but this is doubtful in light of TB cognates which distinguish these two items. Löffler relates ‘womb’ to → páo 匏 ‘gourd’.

‘To cut up, peel, pluck’ [Shi].   ||  [D] Guǎngzhōu mɐk⁷ ‘to peel’ (Sagart 1999: 80), Zhōngshān mɔk⁵⁵ ‘to undress’.  ||  [E] Perhaps connected with MK, but the OC medial *r poses a problem: MK *pɔɔk ‘to peel’ (Shorto 2006 #347) -> Tai: S. pɔɔkᴰ¹ ‘to peel’; note also PTai *dlɔɔk: S. lɔɔkᴰ² ‘to skin, peel’ ᛝ plɔɔkᴰ¹‘an encasement, slipcover, sheath’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 120). This word is thought to be related to → lù1 彔 ’carve’, but ‘carve’ and ‘peel’ are rather different procedures.

‘To take care of’ (a baby by wrapping it in swaddling cloth) [Meng], (people) [Shu]; ‘preserve, protect, maintain’ [Shi].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR paw (上); MGZY baw (上) [paw]  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. Following Táng Lán, Qiu Xigui (2000: 212f) interprets an OB form of the graph as well as an occurrence in Shūjīng 17,10  as ‘to carry (a baby) on the back’, thence ‘take care of’ etc.; bǎo would then be the OC cognate of the TB items under → fù11 負. However, in no textual occurrence, incl. Shūjīng, has bǎo the unequivocal meaning ‘carry on the back’. Alternatively, this could be the s. w. as → bǎo3 寶 ‘precious’ used in a putative sense, lit. ‘consider something precious’, and then act accordingly.  ||  It is not clear if / how → bāo1 包 ‘wrap, contain’, and WT pʰru-ma ‘fortified camp, palace, fort’ (HST: 164) may be related.
(What protects, shields:) ‘secure’ (residence, land) 葆 [Shu]; ‘fort, stronghold’ 保 [Li]; ‘cover’ for a chariot 葆 [Lun Heng].

‘The cloth’ (in which children are carried on the back) [Lüshih], ‘swaddling cloth’ [Liezi], used in the expression qiǎng bǎo 繈 or 襁褓 (qiǎng, MC kjaŋᴮ, ‘string, cord’, here prob. ‘strap’); apparently bǎo refers to the protective swaddling cloth, not to the notion of carrying a baby on the back.

‘To eat to the full, satiated’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR paw (上); MGZY  baw (上) [paw]; ONW päu  ||  [E] Prob. area word: TB-Lushai puarᴴ < puar ‘having eaten enough’ (Unger Hao-ku  35, 1986: 36), Chepang bʰorɁ- ‘eat in plenty, feed generously’, perh. connected with AA-Khmer /póor/ ‘to fill, be full, brim full, swollen’. For the r-metathesis, see §7.7.3.

‘Be precious, treasure’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR paw (上); MGZY  baw, ba’o (上) [paw]; ONW pɑu  ||  [E] ST *pu: PTB *puw  (STC no. 41) > WB ə-pʰuiᴮ ~ ə-bʰuiᴮ ‘price’, JP pʰu³³ ‘be of value, expensive’ (HST: 155), Lushai puᴴ < pʰuu ‘be worthy, deserving’. CVST 1: 63 adds WT spus ‘goods, merchandise’. → bǎo1 保 could be the same word. Sagart (1999: 58) considers bǎo possibly related to fù 富 (under → fú19 福).

‘Carry in the arms’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR  baw (上); MGZY  paw (上) [baw]  ||  [E] This is perh. related to WB puik ‘hold in arms, hug’, and / or to AA-Khmer /pɔɔ/ and /pɔɔr/ ‘hold or carry in the arm(s)’. Note also → bāo1 包 ‘wrap’. -> PMiao *buoᶜ.

‘To repay, requite, reward, respond, announce’ [Shi], ‘report’.  ||  [E] This is prob. an allofam of → fù12 復 ‘return, reply, report’ (so Wáng Lì 1982: 244; Sagart 1999: 58). <> Tai: S. bɔk⁴ ‘to tell, say, inform’.
‘Be low, humble’ [Shi], opposite of ‘high’ [Zuo].
(a) ‘Be low’ [Zuo], ‘be short’ 庳 [Zhouli].  ||  (b) ‘Low ground’ 埤 [Guoyu]; ‘female slave, servant’ 婢 [Li].  ||  [<] endoactive (§4.5.1) ‘what / who is low’. A possible allofam is → bì20 嬖.
‘Slope, bank, dyke’ [Shi, Shu], ‘slanting’ [Yi]. Prob. not related to → pǔ1 浦.
‘Be slanting, oblique’ 惇 [Shu, Yi]; ‘one-sided words, insincere’ 詖 (also MC pje) [Meng].   ||  [<] perh. exoactive, i.e. a verb derived from the noun bēi, bī 惇.

‘Oblique, slanting’ [Chuci], ‘partial, perverse’ 頗 [Shu]; ‘slope, bank’ 坡.   ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu pʰɔᴬ¹, Táishān puɔᴬ¹; K-Méixiàn pɔᴬ¹  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. pʰlay² (McFarland: 550) ‘leaning, sloping’; MC div. I may indicate an OC medial l (§8.2).
‘Oblique’ [Chuci] > ‘depraved, perverse’ [Shu], ‘despise’ [Zuo].   ||  [<] kēxtension of the root *pai ‘slanting, oblique’ (§6.1).

‘Avoid’ [Shi, Meng], ‘go away’ [Guoyu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR bi (去); MGZY  pi (去) [bi]  ||  [E] ST: Lushai paiR < paiɁ ‘out of a straight line, oblique’. Allofams are → bǒ 跛 ‘walk lame’, → piān 偏 ‘oblique’, perh. → bō1 波 ‘wave’.
‘Cup’ 杯 [Li], 桮 [Meng].  ||  [E] ST: WT pʰor-pa ‘bowl, dish, cup’ (Unger Hao-ku  35, 1986: 33).
‘Be unhappy, pained’ [Shi]; ‘to pity’ [Shiji]; ‘long for, miss’ [Hanshu]. Etymology not clear.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pi (平); PR pəj;  MGZY  bue (平) [puɛ]

‘Cowry shell’ [BI, Shi].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR puj (去), PR pəj, LR pəj; MGZY  bay (去) [paj]  ||  [E] ? ST *pop: Chepang bop ‘snail’, JP lə⁵⁵-pop⁵⁵ ‘snail’ (Bodman 1980: 136). A MK word looks similar, but cannot be reconciled with CH: MK *ɓa(a)y > Khasi sbâi ‘cowry, shell, money’, Khmer p`ɯy ‘obsolete small coin’ (Shorto 1972).
‘Fill up, obstruct’ (a hole) [Yi].  ||  [E] ? ST: WT ’ba ‘hole’ (CVST 1: 92). (But WB pʰa ‘patch up, close a hole by patching’ belongs to → bǔ2 補).
‘Resist, obstinate’ [Zuo].

‘Double’ [Shi].  ||  [<] perh. endoactive of péi 陪培 (§4.5).  ||  [E] ? ST: WT ’pʰar-ma ‘double, manifold’ (Unger Hao-ku  35, 1986: 33), Lepcha băr [bər], Adi par- ‘increase’ [Bodman ICSTLL 1987: 7]. → fù7 阜 ‘big mound’ is a different etymon.
‘To augment, double’ [Zuo], ‘accompany, associate, support’ 陪 [Shi]; ‘accumulate, add to’ 培 [Zhuang].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR buj (平); PR bəj; MGZY pue (平) [buɛ]; ONW bɑi

‘To collect, assemble, be together’ [Shi]. Given the dialectal difference between *ə and *o after labial initials in the Shījīng and later, this word may be a variant of the stem *bə due to similarity with the complex ‘swell’ → fù8 阜.

‘Ready, complete, perfect’ [Shi], ‘prepare, provide’ [Zuo].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR bi (去), LR  bi; MGZY pue (去) [buɛ]  ||  [E] ? MK: Mon preŋ ‘to have prepared, prepare, arrange’, note also the Khmer causative prefix bəŋ-. OC -> Tai: S. pʰrakᴰ² < b- ‘prepare, ready’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 207). For the final consonants, see §6.6.

‘To cover’, incl. putting on clothes, also figuratively [Shi], ‘be covered, to wear’ [Zuo], ‘outside garment’ [Yili].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR bi (上去), LR bi; MGZY pue (上去) [buɛ]; MTang bi, ONW be  ||  [E] ST: Lushai belF < beelɁ tr. ‘to cause or make wear, put on’ (garment, load, plaster...). Following Shìmíng, Wáng Lì (1982: 446) relates → pí1 皮 ‘skin, hide’ to this root.
‘Cover oneself with’ [Zuo] < caus. ? (§5.8.2).
‘A cloak’ [Zuo] < general derivation (§3.5).

‘To run, flee’ [BI, Shi], ‘to hasten’ (奔命 ‘hasten to carry out an order’ [Zuo]), frequently in the BI bēn-zǒu 奔走 ‘to run and hurry while serving someone > to busy oneself for’.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *ploŋ (STC no. 140): JP pʰroŋ³³ ‘flee, run away’, Mikir arploŋ < r-ploŋ  ‘run’ ᛝ iŋploŋ < m-ploŋ ‘run, gallop’, Lahu phɔ ‘flee’, perh. also WB hroŋ ‘flee’ [Matisoff]. For the difference in final nasals, see §6.4.2.
‘Be ardent, brave’ [BI, Shu], ‘ardent’ 奔 [Shi].   ||  [E] ST: Lushai pʰuurR < pʰuurɁ ‘zealous, eager, earnest, enthusiastic’. Some of the words under → fén4 墳 probably belong here.

‘Root, stem’ [Shi] > ‘origin, fundament’ [Zuo]; measure for books [Nanbaichao], the origin of this latter meaning is not clear (Norman 1988: 116).  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pun (上); PR pən; LR pən; MGZY  bun (上) [pun]; ONW pon  ||  [E] CH -> Tai-Wuming plønᶜ¹ ‘volume’ (Bodman 1980: 108). If indeed the Wuming -l- should go back to OC, then the final -n  in běn would not be the result of the sound change ST *-l > OC *-n, but be the PCH nominal n-suffix attached to *pul (§6.4.3).  ||  ST *pul: PTB *bul ~ *pul  > Lushai bulR < buulɁ ‘beginning, origin, base, stump, lower part’ ? ᛝ buulᴸ / bulɁᴸ (< buulh / bulɁ/h) ‘be broken off, lopped off’ (as extremity, limb, shoot), NNaga pul ‘tree’ [French 1983: 177], Garo bol ‘root, stump’, Moshang puul ‘root’; JP pʰun⁵⁵ ‘tree, wood’ (STC: 166; HST: 127), perh. also WT sbun ~ spun ‘stalk of a plant’ (CVST 1: 14). This word may be cognate to a root → fēn1 分 ‘cut off, cut in two’ (hence ‘tree stump, tree trunk...’).
‘Be stupid’, a post-Han word which may, however, be old (such words are not common in classical texts) and cognate to WT blun-pa ‘dull, stupid’.

‘Mountain slide; to collapse, die (of a prominent person)’ [Shi]. PMin *p̆- derives perh. from a prenasalized initial, note Yao baaŋ¹ (< *nb-) ‘collapse, fall over’ (Norman 1986: 382).  ||  [E] Etymology not certain, but note TB-Chepang bəŋh- ‘to slip, slide’ (earth, rock) ᛝ bəŋh- n. rock or earth slide, landslide’. Chepang bom- ‘fall down’ ᛝ WT ’pʰam-pa, pʰam ‘be beaten, conquered’ (Bodman 1980: 119) is unrelated.

‘To put the coffin into the ground, bury’ [Zuo]. The word is not related to → biǎn5 窆.  ||  [E] Prob. AA: Khmer: OKhmer pāṅ /paŋ/ ‘to cover, hide, bury’. -> Tai pɔɔŋᶜ¹ < *p- ‘to protect, cover up’ (not related to → bǔ2 補, as Li F. 1976: 40 suggests).

‘Vulva’, a late word which could, however, be old since such items are not mentioned in classical texts.   ||  [D] Mǐn: Amoy tsiᴬ¹-paiᴬ²; with final consonant Kèjiā: Dōngguān ³³tsiᴬ¹-²²petᴰ¹ 支北. Yuè dialects have ⁵⁵hɐiᴬ¹ (Guǎngzhōu) which is a Tai loan (Benedict LTBA 5.1, 1979), but apparently also found in some TB languages: Limbu hira ‘vagina’, Tangkhul Naga hai.  ||  [E] ST *bet ?, PTB *b(y)et (HPTB: 375): PLB *b(y)et§ ‘vulva’, Kanauri pʰɛːts; also Tamang and Baro pi-si [Benedict LTBA 5.1, 1979: 30; LTBA 14.1: 143-6; R. Bauer LTBA 14.1: 147-165]. Benedict [LTBA 14.2, 1991: 151] derives this etymon from a root ‘hidden’, WT sbed-pa, sbas, sba ‘to hide, conceal’, but a WT root with a as in sba does normally not correspond to one with vowel e / i in Chinese; see also → bì12 蔽.   ||  [<] Derived from ‘to open’ pì 闢 (under → pī3 披), final *-t marks nouns of naturally occurring objects (§6.2.1), hence lit. ‘opening’. Syn. → zhì6 膣.

‘To crowd together, encroach upon, near to’ [Zuo, Meng]; ‘to urge, press, close’ 逼 [Meng, Zuo].  ||  [E] Prob. ST: TB-Lushai pikᴸ ‘be thick, dense, impenetrable, overcrowded, overgrown’. Alternatively, Baxter (1992: 473) relates this item to → lì1 力.

‘Nose’   ||  [D] Mand. bízǐ 鼻子. This form in final *-t  is found in modern central and northern dialects as well as in the medieval Shāzhōu dialects in the NW, e.g. Gàn pʰitᴰ, Línchuān pʰitᴰ². Acc. to Baxter (1992: 319) this word may reflect an early loss of final *-s  (in *-ts, *-ks) which seems to have occurred in the northwest area; or it may reflect a dialectal change from earlier *-s to *-t (Pulleyblank JAOS 118.2, 1998: 204f).  ||  [E] Perh. cognate to WT sbrid-pa ‘to sneeze’ (HST: 113), but CH has no trace of an r.

‘Nose’ [OB, Meng].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR bi (去);  MGZY pi (去) [bi]; ONW bii  ||  [D] This tone C variant is found in ONW, Sui-Tang Cháng’ān, MC, and in modern southern dialects.: Min *bʰiᶜ: Jiàn’ōu pʰiᶜ², Fúzhōu pʰeiᶜ, Xiàmén pʰı̃ᶜ²; Kèjiā: Méixiàn pʰiᶜ¹ (Norman 1988: 223).
‘To smell’ in Kèjiā and Mǐn: PMin *biᶜ: Jiàn’ōu piᶜ², Xiàmén pʰiᶜ² < *bʰiᶜ.

‘To be associating’ [Shi], ‘equal, similar’ [Li],’compare’ [Zuo]. Possibly → pì5 譬 ‘example’ could be related.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pi (上), PR pəj, LR pi; MGZY  bi (上) [pi]; MTang pi, ONW pii  ||  [<] endoactive of bì 比 *pih (§4.5).  ||  [E] ST: Lepcha bín ‘follow closely, belong to, be with, be next to’ (Geilich ibid.); WT pʰyi ‘behind, after’ ᛝ pʰyi-ma ‘later, subsequently’ ᛝ pʰyid ‘after, following’ ᛝ pʰyin ‘later, afterwards’. The wf → bīn2 濱 either belongs to the same root, or two ST roots, *pi ‘edge, outside’ and *pi ‘next to, follow, after’ have partially converged in CH and WT.
‘To put together, match, assemble’ [Shi].  ||  [<] exoactive of bǐ 比 (§4.3). The readings of this and the next item are from Jīngdiǎn shìwén.
‘To join’ [Shu], ‘go together with’ [Shi], ‘follow’ [Lun], ‘close together, successive’ [Li].
‘Several together’ [Guoyu], ‘close to’ [BI] (Geilich 1994: 125).

‘Deceased mother, ancestress’ [OB, Shi].  ||  [E] ST *pi: PTB *pəy  or *piy > WT Ɂa-pʰyi, pʰyi-mo ‘grandmother’, Kanauri a-pi, WB ə-pʰeᴮ ‘great grandfather’ᛝ ə-pheᴮ-maᶜ ‘great grandmother’ (STC no. 36); Lushai piᴴ ‘(great-) grandmother’ (Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 172).
‘Unripe grain, chaff’ [Zuo], ‘petty’ [Zhuang].  ||  [E] ? ST *pi(Ɂ): Lushai piᴴ < pii ‘short and small for one’s age, stunted growth’.
‘Sore on the head’ [Zhouli].  ||  [E] ? ST: WB ə-pʰeᴮ ‘scab over’ (head) (CVST 1: 101).

‘Writing brush’ [Li].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pi (入); MGZY bue (入) [puɛ]; ONW pit  ||  [N] Baxter (1992: 280) reconstructs the OCB form on the basis of div. III chóngniǔ vocalism and the phonetic series which implies *-ut.  ||  [E] SW (Shuōwén jiězì gǔlín: 1271) says that bǐ is a word from the region of Qín 秦 (NW), and that in Chǔ 楚 the word is yù 聿 (jiuet) ONW iuit (?), in Wú 吳: bù-l  不律 (pjəu-ljuet) ONW pu-luit, and in Yān 燕 (NE) fú 弗 (pjuət) ONW put (discussed by Sagart ICSTLL 1990: 7). The word has been borrowed by Middle Korean (pwut), Old Japanese (pude), and Viet. bút (pre-Sino-Viet.) (Miyake 1997: 189, 192). All these data point to an initial cluster *pr-  or *pl-  and an OC rime *-ut. If derived from → lǐ4 理里 (ljiᴮ) ‘lines’ ᛝ WT ’bri-ba, bris ‘to draw, write’ as is sometimes proposed, one needs to assume the loss of a PCH medial *w in the latter items. Benedict compares bǐ with PAN *bulut ‘fiber’ (STC p. 178f). WT bir ‘writing brush’ is a MC loan (MC final -t > WT -r).  ||  Baxter’s OC form can be related to TB ones which are mentioned under → shuā 刷.  ||  Perh. → fú9 拂 ‘to brush off’ may belong here. For an overview of similar etyma, see the Table S-2 under → shuā 刷.
‘Border, outskirts’ [Zuo] > ‘rustic, common’ [Lun] > (‘consider rustic, common’:) ‘to despise’ [Shu]; ‘district, border town’ [Li, Zhouli]. Possibly related to TB items under → bīn2 濱.

‘To make / let someone do something, cause, direct, provide’ [Shi, Shu].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR pi (上), PR  pəj; MGZY bi (上) [pi]; ONW *pie  ||  [E] Etymology not clear, although it brings to mind the MK causative prefix p-.
‘A fine comb’ [GY].  ||  [E] Perh. ST: WB pʰriᴮ ~ pʰiᴮ ‘to comb, brush’, but MC points to the absence of medial *r in OC.
‘Be necessary, must’ [BI, Shi]. — [E] Etymology not clear.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pi (入); MGZY  bi (入) [pi]
‘Bubble up’ (as water from a spring) [Shi] is a vocalic variant of → fèi4 沸 (§11.5.1).
‘Lath tied to bow for keeping it in shape’ [OB, Yili].  ||  [E] Perh. ST: Chepang pit- ‘grip’ (as with pincers, tongs, legs), ‘hold between knees or under the arm’.

‘To give’ [Shi].  ||  [D] (MC piᴮ) is common in Yuè dialects: Guǎngzhōu peiᴮ¹, Táishān iᴮ¹ < piᴮ, Téngxiàn Ɂbiᴮ¹.  ||  [E] ST *pi(s): PTB *pəy (STC no. 427) > Chepang bəyɁ-sa ‘to give’, Lepcha byi ᛝ byi-n ‘to give’; LB: WB peᴮ ᛝ pʰit ‘invite, offer to give’, Atsi pjí, Lahu pî. PLB *bek ‘give, bestow’, Miri bi; Lushai peᴸ / peekF < peeh (< pes) / peek ‘to give, offer’.   ||  [C] A derivation is → bīn1 賓 ‘guest’.

‘Worn out’ [Shi], ‘damage, ruin’ 敝 [Zuo]; ‘to fall down, die, destroy’ [Zuo] > caus. ‘kill’ 斃 [Li]; ‘fall’ [Guoyu], ‘bring down, stop’ 弊 [Zhouli].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR bi (去); MGZY pi (去) [bi]; ONW biei  ||  [C] Allofam is → pí7 疲罷 ‘exhausted’ (Pulleyblank 1962: 215), hence bì: *be(t)s < *bai-(t)s. See → fèi6 廢 for additional comments.   ||  [E] ST: Lushai pʰuaiᴴ < pʰuai ‘be worn, worn out, frayed’, JP pʰje³¹ ‘to ruin’.

‘To screen, keep in ignorance, deceive’ [Zuo]. There may be a connection with Lushai palɁᴸ < *palh ‘to miss, not know’; or alternatively with → píng6 屏軿 ‘screen’. Unger (Presentation in Rome Sept. 6, 2001) relates bì to WT sbed-pa, sbas ‘to conceal’ (see also → bī1 屄).
‘Sovereign, ruler, governing official, the authorities’ [BI, Shi].
‘Corrective measures, punishment’ [Shi], ‘regulate, arrange’ [Meng].
‘Arm’ [Liji].  ||  [E] ST: Lepcha a-ká pek, Limbu phuk-bek ‘forearm’ (Matisoff 1985a: 429).

‘Favorite person’ [Meng], ‘favorite concubine’ 嬖 [Mo]; → pián1-bì 便嬖 ‘male and female servants’ [Meng].  ||  [E] KT: PKS *jaak  ‘woman, girl’; PT *Ɂb-: Boai bikᴰ¹ ‘girl’.  ||  Note bèi 婢 (bjieᴮ) OCM *beɁ ‘female slave, servant’ [Li] which is a derivation from → bēi1 卑 ‘low’, perhaps a reētymologization of bì.

‘Thighbone’ [Li].  ||  [D] Yuè dial. ‘thigh’, e.g. Guǎngzhōu tai²²-pei³⁵ 大髀 ‘thigh’ (R. Bauer LTBA 10.1, 1987: 169ff).  ||  [E] ST: WT dpyi ‘hip, hipbone’ (CVST I: 2) This etymon could be related to Lushai pʰeiᴸ ‘foot, leg’ [Weidert 1987: 204] (so CVST ), but see → féi2 腓.
‘To shut, obstruct’ [Shu].

‘To close, shut’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Area etymon: TB-PL *pi² ‘to close’, Mru pit ‘shut, close’ (Löffler 1966: 141). <> MK *[c]ɓiit, *[c]ɓiət ‘to cover, close, block up’ (Shorto ɐ1039): OKhmer pit /it/ ‘to shut, close’.

‘Wooden fork’ [Shi, Li], ‘fork’ (a constellation) [Shi], (fork with net:) ‘hand-net’ for catching birds [OB, Shi], 罼 [Guoyu]. This is probably the s. w. as → bì26 篳 ‘interlaced branches, wattle’. Perh. related to bò 詭 (bɛk) *brek ‘net for catching birds’ [SW].  ||  [E] Etymology not certain, possibly related to TB-Lushai pʰiirᴸ < pʰiir ‘double, forked, twin’. But Lushai could be related to → pǐ1 匹 ‘pair’ instead.

‘To finish, complete’ [Xun] > ‘completely, all’ [Shu].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR  pi (入); MGZY bi (入) [pi]; MTang pir < pir, ONW piit  ||  [E] ST: Lushai peiɁᴸ < peih < *-s ‘to finish, complete’; WT dpyis pʰyin-pa ‘to come to the last, arrive at the end’ (pʰyin-pa ‘to go, come’). Prob. not related to → bà2 罷 ‘finish’.

‘Fence, hedge’ [SW], ‘wicker door’ (made with interlaced branches) [Zuo, Li]; 篳路‘fuel cart’ (Giles) or ‘wooden cart’ (Legge) [Zuo]. The association with with → bì24 畢‘wooden fork, hand-net’ (which is prob. the s.w.) and with PLB *pyik ‘thicket, jungle’ (Bodman 1980: 158; HST: 148), is closer than Karglren’s (1933: 94) association with → fú11 茀 ‘screen, cover’.
‘To shoot at’ [Chuci].  — Etymology not clear.
‘To weave’ [Li].

‘Braid, plait’ [Hànshū].   ||  [<] exopass. of biān (§4.4), lit. ‘what has been woven’.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *pyar ~ *byar (STC no. 178) > WT ’byor-ba ~ ‘byar-ba ‘stick to, adhere to’ ᛝ sbyor-ba, sbyar ‘to affix, attach, join, connect’; Bahing pʰjer ‘to sew’; Lushai pʰiarᴴ < pʰiar ‘to knit, plait’ (Bodman 1980: 173; HST: 119); PLB *pan² ‘to braid, plait’ (Matisoff D. of Lahu: 903).
‘Otter’ [Huainan]. CVST 1: 100 relates this word to WB pʰyam ‘otter’ (for the vowel see §11.3.2, for the final see §6.7).
‘Bat’ (animal) [SW].  ||  [E] ST *p/bək (?): PTB *baːk [STC no. 325]: Lushai baakR, Garo do-bak (do ‘bird’) ‘bat’ (HST: 39), Mikir plàk-wúk ~ -plàk-bat.
‘Side, periphery’ [BI, Zuo], ‘lean against’ [Liji]. Probably cognate to → piān1 偏 ‘side’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pjen (平); MGZY bÿan (平) [pjɛn]; ONW pėn
‘A vessel of clay or wood for serving food’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST *pel: Lushai beelᴴ ‘pot, utensil, vessel’.
‘Flat and thin’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST *per: PTB *peːr ‘flat’ [STC no. 340] > Lushai peerᴸ / perɁᴸ (? ᛝ pʰeiᴴ ‘level, flat, horizontal’); NNaga pweːr ‘thin’ [French 1983: 222].
‘Narrow’ [Shi].   ||  [T]  MGZY bÿan (上) [pjɛn]
‘Writing slip’ [Guoce].   ||  [<] Tone A nominalization (§3.1).
‘A circumscription, population district’ [Heguan].  ||  [E] ST: Lushai bialᴴ < bial ‘a circle, province, circuit; be round, include’. Prob. not related to → biàn7 遍 ‘all’.

‘To diminish, weaken’ [Shi], Mand. ‘demote, reduce, depreciate’.  ||  [E] ST: OTib. ’pʰam-ba, pʰam ‘to be diminished, reduced, found wanting, of lesser quality’ (WT ‘be beaten, conquered’) (HST: 63). Note PTai *pʰl/r-: S. pʰɔɔmᴬ¹ ‘lean’. A possible allofam may be → fèi6 廢 (so Karlgren 1956: 18).
‘To lower a coffin into the grave, bury’ [Li]. The word is not related to → bèng 塴.  ||  [E] ST: WT ’bum ‘tomb, sepulcher’, Lushai pʰuumᴴ ‘to bury, inter’ (CVST 1: 7).
‘A cap’ (symbol of manhood?) [Shi]. Wáng Lì (1982: 582) relates this word to → miǎn3 冕 [miɑnᴮ] ‘ceremonial cap’.
‘Convenient’ [Li], ‘comfortable’ [Chuci].  — [E] Etymology not clear.

‘To change’ [BI, Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pjen (去);  MGZY bÿan (去) [pjɛn]; ONW pan  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. plianᴮ¹ < *pl- ‘to change’. Baxter (1992: 365) thinks it likely that this word is cognate to → luàn 亂 OCB *C-rons ‘disorder’. It is perh. related to WT sprul-ba ᛝ ‘pʰrul-ba ‘juggle, appear, change, transform’ (Shī Xiàngdōng 2000: 200).
‘All together, everywhere, comprehensive’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ? ST: Lushai pʰiarR < pʰiarɁ (< -Ɂ) ‘all, entirely, completely, the whole lot’. Prob. not related to → biǎn2 扁 ‘circumscription’.
‘Long hair’ [Han time]. The graph also writes → shān2 髟.  ||  [E] <> PMiao *preu²ᴬ, PYao *py¹ei¹ ‘hair’.
‘Leaping flames’ [Lü].  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. pleeuᴬ¹ < *pl- ‘flame’ (Bodman 1980: 168). <> MK: Pearic phlaw ~ phlew ‘fire’.
‘Branch’ [Zhuang].
‘Tip, end’ [Zhuang].
‘To divide, separate’ [Zhouli].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pje, bje (入); MGZY  bÿa (入) [pjɛ]; ONW pat

‘Be different’ [Li].  ||  [<] endopass. of bié 別 (pjät 3) (§4.6) (Baxter / Sagart 1998: 46). This word is prob. cogn. to → liè1 列.  ||  [E] ST: PLB *brat ‘split, crack’ > WB prat ‘be cut in two’ [Matisoff D. of Lahu 836].

‘A gift, present’ [BI]; ‘to present a gift’ [BI] > ‘guest’ [BI, Shi] > ‘ancestral spirits’ (as guests at a sacrifice) [OB, Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pin (平); MGZY bin (平) [pin]; ONW *piin  ||  [<] n-nominalization from → bì8 畀 ‘give’ < ST *pi, lit. ‘gift, gift-giver’.  ||  [E] ST *pi ‘give’, see → bì8 畀; some TB items are close to OC: WT sbyin-pa ‘to give, bestow; gift’; WB phit ‘invite, offer to give, invite to take’.

‘To receive as a guest, treat as a guest’ 賓 (which involves presentation of gifts) [OB, Shi]; 殯 SW: “put the dead in a coffin to be taken out and buried where the ancestral spirits (‘guests’) meet him”, i.e. lit. ‘to have (the dead) treated like a guest (by the ancestral spirits)’ > ‘to put the body in a coffin’ [Li], ‘convey a coffin’ [Zuo] (Wáng Lì 1982: 541).   ||  [<] exoactive of bīn 賓 (pjien 4) (§4.3).
‘To become a bride, wife’ [Shi].  ||  [<] endopass. of bīn 賓 (pjien 4), lit. ‘be received like a guest’ (§4.6).

‘Shore, bank’ [Shu].    ||  [E] ST: Lepcha bí ‘edge, border’, lyaŋ bí ‘utmost limit of a place’; WT pʰyi ‘outside’ (including the notion ‘at the outer edge’ as in pʰyi žiŋ ‘the field outside’) ᛝ pʰyin ‘outside’. The wf → bǐ1 比 either belongs to the same root, or two ST roots: *pi ‘edge, outside’ and *pi ‘next to, follow, after’ have partially converged in CH and WT. In either case, these nouns would be n-nominalizations of a stem *pi (§6.4.3). If there should be a connection with AN: PMal.-Pol. *te(m)biŋ ‘bank, shore’ (Thurgood 1999:10), a substrate may possibly have influenced the semantic development of the CH item.
‘Be on the edge, urgent; river bank’ [Shi]; → fén5 墳濆 may be a vocalic variant.   ||  [<] perh. endopass., i.e. a sv derievd from bīn (§4.6) ?

‘Kneecap, shin, tibia’ [Da Da Lliji, Hanfei].  ||  [E] ST: TB-Nung bɛ³¹-pʰin⁵⁵ ‘knee’.   ||  [C] Karlgren (1933: 94) relates the CH word to → fú14 韍芾 ‘leggings, cover’.  ||  Partial synonyms are → bì22 髀 ‘thighbone’; → féi2 腓 ‘calf of leg’.
‘Weapon’ [BI, Shi] > ‘soldier’ [Zhouli]. This may possibly be related to → bǐng2 秉 (handled instrument?).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR piŋ (平); MGZY bing (平) [piŋ]; ONW peŋ

‘Ice’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Perh. related to PTB *pam > Tangkhul Naga pʰam ‘snow’, Kanauri pom ‘snow’, Jiarong ta-rpam ‘ice’ (CVST 1: 64). Alternatively, Baxter (1992: 273) considers this cogn. to the following, he reconstructs bīng with initial *pr-:

‘Ice’ [Shi].  ||  [E] If the connection between OCB prjəŋ and *b-rjəŋ is correct, then this wf could have come from AA, although the meanings are not very compelling: Khmer preṅa /preŋ/ ‘to become hard, solid’ < -reṅa /-réeŋ/ ‘to dry up’ [Jenner / Pou 1982: 269; 523] (there are many vocalic and other variants of this etymon). The unusual initial alternation p ~ r also speaks for a non-ST origin. OC *ə = Khmer /e/ has parallels.

‘Bright’ 炳 [Yi]; ‘happy, bright’ 邴 [Zhuang].  ||  [E] Belongs prob. to an AA wf, see under → liàng0 亮. Unger (Hao-ku  34, 1986) reconstructs OC *pl(j)aŋɁ and considers this word part of the wf under → yáng9 陽, as well as related to Tai: S. plaŋᴬ¹ ‘bright’.

‘To grasp, hold in the hand’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] ? ST: Lushai beŋᴴ ‘ear, eye (of a needle), handle (of a cup), loops’, or Lushai liaŋᴴ ‘handle’ (of a pot); however vocalic and semantic agreement is not close. Alternatively, Unger (Hao-ku  34, 1986) relates this word to WT len-ba (loŋ-pa, -pa), bloŋs, blaŋ, loŋ(s) ‘to take, grab’. Wáng Lì (1982: 173) relates this wf to → bǎ 把 ‘handful’. Perh. → bīng1 兵 is related.
‘A handle’ (of axe, flag) [Shi].  ||  [<] exopass. of bǐng, lit. ‘what is grasped, held’ (§4.4).

‘Side by side’ 並 [OB, Shi], 併 [Li]; ‘next to each other’ 並 [Shi]. The meaning ‘together, even, also’ has tone C (Downer 1959: 289).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR piŋ (去);  MGZY bing (去) [piŋ]; ONW bėŋ  ||  [E] ? ST: Chepang bʰiŋ- ‘be close together (as object, friends), double up’.  ||  A similar TB etymon may be related, but the medial *r is unexplained: Chepang breŋɁ- ‘be close together, side by side’, WB hrañ ~ hyañ (< hriŋ or hreŋ) ‘put together side by side’ ᛝ ə-hrañ ‘a pair’, Lushai ṭʰiaŋᴴ / ṭʰianᴸ ‘side by side (only of two), in a pair’. However, Lepcha byer, byăr ‘be in juxtaposition’ ᛝ byek ‘interval of time / space’ may belong to WT bar ‘intermediate’.
‘Combine two’ (things) [Zhouli], ‘all together’ [Shi], ‘likewise’ [Shu].
‘Two side by side, double’ [Zhuang], ‘two sticking together’ [Zuo] > ‘horse side by side with another’ [Zuo] (also read MC bieŋ).
‘To remove’ [Zuo], ‘retire’ [Li] (cognate to → píng6 屏軿 ‘screen’ acc. to Karlgren 1956: 16).
‘Eliminate’ [Xun] (cognate to píng acc. to Karlgren GSR 824g; Wáng Lì 1982: 339).
‘To drive out, relegate’ [Meng].  ||  [<] r-causative (§7.5).

‘Be ill, suffer, sickness, disease’ [Shu].    ||  [D] PMin *baŋᶜ > Fúzhōu paŋᶜ², Amoy pı̃ᶜ²  ||  [E] This wf may belong with → bǐng1 炳昺邴 with the basic meaning ‘warm, hot’. Also, a possible connection with shāng 傷 (under → yáng4 蜑瘍) has been suggested.
‘Be full of grief’ [Shi] (Karlgren 1956: 10).

‘A wave’ [Shi], ‘be shaken as on waves’ [Zhuang].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pwɔ (平); MGZY bwo (平) [pwɔ]; ONW pɑ  ||  [E] This word may belong to the root *paj ‘slanted, not level’ → bēi2, bī 惇 (so Huáng Jīn-guì, Shěn Xí-róng YYWZX 1987.8: 44), but prob. not to → bò1 播簸 ‘winnow’ (as suggested by Wáng Lì 1982: 444).  ||  Note WT dba’ (-kloŋ) ‘wave’, but the finals do not match (we should expect WT dbe).

‘Alms bowl’, also written with radical 金 [GY], or with an altogether different graph which acc. to GY, quoting the commentator Yán Shīgǔ 顏師古, occurs first in Hànshū. Bō derives from Skt. pātra which also has been loaned into Middle Korean (pali) and Old Japanese (pati) (Miyake 1997: 186).

‘Be the eldest’ (as father, brother, sister) [Shi], ‘elder, lord, clan head’ [Shi], a feudal title (‘earl, count’) [BI], measure word for persons above commoners [BI]; later and in Mand. ‘father’s elder brother, uncle’, in dialects also ‘father’, as in Gàn-Wǔníng  pɑɁᴰ¹ (~ pɑᴬ¹).   ||  [T] Sin S. SR pəj (入), LR pəjɁ; MGZY bay (入) [paj]; ONW pëk  ||  [E] ? Area word: TB-Mru rak, Kukish prak ‘eldest brother’ (Löffler 1966: 140); LB-Lahu phâ ‘god, lord’ <- Siam. pʰráɁ <- Khmer [Matisoff D. Lahu: 883]. Since Kuki-Chin languages have incorporated MK loans, this etymon may ultimately be AA. Among alternative proposals is derivation from → bái1 白 ‘white’, hence bó ‘the white-haired one’ (so Karlgren 1956: 10), note the semantics of → pó3 皤 ‘white > white-haired’ – but this is prob. a folk etymology.
‘Take the lead, have hegemony’ [Lunyu] (Wáng Lì 1982: 291).   ||  [<] exoactive / trans. of bó (§4.3.2).
‘Silk material’ [BI, Shu] is prob. the same word as → bái1 白 ‘white’.

‘Shoulder-blade’ 胉 [JY]; 拍 [Zhouli; GYSX, JY; GSR 782m].  ||  [D] Mand. ‘shoulder’ 膊; 髆 (GYSX: 478; GSR 771l; also Pulleyblank MC). This form QYS pâk survives in Yuè dialects: Guǎngzhōu pɔkᴰ¹-tʰɐuᴬ² 膊頭. The following are variants or dictionary readings.  ||  [E] Apparently an areal etymon: PTB *p(r)ak ᛝ *r-pak  (Matisoff 1999: 6): WT pʰrag < prak  ‘shoulder’, JP gə³¹-pʰaɁ³¹ < pʰak. <> Tai: S. baaᴮ¹ (PTai *Ɂbaaᴮ) ‘shoulder’, Be via³³. MK *paʔ, *pah ‘shoulder’ (Shorto 2006 #100), or MK *blaʔ ‘shoulder’ (Shorto ɐ218). Possibly, the multiple readings of MC could stem from multiple sources for this word.   ||  [C] A cognate may be bǎng 膀 ‘upper arms’ which is a late word.
‘Shoulder-blade’, variant of the above: 胉 [Yili; GYSX 415; JY; GSR 782q], 膊 [SW, GYSX: 478; GSR 771l].
‘Shoulder-blade’ [JY acc. to ZWDCD 7: 1002].

‘Thin’ [Shi].    ||  [T] Sin S. SR baw (入), LR bawɁ; MGZY paw (入) [baw]; ONW bɑk  ||  [D] PMin *b̯ok  ||  [E] ST: PTB *ba (actually *baɁ ?) ‘thin’ (HPTB: 24) > PLB *pa² (~ *Ɂpya¹ ?) ‘thin, flat’ (Matisoff 1970: JAOS 90.1: 39) or *ba² (Thurgood CAAAL 13, 1980: 212) > WB paᴮ; JP pʰa³¹ ‘thin’, Garo ba [Matisoff 1974 no. 206; STC no. 25]; Tiddim Chin paa¹ < paːɁ, Chepang beɁ < baɁ [Weidert 1987: 26; Ostapirat LTBA 21.1, 1998: 238]; WB pak ‘shallow dish’. The following items are borrowed from some ST source: PKS *waːŋ¹ ‘thin’; Yao piaɁ.
‘A hoe’ [Shi] may be of MK provenance: PMonic *pɔk ‘to hoe, clear land’ ᛝ *c(l)-*m-ɔk ‘a hoe, spade’, in Yuè dial. like Táishān pɔŋ³⁵/ᴬ¹.

‘Horse with mixed (brown and white) colors, mixed’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WB prok ‘be speckled, spotted’ ᛝ ə-prok ‘decoration’ (-> MK-MidMon /əprɔk/ ‘variegated color, surface decoration’), Mikir pʰròk ‘speckled’ (Bodman 1980: 142;  ||  HST: 138), JP prúɁ  [Matisoff TSR no. 360], Mru preu ‘of mixed color’ [Löffler 1966: 135]. A cognate may be → bān2 斑 ‘variegated’.
‘To overthrow, lay prostrate’ [Zuo] is prob. cognate to the wf → fú4 伏服.
‘Powdery’ (soil) [Zhouli].  ||  [E] ST *put: WB pʰut ‘dust’, Lushai pʰutᴸ ‘flowery, powdery’; CVST 1: 8 adds these words to → fú8 弗 ‘gust of wind’.
‘Sudden’ [Zhuang, Lunyu].  ||  [E] ST: Lushai pʰuutᴴ ‘suddenly, on a sudden’. This word may be related to → fú8 弗 ‘gust of wind’.
‘Navel’ [GY], usually ‘neck’. Benedict (LTBA 5.1, 1979) relates this late word to WT dbus ‘middle, centre’. Alternatively, this could be an AA word: PMonic *p[r/n]us ‘navel, center, axis of wheel’.

‘To walk lame’ [Yi].   ||  [D] Some southern dialects preserve the OC rime: Y-Fóshān pɐiᴬ¹; PMin *paiᴮ.   ||  [E] ST: PTB *pay ᛝ *bay ‘lame, limp, oblique’ ᛝ *bay ‘left’ (side) (Matisoff 1995a: 42; LL 1.2, 2000: 153) > WB pʰai ‘go aside, put aside’ ᛝ pʰaiᴮ ‘go aside, get out of the way’ ᛝ pai ‘put aside, away, reject’ ᛝ bʰai ‘left side’, Lushai baiR < baɁ ‘walk lame’. This is prob. an allofam of → bēi2, bī 惇 ‘slanting’.
‘To walk lame’ [Li].  ||  [<] either a derivation with an additional final *-k (*pai-k) (§6.1), or the result of an OC *-Ɂ ~ *-k  alternation.

‘To winnow’ 播 [Zhuang], ‘shake’ 播 [Lunyu].   ||  [D] In most dialects, the verb ‘to winnow’ and the n. ‘winnowing pan’ are homophones: Y-Guǎngzhōu pɔᶜ¹; K-Dōngguān pɔiᶜ n., vb. But a few dialects make a distinction where the tone C reading is reserved for the noun: Mand. bò 簸; PMin *puɑiᶜ.   ||  [E] ST: PTB *pᵂaːy ‘chaff, scatter’ > PL *pway² ‘chaff’ > WB phwaiᴮ ‘husk, chaff’ [Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 143] (Bodman 1980: 138), Lushai vaiᴴ ‘husks of grain’. This etymon is prob. distinct from → bò2 播譒 as TB cognates suggest.
‘To winnow’ [Shi] is in some dialects a reading for the verb: Mand. bǒ, K-Meix paːᴮ  ‘to winnow’. This is prob. also the OC reading for the verb 簸 in Shījīng.

‘To spread, sow, publish’ 播 [Shi]; ‘to promulgate’ 譒 [SW: Shu].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *bᵂâr (STC: 174 n. 463; n. 460) > WT ’bor-ba ‘to throw, cast’, Bahing war ‘throw away’, Chepang waːr ‘sow’, Mikir wár ‘throw’ (STC: 172, 174; 191). Prob. an area word: MK-PVM: U´y-lô wâr⁴, Lâm-la vay² ‘to sow’, some languages have a form kway, M˜i-so≥ n pay²; Viet -> Tai: S. hwan¹ (Maspero 1912: 71, 73). OC -> Tai: PT *Ɂb-: S. bɛɛᴬ¹ ‘extend, spread’. But S. prai¹ ‘to sow, scatter’ seems to be unrelated. This etymon is prob. distinct from → bò1 播簸.

‘To cleave, split’ 擘 [Li]; ‘crack, burst’ 薜 [Zhouli]; ‘tear apart, cleave’ 捭 [Li].   ||  [D] Southern dialects have initial m-: Y-Guǎngzhōu maːk⁷ ‘to break’, G-Nánchāng miɛ³, Kèjiā mak⁷ ‘to open, break’ (Sagart 1999: 80-81). This etymon is also found in KT: PKS *hmaːk⁷ ‘to split, chop’.  ||  [E] Area word: TB-Chepang prek- ‘cleave, divide down center’. <> KT (OC loan?) PKS *pra:k⁷-ti ‘break, tear’; PT *pr-: S tɛɛkᴰ¹ᴸ, Lóngzhōu pʰeek, Boai teek. <> ? MK *tbaik ‘to cleave’ (Shorto 2006 #364) > Khmer: pēka /baaɛk/, OKhmer pek /ɛɛk/ ‘to break, burst, split’.  ||  Perh. related to → bǎi2 捭 *breɁ ‘to open’. For an overview of similar items, see → lí10 離 and the Table P-1 under → pī3 披.

‘To escape, run away, abscond’ [Shu]. Benedict (LTBA 14.2, 1991: 152) relates this word to WT sbed-pa, sbas, sba ‘to hide, conceal’ ᛝ ’ba-bo ‘hole, cave, cavern’, Kiranti bha ‘anus’, Mikir iŋbò < m-baᴬ ‘lose, get lost’(see also → bī1 屄).

(‘Cracking’ of a bone or tortoise shell in fire, go ‘pop’:) ‘To divine by oracle bone’ [OB, Shi].  ||  [E] ST: PLB *ɴpökᴴ ~ *Ɂpökᴴ ~ *Ɂbök§ ‘explode, pop’ [Matisoff 2002 no. 108] > WB pok ‘go off’ (as gun) ᛝ pʰok ‘to fire’ (a gun), Lushai puakF / puaɁᴸ ‘to explode, burst, pop’, Mru pok ‘to burst’, JP pʰok⁵⁵ ‘to hit’, boɁ³¹ < bok³¹ ‘erupt, burst out’, Lepcha bu ‘to burst’ (vessel), crack, split’.

‘To mend, repair, assist’ [Shi].   ||  [D] PMin *≠puoᴮ ‘to mend’: Jiànyáng vio³ derives perh. from a pre-nasalized initial (for the medial i in Jiànyáng, compare W-Wēnzhōu pəu⁴⁵), note Yao bia³ (< *nb-), PMY *npa² (Downer 1982) ‘to patch, repair’ (Norman 1986: 382).  ||  [E] Area word: TB-WB pʰa ‘mend, patch’, Nung əpʰa ‘adhere’ (Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 163), JP pa³¹ ‘be mended’. <> MK: PVM *k-paːɁ ‘to repair, sew’ [Ferlus], Khmer /pah/ (i.e. prob. = paɁ) ‘to patch, mend, fix’. <> Tai-S. paɁᴰ¹ and pooﬂ ‘mend’ is a loan. But Tai pɔɔŋᶜ¹ < *p- ‘to protect, cover up’ (Li F. 1976: 40) is not related, see → bèng 塴.   ||  [C] Perh. connected with → fú2 扶 ‘assist’.

‘Not’ [OB, Shi]. The irreg. Mand. reading in b- (no dentilabial f-) belongs to the popular stratum, the regular development from QYS and OC is represented by fǒu 否 below. Although bù is the normal negative in literary Chinese from the OB down, it is now confined to Mand. dialects. In the OB, negatives with initial *p- negate actions which are beyond the control of living persons (Takashima 1996: 365ff).  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. bɔ(ɔ)ᴮ¹ < *Ɂb- ‘not’, Saek booᴮ¹ ‘negative, no’.   ||  [C] Allofams: → fēi1 非, → fěi1 匪棐.
‘Not, be wrong’ [OB, BI, Shi], same word as above. This is the expected Mand. reading of the negative 不 based on  QY pjəu(ᴮ/ᶜ).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR fəw (上); MGZY Hwuw (上) [fuw]

(1) ‘Cannot, do not want to, not’ [OB, Shu] (DEZC p. 48; §6.2.2), later also ‘resist’.   ||  (2) ‘Not (verb) him / her / it’ [Shu], fusion of bù with the obj. pronoun zhī  之.   ||  [T] MTang pfur, ONW put. – The later forms for bù 不 in final -t really reflect this word: Sin Sukchu SR pu (入);  MGZY bu (入) [pu].

‘Cloth’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR pu (去); MGZY bu (去) [pu]; ONW po  ||  [D] Min *pioᶜ (from poᶜ via pəoᶜ? This is the regular form up the coast in Wēnzhōu).  ||  [E] Prob. AA, but it could alternatively be the same etymon as ‘spread out’ (→ bù3   布). A Han dyn. loan is jià-bù 幏布 < QYS ka(ᶜ)-puoᶜ ‘cotton, cotton cloth’ from the ‘Mán and Yí barbarians’ on the middle Yangtze River [SW, Hòu Hànshū]. A later loan (ca. 430 AD) is gǔ-bèi 古貝 ONW koᴮ-pɛiᶜ < -pɑs (Baxter, 1989: ‘An AA word for cotton in Chinese’, Chicago Early China Conference).  ||  AA forms: *k-rn-paːs, e.g.: Khmer krɑbaah, Bahnar ko’paih (< -s), PVM *k-paːs (Ferlus), Chrau paih (< -s), Khasi kṇpʰaːt. <> Tai: S. pʰaaᶜ¹ < *pʰ- ‘cloth’ (Li F. 1976: 46). From AA into -> Skt. kārpāsa≥m ‘cotton, cotton cloth’, -> Greek kárpasos.  ||  In turn, bù may have been loaned into Middle Korean pwoy ‘hemp cloth’ (Miyake 1997: 188).

‘To spread out’ (a mat) [Li], ‘display, announce, disperse’ [Zuo]. → bù2 布 ‘cloth’ is often thought to be the same word.   ||  [D] PMin *pyoᶜ ‘set out’ (rice seedlings).  ||  [<] exoactive of a root *PA(Ɂ) (§4.3).  ||  [E] ST: Lushai pʰaɁᴸ (< phah) ‘to spread’ (as cloth), ‘place flat on the ground’. CH -> Tai: S. pu¹ ‘to spread out, lay or stretch out (carpet)’.
‘Be wide’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [<] kēxtension (§6.1) of a root *PA(Ɂ).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR paw (入), LR pawɁ;  MGZY baw (入) [paw]
‘Be vast, wide’ (of mandate, injury, walls, plain) [Shi].
‘To spread out, extensively’ 尃 [Yi], 鋪 [Shi] (鋪 also read QY pʰuo); ‘to spread out, widely, extensively, arrange, set forth, publish’ 敷 [Shi].  ||  [<] caus. aspiration of fǔ 甫 ‘large’ (§5.8.2).
‘Large’ (of a field) [Shi].  ||  [<] endoactive of a root *PA(Ɂ).

‘To walk, step (stride of two legs), course’ [OB, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR bu (去); MGZY pu (去) [bu]; MTang bu < bo, ONW bo  ||  [D] PMin *±b-: Jiànyáng voﬂ ‘to step, stride’ derives perh. from a prenasalized initial, note Yao biaﬂ (< *nb-) ‘step, stride’ (Norman 1986: 382).  ||  [E] ST: Mru pak ‘go, walk’, Lushai vaakF / vaɁᴸ ‘to go, walk’ [Löffler 1966: 146].

‘Have food in the mouth’ [Zhuang].   ||  [D] This is the Mǐn word for ‘to chew’: PMin *boᶜ, but Jiàn’ōu piɔ⁴⁴ (prob. from *boᶜ via bəoᶜ).   ||  [<] endopass. of bū 餔 pɑ ‘to eat’ (§4.6).  ||  [E] ST: PTB *wa (or *pa) ‘bite, chew’ (STC no. 424; CVST I: 119; Weidert 1987: 138) > WB waᴮ ‘to chew’, JP gə³¹-wa⁵⁵ ‘to bite’.  ||  It is not clear if / how the following may be connected: TB-Lushai baarᴴ ‘to stuff food into one’s own mouth’ ᛝ barɁ ‘to stuff food into the mouth of another’ (tones?) (Unger Hao-ku  35, 1986: 34). Note also Tiddim Chin baːkF / baɁᴸ ‘to feed forcibly (from baarh ?); and MK-Khmer ¨pana / -pɑɑn/ ‘to feed by introducing premasticated or other food into the mouth of (infant, chick, etc.). -> Tai /pˆɔɔn/.
‘To eat’ [Meng], ‘meal in the afternoon’ [Lü].
‘To give to eat’ [JY] (Unger Hao-ku  35, 1986: 34).  ||  [<] exoactive /caus. of bū 餔 ‘to eat’.

‘Be well endowed’ [Shi], ‘ability’ 才 [Zuo]; ‘material, talent’ 材 [Shu]; ‘value’ 財 [BI, Shu].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR dzaj (平); MGZY tsay (平) [dzaj]; ONW dzɑi (dzɛi ?)  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. Matisoff (1995: 42f) proposes cognation with PTB *(t)saːy ᛝ *(d)zaːy with the basic meaning ‘property, livestock, talent’. The TB and OC vocalisms are difficult to reconcile, though; some of the TB words are here associated with → xī11 犀 ‘rhinoceros’. Alternatively, cái may have an AA origin: Khmer ceḥ /ceh/ ‘to know..., know how, be able’ ᛝ caṃṇeḥ /cɑmnèh/ ‘knowledge... ability, competence, proficiency, aptitude, experience’ (there are other cases where Khmer /e/ = OC *ə).  ||  Most likely, this word is derived from ST *tsə ‘come forth’ (as child, seedling, → zǐ1   子); for the semantic connection between ‘birth’ and ‘natural characteristic / endowments’, compare → shēng2 生 ‘give birth, live’ ᛝ → xìng2 性姓 ‘what is inborn: one’s inner nature; one’s name’. Thus a WT cognate of cái is prob. mtsʰan ‘name’ ᛝ mtsʰan(-ma)  ‘shape and peculiar characteristics of separate parts of the body; genitals; mark, token, symptom’ (with the nominalizing n-suffix §6.4.3).
‘Only when / at (time)’ [Hou Hanshu]. Matisoff (1995: 74f) suggests that this is cogn. to TB-Lahu šā and šē.

‘To gather, pluck’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. Perh. from ST *tsə: WT btsa ‘fruit’, btsas ‘harvest, to reap’ (CVST 4: 17); PLB *tsyakᴴ ‘to pluck’. To the same stem may belong → cái1 才材財, → zǐ1 子. Alternatively, note WT tsʰod-ma ‘vegetable’, the vocalic correspondence would be parallel to → cǎi2 采 ‘color’ (see §12.9[3]).
‘Vegetables, edible plants’ 菜 [Shi] > ‘appanage’ 采 [Shu].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'aj (去); MGZY tshay (去) [ts'aj]; ONW tsʰɑi  ||  [<] exopass. of cǎi, lit. ‘what is gathered, plucked’ (§4.4).
‘Color, pigment, be colorful’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT tsʰos ‘paint, dye, to color’. The vowel correspondence is prob. ST *ə > OC *ə, > PTB *a > WT o (see §12.9[3]).
‘Silkworm’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dzam (平), PR dzan; MGZY tsam (平) [dzam]  ||  [E] Bodman (1980: 58) relates this word to WT sdom ‘spider’. Perh. cogn. to → jiàn12 蔪 ‘entwine’.

‘Have in the mouth’ tr. (have a taste in the mouth) [Huainan] is perh. derived from ǎn 唵 ‘hold in the mouth’ (under → ān4 喑) with the transitivising s-prefix (§5.9.2). Karlgren (1956: 18) relates this word to → zá 噆 ‘bite’.

‘Shiny, beautiful’ 粲 [Shi], 燦 [Chunqiu fanlu].  ||  [E] Perh. a ST word, it could either be related to WT mtsʰar-ba ‘bright, shining, beautiful’ (so HST: 49); or, acc. to Unger (Hao-ku 35, 1986: 30) to WT gsal-ba ‘be clear, distinct, bright’. Since MC tsʰ- = WT gs- (§5.9.1), Unger’s suggestion seems on balance preferable.

‘Cold’ [Yi Zhoushu].   ||  [<] prob. intensive aspiration of → liáng3 涼 ‘cold’: s + hraŋ (§5.9.2).   ||  [D] LH tsʰɑŋ is an old Wú dialect word in Shìshuō xīnyǔ; it is still used in Mǐn dialects: Fúzhōu tsʰeiŋᶜ¹, Xiàmén tsʰinᶜ¹, Jiànyáng tʰoiŋᶜ¹ ‘cold (of weather)’ (Norman 1983: 207). Unrelated to → qìng1 凊 ‘cold’.

‘Green, azure, blue’ [Shi]. This may be an old dialect variant of → qīng1 青 (Baxter, JCLTA 19, 1983), note Mǐn tsʰaŋ for qīng 青 and its use for ‘sky, heaven’ in the ancient Yuè area (later Mǐn) of the Han period [Yuèjuè shū].  ||  In the form cāng-láng 蒼浪 / 狼 / 筤 (tsʰâŋ-lâŋ) the initial l- is the reduplicative syllable onset (§2.7).  ||  [E] ST *saŋ: Garo tʰaŋ < saŋ ‘live’ ᛝ gatʰaŋ < k-saŋ ‘green’, Dimasa gatʰaŋ ‘alive, living, green, unripe’. This stem is parallel to ST *siŋ, see → qīng1 青.

‘To conceal, store’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu S dzaŋ (平); MGZY tsang (平) [dzaŋ]; ONW dzɑŋ  ||  [E] ST: WT gsaŋ-ba ‘secret, conceal’ (HST: 57). In addition, the following belong to ST *saŋ: WT ’tsʰaŋ-ba ‘to press into, stuff inside’ ᛝ mtsʰaŋ ‘evil hidden in a person’s heart’.

(1) ‘A treasure’ 藏 [Shi] > ‘intestines’ 臟 [Zhouli]. For a semantic parallel see under → fù3 付.  ||  [E] ST: WT ’dzaŋs-pa ‘to hoard wealth’.   ||  [<] *dzaŋ + pass. s/h-suffix (§4.4), lit. ‘what is being stored’.   ||  (2) ‘Storehouse’ [Zuo] (Downer 1959: 275).  ||  [<] *dzaŋ + general purpose s/h-suffix (§3.5) (lit. ‘what does the storing’).

‘To bury’ (a corpse) [Lunyu]. Old texts seem to confirm what the graph suggests, that the dead were once wrapped in straw or grass, i.e. literally ‘concealed’.  This word is unrelated to sāŋ 喪 ‘mourning, burial’ (under → wáng1 亡).
‘Granary’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'aŋ (平); MGZY tshang (平) [ts'aŋ]
‘To grasp’ [Li], ‘to handle’ [Zuo].
‘Principles, purpose’ [Meng].  ||  [<] exopass. of cāo 操 (tsʰâu) (§4.4), lit. ‘what is grasped’.

‘Grass, small plant’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin S SR ts'aw (上); MGZY tshaw (上) [ts'aw]; ONW tsʰɑu  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. Perh. related to WT rtswa ‘grass, plant’, Balti, Purik rtswa, stwa (Jaeschke  p. 437a) confirm the medial w. The WT word could be reconciled with CH if analyzed as *rtsu-a with the a-suffix which is also found in tʰa-ga-pa ‘weaver’ < *tag-a. Alternatively, this could be yet another version of the AA word under → chú4 芻.

‘Be going to the side, be slanting, deviating’ > ‘side’ [Shi].  ||  [E] MK: OKhmer jre /crée/ ‘to turn down, tilt, slope, decline, (of sun) go down, set’, acc. to Jenner / Pou (1982: 268) a derivative of OKhmer *re /ree ~ rəə/ ‘move, stir, change course’, from this root is also derived the Khmer (and OC) wf under → lǐ6 理. For the CH final -k, see §6.1.
‘Be slanting, oblique’ 仄 [Zhouli] > ‘sun going down, afternoon’ 昃 [OB, Shu].

‘To fathom, measure’ depth 測 [Shi]; ‘to pity, be pained’ 惻 [Yijing, Meng]; ‘deep (or sharp?) cutting’ of a plow 畟畟 [Shi] (also QY tṣjək). The basic meaning seems to be ‘cut deep, go deep’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ’əj (入); MGZY chhiy (入) [tʂ’əj]; ONW tṣhik

‘Latrine’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ’ʅ (去); LR tʂ’ʅ; MGZY chhi (去) [tʂ’ʅ]  ||  [E] ST: PTB *ts(y)i ‘urinate’ > WT gči(d)-pa ‘to urinate’ ᛝ gčin ‘urine’; WB tsʰiᴮ ‘urine’, NN *C-chi ‘urine’, Chepang cʰyuɁ ‘urine’ [Weidert 1987: 27]. For the OC medial *r, see §7.4; the vowel correspondence is unusual, see §11.2.2.

(‘Bamboo slips’:) ‘to document, write down’ (on bamboo slips) [OB, BI, Shu] > n. ‘document’ [BI], 策 [Zuo], ‘book’ in M-Xiàmén lit. tsʰikᴰ¹, col. tsʰeɁᴰ¹; ‘Achilea stalks used for divination’ (the radical implies bamboo 筴). Sagart (1999: 214) suggests a possible further connection with → jī9 積 ‘collect, accumulate’. OTib. gtsigs ‘document, official text, decree’ is perh. a CH loan.

‘To spear’ (fish) 簎 [Zhouli], ‘a kind of lance’ 矠 [SW].  ||  [E] This is probably a vocalic variant of the synonym → chuō 政 (tṣʰåk) [tṣʰɔk] *tshrok; note MK *cuk, *cuuk, *cuək, cak, *ciik, *c(i)ək ‘to prod, pierce’ (Shorto 2006 #292) > OKhmer cāk /cak/ ‘to pierce, stab, jab....’ For the CH retroflex initial, see §5.10.3. Variants or syn. are → chuō 政, → zé6 矠.

‘A fork’ [SW].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'a (平); ONW tṣʰä  ||  [E] ? MK: The reference to the eastern end of the Yangtze River may support an AA connection: Khmer cēka /chaaɛk/ ‘to be divided, split, cleft, forked, bifurcated....’ This AA etymon may also be represented in → xī4 析 ‘split’. For the absence of final -k in CH, see §6.9. Alternatively, chā may be the s. w. as → chā2 差 ‘divergence’ (< ‘branch off’), but see there.  ||  The SW glosses the graph chā 叉 as ‘crossing hands’, thereby implying a basic meaning ‘branches crossing each other’; this suggests a connection with → cuò3 錯 ‘crossing, mixing’, also TB-JP gə³¹-tʃai⁵⁵ ‘intersect’.
‘Forked branch of a tree’ (used for spearing fish) [SW, Zhuang]. Duan Yucai says that yā-chà 椏杈 is a Dōng-Jiāng (eastern Yangtze) dialect word for ‘branch’ (Wáng Lì 1982: 440).

‘Divergence, difference, distinction’ [Shu], ‘mistake’ [Xun] (cf. → cuò4 錯 ‘mistake’).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'a (平); ONW tṣʰä (~ tṣʰëi)  ||  [E] The etymology is not clear, perh. the s. w. as → chā1 叉 ‘fork’, lit. ‘branch off’ > ‘diverge’, but the semantic field of this wf points in a different direction (‘graduated’). Or perh. AA: Khmer cāya /caaj/ ‘give out, scatter, disperse’ ᛝ OKhmer /cŋaaj/ ‘be separated, apart, far away, be different’. Or ST: WT sre-ba ‘to mix with, mingle’.   ||  [C] Allofams are perh. → chá3 察 ‘examine’, and → cuō3, chī 慚 ‘uneven teeth’.
‘Uneven, irregular’ [SW] (Karlgren 1956: 16)
‘Graduated, of different length’ [Shi].   ||  [<] Prob. a reduplicated form where the second syllable has the *l ~ *r onset (§2.7).

‘To husk (grain) with a mortar and pestle’ 臿 [SW], ‘to insert’ 插 [Guoce].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu 插 SR tʂ'a (入)  ||  [E] Alternatively, it may be related to PLB *kyap ~ *tsap ‘stick into, insert’, WB kyap ‘put into and twirl about...’, Akha tsawᴴS ‘pierce, stab’; but the initials are difficult to reconcile.

‘Pound wheat’ (with mortar and pestle) (Duàn Yùcái; Baxter 1992: 548).   ||  [<] prob. an s-prefix iterative derivation from → yā3 壓 ‘press down’, hence <  PCH *s-Ɂrəp (§5.9.1), even though the MC vowels do not agree (ă vs. a < OC *rə vs. *ra?).

‘Tea’ [Han period].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR  dʐa (平); ONW dä  ||  [E] Sagart (1999: 188) suggests that chá is a loan from Loloish (TB) *la ‘leaf, tea’, PLB *s-la ‘leaf / tea’ (HPTB: 48), as tea may have originated in Sìchuān (Lolo area); this word has wider distribution, also in Zhuang (Tai) la⁴ means ‘tea’, the ultimate source seems to be PAA *sla ‘leaf’. Alternatively, Qiu Xigui (2000: 326) considers ‘tea’ with its bitter leaves a semantic extansion of tú 荼 ‘name of a bitter plant’ (Sonchus oleraceus).

‘Cut trees’ [Guoyu].  ||  [E] Possibly AA in light of zé ‘clear away trees and brushes’ (to make room for settlements): OKhmer sre /srɛɛ/ ‘wet or irrigated rice field’, perh. originally ‘land cleared for cultivation’ (Jenner / Pou 1982: 271). An allofam is perh. → chái1 柴 ‘firewood’.
‘Clear away (trees and brushes)’ [Shi].
‘Cut off’ [Gongyang].

‘To examine’ [Shu], ‘discern’ [Li] is either derived from → chā2 差 ‘distinction’, or from → chāi 差 ‘choose, select’; ‘examine, discern’ is the process of sorting out differences, selecting.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'a (入)
‘A Buddhist temple’, borrowed from Skt. kṣetra ‘field, place, seat, sphere of activity’;  Middle Korean tyel and Old Japanese tera ‘temple’ derive perh. from the CH word (Miyake 1997: 189).

‘To pick out, select’ (e.g. pick horses out of a herd) [Shi].  ||  [E] Prob. AA: Khmer /sral/ ‘to take the pick of, select’. Or semantically less likely, this may be the s. w. as → chā2 差. Allofam is perh. → chá3 察 ‘examine’.

‘Firewood’ [Li] > ‘burnt offering’ [BI, Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐaj (平); MGZY cay (平) [dʐaj]  ||  [D] The graph 柴 writes the Mǐn word for ‘wood, firewood’, see under → jiāo6 焦.  ||  [E] Chái is perh. related to → chá2 槎 ‘cut trees’; OC rimes *-ai  and *-e are occasionally confused in wfs. Perh. from MK *jheeʔ (and variant forms) ‘wood’ (Shorto ɐ254): OKhmer jhe ‘wood’, Lawa Umphai cheʔ ‘firewood’. Note also PHlai *tsʰai¹ ‘tree’  ‌[Matisoff 1988c no. 293].

‘Class, category, equals’ [Zuo] occurs also in Tai: S. raaiᴬ² ‘set, category, list’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 156). For the initials, see §7.1.5. Perh. connected with → qí15 齊 ‘be equal’ (so Karlgren 1956: 16).   ||  (chái3)  儕  (dẓăi)  ||  The graph is used to write the Mǐn dial. word for ‘many’: PMin *d̯zeᶜ > Yǒngān tseᶜ¹, Jiànyáng laiᶜ², Fúzhōu saᶜ², Amoy tsueᶜ². Yue Hashimoto (CAAAL 6, 1976: 1) relates this word to Tai: Zhuang (Lóngzhōu) laːiᴬ¹ ‘many’ < PTai *hlaiᴬ¹. The Tai word is related to → duō 多.

‘Scorpion’ [Shi]. The phonetic wàn3 萬 which writes words like → mài5 邁勱 *mra(t)s ‘walk’ suggests that the OC initial was *rh- rather than a dental stop.   ||  [<] Chài is derived from → lì15 厲 ‘sharp’ with the nominalizing ST s- / aspiration (§5.2.4); there may also be a connection with zhé 蜇 (ṭjät) LH ṭiat, *trat (?) ‘to sting’ [Liezi].
‘Irresolute’ [Chuci] is perh. cognate to the wf → chǎn2 嘽幝繟 ‘slow’.

‘Be craggy’ (of rocks on a mountain) [Shi].  ||  [E] AA: Khmer /kr´əəm/ ‘be rough, uneven, bumpy, rugged’ ᛝ /cr´əəm/  ‘move around, restless, in motion, agitated...’ ᛝ /pr´əəm/  ‘to move (around), stirred up, excited’. AA -> TB-WB kramᴮ  ‘rough, coarse, violent’. Khmer /kr´əəm/ ‘rocky’ shows that → kān3 嵁 *khrə̂m ‘rocky’ is an AA allofam.
‘Uneven, unequal, disorder’ [Zuo].
‘Mixed, disparate’ [Li].  ||  [<] perh. exopass. of chán (§4.4).
‘Uneven, of varying length’ (flowers) [Shi].
‘Farm, farmyard’ [Shi]  ||  [E] KT: S. rianᴬ² < *rianᴬ ‘house’; PKS *hraːn¹ ‘house’; PHlai *rɁuun¹ ‘house’. For the initials, see §7.1.4.
‘To bind, wind’ [Lie].  ||  [E] ST: WT star-ba ‘tie, fasten’ ᛝ dar ‘silk, piece of cloth, scarf’ (HST: 43).
‘A belt or wrapping cord’ [Shiji].
‘To open up, make clear, explain’ 闡 [Yi] is perh. the s. w. as → chǎn2 嘽幝繟.
‘Slow, drawn-out, easy-going’ 嘽 [Li]; ‘slow’ 幝 [Shi]; ‘indulgent, generous’ 繟 [Lao]. Perh. → chǎn1 闡 ‘explain’ is the s. w.
‘Relinquish, cede, hand over’ [Meng] (< ‘be generous’).    ||  [C] Allofam is perh. → tǎn3 儃坦 ‘at ease’; → chán1 儃 ‘irresolute’.

‘To breed, bear’ [Zuo], ‘produce’ [Li], ‘product, livelihood’ [Meng].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'an (上); MGZY shan (上) [ʂan]; ONW ṣän  ||  [E] ST: WT srel-ba ‘to bring up, rear’ (Bodman 1980: 143; HST p. 40). The MK-Khmer synonym /sɑmraal/ is phonologically also compatible with this word (see → miǎn2 娩).

‘Splendid, prosperous’ [Shi] is perh. related to → yáng9 陽暘 in which case this word might go back to earlier *k-hlaŋ. This would be supported by PVM *hlaŋᴮ ‘bright’. Note the phonetic parallelism with → chàng1 唱倡.
‘Lower garment’ [SW 8: 3410].  ||  [E] Bodman (1980: 80) compares this word to WT g-yaŋ ‘animal skin clothing’. For the initials see §9.3.
‘Lower garment, skirt’ [Shi].

‘To perpetuate, have or be forever’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐjaŋ (平); MGZY zhang (平) [ʐaŋ]; MTang źaŋ, ONW  dźaŋ  ||  [E] ST *jaŋ: Acc. to Bodman (1980: 79) related to WT yaŋ ‘again, still, once more’. For the initials see §9.3. WT yaŋ may possibly belong to → yòu1 又 instead, however.
‘To continue, still, consider to continue, hope for’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ʐjaŋ (去); MGZY zhang (去) [ʐaŋ]; MTang źaŋ, ONW dźaŋ

‘To taste’ [Shi] > ‘try’ (doing something) [Zhuang].    ||  [D] PMin *d̯žioŋ  points to earlier *m-d(j)aŋ  ||  [E] ST *m-jaŋ: PTB *m-yaŋ : Chepang yaŋ-sā ‘to taste’ (sample food), WT myoŋ-ba, myaŋs / myoŋ  ‘to taste, enjoy, experience’ (Bodman 1980: 80), from < PTib. *m-yaŋ.  However, WB mrañᴮ ‘to taste, try by tasting’ suggests that the ST initial might have more been complex. For the initials see §9.3.

‘Vegetable garden, a (pounded) threshing area’ [Shi 154, 7 etc.]; this word also means ‘meadow’ (in the mountains) [BI] (related?).  ||  [E] Etymology not certain, perh. ST: WT ra-ba ‘enclosure, fence, wall, yard, courtyard, pen’, and related to → zhù1, chú 宁 [ḍiɑ(ᴮ)]; for the initials see §7.1.4, for the finals see §6.5.2. The basic meaning would then be an ‘enclosed area or yard’. Shī Xiàngdōng (2000: 32) relates cháng to WT tʰaŋ ‘high plain’, but see → chǎng 敞.

‘Intestines’ [Shi].   ||  [T] MTang ḍaŋ, ONW daŋ — [D] PMin *dɔŋ  ||  [E] ST: WT loŋ-ka ‘intestines, entrails, guts’, Chepang yoŋ-kliɁ ~ lyoŋ-ki (Matisoff, BSOAS 63.3, 2000: 364); perh. also PTB *yaŋ ‘guts’ (Matisoff 1978: 216). OC or TB ? -> PMY: *gl- (Solnit acc. to Strecker 1989: 28): PY klaaŋ² ‘intestines’ (Bodman 1980: 112). WT gžaŋ (< *gryaŋ? *glyaŋ?) ‘anus’ prob. belongs to → gāng6 肛 ‘lower intest., anus’.
‘High, level land, spacious’ [Han time].  — [E] ST: WT tʰaŋ ‘a plain’ (HST: 119).

‘To lead in singing, intone’ 倡 [Shi] > ‘to take the lead’ (generally) [Guoyu, Hou Hanshu].  ||  [E] ST: WB ə-kʰraŋᴮ, ə-kʰyaŋᴮ ‘a kind of song’ (< *khlaŋᴮ?); perh. also Proto-Bodo *ləɁŋ ‘to sing’ [Burling 1959: 443]. Parallelism with the phonetic element → chāng 昌 strengthens the OC reconstruction and ST etymology.
‘Wine, spirits’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT čʰaŋ (< C-hrjaŋ ?) ‘fermented liquor, beer, wine’ (HST: 160).
‘To snatch’ [Li] is prob. related to Tai: S. chokᴰ¹ ‘id.’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 156).
‘To seize, take by force’ (a throne) [Meng].   ||  [C] An allofam may be → zhuā 抓 ‘grasp’, but the OC vowels differ.

‘Nest’ [Shi], ‘make a nest’ [Zuo].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐaw (平); MGZY caw (平) [dʐaw]  ||  [E] Related to PMY *rau² ‘nest’ (Downer ICSTLL 1982, Beijing); PHlai *rɁuak⁷ ‘nest’. This word is perh. cognate to → zhuā 抓 ‘grasp’, hence cháo was originally a ‘perch’ (note the Tai semantic range of zhuā), but the OC vowels do not agree.

‘Chariot’ [OB, BI, Shi] > ‘wheel’ as in fǎng-chē 紡車 ‘spinning wheel’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'je (平); MGZY chÿa (平) [tʂ'jɛ]; ONW tśʰa   ||  [D] PMin *tšʰia; in some southern dialects ‘to mill’, e.g. Y-Guǎngzhōu tsʰɛ⁵³-mɐi¹³ 車米 ‘mill rice’.  ||  [E] Horse and chariot were introduced into China around 1200 BC from the west (Shaughnessy HJAS 48, 1988: 189-237). Therefore, this word is prob. a loan, apparently from an IE language (V. Mair, EC 15, 1990: 45ff; Robert Bauer, Sino-Platonic Papers 47, 1994): Toch. A kukäl, Tocharian B kokale, note Greek k´ykla or k´ykloi (‘wheels’:) ‘wagon’ [Pokorny IG etym. Wörterbuch I: 640]; an older variant survives in Northern Mand. gū-lū ‘wheel’ (so Bauer). Alternatively, acc. to Baxter / Sagart (1998: 48) chē is a derivation by k-prefix from → yú11 舁譽 ‘lift up’ (§5.4); note the WT semantic parallel tʰeg-pa ‘vehicle, carriage, riding beast’ < id. ‘to lift, raise, hold, support’.

‘Chariot’ (a piece in a chess game), lit. for ‘carriage’ (as in Tang poetry: Branner T’ang Studies 17, 2000: 44). For a similar phonological doublet, note → chǔ3 處 ~  jū2 居. Different readings of 車 are discussed by Baxter (1992: 480; 862 n. 356). Shìmíng states that the reading in MC -jwo is the older one; this is prob. based on a scribal error in a Shījīng version (Baxter 1992: 360; 480). On the other hand, Baxter points out that therefore the reading MC kjwo may be a lexicographical ghost, while a reading MC kʰjwo mentioned in JDSW seems closer to MC tśʰja with its aspiration. However, MC kjwo has enjoyed to this day general currency while MC kʰjwo is unknown apart from this sound gloss.   ||  [C] Possible allofam → kù1 庫.

‘To remove, take away, clear away’ 徹 [BI, Shi], 撤 [Lunyu].  ||  [<] r-causative of shì 逝 (§7.5) (Sagart 1999: 111). This word looks like a derivation from → chú2 除 [ḍiɑ] ‘remove’ with a t-suffix (§6.2.2). However, the phonetic of 徹撤 implies a T-like initial consonant whereas the phonetic of 除 implies an L-like initial (§12.1.2).
‘To discard, left over’ [Shi] (Sagart 1999: 111).   ||  [<] r-causative of shì 逝 (źjäiᶜ) (§7.5) with exoactive / extrovert tone C (§4.3.1).
‘Go away, pass on, come to the point that’ [Shi]; a Han period dialect word for ‘to marry’ (of a woman) in Qín and Jìn [FY 1, 14].

‘To go to’ [Shi]; ‘to marry’ (of a woman), a Han period dialect word in Sòng and Lǔ [FY 1, 14]. Acc. to the phonetic series, shì has a T-like initial. There is an occasional interchange of final-k and -t, note that chè prob. also had the vowel *e.
‘A precious object’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'im (平), PR, LR tʂ'in; MGZY chim (平) [tʂ'im]  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. ta-nim ‘jewel’ (Unger Hao-ku 47, 1995: 141).

‘To sink’ [Shi], ‘submerged’ [Guoce], ‘submerge’ something as a sacrifice [OB] > ‘put poison in liquid’ [Zhouli]; ‘deep’ [Zhuang] (~ Chuci → zhàn1 湛 [ḍɛmᴮ] *drə̂mɁ ‘deep’). Acc. to Downer (1959: 282), the intr. ‘to sink’ is read in tone A, while the causative ‘to drown, immerse’ [Zuo] is read in tone C acc. to ancient commentators.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐim (平), PR, LR dʐin; MGZY chim (平) [dʐim]; ONW dim  ||  [<] derived from → yín3 淫 *ləm; the OC initial may have been *rl- as Baxter suggests; note the Khmer form below.    ||  [E] Area etymon: MK *ləm, *ləəm ‘to sink’ (Shorto 2006 #1403): Khmer ralāṃ /rloəm/ ‘be soaked, drenched, drowned’. Katuic *[s/c]əlim, *[t/d]əlim ‘to sink’. PMonic *[]ləm ‘to immerse sth.’ > OMon tulum ‘to drown’ (oneself) , Mon *kəla±əm, Nyah Kur *chəlÆəm; Mon tanim ‘be inundated’, Mon tinlum ‘to sink’  [Diffloth 1984: 221]. <> TB: Chepang: klyum- ‘submerge, be hidden’ ᛝ klyumɁ- ‘bury, submerge, cover’.   ||  [C] Allofams are prob. → yín3 淫, and perh. → chěn2 瀋沈 ‘a liquid’, → hán4 涵, → zhàn1 湛. Similar looking word in final -m include: → dān 耽湛, → jiān 熸, → jiān 漸瀸湛, → lín 淋霖, → shēn3 深, → zhān2 沾霑, → zhēn2 斟, → rǎn 染.   ||  Languages in the area have  similar words, but they are difficult to match with potential OC relations:   ||  AA: PNBahn. *krăm, PSBahn. *kəram ‘sink’.   ||  AA: Khmer /sr`əm/ ‘to sink slowly into water, drop slowly out of sight’.  ||  AA: PMonic *hoom ‘to take a bath’ ᛝ caus. *p-hoom ‘bathe, wash’; PVM *tʰămᴮ ‘bathe’ [Thompson], perh. PSBahn. *Ɂum ‘bathe’.   ||  KT: Saek ramᴬ² ‘be wet’ (ᛝ ramᴬ¹ ‘black’); PKS *Ɂram¹ ‘sink’.   ||  Tai čʰumᴮ¹ ‘wet’, čumᴮ¹ ‘soak, immerse’; Lóngzhōu tumᴬ² ‘wet’.  ||  TB: WT tʰim-pa ‘disappear, being absorbed, evaporate, be melted, to sink’ (e.g. into unconsciousness) ᛝ stim-pa, bstims ‘to enter, penetrate, be absorbed’.  ||  TB: Chepang ɉyomɁ- ‘to sink in, be pressed down’.
‘Poisoned wine’ 酖 [Zuo]; ‘to poison’ 鴆 [Guoyu] (Karlgren GSR 656f).   ||  [<] exopass. of chén 沈 ‘put poison in liquid’ (§4.4).

The 5th of the Earthly Branches, identified with the dragon [OB].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR ʐin (平), LR dʐin; MGZY zhin (平) [ʐin]; ONW dźin  ||  [E] Norman (1985: 88) considers this an AA loan, note Viet. trăn, WrMon klan  ‘python’. This would then be the original graph for shèn 蜃 (źjenᶜ) ‘some kind of dragon’ [Hànshū, Tiānwén zhì].

‘Early morning’ [OB, BI, Shu].  ||  [<] endopass. of zhèn 振震 ‘shake, move’, lit. ‘the time when creatures begin to stir’; see §4.6 for explanation. Alternatively, it may be connected to MK: Mon tmin, tmiin ‘morning’.
‘Dust’ [Shi].  — [E] ST: WT rdul ‘dust’ (HST: 68).
‘Set forth, set out, spread out, arrange, marshal, display’ [Shi], ‘diffuse, give’ [Zuo].
‘Battle array’ [Lunyu].  ||  [<] exopass. of chén 陳 (ḍjen) (§4.4), lit. ‘what is arranged’, thence ‘line up in battle order’ [Zuo] (Downer 1959: 286).

‘To laugh’ [Zhuang].   ||  [E] ST *C-rə(-C): Lushai ṭhenR ‘smile’; perh. also related to PTB *rya-t ‘laugh’ (STC no. 202): WT gža-ba < g-rya ‘sport, joke, play’, Kanauri-Bunan sred, WB rai ‘laugh’. For the initial, see §7.1.4.

‘A liquid’ 瀋 [Zuo]; ‘juice’ 沈 [Li].   ||  [<] nominalizing k-prefix derivation from the stem of → yín3 淫 ‘soak’; see → chén2 沈 for wider connections. Alternative: perh. be related to Tai S. namᶜ < *nl/r- ‘water, liquid’ (so Unger Hao-ku 47, 1995: 140), but the initials are difficult to reconcile.

‘Red’ [Shi] as the color of a bream’s tail or that of blushing, also glossed as ‘deep red’ (Giles), hence chēng referred originally perh. to the intensive red of certain types of exposed (naked) skin color.  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. dɛɛŋᴬ¹ < *Ɂdl/riɛŋ ‘red’, Saek riiŋ¹ < ˘riiŋᴬ¹ ‘be red’, Be liŋ¹³ ‘purple’; PMiao *Ɂl—  Nᴬ ‘red’. Prob. not related to PTB *kyeŋ (STC no. 162; HST p. 123).   ||  [<] possibly an intensive derivation of → chéng5 裎 *dreŋ ‘naked’ (§5.8.3), then the Tai items would be CH loans.
‘To weigh’ [Li].  ||  [E] This may either belong to the wf → chéng2 丞承 ‘lift’; or be of MK origin: Khmer thlɣŋ ‘to weigh’ (because of the medial l, the Khmer word cannot be a CH loan).
‘To stare at’ [Zhuang] also is found in Tai: S. tʰliŋ (WrSiam tʰa-liŋ) ‘a fierce stare, to stare hard at’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 154).

‘To complete, achieve, build’ 成 [BI, Shi]; ‘put’ (in receptacle), ‘load, pack’ [BI, Shi], ‘a vessel full’ 盛 [Meng]; (filled-in earth, stamped earth:) ‘city wall’ [Shi] > ‘city’ 城 [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐiŋ (平); MGZY zhing (平) [ʐiŋ]; ONW dźeŋ  ||  [D] PMin *d̯žiaŋ 成 ‘percent’; PMin *žiaŋ ‘town’.  ||  [E] Prob. not related to → yíng2 盈嬴 ‘full’. Bodman (1980: 160) relates 城 to WT gyaŋ, gyeŋ ‘pisé, stamped earth, wall’ ᛝ rgyaŋ ‘wall’ ᛝ ’geŋs-pa, bkaŋ ‘to fill, to fulfil’ ᛝ skoŋ-ba, bskaŋs ‘to fulfil’.
