For the vowels, see §11.3.2; for the initials §12.1.1 (3). The initial velar is perhaps confirmed by PWa which borrowed this word as *kiŋ ‘town, village’.
‘Abundant, highest degree’ [Zhuang, Li].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ʐiŋ (去); MGZY zhing (去) [ʐiŋ]; ONW dźeŋ  ||  [<] exopass. of chéng1 ‘be filled’ (§4.4).

‘To lift, hold up, present, receive’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐiŋ (平); MGZY zhing (平) [ʐiŋ]; ONW dźiŋ  ||  [E] This wf is prob. related to → dēng1 登. There is a similar wf, but with initial *l-: → chéng3 乘. HST: 104 relates this wf to WT greŋ-ba ‘rise, stand up’, but the WT medial -r- should be expected to have a MC counterpart.
‘To lift, raise, set forth, display’ [OB, BI, Shu]. ‘To weigh’ → chēng2 稱.
‘To appreciate, equal to, corresponding’ [Shi] > ‘capable of’ [Li].  ||  [<] exopass. of chēng 稱 (tśʰjəŋ), lit. ‘be lifted to (a level)’ (§4.4).
‘To offer (gift, sacrifice)’ [Shi]
‘Lift’ [Yi], ‘save, help’ [Zuo].
‘To mount, ascend, ride, drive’ [Shi].
‘Chariot, team of four horses’ [Shi].  ||  [<] exopass. of chéng 乘 (dźjəŋ), lit. ‘what is mounted’ (§4.4).

‘To mount, rise, raise’ [BI, Shi] > ‘to present’ [Li].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂiŋ (平); MGZY shing (平) [ʂiŋ]; ONW śiŋ  ||  [<] perhaps caus. of chéng 乘 (dźjəŋ) (§5.2.2). Bodman (1980: 185) considers this word a doublet of → xīng6 興.   ||  [C] See also → téng2 騰; → shèng6 勝 is perh. cognate.
‘Door posts’ [Li], ‘serve as a stay or support to’ [Zhouli].  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. soŋᴬ² (WrSiam. drŋ) (Manomaivibool 1975: 153). Or TB-Lepcha tă-raŋ ‘upright beam in house’ (Bodman p.c.).

‘Naked’ [Meng].  ||  [E] This is prob. related to TB-Mikir -reŋᴸ angseᴴ ‘naked’, WT sgren-mo ‘naked’ (WT rǰen ‘naked’ is a dialectal backform: Beyer 1992: 146), JP krin³¹ ‘naked’, Lushai ṭeenR  ‘be bare’ (as a hill side) (Unger Hao-ku 38, 1992: 82). This word could ultimately belong to → luǒ2 裸, all based on a ST root *roi; see the Table L-1 ‘Naked, red’ for an overview of related and similar etyma. A derivation is → chēng1 赬 ‘red’ (so Karlgren 1933: 69) as ‘naked’ is associated with ‘red’.
‘Limpid, clear’ [Li].  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. riaŋᴬ² ‘limpid, clear’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 152).
‘Suppress’ 徵 [Yi]; ‘correct with harsh measures, repress’ [Shu], ‘warn’ 懲 [Zuo]. This word may be connected with → líng7 陵泠凌 ‘oppress’.
‘To stutter’ [SW, Hanshu].  — [E] Etymology not clear.

Xnote: (?)  Sin Sukchu SR k'i (入) LR tʂ'iɁ; MGZY khi (入) [k'i]
Notes: ‘To eat’ [Xīnshū 新書, spurious?], has been since the 18th cent. the ordinary Mand. word for ‘to eat’ [Kāngxī zìdiǎn, Hóng Lóu Mèng] (Sino-Platonic Papers 98, Jan. 2000: 75ff). Phonetically the MC form does not agree with Mand., nor does the alleged older variant graph → chī3 喫. Etymology therefore unknown, perhaps it is the same word as ‘stutter’ (‘eat one’s sounds’?) (Norman 1988: 76, n. 6).
‘To eat’ 喫 [ONW, Yupian], said to be a variant graph for chī2 吃, etymology unknown; neither 喫 nor 吃 can be connected with Mand. chī phonetically (Norman 1988: 76, n. 6).

‘Mountain demon’ 离 [SW], 魑 [Zuo], 螭 [Lü] occurs in texts only in the compound chī-mèi 魑魅; chī has been extensively discussed by Carr (LTBA 13.2: 136ff.).  ||  [E] ST: WT ’dre < ɴdre ‘goblin, demon, evil spirit’ ᛝ gre-bo / -mo ‘species of demon’; KN *t/s-rai [IST: 23]: Tangkhul raiᴴ ‘unclean spirit’, Bodo ráj ‘devil’. This is distinct from WT sri, Lushai hriF ‘evil spirit which causes sickness’. Note also PKS *laːi⁴ ‘devil, ghost’ which may be a CH loan because of the initial *l-.
‘Pool, pond’ [Shi] is perh. a ST word, note Lushai dilR  ‘lake, pond, tank, pool’, or Lushai liᴴ < li ‘deep pool’.
‘Islet’ 坻 [Shi] is the s. w. as ‘raised path from gate to the wall of a palace’ 墀 [Hanfei] acc. to Baxter (1992: 463f).
‘Ant eggs’ [Li] may possibly be connected with → dié1 垤 ‘ant-hill’.
‘Spittle of a dragon’ [Guoyu]. STC (171 n. 457) relates this word to PTB *m-tśril  ‘spittle’, but the rimes do not agree.

‘Walk hesitatingly’, or perh. ‘pacing up and down’ [Shi], Mand. ‘hesitate, waver’.   ||  [E] <> Tai: S. riiᴬ²-rɔɔᴬ² ‘walk hesitatingly, undecided’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 152f); for the initials, see §7.1.4.

‘To cleave, separate, take away’ [OB, Zhuang].   ||  The original graph 多 shows two separate pieces of meat, hence ‘separate’, although the conventional interpretation of the graph is ‘2 pieces of meat’ = ‘many’. Since 多 occurs already in the earliest OB, but only as a loan for → duō ‘many, all’, the donor word ‘cleave, separate’ must already have existed at the beginning of writing.   ||  [E] ST: WT ral ‘rent, cleft’ ᛝ ral-ba ‘torn’ (clothes) ᛝ ’dral-ba, dral / ral ‘to rip up, tear to pieces’ ᛝ hral-ba ‘to rent, tear up’ ᛝ sgral-ba ‘to cut to pieces’.
‘To cleave wood following fibers’ [Shi].
‘To disembowel’ [OB Bingb. 7.1 Period I; Zhuang].

‘To split, rent’ [Shi], ‘fissure’ [Zhouli] occurs also in Tai: S. hakᴰ¹S < *tʰr- ‘to be broken’ (stick) (Li F. 1976: 44). Prob. not related to → pò1 破.   ||  [<] final -k form of chǐ1 拸 (ṭʰjeᴮ) (§6.1.1).   ||  [C] This wf may be related to → chǐ2, chí  誃. For an overview of similar items, see the Table P-1 under → pī3 披. For similar words and possible allofams, see → lí10 離.

‘To separate’ [Guoce].  ||  [E] ST: PL *C-klay¹/³ ‘to separate’; Chepang kləyh-sa ‘to break’ (as sticks), Lushai hlaiR ‘to flay, to skin, split’ (as cane).   ||  A cognate is perh. → tā 他 ‘other’. This word may belong to → chǐ1 拸 (ṭʰjieᴮ) and to → chǐ3 侈哆移 ‘wide, extend’; perh. also connected with Tai S. sa⁴-laai² ‘to be split, cracked’.  ||  For an overview of similar items, see the Table P-1 under → pī3 披. For a listing of similar words and possible allofams, see → lí10 離.

‘Great’ [Shi], ‘extravagant, overbearing’ 侈 [Zuo]; ‘large’ 哆 [Shi] (also read QY tśʰjaᴮ); ‘enlarge’ 移 [Li]; ‘wide, extend’ [Guoyu].   ||  [E] ST: OBurm klai [IST: 342], WB kyai ‘wide, broad’ ᛝ kyaiᴮ ‘wide apart’ ᛝ kʰyaiᴮ ~ kʰraiᶜ ‘make wide apart, be diffused’ ᛝ kʰyaiᶜ ‘wide, spread out’. HST: 139 relates ‘wide, extend’ 掵 to WT gčal-ba ‘to spread, lay out’. WT čʰe-ba, čʰen-po ‘great’ < *te (HST: 88) seems to be a different etymon. Chǐ3 may be the s. .w.  as → chǐ1 拸 ‘to ‘separate’.
‘Spread, grow numerous’ [Zuo] < final -k form of 侈哆移 (tśʰjieᴮ) (§6.1).
‘To extend’ [Li], ‘spread’ [Shi].
‘To expand’ [Yi], ‘spread out, expose’ [Guoyu].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR ʂi (平), PR, LR ʂʅ; MGZY shhi (平) [ʂʅ]; ONW śe  ||  [C] This wf may be part of a larger group, see → lí10 離.

‘Shame’ [Shi], ‘disgrace’ [Zuo]. Pulleyblank (1973: 121) relates chǐ to words meaning ‘shame’ with initial *n- and different rimes, see → xiū3 羞. Psychologists tend to associate ‘guilt’ often with auditory admonition (Eberhard (1967: 12), therefore → ěr1 耳 ‘ear’ is possibly not only part of the graph for mental association, but chǐ may even be cognate to ‘ear’. For the *r in the OC initial, note the *r- prefix in TB lgs; MC ṭʰj- derives from a complex initial nasal cluster also in chǒu 丑.

‘Tooth (any kind), tusk’ [OB, Shi] (Norman / Mei 1976: 289-92).  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'i (上); PR, LR tʂ’ʅ; MGZY chi (上) [tʂ'i]; MTang tśʰi, ONW tśʰə  ||  [D] PMin *kʰiᴮ¹ ~ tʃʰiᴮ¹  ||  [E] The etymology is not clear; chǐ is not related to WT mčʰe-ba ‘canine tooth’, see → diān3 齻 ‘eyetooth’, but may be the same word as PMin *kʰiᴮ ‘tooth’. An AA etymon for ‘tooth’ looks vaguely similar: e.g. Khmer khnae ‘tusk, spur’ (Shorto 1971: 85), Mon inscr. gnis > gnih ‘eyetooth, canine’ (AA medial n often disappears in CH).
‘Salty soil’ [Shu] is perh. connected to → xì4 潟 (sjäk) [siak] ‘salty soil’ and may belong to → gǔ15 盬 and → lǔ1 鹵.

‘Red’ [BI, Shi] is from earliest times the basic term for ‘red’ (Baxter JCLTA 1983), rivaled only by → zhū1 朱. The OC initial is suggested by *hl- in the phon. series.  ||  <> Tai: S. tʰiakᴰ¹ ‘red’ may be a pre- or early Han loan.   ||  [D] PMin *tsʰiak  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. The phonetic series implies an OC L-like initial, also the graph 赤 writes a word ‘expel’ with incontrovertible OC *l- (→ shě2 舍捨). There are no TB comparanda with a close phonological fit; one could cite WT kʰrag ‘blood’ (HST: 123) which is here associated with → hè4 赫; or PTB *tsyak = *tśak ‘red’ (cognate acc. to STC no. 184; p. 168 n. 452), Lushai čak ‘red’, as well as the TB items under → hè4 赫 ‘red’ with which it may possibly be connected.    ||  Perh. the following word may be related; like chì3, it had apparently a complex initial cluster in OC:
‘Red’ [Shi]. — [D] Amoy tsʰioɁᴬ¹

‘Wing’ [Guoce].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ’ʅ, ʂi (去), PR ʂʅ, LR tʂ’ʅ; MGZY shi (去) [ʂi]; MTang śi, kie (?)  ||  [N] The Mand. form is apparently derived from MC śjeᶜ with irregularly affricated initial. Mǐn kʰek  may suggest an OC velar element in the initial. The origins and connections between the disparate forms are obscure (GSR 864). ‘Leaf’ → yè4  葉 can apparently also mean ‘wing’ in some dialects.

‘Cooked sacrificial millet’ 饎 [Shi], 耡 [Zhouli]. The phonet. series imply an OC initial *j-, hence the word may be related to WT yos ‘slightly roasted corn’ (mostly barley or wheat). Baxter a. Sagart (1998: 52) relate chì to → qǐ3 芑.
‘Be young, weak’ (of a person) [Shu].  — [E] ST: WT čʰuŋ-ba ‘small, young’.
‘Empty’ [Lao] looks similar to WT stoŋ-pa ‘empty’.

‘To hull grain with a pestle’ [Shi], ‘beating stick for beating time in music’ [Zhouli]; ‘to beat’ 淳 [Zuo].   ||  [E] KT: S. *klooŋ ‘hull rice’ (STC: 178 n. 472), Kam-Sui *tyuŋᴮ, which in turn is perh. ultimately related to AA: Kharia du’ruŋ ‘to pound’ (rice), Munda ruÂuŋ ‘to husk grain’ (in a husking machine). TB forms (if related) appear to be phonetically closer to → chuáng2 橦.
‘To pierce’ (a person to kill him) [Guoce]. A syn. and cognate is → dòng1 洞.   ||  [E] ? ST: Perh. related to WT mduŋ ‘lance, spear, sting of insect’ (CVST 2: 15).

‘Insect, worm’ [Shi], in some early texts [e.g. Zhouli] also ‘animal’ in general (Carr CAAAL 21, 1983: 7ff).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐjuŋ (平), PR dʐuŋ; MGZY cÿung (平) [dʐjuŋ]  ||  [E] ST: PTB *d-yuŋ > Geman Deng klɑuŋ⁵⁵, or Garo dźoŋɁ  (Joseph / Burling LTBA 24.2, 2001: 45), Dimasa yuŋ < dyuŋ (STC: 34; HST: 98).

‘Take out, pull out, remove’ (e.g. draw weapons, remove thorns from a branch) 抽 [Shi], ‘pull out (liver)’ 盩 [Lü].  ||  [C] 盩 is said to be the older graph for the word (ZWDCD 6: 1032); accordingly 抽 is apparently a later simplified way of writing chōu. OCM could therefore have been either *thru, or a rare *t-hlu or the like which the phonetic may imply. 盩 zhōu (ṭjəu) *tru is the reading for the name of a county.   ||  [E] An outside connection is not certain. If OCM were *t-hlu, the word could be related to TB-Chepang klu- ‘pull out’ (hair) ᛝ glu- ‘pull out (larger) weeds, cultivate crop’ ᛝ blu- ‘remove, root out’. <> Tai: S. tʰa-lokᴰ¹ ‘id.’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 149, but the Tai final stop is unexplained). <> Alternatively, if OCM were *thru, the word could be compared to MK *tɗus, *tɗuəs ‘to pull out, off, back’ (Shorto 2006 #1904a) which is however not widely represented in the MK family. It is possible that a MK post-initial dental stop is reflected in OC as a medial *r, but the MK final *s should have left a trace in OC.
‘To improve, get cured, recover’ [OB, BI, Shi], ‘harm’ [Guoyu] is prob. cognate to → liào3 療樂.

‘Sound of an ox breathing’ [SW].  ||  [E] ST: The basic meaning of this etymon is ‘breathe in’: WB huik ‘pant, be out of breath’; it is not clear if or how WB hru ‘breathe, draw into the nose, mouth’ ᛝ hruik  ‘draw into lungs with protracted effort’ are related.

‘Strong smell’ [Shi], ‘foul’ [Shu] > Mand. also ‘stinking, disgusting’.    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'iw (去); MGZY chiw (去) [tʂ'iw]; MTang tśʰeu < tśʰu, ONW tśʰu  ||  [D] M-Xiàmén lit. tsʰiuᶜ¹, col. tsʰɑoᶜ¹, Fúzhōu tsʰauᶜ

‘To smell, inhale’ [Lun] > Mand. ‘smell, scent, sniff’. CH -> PTai *xiəuᴬ¹ ‘to smell bad, putrid’.   ||  [T] MTang hiu > heu; ONW hu  — [D] M-Xiàmén lit. hiuᶜ¹ ‘bad smelling’.   ||  [C] An allofam is perh. → chǒu2 醜.

(‘Counterpart’:) ‘mate, companion’ [Shu], (‘equal items’:) ‘class, category’ [Shu], ‘equal’ [Guiguzi]. Syn. qiú 仇 (gjəu) ‘mate, companion, antagonist’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT do ‘two, a pair, a couple, an equal, match, companion, mate’ ᛝ dod ‘an equivalent’, WB tu ‘be like, similar’ (CVST 2: 14). On the other hand, note PWMiao A ntrauﬂ ‘husband, lover’.

(‘To counter’:) ‘to pay back, reply, opponent, enemy’ [Shi]; ‘pledge with wine a second time’ 酬 [Shi], ‘requite’ 脅  [Shu], ‘recompense with gifts’ 酬 [Zuo].  ||  [E] ST: Lushai doᴴ ‘be at enmity with, be hostile’, doᴴ ‘to counter contributions...’; but Lushai ‘be at enmity with’ may equally well belong to → dòu6 鬥  ‘quarrel’.
‘A pair’ [Zuo]  ||  [<] n-nominalization of chóu  讎 *du (§6.4.3)

‘Ploughed field’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐiw (平); MGZY ciw (平) [dʐiw]  ||  [E] <> Manomaivibool (1975: 150-53) discusses the possibility of a connection with Tai: S. tʰiakᴰ² < *d- ‘ploughed field’, but phonologically the forms are difficult to reconcile; see also → zhái 宅.

Cyclical sign for ‘ox’ [OB].  ||  [E] MK (Mei 1980; Norman 1985: 87): PVM *c-luː > kluː / tluː ‘buffalo’ > Viet. trâu [ṭəw]. For the *l > *r shift, see §7.3. However, a different MK synonym seems to be a closer fit for OC, although it enjoyed no wide distribution: *ruuk ‘ox’ (Shorto 2006 #396): Biat nɗroːk (< kuən ruuk by contraction). The meaning ‘ox’ has been obsolete since the beginning of writing, but → láo1 牢 ‘calf’ may belong to the same root. 丑 is the original graph for ‘claw, finger’ → niǔ1 狃丑.

‘Ugly, evil’ [Shi] > ‘to hate’ [Zuo]. Acc. to Lau (1999: 53), this word is cognate to chòu 臭 ‘foul’ (under → chōu3 犨), also in its meaning ‘multitude (of enemies)’ [Shi] (then originally ‘the disgusting ones’) > ‘category, class’ [Li] > ‘of the same kind’ [Meng].
‘To rot, decay’ [Shi] > Mand. also ‘aged, senile’.

‘To come out’ (of a place) [OB, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'y (入); MGZY chÿu (入) [tʂ'y]; MTang tśʰur < tśʰuir, ONW tśʰuit   ||  [D] PMin *tšʰuit > Xiàmén tsʰutᴰ¹  ||  [E] ST: JP lot³¹-lam³³ ‘outlet’, Trung kl≠ɔt ‘come out’ (Zhengzhang Shangfang in Pan Wuyun 2000: 148); KN-Chinbok hlɔt ‘come out’.
‘To bring out, send out, take out’ [Shi].   ||  [<] exoactive of chū 出 (tśʰjuət) (§4.3).
‘To expel, degrade, expurgate’ [Shu].  ||  [D] M-Xiàmén lit. tutᴰ¹, col. lutᴰ¹  ||  [<] r-caus. of chū 出 (§7.5) (Pulleyblank 1973: 118).   ||  [C] Perh. → chūn 春 ‘spring’ is related.

‘Nephew, sister’s son’ [EY] is related to PTB *tu ~ *du ‘nephew’ (STC: 158). A word with initial *t- could prob. be written with a graph which earlier represented a cluster *kl- (→ chū2 出). Sagart 1999: 167f derives this word from → chū1 出 ‘come out’ in the sense of ‘be born’ which would be parallel to → shēng3 甥 ‘nephew’.
‘Be first, begin, beginning’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'u (平); MGZY chu (平) [tʂ'u]; MTang tṣʰy, ONW tṣʰø < tṣʰo  ||  [D] M-Xiàmén lit. tsʰɔᴬ¹, col. tsʰueᴬ¹
‘To start work’ [Shi], ‘commence, create’ [Lunyu] (Pulleyblank 1962: 233).  ||  [<] terminative of chū 初 *tshra (§6.5.1).

‘To remove, clear out’ tr. [Zuo, Hanshu].  ||  [T] Sin S. SR dʐy (平); MGZY cÿu (平) [dʐy]; MTang ḍy < ḍø; ONW dø < dio (?)  ||  [D] M-Xiàmén lit. duᴬ²  ||  [<] r-caus. of shū 抒 (dźjwoᴮ) (§7.5).  ||  [E] Perh. an area etymon: TB-WT ’dag-pa ‘clear away, remove’ (HST: 124). <> AA: Khmer ṭaka /dɑɑk/ ‘to pull or wrench out, uproot’ ᛝ raṭaka /rdɑɑk/ ‘be pulled or torn out... removed’. Alternatively, cognation with WB hraᴮ ‘remove out of the way’ is phonologically also possible. The AA forms may be closer to OC because of the r-affix and the loss of final consonant after long vowel (§6.9). A derivation with t-suffix may be → chè2 徹撤 ‘remove’, but that is doubtful.
‘To be removed, pass away’ [Shi].  ||  [<] exopass. of chú 除 (ḍjwo) (§4.4).
‘To eliminate’ [Zuo].

‘A hoe’ [Chuci].  ||  [D] Wu-Kāihuà zɑᴬ²; M-Xiàmén tiᴬ¹, Cháozhōu tɯᴬ¹, Fúzhōu tʰyᶜ², Jiàn’ōu tʰyᶜ² (the stop initials does not agree with the QYS; a similar case is → shāi, shī  篩)  ||  [E] Perh. MK *ras, *raas, *riəs ‘to rake, comb, scratch’ (Shorto 2006 #1928, note also ɐ1938 *cra[a]s ‘scrape [clean]’): OKhmer ‌/crās/ ‘to scrape or brush against’ ᛝ camrāsa /cɑmraah/ OKhmer caṃrās ‘to rake, hoe’ ᛝ Khmer rā’sa /roəh/ ‘to scrape, rake, hoe, harrow’. For loss of foreign final consonant, see §6.9.

‘Hay’ (for fodder or fuel) [OB, BI, Shi], ‘grass cutter’ [OB, Shi]; ‘to cut’ tr. (grass, firewood) [Lüshi chunqiu, SW, Mand.]; factitive: ‘to feed hay to’ [Lüshi chunqiu].  ||  [E] MK: PMon *ksɔɔy ‘useless fiber, hay’, Mon *chu±e ‘grass, weed, hay’, PWa *sɔh ‘cut grass’. For the absence of final *-y in CH see §6.9. → cuò1 莝 ‘hay’ is derived from the same AA etymon. An allofam may be → zōu2 騶 ‘groom’.
‘Chicken, young of animals’ [Liji].  — Etymology not clear.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐu (平); MGZY cu (平) [dʐu]

‘Pestle’ [Yi].   ||  [D] CDC chuᴮ¹; M-Xiàmén (lit.) tsʰuᴮ¹  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. The phonetic indicates that the OC word had a complex initial with an *ŋ-like element (or nasal + velar?). The word is reminiscent of MK-PMonic *gnriːɁ, Nyah-Kur ŋrÆiːɁ ‘pestle’ (for the vowels, see §11.1.3).

‘Thorny bush / tree’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'u (上); MGZY chu (上) [tʂ'u];  CDC chuᴮ¹; ONW tṣʰo > tṣʰø  ||  [E] MK *jlaʔ ‘thorn’ (Shorto 2006 #205): PMonic *jrlaaɁ ‘thorn, thorny bamboo’ (added to names of thorny plants), Khmu’ /cərlaɁ/, Semai /jərlaaɁ [Diffloth 1984: 80]. The complex MK initial needed to be simplified in CH, apparently by elimination of the medial l.  ||  Table C-1  ‘Knock, Push, Touch’ (for → chù1 觸) →

‘To stay, keep still, dwell’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] ST: TB: WT gda’-ba ‘to be, be there’ (locative vb.) ᛝ WT gdan ‘seat’: ‘a bolster, a place of residence, situation, rank’, Mikir kedō ‘to dwell’; with the original l-initial in TGTM *glaːᴬ/ᴮ ‘place’ (Mazaudon 1996 LTBA 19.1: 107); Lushai tlaᴴ / tlatᴸ ‘to be, exist, live, remain’; Pwo Karen (Kyonbyaw) lân ‘place’ (Kato A. 1995 LTBA 18.1: 68).    ||  [C] → jū2 居 which is prob. a variant.
‘A place’.    ||  [T] Sin S. SR tʂ'y (去); MGZY chÿu (去) [tʂ'y]; ONW tśʰø < tśʰo

‘To butt’ [Yi], ‘knock against’ [Zuo].   ||  [D] Mǐn Xiàmén lit. tsʰiokᴰ¹, col. tsʰikᴰ¹  ||  [E] ST *tok WT tʰogs-pa ‘to strike, stumble, run against’, Lushai tɔɔkᴴ ‘to knock (against)’, Mikir tòk- ‘to strike, beat’.   ||  TB parallel stem with initial affricate: Mikir chòk ‘beat, hit, strike’ (STC: 53), WT ’tsʰogs-pa ‘to hew, chop’, note also Kuki-Naga *tsjuk ‘knock against’. Further cognates and / or parallel stems are listed in Table C-1.  ||  Li F. (1976: 41) associates Tai-S. tʰuukᴰ¹ᴸ < *tʰ- ‘right, cheap, to touch’ with chù1 觸, but the S. word is only in its last sense a loan from ST (→ zhù7 注 ‘touch’), while ‘right, cheap’ belongs with WB tʰuik ‘be worth, have a certain value, be worthy, be fit’ and with Mon tʰɔik ‘be good, right’.

‘Bend’ [Xun]. The word belongs to a root *tru from which is also derived → zhǒu1 肘 ‘wrist, elbow’ q.v.  ||  [E] ST: WB kruiᶜ ‘bow down, stoop’. Bodman 1969: 337 relates this word to WT ’dud-pa, dud / btud ‘to bend down, incline’.

‘To rear, to nourish, cherish’ (animals) (also 慉 [Shi]) > ‘support’ [Shi].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR  tʂ'y (入), PR tʂ'uɁ; MTang ṭʰuk, ONW tʰuk  ||  [E] Etymology not clear, but prob. ST: PTB *hu ‘rear, raise, nourish’: PLB *hu³, Abor-Miri u, Qiang (Mawo) ≈u [HPTB: 58]. Perh. related to → hǎo 好. Alternative affiliation:  ||  ST: JP kruɁ⁵⁵ < kruk⁵⁵ ‘to sprout’, kʰruŋ³³ ‘be alive’, WT ’kʰruŋ-ba ‘be born, come up, to sprout’ (HPTB: 285). See Table C-2 for synonyms.  ||  Zhengzhang relates WT lug ‘sheep’ to this word (Sagart 1999: 195), this would be parallel to → yáng1 羊 ‘sheep’ ? ᛝ yǎng2 養 ‘raise’; however, WT lug is prob. related to → dú6 犢.  ||  Table C-2  Birth, sprout, nourish →
‘Domestic animal’ [Zuo; EY 19] (tone C reading: Downer 1959: 276).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR xy (入); MGZY hÿu (入) [xy]  ||  [<] exopass. of chù, xù 畜 (§4.4), lit. ‘what is being / has been raised’.

‘River’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] Area word: PTB *kluːŋ (STC no. 127) > WT kluŋ ‘river’; Kachin kruŋ ‘valley, dale’, OBurm. kʰloŋ [IST: 353], WB kʰyuiŋᴮ ‘stream’; perh. also Lushai luaŋᴴ / luanᴸ < luaŋ / luanh (< luaŋs) ‘to flow’ (water, river) (so Unger Hao-ku 50, 1995: 156). This etymon may ultimately be connected with → jiāng1 江 (*kruŋ ~ *kluŋ?). Like OC, MK-PWa has both forms for ‘river’: *klɔŋ ‘river’ and *krɔŋ ‘large river, sea’. STC (p. 131f. n. 129) suggests that the WT root may be separate from the AA one, and considers it to be a variant of shuǐ 水 ‘water, river’. <> Tai: S. kʰlɔɔŋᴬ² ‘canal’ is unrelated, see → táng1 唐.
‘To bore through’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin S. SR tʂ'yen (平); MGZY chwÿan (平) [tʂ'yɛn]; ONW tśʰuan  ||  [E] ST: WT rtol-ba ‘to bore, pierce, perforate’.
‘Tip, end, point’ 耑 [Zhouli], 端 [Li]; ‘beginning, first, symptom’ 端 [Meng]; ‘to bore’ 射  [Fangyan].  ||  [E] ST: WT rdol-ba, brtol ‘to come out, break out, sprout’ (HST: 117).

‘Boat’ [Mo].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐyen (平); MGZY cwÿan (平) [dʐyɛn]  ||  [D] PMin *d̯žiun ~ *d̯žion  ||  [N] The word appears in texts later than → zhōu1 舟 and seems to replace it by Han times (Huáng Jīnguì, Shěn Xíróng YYWZX 1987.8: 41-44). FY says that chuán is the word for ‘boat’ in western China, and (AA) zhōu and háng are the words common in central and eastern China. PMin *d̯ž- suggests a pre-nasalized initial. Graphic variants are written with 工 or 公 which are, however, not phonetic, i.e. a word like GY xiāng is spurious (Huáng Jin-guì, Shěn Xí-róng). There are more words which have a final -n in CH, but -ŋ in TB and other languages (§6.4.2).  ||  [E] Area etymon of AA origin (Luce acc. to Weidert 1987: 129; Shorto 1972: 15). PMK *lu(u) ~ *l(u)əŋ ‘to hollow out’ (Shorto 1972: 15) > OMon dluŋ ‘boat’ ᛝ MidMon /kəmløŋ/ ‘to hollow out’, Khmer /luŋ/ ‘make a hole / pit / cavity, dig, excavate, bore, hollow out’, Bahn.-Sre (daa) törluŋ ‘to hollow out’ (Shorto 1971: 31), PSBahn. *pəluŋ ‘canoe’, PWa *Ɂlɔŋ ‘coffin’, Lawa U loːŋ ‘boat’. The initial in Viet. xuòng [sɯ`əŋ] < ž- ‘boat, canoe’ suggests that this is a CH loan, but the final velar as well as the meaning ‘canoe’ point to MK. Related to this root are apparently words for ‘inside’ (< from ‘hollowed out’): PVM *k-lɔːŋ ‘inside’ [Ferlus] > SViet. trăwŋ, PSBahn. *kəluːŋ ‘middle’, OKhmer kaṃluŋ /kənluŋ/ ‘interior space, inside’, Katuic *kəlhoːŋ ‘inside’, KhmuɁ kluaŋ. These items are prob. not connected with → zhōng1 中 ‘middle’. <> ST-PTB *m-loŋ (HPTB: 294) > WB loŋᴮ ‘canoe, long boat’, also WB hluiŋ ‘excavate, a niche’; Lushai lɔŋᴸ ‘boat’ ᛝ lɔŋF ‘to take out the heart’ (of a tree), S. Khami mlauŋ, N. Khami pʰlauŋ, Kyaw mlauŋ. OC agrees closely with the Kuki-Chin forms *mloŋ; Mikir telòŋ.  ||  From Southern Mǐn forms like tsuŋ⁵⁵ is derived Malay jong, Java ǰong ‘junk’ (Zhāng Yǒng-yán YYWZX 1989.9: 94).  ||  A semantic parallel (and cognate?) is → yú14 俞 OC *lo ‘scoop out, make hollow, canoe’, see there for further items. Syn. → fāng2 方; → háng4 航杭; → zhōu1 舟.
‘Bed’ [Shi]. Perh. cognate to AA-Khmer /rɔɔŋ/  ‘to hold upright, support from below’, and / or OMon joṅ /ɉɔŋ/ ‘couch, bed’ (a CH loan?). For the initials, see §7.1.5.
‘To strike’ [Li].

‘To strike’ [Li]. Unger (Hao-ku 20, 1983, 169) draws attention to the possible morphological parallel with WT where brduŋs is the pf. to rduŋ (pres.) above.  ||  [T] Sin S. SR tʂaŋ (去), PR, LR tʂwaŋ; MGZY cwang (去) [dʐwaŋ]

‘Assault engine, knocker’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT rduŋ-ba, brduŋs ‘to beat, hammer, break to pieces, thrash, pound’; WB tʰoŋᴮ  ‘pound’ (vb?), JP tʰoŋ³¹ ‘kick’ (HST: 40).  ||  This group is not related to → chōng3 舂 *lhoŋ. For ST cognate and / or parallel stems see Table C-1 under → chù1 觸.

‘To blow, play a wind instrument’ tr. 吹 [Shi]; ‘to blow’( into a stove to get the fire going) > ‘to heat, cook’ 炊 [Gongyangzhuan], ‘to steam’ (rice) 炊 [Jìnshū 晉書].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'uj (平); MGZY chue (平) [tʂ'uɛ]; ONW tśʰue  ||  [E] Perhaps shared with AA: Khmer khloy n. ‘flute’. CH aspiration is associated with exhaling §5.8.5.
‘Musical concert’ [Liji].

‘To droop’ (as wings of a bird; reins) [BI, Shi], ‘sag, hang down’ (as clouds from the sky) [Zhuang], ‘let hang down’ (sashes etc.) [Shi].  ||  [E] ST and area etymon. ST *(d)jol ?: PTB *dzywal (STC no. 242) > WT ’ǰol-ba ‘to hang down, dangle’ (cow’s udder; tail etc.) ᛝ gžol-ba ‘train, trail, retinue’ (including: as in robe with a train etc.) (Pulleyblank 1962: 215), g-yol ‘curtain’; Lushai fualR ‘sag, hang low’ (e.g. coat). <> AA: Khmer yola /jóol/ ‘to hang, swing, dangle’, -yāla /-jíiəl/ ‘to hang down’, also yāra /jíiər/ ‘to hang down, dangle ...’. MK -> Tai: S. yoy⁵ ‘to hang down’ (McFarland: 668), PTai *hɔiᶜ¹ ‘to hang down, suspend’.  ||  Alternative affiliation: WT g-yur-ba ‘to droop, hang or sink down’ (Bodman 1980: 80). [C] Perh. related to → shuì1 睡, → duǒ2 朵, → wěi2 委, → ruǐ 繠蕊.
(‘Drooping = ?) ‘far end’ (of a place): (of a hall) [Shi], ‘border, frontier’ [Zuo].
‘Press down, crush’ [Lü].  ||  [<] r-caus. (§7.5) of chuí (Pulleyblank 1962: 215), + exoact. / caus. tone C (§4.3).
‘Pot, jar’ [Lie]. Perhaps related is the ancient Chángshā dialect word for ‘pot, jar’ duò 瞶 (duâᴮ) [GY]. - [E] ? ST: WT yol-go, yol-ma ‘earthenware, crockery’.

‘Spring’ (season) [Shi], in OB perh. ‘spring-summer’.   ||  [T] MTang tśʰun, ONW tśʰuin  — [D] PMin *tšʰuin  ||  [E] Acc. to Boltz (JAOS 99.3, 1979: 436) chūn is cognate to → chǔn 蠢  (tśʰjuenᴮ) ‘stir, come to life’ (as insects), and also to → chū1 出 ‘come out’. Alternatively it may be related to TB-Lushai fuurᴸ ‘summer, monsoon’ (from ST *tj-?), or to Rongmei tûn, Liangmei ka-t˜un [Weidert 1987: 209f].

‘Lip’ [Zuo] > ‘banks’ (of a river) 漘 [Shi]; the basic meaning was apparently ‘edge, rim’ (Wáng Lì 1982: 517).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ʐyn (平), CPR dʐyn; MGZY cÿun (平) [dʐyn]  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. The most likely cognate is TB-Lepcha a-dul ‘lips, edge of a vessel’ (Geilich 1994: 272). Mikir iŋtùr < mtùr ‘lip’ is perhaps a loan from MK-Khasi: ʃṇtur ‘mouth’. STC (158 n. 428) associates chún with WT mčʰu ‘lip, beak of birds’  (but see under → zhǔ7 斸), HST: 39 connects WT with zhòu 啄咮 ‘beak’ (→ zhǔ7 斸).
‘To flow’ [Zhuang], ‘to soak’ [Guoyu] > (? ‘soaked land’:) ‘salty and poor land’ [Zuo].
‘To moisten’ [Zhouli], ‘moist, fat’ [Li].

‘Be wriggling, moving, swarming’ (of insects > people) 蠢 [Shi] > ‘agitated’ 惷 [SW: Zuo]. Boltz relates this word to → chūn 春 ‘spring’.    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂ'yn (上); MGZY (蠢) chÿun (上) [tʂ'yn]; ONW tśʰuin
‘Be agitated, anxious’ [Zhuang].
‘Be sorrowful, anxious’ [Chuci].

‘To spear’ (fish) [Zhuang].  ||  [E] MK: Khmer cūka /còok/ ‘lift with tool...’ ᛝ cpūka /cbòok/ (archaic:) ‘trident for lifting fish’, perh. also PWa *cɔk ‘to catch’ (fish by hand). See → cè5 簎 for OC and MK variants. For the CH retroflex initial, see §5.10.3. Note also → zé6 矠.

‘To taste, eat’ 啜 [Li], ‘to drink’ 歠 [Li].  ||  [D] This is the word for ‘to drink’ in some southern dialects: 啜 K-Méixiàn tsʰɔt¹¹, M-Fúzhōu tsʰuɔɁ⁴³, Jiàn’ōu tsʰyɛ³⁴, Xiàmén tsʰeɁ³².   ||  [E] The TB words under → zá 噆 may possibly belong here.
‘Female’ of birds, game [Shi], in modern dialects also of other animals, e.g Wú-Sūzhōu ts‘ɿ⁴⁴-ãiʏ²⁴/²¹ 雌牛 ‘cow’; opposite xióng 雄 ‘male’. — Etymology not clear.
‘Small intestines’ [GY].   ||  [E] <> PTai *saiᶜ¹ ‘intestines’ (Luo 2000: 86f). This word is distinct from → zì3 胔.

‘Word, speech, excuse, pleading’ 辭 [BI, SWhi, Shu], ‘word, expression’ 詞 [Hanfei].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR zɿ (平), LR zɿ; MGZY zhi (平) [zɿ]  ||  [E] ST *s-lə: WT zla-ba, zlas ‘to say, tell, express’ (CVST 3: 1). The modern Mand. pronunciation has led to the erroneous identification with WT tsʰig ‘word’.

‘This (here)’ [Shi] is an independent pronoun (§3.3.3) (Pulleyblank 1995: 86). The phonetic series of cǐ is inconclusive concerning the OC rime, Karlgren assumes *-ar (i.e. OCM *-ai), but cognation with sī (next) suggests OC final *-e.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'ɿ (上); MGZY tshhi (上) [ts'ɿ]; ONW tsʰe
‘This’ [Shi, but especially Lúnyǔ and Lǐjì: Tángōng where sī replaces the usual cǐ] (Pulleyblank 1995: 88).

‘Be second, next following’ [Shi], ‘to arrange in order, order, sequel’ 次 [Zuo]; ‘well arranged, convenient’ 佽 [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'ɿ (去); MGZY tshhi (去) [ts'ɿ]; ONW tsʰi  ||  [E] Since acc. to SW, → èr1 二 ‘two’ is phonetic in cì, Pulleyblank (1962: 133) derives cì from èr  and postulates an OC cluster of the type s + n- (see comment under → qī1 七 ‘seven’; §5.9.2).

‘Thorn’ [SW].   ||  [<] This late (i.e. Han period) word is derived from cì 刺 [tsʰiek] by the general derivation tone C (§3.5).  ||  [E] ST: WT tsʰer-ma ‘thorn, thorn bush’ ᛝ gzer-ba ‘to bore into’ ᛝ gzer ‘nail’. MC initial tsʰ- can regularly derive from ST *k-s-, *k-z- (§5.9.1); for the loss of final *r in OC, see §7.7.5. Khmer jera /céer/ ‘to blame, criticise, scold’ which cannot be a CH loan on phonological grounds, suggests that ‘stab’ and ‘criticise’ are seperate etyma which have converged in OC. A similar sound symbolic item is also found in MK: OKhmer cāk /cak/ ‘to pierce, stab, prick’ (or CH loan?).

‘To criticize’ [Shi], ‘attack, satirize’ [Zuo]; ‘to kill’ [Zuo].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'ɿ (去); MGZY tshhi (去) [ts'ɿ]  ||  [<] exopass. / exoact. derivation of cì 刺 (tsʰjäk) (§4.3-4), lit. ‘cause to be stabbed’. Downer (1959: 284) reserves the tone D form LH tsʰiek for the meaning ‘stab’.
‘Pierce, stab’ [Meng].

‘To give, to present with’ [BI, Shi], ‘bring’ (tribute) 錫; ‘be given, be presented with’ 賜 [Lunyu]. Xí 錫 is simply a loan graph for cì (Qiu Xigui 2000: 399f).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR sɿ (去); MGZY shi (去) [sɿ]  ||  [<] This word could be a final *-k form (§6.1) of → shī9 施 ‘give’. Sagart (1999: 71) relates this word to yì 易 ‘change’ (under → yí8 移), hence lit. ’exchange’.
‘Onion’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT btsoŋ ‘onion’ (HST: 114); Mru choŋ (Löffler 1966: 142).

‘Go along with, follow’ [OB, BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dzjuŋ (平), PR, LR dzuŋ; MGZY tsÿung (平) [dzjuŋ]; ONW dzuoŋ  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. Perh. related to WT rdzoŋ-ba, (b)rdzaŋ(s) ‘to send, expedite, dismiss’ ᛝ rdzoŋ(s)  ‘act of accompanying, escorting’. Tib. a usually does not correspond to a Chinese back vowel. An alternative association could be with WT stoŋs-pa ‘to accom- pany’; or perh. with → sòng1 送 (suŋᶜ) ‘to escort, follow after, go along’.
‘Follower’ [Shi 104]; zòng mǔ ‘mother’s sisters’ [Liji], zòng dì ‘cousins’ [Zuo] (Downer 1959: 290).   ||  [<] LOC general derivation (§3.5).
‘Be craggy, craggy height’ cuī-cuī 崔崔 [Shi 101, 1], cuī-wéi 崔嵬 [Shi 201,3]. Acc. to Baxter (1992: 231) cuī is perh. related to:
‘High, precipitous’ [SW].
‘Deep’ (of an abyss) [Shi 197, 4].
‘To dip into a fluid’ 淬 [Guoce], ‘plunge’ (a red-hot sword blade into water to harden it) [Hanshu], ‘to dye’ [Yili], person getting ‘soaked’ by dew [Huainan].
‘Kingfisher’ [Zuo] praised for its brilliant turquoise feathers. The bird is noted for diving into water to seize a fish.   ||  [C] → zuì1 醉 belongs perh. to the same root.
‘Be among, exist’ [Shi] < ‘be in there’, is possibly a demonstrative *-n  derivation from → zài1 在 *dzəɁ (Pulleyblank, ICSTLL 1998: 11).
‘Thumb’ [Gongyang], ‘inch’ [Meng].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'un (去); MGZY tshun (去) [ts'un]; ONW tsʰon  ||  [<] general derivation (noun) of cǔn 忖 (§3.5).
‘To measure, consider’ [Shi].

‘To rub, polish’ [Shi] (e.g. ivory). A derivation is → cuò2 錯厝 ‘grindstone’.  ||  [E] AA: Khmer /cnaj/ ‘to cut’ (gems), ‘to polish’. And / or related to Lushai cʰaiR (Lorr. chhai) ‘caress, fondle’ (Baxter acc. to Matisoff 1995a: 42).
‘To pinch with the fingers, a pinch full’ [Li].  ||  [E] ST: PLB *tswat ᛝ caus. *Ɂtswat ‘to pluck’ (as a fowl, stringed instrument): WB cʰwat  [Matisoff TSR: 39].

‘Salt’ [Li]  ||  [E] ST: PTB *tsa (STC no. 214) > WT tsʰwa (i.e. tsʰa) ‘salt’, Kanauri tsa; PL *(t)sa², WB cʰaᴮ (HST: 128). The OC rime does not agree with TB, perh. when the Lǐjì’s late Zhou / Han passage was written, the word had already lost its final OC *-i.

‘Hay’ 剉 [Wú-Yuè chūnqiū], ‘cut hay’ tr. 莝 [SW, Shiji]; factitive: ‘to feed hay to’ (horses) 摧 [Shijing].  ||  [E] AA: PMon *ksɔɔy ‘useless fibre, hay’, Mon *chu±e ‘grass, weed, hay’, PWa *sɔh ‘cut grass’ (for the initials, see §5.9.1). → chú4 芻 ‘hay’ belongs to the same AA etymon.
‘Whetstone, grindstone’ 錯 [Shi], 厝 [SW] is a k-extension (§6.1) of → cuō1 磋 ‘rub, polish’.

‘Crossing, mixed, ornate’ [Shi], ‘alternating’ [Li].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'aw (入), LR ts'awɁ; MGZY tshaw (入) [ts'aw]; ONW tsʰɑk  ||  [E] ? ST: Chepang caɁ- ‘be mixed’ (colors, kinds).  ||  [C] An allofam is → jiè7 借 ‘to borrow, lend’. Since SW glosses → chā1 叉 as ‘crossing hands’, these wfs may be related.
‘To present and drink a cup in response to the pledge cup’ [Shi] (醋 [Yili]), ‘a matching libation’ [Shu], ‘to reward’ [Shi].
‘To reward, sacrificial meat and wine’ [Zuo] > ‘to give prosperity’ > ‘confer a fief’ 胙 [Guoyu] > ‘blessings’ 祚 [Shi].

‘Mistake’ [Baopuzi].  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. Perh. the s. w. as → cuò3 錯, hence lit. ‘a mix-up’. Alternatively, note perh. AA: Khmer khcoḥ /kcaoh/ ‘have a flaw, be defective, be wrong, mistaken, in error...’ ᛝ OKhmer /cak/ ‘pierce, stab...’ ᛝ OKhmer /coh/  ‘perforate, pierce, prick’.
‘To attach, fix’ [JY].  — [E] ST: WB tap ‘put in, fix’ (HST: 38).
‘To hit, strike’ [GY].  — [E] ST: WT tʰab-pa ‘to fight, quarrel’ (HST: 94).

‘To break through, come out, sprout, prosper, reach to, be born’ [OB, BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR da (入); ONW dɑt  ||  [E] ST: PLB *dat ‘alive, to be’ [Matisoff 1972: 30] (HST: 48); Lushai dɔɔtF / dɔɁᴸ ‘to pierce, stick in, sprout up’. Perh. also connected to MK-Mon das ‘be, become’.

‘To respond’ [Shi, Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ta (入); ONW tɑp  ||  [E] ST: Prob. WT ’tʰub-pa ‘get the better of, be able to stand or bear, be a match for’ (so Bodman 1980: 117) ᛝ gtub-pa ‘be able’ (HST: 80). Other suggestions: HST: 37 relates this word to WT ’debs-pa, btab ‘cast, throw, respond’; Matisoff (1995: 44) to → dí3 敵 ‘opponent, enemy’; Unger (Hao-ku 21, 1983: 183) with reservations to WT tʰab(s)  in kʰyim-tʰab(s) ‘husband, wife’ (however, the QY back vowel in duì does normally not correspond to WT a). CH -> Tai: S. tɔp⁴ ‘to reply, answer’.
‘To reply (to a person), answer’.  ||  [<] exoactive of dá 答 (tập) (§4.3).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tuj (去); MGZY due (去) [tuɛ]; ONW tuɑi
‘Small bean, pulse’ [SW, Zhouli].  ||  [E]  PMY *dəp ‘bean’ (Bodman acc. to STC: 195; Sagart 1999: 187).

Xnote: Sin Sukchu SR tiŋ (上) LR ta
Notes: ‘To beat, hit’ [Weishu, Liangshu; GY] is a post-classical word. It seems to occur also in PMon: dah ‘hit’ (CH loan?).

[T] Sin S. SR daj (去), PR, LR da; MGZY tay (去) [daj]; Sui-Tang dɑ(i)ᶜ, ONW dɑC/ᶜ  ||  [D] PMin *dɑiᶜ; Y-Guǎngzhōu taiᶜ², Táishān aiᶜ; K-Méixiàn tʰaᶜ    ||  ‘Be big, great’ [OB, Shi]. The diphthong reading dài is traditionally viewed as the correct one, or as the literary one. However, already in Han times we find the reading dɑᶜ, Sui-Tang has both dɑᶜ and dɑiᶜ which agrees with the modern pronunciations dà and dài (Coblin TP 1994: 156ff).  ||  [E] There are no unambiguous outside cognates. Perh. ST: PTB *tay ‘big’ (Matisoff 1995a: 53) > WT mtʰe-bo ‘thumb’, Nung tʰɛ ‘big, large, great’, Mikir tʰè, ketʰè ‘id.’; WB tay ‘very’; Abor-Miri ta ‘large’. The TB forms do not have a final *-s, though, but a final *-y which “indicates emergent quality in stative vbs.,” acc. to Matisoff. The TB word has also been associated with → duō 多 (Baxter acc. to Matisoff 1995a: 44), but a different etymology for the latter seems preferable. Possibly, what has resulted in CH dà and duō has elsewhere converged (HST: 42).
‘Be too great, very great, excessive’, in titles ‘grand-’ [Shi]. It is not clear if tài ‘name of the west wind’ [OB, Shi] is related.

‘Substitute, take the place of, supercede’ [Shu] > ‘generation’ [Shi], ‘dynasty’ [Lunyu]. The fundamental notion of this wf is perh. ‘switch things around’, → tè1 貣 may also belong to this wf.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR daj (去); MGZY tay (去) [daj]; ONW dɑi  ||  See → dài9 戴  for an AA parallel.
‘Change, alter, deceive, err’ [BI, Shi].
‘Deceive’ [Li].
‘Wave’ [Chuci], a late OC word, apparently from a southern dialect. The older syn. is → bō1 波.   ||  [E] ST: WT rlabs ‘wave’ (Bodman 1980: 52).
‘Arrive, come to that, at the time that, when’ [Shi].   ||  [E] ST: PTB *la: PLB *la, WB la ‘come, reach in degree’. The ST level had apparently already doublets *lə ~ *rə (→ lái1 來) ‘arrive’.

‘Belt, sash’ [Shi], ‘string’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR taj (去); MGZY day (去) [taj]; ONW tɑC  ||  [E] ST with the basic meaning ‘circumference, circumscription’: PTB *m/s-taːy (HPTB: 210), PLB *n-day³: Lahu de ‘expanse of terrain’, WT sde ‘part, portion (of a country); province, district, territory’, Lushai taiR ‘waist’ (Matisoff 1995a: 43). Perh. also AA-OMon taḍay ‘middle’.

‘To come to, reach to’ [Shi].   ||  [E] Baxter (1992) reconstructs OCB *(g-)ləps and relates dài to → tà2 遝沓. Sagart (1999: 127) relates it to lì 蒞 ‘arrive’ (under → lái1 來). Alternatively, this could be an AA substrate word: Lave le´c, Sre lot, Stieng luh ‘to come’; AA -> TB-Lepcha lat ‘to come, reach’ (Forrest JAOS 82, 1962: 333-4). Or AA: Riang laic, Palaung hlaeːx, Bahnar klech ‘to reach’.

‘To bear, support’ [Zuo], ‘carry on the head’ [Meng].  ||  [E] AA: (OKhmer *-dai ~ *-dāya /-dəj ~ -daaj/ ‘to bear, support’ >) OKhmer dnāy /dnaaj/ ‘retainer, king’s servant’. AA -> Tai thanaaj ‘attorney, representative’; Khmer /pdaaj/ ‘to support / base onself on, rely on’ ᛝ Khmer tāṅa /taaŋ/ ‘to take the place of, replace, substitute, represent’. The semantic development of the Khmer etymon is parallel to the CH word → dài1 代 *ləkh with OC initial *l (if our interpretation of OC is correct), rather than *t- which is suggested by Khmer.  ||  The word belongs to an AA wf which includes → méi6 媒禖 ‘marriage go-between’ and → pēi1 胚 ‘pregnant’.

‘Be red, vermilion, cinnabar’ [Shi] has in antiquity been a mineral from the ancient southern states Bā (Yúnnán) and Yuè (Zhèjiāng) [SW].  ||  [E] KT: PKS *h-lanᶜ ‘red’ (Edmondson/Yang). The OC initial and *t- ~ *k- doublets indicate that OC has borrowed this item. Perh. → tǎn1 袒襢 ‘bare’ is related, as skin color tends to be associated with ‘red’, but see there. Alternatively, HPTB: 177 suggests ST *tja-n (*tya-n) ‘red’.
‘丹 砂 vermilion ore’ [Xun], ‘ore’ [JY] may be a variant of dān, both could theoretically derive from an original foreign *klan, see below.
‘A red flag’ [Shi, Shiming] (Wáng Lì 1982: 563).

‘Single, unit’ [Shi], ‘single, simple’ [Li]; ‘unlined garment’ 襌 [Li].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tan (平); MGZY dan (平) [tan]; ONW tɑn  — [D] CDC tan¹  ||  [E] ST *twar ? : PTB *t(w)ar > WT tʰor-bu ‘single, separate’ (Matisoff 1995a: 80); or ST *day ~ *tay ‘single’ (Matisoff 1997a: 21). Pulleyblank (in Rosemont 1991: 31) connects dàn with → tǎn1 袒襢 ‘bare’.
‘Only’ [Chǔci].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dan (上); MGZY tan (上去) [dan]
‘Disease, suffering, distress’ 癉 [Shi], 亶 (dǎn) [Li].
‘Exhaust’ [Zhuang].
‘Painful’ 旦 [Shi].
‘Exhausted, fagged out’ [Shi].
‘Exhausted, sick’ (horses) [SW: Shi], ‘toiled, exhausted’ 憚 (QY tâᶜ only) [Shi].  ||  [E] ST *-dar: WT ldar-ba ‘weary, tired, faint’ (HST: 159); Chepang dyarh- ‘discomfit, sudden pain...’

‘Abandon oneself (in pleasure)’ 耽 [Shi]; ‘to be sunk in, steeped in (pleasure), rejoice’ 湛 [Shi].  ||  [E] Area word: AA: PVM *tămᴮ ‘to drown, sink’ [Thompson]; Wa-Lawa-Bulang *ntɣm ‘soak rice’. AA -> Tai: S. dam < *Ɂd- ‘to dive’ ᛝ damᴮ ‘to sink down deeply, to a great depth’ (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 58), tuam³ ‘be submerged, overwhelmed’. Dān is usually thought to be cognate to → chén2 沈 (Wáng Lì 1982: 607).  ||  OCM  *tə̂m can also derive from a hypothetical *tləm in which case there may be a TB connection instead, but the meanings do not agree closely: Lushai liamR < liamɁ ‘to overflow, disappear’, WB hlyamᴮ ‘be brimming full’ ᛝ hlyam ‘run over, overflow’; WT ltam-pa, gtam-pa ‘full’ ᛝ ltem-pa ‘full, overflowing’. <> PTai *tl-: S. temᴬ¹ ‘full’.

‘To carry on the shoulder’ [Guoce].   ||  [D] PMin *±tɑm ‘to carry’; acc. to Norman (1986: 382) the Northern Min ‘softened initial’ *±t- points to OC prenasalization which is supported by Yao daam¹ < *nd-, PMY *ntam¹ ‘to carry’.  ||  [E] Area word: TB-WB tʰamᴮ ‘to carry on the shoulder’ (Bodman 1980: 112), JP tʰam⁵⁵ ‘carry’, Dulong ɑtɑm. <> PMY *ntam¹ ‘to carry’, Yao daam¹ < *nd-. <> Perhaps the MK items are also related: MK: Khmer dāṃ /toəm/ ‘to bear’ ᛝ drāṃ /troəm/ ‘to support patiently’ [Jenner / Pou 1982: xlix]. Khmer drāṃ -> Kam-Tai: PT *tʰr-: S. haamᴬ¹ ‘two or more people carry’ (Li F. 1976: 45), Saek raam² (< hr-?) ‘two or more carry’.  ||  A variant with initial *kl-: MK *klam, *kləm ‘to carry on shoulder’ (Shorto 2006 #1406): Khmu klam ‘carry on the shoulder’, PWa *klɐm (for the initials, see §8.2.1).
‘Burden’ [Zuo].   ||  [<] *tam + pass. s/h-suffix (§4.4), lit. ‘what is carried’.
‘To beat, pierce’ [Lie] is perh. related to Tai: PTai *t-: S. tamᴬ¹ ‘to pound’, esp. in a mortar (Li, HCT: 98).

‘Gall’ [Xun].  ||  [E] MK *t1ləəm, *t1luəm ‘liver’ (Shorto 2006 #1411): Khmer thlaəm, PNBahn. *klàm ‘liver’, PVM *lɔːm (for the initial correspondence, see §8.2.1). As in the case of → dān6 擔, there is an alternative form with initial *t-: Palaunic *kt1uəm ‘liver’ (Shorto 2006 #B89).
‘Sincerity, truth’ [ Shi].
‘Be done in a sincere manner, sincere’ [Shi].
‘The time of sunrise, dawn, morning, bright’ [OB, BO, Shi]. This word is not related to ‘red’ → dān1 丹 as the TB cognate shows.  ||  [E] ST: Chepang darɁ-do  (place) ‘of sunrise, in east’.

‘Eat, swallow’ 啗 [Guoyu]; ‘devour’ [Xun]; ‘keep in the mouth’ 嘾 [QY: Zhuang].   ||  [E] <> Tai: S. diimᴮ¹ < *Ɂd- ‘to swallow’.   ||  [C] Perh. this is related to hàn 頷 (under → hán1 含函) (so Bodman 1980: 110), and perh. to → xián11 銜.
‘Insipid’ [Li]. Geilich connects dàn with items under → tián4 恬 ‘calm’.   ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu tʰaːmᴮ. It is not clear how PMin *±tsiamᴮ ‘insipid’ may be related.

‘To fear, dislike’ [Shi].  ||  [<] exopass. of tán 彈 (dân), lit. ‘be shaken’.  ||  [E] ST: WT ’dar-ba ‘tremble, shudder, shiver with fear or cold’ ᛝ sdar-ma ‘trembling’ (HST: 152) ᛝ dar-bu ‘throbbing’. Also PMK *gtar ‘shiver, tremble’ (Shorto 1976: 1047).
‘Shake’ [Zhouli].
‘To tremble (with cold)’ 顫 [GY], ‘be trembling, afraid’ 戰 [Shi]; this is the s. w. as → zhàn2 戰 ‘war’.
‘Have the value of, be equal of, rank, to face, vis-à-vis’ [Zuo], ‘match, capable’ [Meng].  ||  [E] ? ST: Perh. related to WT daŋ ‘(together) with, and’.
‘Right, ought’ [Meng], ‘suitable’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR taŋ (平); MGZY dang (平) [taŋ]  ||  [<] exopass. of dāng 當 *taŋ (§4.4), lit. ‘what is being matched’.
‘Class, category’ [Lunyu] > ‘party’ [Zuo] > ‘partisan, partial’ [Shu].  ||  [<] endoactive of dāng 當 *tâŋ (§4.5.1), lit. ‘that which is equal in rank’.

‘To know’ [FY 1.1] is a Han period Chǔ dialect word. Two possible etymologies: (1) This may be compared to PTB *m-taŋ > WB tʰaŋ ‘visible’ ᛝ ə-tʰaŋ ‘thought’, WT mtʰoŋ-ba ‘to see, perceive, know, understand’, Kanauri taŋ ‘to see’. (2) A southern dialect form of dǒng 懂 ‘understand’ with the typical shift to a (J. Norman).
‘To drop, submerge’ means ‘to fall’ (of rain) in Mǐn and adjacent Wú dialects: Fúzhōu tɐuŋᶜ² in touŋ⁵³-ŋy³¹ ‘to rain’ 挏雨, Shùnchāng tʰ˜oᴮ² (Lǐ Róng FY 1992.2: 112-114).

‘Knife’ [OB, Shi].  ||  [E] ? Area word or CH loan: TB-Karen *Ɂdo ‘knife’, JP n³¹-do³¹ ‘short knife’, Viet. daw ‘sword’, Stieng taaw, etc., a common word for ‘sword’ in MK languages [Huffman 1975: 14].

‘To turn over, invert’ [Shi], ‘contrary’ [Hanfei], ‘to pour’ (from a pot) occurs also in TB-JP du⁵⁵ ‘to pour’ (from a pot), MK *tuh ‘to pour out’ (Shorto 2006 #2003): PVM *toh ‘to pour’. ? Tai: S. tokᴰ¹S ‘to fall down’ (Li F. 1976: 41); for the final consonant, see §3.2.2.
‘Ocean island’ [Shu] is reminiscent of Mon tkoɁ ‘island’, but prob. unrelated (we should expect a CH aspirated initial tʰ-, see §5.9.4).

‘To pound’ (as rice) [Li], still used in southern dialects, e.g. Yuè-Táishān au⁵⁵-mbai⁵⁵ 搗米; ‘to beat’ [Hanshu].   ||  [E] ST *tu: JP tʰu⁵⁵ ‘push’, WB tuiᴮ ‘push, butt, shove against’ ᛝ tʰuiᴮ ‘thrust, stab, strike’. A TB parallel stem is Lushai čʰuᴴ / čʰutᴸ ‘to strike’ (with rod), ‘pound, stamp, knock, tap’. For ST cognate and / or parallel stems, see the table under → chù1 觸 for an overview.

‘To arrive’ [Shi].   ||  [E] Perh. ST, yet the TB rime is different from OC: WT gtug-pa ‘to reach to, touch’ (e.g. putting the forehead against the breast of an image) ᛝ tʰug-pa ‘to reach, arrive at, come to, meet, touch’;  WB tuiŋ ‘to arrive, reach, attain’, JP du³¹ ‘arrive’. Hpwever, these TB items could just as well belong to → zhǔ8 屬.

‘Road, way, method’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR daw (上去); MGZY taw (上) [daw]; ONW dɑu   ||  [<] either an endoactive noun ‘the thing which is doing the conducting’ (§4.5.1) derived from the following word (dào  道導), or the latter is a LOC general tone C derivation from ‘way’ (§3.5).  ||  [E] Pulleyblank (1973: 120) believes that dào ‘talk’ is cognate to → tán2 談. Gong Hwang-cherng (1995: 61) presents parallels which suggest a pattern of OC *əm > *u. 道 is shared with Yao klăuᴮ ‘road’ (Haudricourt 1950: 559; but Downer 1982 *kau²).

‘To go along, bring along, conduct’ 道 [Zuo], 導 [Meng] > ‘explain’ [Li] > ‘talk about’ 道 [Lao, Meng]. The Han period dialect of Eastern Qi has the words yù 裕 [joᶜ] *lokh and yóu 猷 [ju] *lu or *ju (?) ‘road’ [FY 3.23] which may be related.

‘Unhusked rice’ [Shi].   ||  [D] PMin *tiuᴮ² 犁 (corresponds to QYS ḍjəuᶜ [JY], LH ḍuh) may possibly be a variant (Norman, p.c.).  ||  [E] Etymology is not certain. The word could belong to the wf → yóu4 油 ‘overflow’ (i.e. the notion of a flooded rice field). More likely, it is an area word (rice culture originated in the south): PMY *nblauᴬ (Bodman 1980: 112). The relationship with similar-looking MK words is ambiguous, we find PVM *Ɂa-lɔːɁ ‘unhusked rice’, Viet. lúa ‘paddy’ [Ferlus], but Khmuic *lɔɁ ‘glutinous rice’ (Ferlus 31st  ICSTLL, 1998: 90) whose meaning seems to connect the MK etymon with → nuò4 糯.

‘To get’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR təj (入), LR təjɁ; MGZ  dhiy (入) [təj]; ONW tək  ||  [D] Dé is Mand. col., Gānsù dei (Demiéville 1950: 52); dé is sometimes thought to be an allofam of → dé2 德 ‘virtue’.  ||  [E] Based on his theories on OC phonology, Pulleyblank (EC 16, 1991: 50) believes that dé and → d´e2 德 are cognate to WT tʰub-pa ‘be able, cope with’, but see → dá2 答.

‘Moral force, prestige, character’ (A. Waley) [BI, Shi], ‘quality, nature’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] Based on his theories on OC phonology, Pulleyblank (EC 16, 1991: 50) believes that dé and → dé1 得 are cognate to WT tʰub  ‘a mighty one, having power’, but see → néng2 能 .   ||  [C] An allofam is perh. → zhí2 直 ‘straight’.

‘genitive particle’ in Mand., appears for the first time in a Song document (Coblin p.c.) and later in an inscription of 1238 (Mei Tsu-Lin BIHP 59.1, 1988). It is thought to be a col. archaism of the classical ‘genitive particle’ → zhī1 之.

‘To rise, ascend, mount, raise’ [Shi, Shu], ‘to ripen’ [Meng]; ‘ritual vessel with high foot’ [Yili], ‘high foot’ 鐙 [Li] is perh. the s. w. as → dēng2 燈 ‘lamp’. Wáng Lì (1982: 253) and Matisoff (BSOAS 63.3, 2000: 363) add → zhì15 陟 to this wf.
‘A rising slope’ [Mu Tianzi].

‘Step of stairs’ [Lunyu] > ‘degree’, [Yi], ‘rank’ [Zuo], ‘classify’ [Zhouli].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR təjŋ (上), PR, LR təŋ; MGZY dhing (上) [təŋ]; ONW təŋ  ||  [<] endoactive of dēng (§4.5.1).   ||  [C] Additional allofams are perh. → zēng 曾增憎橧, → chéng2 丞承, also → téng2 騰.

‘Lamp’ 鐙 [Chǔci].  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. Perh. the same word as dēng 鐙 ‘vessel with high legs’, under → dēng1 登 ‘rise’. The relationship with ‘candle’ in MK languages, if any, is not clear (CH loan? MK loan ?): Viet d`ɛn (North), d`ɛŋ (South), Khmer tiən, Mon nañ  (Huffman 1975). Khmer ? -> Tai: Saek thianᴬ² < d- ‘candle’.
‘To wait’, a medieval northern dialect word, prob. related to the following (so Wáng Lì 1982: 90):
‘To wait, treat, behave’ [Lunyu]. For the final, see §3.2.4. Karlgren (1956: 17) adds this word to shì 侍 ‘wait upon’ (under → shì15 恃).
‘To lower’ [Zhuang].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tjej (平), PR ti; MGZY di (平) [ti]; ONW tėi  ||  [E] ST: WT mtʰil, OTib. tʰild < m-tild ‘bottom, floor, lower part’ (HST: 47), Tamang ³tiː ‘below’.
‘Base, foundation, root’ 氐 [Shi]; ‘bottom’ 底 [Lie]; ‘root, base’ 柢 (also tiei[ᶜ]) [Laozi].   ||  [<] endoactive of dī 低 (tiei) (§4.5.1).

‘To drip, drop’ [Wenxuan, GY].  ||  [E] ST: This onomatopoetic root is shared with WT: gtig(s)-pa ~ ’tʰig-pa, tʰigs ‘to drop, drip’ ᛝ ’tʰig-pa, btigs ‘cause to fall in drops’ ᛝ tʰigs-pa ‘a drop’ (STC: 180), JP theɁ³¹ < tʰek³¹ ‘dropping, dripping’.

‘Low servant’ [Shu], could either be derived from the name of a northern tribe; or, more likely, be MK *Ïiik, *Ïik, *Ïiək ‘slave, temple slave’ (Shorto 2006 #329), PNBahn. *qd≠ìč ‘slave’, PSBahn. *dəc ‘slave, servant’.

‘Translators, interpreters’ [Lüshi], later simply dī 鞮 ‘to translate’ [Chenshu]. This may possibly contain a foreign loanword, note Turkic t¨ıl > til ‘tongue, language’ (Behr 2000). However, Behr prefers to consider dí OC *lek an allofam of shì 釋 ‘to translate’ (under → yì35 繹).

‘Enemy, opponent, enmity’ [BI, Shu].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *m-taːy (*tayɁ): JP tai³¹ ‘avenge, retaliate’, mə³¹-tai³¹ ‘vengeance’, Lushai taiR < taiɁ ‘be at enmity with one another, have a grudge against’. For *-k, see §6.1.

‘To buy grain’ [Zuo].     ||  [D] M-Xiàmén tiaɁᴰ², Y-Guǎngzhōu tɛk (Lin et al. YYWZX 1996.2: 113ff)  ||  [E] This etymon is reminiscent of AA-Pearic taok ~ tɔːk ‘to sell’, or of → yù23 賣 ‘sell’. Syn. → gǔ11 賈; → mǎi 買; → shòu2 售.
‘To sell grain’ [Mo; SW 2680].   ||  [D] M-Xiàmén tʰioᶜ¹, Y-Guǎngzhōu tʰiuᶜ, K-Méixiàn tʰiauᶜ  ||  [<] caus. aspiration (§5.8.2) + exoactive (§4.3) of dí 糴 (diek).

‘To clean, clean out, denuded’ [Shi], ‘wash’ [Li], ‘to clarify’ (spirits) [Zhouli] (Wáng Lì 1982: 302). The etymology is not clear. It could be either a derivation from → yóu10 射油 *liu ‘flow’, or be related to → zhuó11 濯 *d-lauk ‘be clean’ (but the OC rimes do not agree).
Sui-Tang Chang’an tiiᴮ writes the col. genitive particle (→ zhī1 之 of classical texts); starting in Song and Yuan documents it is written → de3 的.

‘Earth, ground’ [Shi]. The QYS reading is unique and puzzling.   ||  [T] Sin S. SR djej (去), PR, LR di; MGZY ti (去) [di]; ONW dii  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. Since the OC initial was L-like, it may be compared with PTB *mliy ‘earth’ (STC no. 152) > WB mre ‘earth, ground’, Mikir mili ‘bare ground’, Nung məli ‘ground, mountain’. However, this TB etymon rather seems to belong to → shì13 室 ‘house’. On the other hand, there are AA words which resemble Chinese: Munda ɔte ‘field, land’, Khmer Êi ‘earth, soil’, Mon Êi ‘land, earth’, PSBahn. *(nə)təh ‘earth’. Neither of these possibilities agrees phonologically with OC; perhaps these two etyma have converged.

‘Younger brother’ 弟 [Shi]; ‘younger secondary wife’ 娣 [Shi] (also LH deiᶜ).  ||  [T] Sin S. SR djej (上), PR, LR  di; MGZY ti (上) [di]; ONW dėi  ||  [D] PMin *dieᴮ  ||  [<] endoactive of dì 第 ‘order, sequel’, lit. ‘the person who is following in sequence’ (§3.3.1).   ||  [E] ST *dwi: PTB *doy ‘younger brother’ (STC no. 309; HST: 49) > WB tʰweᴮ ‘be youngest’, JP šədói ‘last born child’; also found in Mon deɁ ‘younger sibling’ (<- TB?).
‘Respectful towards elder brothers, fraternal’ 弟悌 (Mand. tì) [Meng].  ||  [<] either exoactive (§4.3) or late OC general tone (§3.5) of dì 弟 (dieiᴮ).
‘Order, sequel’ [Zuo]. Karlgren (1956: 14) connects this word with → tī1 梯 ‘ladder’.
‘To look at from the side / askance, glance at’ [Li]  ||  [E] ST: Chepang dʰəy- ‘concentrate, look at’ (esp. when aiming), ‘be watchful, alert’ ᛝ dʰes- ‘see clearly, sight clearly’ (when aiming).

‘God, ancestor, honorific for deceased fathers’ [OB, Shi] (Eno EC 15, 1990: 1-26).    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ti (去), PR, LR ti; MGZY di (去) [ti]; ONW tėi   ||  [E] ST: WT tʰe ‘celestial gods’ of the Bon religion (HST: 164), JP mə³¹-tai³³ ‘god of the sky’.
‘A kind of great sacrifice’ [OB, Zuo].
‘Stem of a fruit’ [Li].
‘(Gourd) stem’ [Shi] (Sagart 1999: 91).
‘To kick’ [Zhuang] is prob. cognate to → tí4  蹄 ‘hoof’ (so HST: 100).  ||  [E] ST: WT rdeg, PLB *tekᴴ ‘kick’ (HST: 100), Garo ga-tek, Tangkhul Naga kəkətʰək.

‘Top of head’ 顛 [Shi]; ‘top (of a mountain), forehead’ 巔 [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT steŋ ‘above’ (Shafer, IST: 65; Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 48), JP puŋ³³-diŋ³³ ‘zenith, top, top of the head’ (ᛝ d¯ǐng: STC: 180); Zemi (Naga) tiŋ ‘sky’, Lushai paᴸ-tʰianᴴ ‘god’ (lit. ‘father above’) ᛝ tiaŋᴴ / tianᴸ to pile up, pile on top of another’ [French 1983: 157; 374]. Prob. → tiān1 天 ‘sky, heaven’ belongs to this wf. In light of the simple T-initial in TB and prob. also OC, this wf is not related to → diān2 顛傎 (the same graph can be used for a stem *tin as well as *tlin).
‘Top of the head’ [Yi].  ||  [<] endoactive of diān 顛巔 (tien) (§4.5). The rime *-eŋ may be due to paronomastic attraction to AA → dìng2 定顁 ‘forehead’.
‘To brand’ (the forehead) [Yi].   ||  [<] caus. aspiration of diān 顛巔 (tien) (§5.8.2).

‘To topple, fall down, be overthrown’ 顛 [Shi], 傎 [Guliang].  ||  [E] Area word: TB-WB lañᴮ ~ laiᴮ < lin/ŋ ‘fall’; Miao gliŋ ‘to fall’. This etymon is prob. not related to the wf → diān1 顛巔 ‘top of the head’ whose initial is a simple dental stop in ST. For inital CH t- = foreign gl-, see §8.2.1.

‘Eyetooth’ [Yili].  ||  [E] ST *t(j)w(a)i ‘eyetooth’: PLB *džway (HPTB: 31) > WB cwai, WT mčʰe-ba (Tib. *tswe > tse > tsye > čʰe); diān has the nominal n-suffix (§6.4.3); for loss of ST medial *w, see §10.2.1.
‘To vouch for, guarantee’ [Jīnshǐ ] is perh. cognate to WT sten-pa ‘to keep, adhere to, depend on’ (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 50). This may be the s. w. as → diǎn2 典.
‘To direct, rule, norm, constant’ [Shi, Shu], ‘document’ [OB] has been compared to WT brtan-pa ‘firm, steadfast’ ᛝ gtan ‘constant, enduring’ (HST: 79). This may be the s. w. as → diǎn1 典.
‘Buttock’ [GY], a variant of → tún6 臀.  ||  [E] ST: JP šətīn ‘buttocks’ (Matisoff LTBA 17.2, 1994: 138).
‘The rear’ (of an army) [Zuo] > ‘to protect’ [Shi].
‘Lightning’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST or area word: PYao *(Ɂ)liŋ ‘lightning’ (Benedict 1976: 97); TB-Chepang pliŋh-Ɂo ‘lightning’ ᛝ pliŋh-sa ‘flicker’ (of fire).
‘To wither, fade, fall’ [Guoce]
‘Dried up, wizened’ [SW: Shijing] is prob. related to Tai: S. tokᴰ¹ ‘to become faded (color)’. For the MC medial -i-, see §9.1.3.

‘To engrave, carve > injure’ 雕 [BI, Shu], 彫 [Zhuang, Zuo].  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. CVST (2: 130) relates this word to WB tʰuiᴮ ‘engrave, write, stab’.  ||  CH ? -> Tai: S. tieuᶜ (McFarland 1944: 367: dtiew³), Saek diiw³ ‘whittled sticks’ (for shaking to tell fortunes) (§9.1.3).
‘To angle, fish with hook and line’ [Shi] is related to Tai: S. tokᴰ¹ ‘to angle, fish with hook and line’. For the phonological differences, see §9.1.3; §3.4.

‘Ant-hill’ [Shi] > ‘mound’ [Meng] (GSR 413o).  ||  [E] ST: KN *m-hliŋ (but note Sabeu p±a-lait) ‘ant’ [IST: 27]. TB cognates to words in GSR 413 have pre-initial *m- (§8.1.5). This may possibly be the s. w. as → dié2 咥 ‘bite’, and / or also be connected with → chí3 蚳 ‘ant eggs’.

‘To bite’ [Yi] (a tiger a person) from which could be derived → zhì2 蛭 ‘water leech’. This could either be the s. w. as → dié1 垤 ‘ant-hill’; or be related to AA-Khmer dica /dic/ ‘sting, bite, prick’ (of insects, reptiles, plants). A syn.is → shì23 噬 .

‘To stumble’ [Xun].   ||  [T] ONW dėt  ||  [D] PMin *buɑt ‘stumble’ is possibly related in light of the TB cognates.   ||  [E] ST: PTB *ble ‘to slip’ (STC no. 141; HPTB: 203f), TGTM *pleːᴮ ‘slippery’; PKaren *pʰle³ ~ *Ɂble²  ‘id.’ (STC: 139 n. 375), JP gə³¹-pʰrai⁵⁵ ‘to slip’, Digaro ble ‘slippery’; Mikir -iŋlìt < m-lìt ‘be slippery’; WT ’byid-pa ‘to slip’ < mlit ?, Lepcha flut ~ flit ‘to slip from’ ᛝ plut ‘let slip’ [Bodman ICSTLL 1987: 21]. Lushai has a possible cognate (medial l does not occur after labial stops): pʰetᴸ / pʰeɁᴸ < pʰeɁ/h ‘to trip up, slip away’, also pialR < pialɁ ‘to slip’ may be connected. <> This etymon is also found in Tai: S. pʰlaatᴰ²ᴸ < *blat ‘to slip and fall’, Dioi śwat¹ [Maspero 1912: 86]. HST: 140 associates this word with WT ldig-pa ‘to fall and sink through’.   ||  [C] It is not clear if dié is connected with → yì13 泆溢. This word is apparently distinct from, and parallel to, the syn. → zhì16 疐 *tri(t)s; see the Table D-1 for an overview.  ||  Table  D-1  To slip, slippery, trip →

‘Paralyzed, unable to move’ [Zhuang].  A partial syn. is niè  踂.  ||  [E] ST: TB-PLB *Ɂtap ‘adhere, stick to’, Lushai depᴸ / deɁᴸ ‘to be close to, close against, adjacent, adjoin, touch’ ᛝ? deepR ‘copulate with’. The TB etyma overlap with tà2 眔遝沓.
‘To stick to, glue to’ [GY].

‘Tablet’ 牒 [Zuo]; in some Han period northern dialects ‘board’ [FY 5,36].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *lyap (STC no. 212) > WT ldeb ‘leaf, sheet’, JP gə³¹-lep³¹ ‘flat’, Lushai depF ‘flat’ (not filled out like a pod).  ||  CH -> Tai: S. *tʰɛɛpᴰ¹§ ‘classifier for long, flat, narrow objects’.  ||  [N] These two words (dié7 牒 and dié 褶疊) have distinctly different meanings and TB cognates, perh. two different words have converged phonologically in OC. Furthermore, this etymon is a syn. of → zhé7 摺, but the roots are different (*Clep ~ *Cliap vs. *tap); perh. some of the WT items (ldab, ltab) are a conflation of the two roots.   ||  [C] ‘Butterfly’ → hú6-dié 胡蝶 may belong to this wf, but see there. Allofams are perh. → yè4 葉, → xiè4 屧; → xí2 習.

‘Double, lined’ 褶 (garment) [Li] (GY reads this graph also MC zjəp and źjəp), ‘double, accumulate’ [Shuijingzhu].  ||  [E] ST: WT ldeb-pa ‘to bend round, double down’ ᛝ ltab-pa, bltabs < ɴ˘lap ‘to fold’, ldab-pa < ɴlap ‘to do again, repeat’; Mru klep ‘fold up’, Lushai tʰlepᴸ / tʰleɁᴸ ‘to fold (up), bend over’ [Löffler 1966: 122].
‘To beat, strike’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: Lushai deŋᴴ / den ‘to throw, strike, hit’.
‘To beat, strike’ [GY].
‘Dead drunk’ [Jin shu, GY].
‘Dead drunk’ [Shi].

A three or four-legged ‘tripod, cauldron’ [BI, Shi]. A large one is called → nài4 鼐.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tiŋ (上); MGZY ding (上) [tiŋ]; ONW tėŋ  ||  [D] The south has preserved the original meaning ‘cooking pot, pan’: Old South tâŋᴬ 鐺 [San-guo zhi] (Ho Dah-an, BIHP 1993: 869), but PMin *tiaŋᴮ with medial -i- is from a later stratum: Jiànyáng tiaŋᴮ, Fúzhōu tiaŋᴮ, Xiàmén tiãᴮ (Norman 1988: 231).  ||  [E] Most likely, this old area word is related to TB-Mru teŋ ‘sacrificial tripod’ (Löffler ZDMG 116.1, 1966: 141), AA-Wa-Lawa-Bulang *dɐŋ, *(n-)dɑŋ ‘cooking pot’ (or are these CH loans?) Alternatively, Benedict (STC: 178 n. 472; 1976: 98) connects this word with PT and PKS *gliaŋᴬ ‘tripod’, perh. related to AA-Wa-Lawa-Bulang *klɐŋ ‘basin’, PPalaung (AA) geŋ ‘tripod’; note also PTai *giŋᴬ ‘tripod’. But these last forms present phonological difficulties.

‘Forehead’ 定 [Shi 11, 2], 顁 [Erya 2, 146]. Dìng1 定 is an OC T-series (§12.1.2); however, this type of initial with QYS div. I/IV can also correspond to an earlier *tl- from a foreign cluster with medial -l- (OCM *tleŋh, see §8.2.1).  ||  [E] Most likely MK *t1n1iəŋ ‘forehead’ (Shorto 2006 #599): Mon tneŋ ‘forehead’, Wa-Lawa-Bulang *k/sṇtɑŋ ‘forehead’. Alternatively, a connection with → diān1 顛巔 ‘top of the head’ could also be possible. The source of Kadai *C-dəŋᴬ ‘forehead’ is not clear (CH?).  ||  Syn. → tí1 提堤題, é 額 and yán 顏 (both under → yà2 御迓訝), → sǎng0 顙, → yáng8 揚鍚.

‘Small boundary banks between fields’ [Zuo] is perh. a variant or cognate of → zhěn3 畛 (so Lau 1999: 342). Furthermore (or alternatively), dìng could originally have referred to a trampled path, hence cognate to tǐng-tuǎn 町畽 (tʰieŋᴮ-tʰuânᴮ) *thêŋɁ-thônɁ ‘be trampled down (fields)’ [Shi] (so Karlgren GSR 833g). Finally, there may be a connection with → tí1 提堤題 ‘raise’.
‘Winter’ [Shi], in some Mǐn dialects ‘harvest’, what is harvested in the 10th month (winter). Wáng Lì (1982: 608) related this word to → zhōng4 終 ‘terminate’.

‘East’ [OB, Shi]. The OB graph shows some object (but not the sun) in a tree.    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tuŋ (平); MGZY dung (平) [tuŋ]; ONW toŋ  ||  [E] ? ST: Chepang tʰoŋ- ‘lighten, be bright, bright’ (esp. sky) ᛝ toŋh ‘awake time’ (as opposed to dream time). Perh. related to, or influenced by, → tūn2 暾 ‘rising sun’; see there for TB and AA connections. After back vowels OC finals *-ŋ  and *-n are occasionally confused, see §6.4.2.

‘Violent rain’ [Chǔci].  ||  [E] MY: The source of this word is apparently a form similar to Yao *bluŋﬂ ‘rain’; Wáng FS has PYao < PMY *mblÅəŋﬂ, but almost all individual Yao languages have a back vowel: blŭŋﬂ, bjŭŋﬂ, bŭŋﬂ, biŋﬂ (Huáng Shù-xiān YYYJ 1989.2: 113, see also Wáng F. 1995: 126). Perh. ultimately related to the AA etymon under → píng4 萍 ‘rain master’; note a back vowel form PEKatuic *pilo≠oŋ ‘sky’, perh. also Kharia tɔ-bluŋ ‘above’ [Pinnow 1959: 405]. MY back vowels tend to correspond to other languages’ front vowels and vice versa. The word is a loan in CH because it first appears in the late Zhanguo / early Han text Chǔcí (songs from the southern state of Chǔ), is identified as a Jiāng-dōng (Wu-Yue) dialect word in FY; it has a narrower specialized meaning in CH, it is rare in CH while it is the common word for ‘rain’ in MY; and finally it lacks a CH etymology. For *t- < *Cl-, see §8.2.1. For syn. and semantics, see → fēn2 雰氛.

‘To pierce’ (chest with an arrow) [Shiji, Hanshu], ‘a hole’ [GY].   ||  (1) ‘To pierce’ ᛝ → chōng4 巴.   ||  (2) ‘excavate, hole’.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *dwaːŋ ‘pit, hole’ (STC no. 169; p. 22) > PLB *dwaŋ², WB twaŋᴮ ‘hole, pit’ ᛝ tʰwaŋᴮ ‘make a hole into, scoop out’, Tiddim Chin waːŋ ‘hole, make a hole’, WT doŋ ‘deep hole, pit, ditch’.

‘To move, set in motion, shake’ [Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR duŋ (上); MGZY tung (上) [duŋ]; ONW doŋ  ||  [E] Wáng Lì (1982: 357) believes that dàng 蕩 (dâŋᴮ) Sin Sukchu SR daŋ (上); MGZY tang (上) [daŋ] ‘to move, shake’ [Shu, Zuo etc., Guangya] is related. Downer 1959: 288 reads ‘be moved emotionally’ [Lunyu] in tone C.

‘A round vessel’ [BI, Shi] on a stem for serving meat dishes (K.C. Chang 1976: 128) which originated in the prehistoric eastern Lóngshān culture.    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dəw (去); MGZY thiw (去) [dəw]   ||  [C] Perh. related to → tóu3 頭 ‘head’, and dòu3 荳 ‘soybean’.

‘Soybean’.  ||  [E] Etymology not certain, prob. area word: PTB *tu-ŋ ‘bean’ (LaPolla 1994: 171); MK *t1uh, t1əh ‘bean’ (Shorto ɐ2002). Unger (Hao-ku 24, 1984) raises the possibility that this is the same word as ‘a round vessel’ → dòu2 豆 and is derived from → tóu3 頭 (dəu) ‘head’. STC: 195 draws attention to similarity with PMY *dop and → dá3憂 (tập) ‘a kind of pulse’.

‘Neck’ [Zuo].  ||  [D] An old Qí dial. word (acc. to Hé Xiū ca. 180 AD); it is still used in Mǐn dialects: Fúzhōu tauᶜ²-kaukᴰ¹, Jiànyáng loᶜ² (Norman 1983: 207).  ||  [E] ST: PTB *tuk ᛝ *du(k) ‘neck, head’ (STC no. 392; Matisoff 1978: 64f): JP duɁ³¹ ‘neck’, Garo gitok, Mikir tśethok, Lepcha tŭk-tok ‘neck’. See also → dú8-lóu 髑髏.

‘Quarrel, rangle’ [SW], 劑 [Lunyu].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *daw (STC no. 267) > WB doᴮ ‘resent an insinuation, interfere in a quarrel’, Lushai doᴴ ‘be at enmity with’. The TB words could possibly belong to → chóu3 儔 instead; WT sdo-ba ‘to risk, venture, bid defiance’ could be cognate unless it belongs to → dǔ3 賭 (tuoᴮ). Perh. also related to zhuó 椓 ‘to beat, strike’ (under → zhǔ7 斸) (Sagart 1999: 113).

‘Poison’ n. [Shi].   ||  [D] Yuè tukᴰ², Kèjia tʰukᴰ², M-Fúzhōu tøikᴰ²  ||  [E] ST *duk: PTB *duk ~ *tuk (STC no. 472) > WT dug, gdug-pa ‘poison’; PLB *dok: WB ə-tok ‘poison’ ᛝ *Ɂdok ‘be poisoned’ ᛝ *ɴdok ‘poisoned, as an arrow’ (HST: 120), JP tuk⁵⁵ ‘poison’.
‘To poison’ vb., occurs only in Yuè, Kèjiā and Mǐn dialects (Norman 1988: 213):   ||  [D] Yuè touᶜ², Kèjiā tʰeuᶜ¹; M-Fúzhōu tʰauᶜ¹

‘Canal, ditch, drain’ 瀆 [Lunyu]; ‘abortion’ 殰 [Li]; ‘sully’ [Li], ‘insult’ 瀆  [Zuo]. CVST 3: 33 relates dú ‘abortion’ to WT rlug(s)-pa ‘to purge, abortion’. Perh. this is the s. w. as → dú4 櫝韇 ‘container’.
(Any hollowed object > container:) ‘box, case’ 名  [Lunyu]; ‘coffer’ [Lunyu], ‘coffin’ 櫝 [Zuo]; ‘quiver’ 韇 [Yili]. This belongs to the wf. → yú14 俞. It may be the s. w. as → dú3 瀆 ‘drain’.

‘Say / read aloud’ [Shi] > ‘read’ [Lunyu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR du (入); MGZY tu (入) [du]; ONW dok  ||  [E] Perh. related to WT klog-pa, (b)klags ‘to read’, but the vowels do not match (WT a vs. OC o); acc. to Sagart (1999: 209), the WT word is a loan because ‘read’ is a derived meaning in Chinese.

‘Calf’ [Li].  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. (1) It could be a ST word: Kanauri luk ‘calf’, WT lug ‘sheep’, lu-gu ‘lamb, calf’, TGTM *g-luk ‘sheep’. (2) Boodberg (1937: 359) suggests cognation with WT pʰrug ‘calf’ (not likely). (3) Alternatively, it could be a loan from Altaic acc. to Norman (1988: 18): Mongol tuƔul, Manchu tukšan, Evenki tukuč–ən ‘calf’, Lamut tu- ~ tuƔu- ‘to give birth to a calf’. (4) It could be related to → chù4, xù 畜. Dú may be connected with yú  羭.
‘Sheep’ [Lie] (HST: 131).

‘To be alone, alone’ [Shi]. Acc. to FY 79, 111, this was a Han period ‘southern Chǔ’ dialect word for ‘one’, note also M-Fúzhōu sioɁ° (corresponding to QYS źjwok < *dok) ‘one’ which may be related (Norman FY 1983.3: 208).

‘Skull’ [Zhuang, GY]. Li Fang Kuei (1976: 44) who relates this word to Tai: S. (kra-) duukᴰ¹ᴸ < *-Ɂdl/ruok (actually *Ɂluok ?), considers this a reduplication from a hypothetical OC *dlug. This bisyllabic word appears in more variants (tóu-lú  頭顱 and dú-lú  頓顱).  ||  [E] These variants are partially composed of syllables meaning ‘head’ (tóu) of ST stock (Loloish languages have cognates in compound words for ‘head’: Matisoff 1978: 64). Dú 髑 is a ST item which is prob. related to → dòu5 脰 ‘neck’: PTB *du(k) ‘neck, skull’ > Abor-Miri a-tuk, Atong dək-əm, Kaike tʰoppā (< tʰok-pa) ‘head’ (Matisoff ibid. p. 65). One may speculate that the second syllable is related to lóu 婁 [lo] with a hypothetical meaning ‘empty’ or ‘dried’, hence lit. ‘dried head’ as in Lushai. More likely, though, the second part is a reduplication syllable starting with *r/*l (§2.7). Similar-looking items include → lú4 顱; AA-Khmer rɔliə ‘shell, skull’ (from earlier rɔ-laː ?).
‘Skull’ [Guoce]. This form is reminiscent of Lushai luF-roᴴ ‘skull’ (lit. ‘dried head’) and luF-ruɁᴸ ‘skull’ (lit. ‘head-bone’), just as in CH the first syllable is ‘head’.

‘Skull’ [SW, GY], today in Shānxī ‘forehead’. This late form seems to be the s. w. as dú-lóu above, but committed to writing when OC *a had become more back like *ɑ or *o. An additional MC variant is ṭɐk- / ṭʰɐk- [GY] which seems close to KS words for ‘bone’: *tlaːk⁷ (Thurgood) or *k-laːkᴰ (Edmondson/Yang); yet these latter have entered Chinese as → gé5 骼 ‘bone’.

‘Firm, solid, thick’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tu (入); MGZY du (入) [tu]  ||  [E] ST: WT ’tʰug-pa ~ mtʰug-pa ‘thick’ ᛝ stug(s)-pa ‘thickness’ (STC no. 356; HST: 148), WB tʰuik-tʰuik  ‘thickly’. CH has allofams with final -n, see → dūn1 敦惇.

‘To see’ [Li], 聽 [Meng].  ||  [E] ST: LaPolla (1994: 164) compares dǔ to PTB *ta ‘to see’ > WT lta-ba ‘to look’, JP mə³¹-ta³¹ ‘to see’. Dǔ has also been compared to PTai *traaᴬ ‘eye’ (so Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 45).

‘To gamble, bet’ [GY]. Acc. to Norman (1986: 382) the Northern Min ‘softened initial’ *±t- points to OC prenasalization which is supported by Yao dou³ < nd-. This word is also found in other languages: Tai: S. tʰaaᶜ² < *d- ‘to challenge, dare’ (Li 1976: 40). Unger (Hao-ku 36, 1990: 50) proposes cognation with WT sdo-ba ‘to risk, hazard, venture’, but see → dòu6 鬥 (dəuᶜ).

‘A measure (of length), rule’ [Shi], ‘limits, bounds’[Zuo]; ‘an instrument to measure length’ [Shiji], ‘law, regulation’ [Xun].  ||  [<] exopass. of duó 度 (dâk), lit. ‘what is measured’ (§4.4, also §3.5).  ||  [E] ST *dwa / *twa: WB tʰwa ‘measure with a span’, also WB twak ‘cipher, reckon’ ᛝ ə-twak ‘account, reckoning’, Mru twak ‘consider’ < Arakanese? [Löffler 1966: 121]; WT mtʰo ‘a span’ [HPTB: 167]. It is not clear if AA-Mon ÎÅ ‘span’ (i.e. distance of outstretched hand as measure), Bahn. ʃɣda (Pinnow 1959: 318) is related. For the lack of a CH medial -w-, see §10.2.1.
‘To measure, calculate, consider, plan’ [Shi], ‘a measure of width’ [Meng].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR daw (入); MGZY taw (入) [daw]
‘To plan, consider’ (e.g. the weight of something) [Shi, Shu] > ‘a plan, a map’ [BI, Shu]; ‘calculate, expect’ [Lun]; ‘law, regulation’ [Chǔci].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR du (平); MGZY tu (平) [du]

‘To ford’ [Guoce].  ||  [E] ST: WT ’da-ba, das ‘to pass over’ (HST: 116).Dù occurs also in Tai *daaᴮ: S. tʰaaᴮ² ‘wharf, landing’, but ‘river’ in most other Tai lgs. (Li Fang Kuei 1976: 40). The semantic connection of ‘ford’ with ‘river’ has perh. a parallel, see → hé4 河. The virtual phonological identity of the Tai form with late OC (Chinese tone C = Tai tone B), as well as the restriction of this word to the Tai branch of the KT family suggest a Chinese loan. The AA syn. is → jì15 濟.

‘Stomach’ [late word].  ||  [E] Etymology not clear, either (1) ST: WT lto-ba ‘belly, stomach’; and / or Tai: S. tʰɔɔŋᶜ² < *d- ‘stomach’ (Li F. 1976: 40); PKS *loŋᴬ ‘belly’ (Edmondson / Yang), MC tone B corresponds in several other words to foreign -ŋ (§3.2.4). Or (2) ST: TB with final nominal -n: WT don, Bunan, Almora dan ‘belly’ [IST: 140].
‘Animal stomach used as food’.

‘Short’ [Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR twɔn (平); MGZY don (平) [tɔn]; ONW tuɑn  ||  [D] PMin *toiᴮ (Bodman 1980: 77)  ||  [E] Prob. related to → duàn1 斷 ‘to cut’. TB has several comparanda: (1) Lushai tɔiR < tɔiɁ ‘be short’, WB tui ‘short’. (2) NNaga *tʰuar ‘short’. (3) WB toŋᴮ ‘short’ (as garment). Perh. PMin has preserved an original ST etymon, while elsewhere the word has been reinterpreted as ‘cut off’.
‘To cut off, decide, resolute’ 斷 [Shi, Shu]; ‘slice of dried and spiced meat’ (tuânᶜ only) [Zuo]. Karlgren (1956: 9) relates the latter to duàn 段 (duânᶜ) ‘torn to pieces’ [Guan].
‘To cut off, decide, resolute.
‘To cut’ [Guoce].

‘Hammer, to hammer’ [Shi], ‘strike’ [Zhuang].   ||  [E] ST: PTB *tow (STC no. 317) > WT tʰo-ba ~ mtʰo-ba ‘hammer’ (large), JP tʰu³¹ ‘to pound, husk’, WB tu ‘hammer’. CH has added the nominal n-suffix (§6.4.3).

‘Mound’ [Chuci].  ||  [E] The first textual appearance in Chǔcí suggests a foreign word. MK has several roots with the meaning ‘hill, mound’: MK *dul ‘hill’ (Shorto 2006 #1741), and MK *bt1u[u]l, *bt1uəl ‘swelling, mound, hill’ (Shorto 2006 #1738); OKhmer dul ‘to bulge’, OKhmer /duuəl/ ‘knoll, hillock, mound’, PVM *dolᴬ ‘hill’, PSBahn. *tul ~ *nətul ‘anthill’. Also MK *[d][o]r ‘hill’ (Shorto 2006 #1626). <> A similar looking Tai and MY etymon is probably not related because of the post-initial liquid: PTai *Ɂdl/rɔiᴬ: S. dɔɔiᴬ¹ ‘mountain’, Saek rɔɔyᴬ¹, PMY *glaiᴰ ‘mountain’.  ||  The word → tún1 屯 ‘hill’ seems to represent a variant, foreign items cited here could equally well apply to that word.

‘Pestle’ [first attested for the Han period: Wú Yuè chūnqiū, Hànshū, SW, Fāngyán].  ||  [E] MY: PY *tui ‘pestle’; the initial was not *kl- or *gl- as has been suggested in the past (M. Ratliff, p.c.).
‘Pestle’ [SW].

‘Troops’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] Sagart (1999: 85) relates duì to yù 遹 ‘follow’ (under → suì2 遂), hence lit. ‘followers’. Because of the OC L-like initial, the word cannot be related to → tún2 屯窀 and the TB items there, nor to AA: Khmer dāba /toəp/ ‘armed forces, troops, army’.

‘Be solid, thick’ [Li] > ‘earnest, generous’ [Zuo] (in Shūjīng also zhūn 惇 LH tśun) > put. ‘consider thick, weighty’ [Shu].  ||  [E] ST: Chepang dunh- ‘be dense, closely spaced’; PTB *tow ‘thick’ (STC no. 319) > PL *tu¹, WB tuᶜ ‘thickness’ ᛝ thu ‘thick, dense’.    ||  [C] A cognate is → dǔ1 篤.
‘Thick’ (as darkness in a grave) 窀 [Zuo] (also zhūn / LH ṭun or ṭuin).
‘Generous’ [Lao]; ‘ample’ 淳 [Guoyu].
‘Sincere, diligent’ [Li].
‘Shield’ 盾 [Shi], 楯 [Zuo]. WB duiŋᴮ ‘shield’ may be a CH loan since the OC and PTB initials are difficult to reconcile; also the relationship to Chepang dhəl ‘shield’ is not clear.

‘Worn, dull, blunt’ [Zuo], ‘exhaust’ [Zuo], ‘to ruin’ [Guoyu].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tun (去); MGZY dun (去) [tun]; ONW ton  ||  [E] ST: HST: 67-68 relates this word to WT rtul-po ‘dull, blunt’ and adds WT dul-ba ‘soft, mild, tame’ ᛝ ’dul-ba, btul ‘to tame, conquer, subdue’; Chepang dyulh- ‘be blunt, worn’ (edge of tool). Other languages have similar-looking words which are unrelated, though: PTB-LB *dum² ‘blunt’ (Thurgood CAAAL 13, 1980: 212) > WB tumᴮ; PYao *bl—  n—  ‘dull, blunt’; AA-PSBahn. *luːn ‘dull, blunt’.
‘Dull, blunt’ [Guoyu].
‘Confused, stupid’ [Lao].
‘To withdraw, escape’ 遁 [Shi], 遯 [Shu] > ‘evasive’ 遁 [Meng]. This word may lit. mean ‘turn to the back’ and thus be cognate to → tún6 臀 ‘buttock’.

‘There are many, have many, all the...’ [OB, BI, Shi]. For the initial, see §8.2.1.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tɔ (平), LR tɔ, twɔ; MGZY do (平) [tɔ]; ONW tɑ  ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ⁵⁵tɔᴬ¹, K-Méixiàn tɔᴬ¹, PMin *tɑiᴬ¹  ||  [E] KT: PTai *hlaiᴬ¹ ‘many’, PHlai *¬Ɂooi¹ ‘(how) many’ (Thurgood 1991: 38; Baxter a. Sagart 1998: 53); the Tai item is also suggested to be the source of the Mǐn word for ‘many’, see → chái3 儕. Others connect dūo with the TB items under → dà 大.

‘Many, all’, forms plurals, especially for persons to whom respect is due [BI, Shi]. Zhū replaced earlier OB duō 多 in this sense, e.g. OB  duō yǐn 多尹 ‘all the administrators’ [OB Yib. 867] > 諸尹 [BI]. In BI both duō and zhū occur. Subsequently in Shījīng, duō is rare in the sense ‘all’, zhū becomes the norm: zhū hóu 諸侯 ‘all the feudal lords’ [Shi 6,34]. Therefore, it is conceivable that zhū had branched off from duō 多 (tâ) *tlai in the sense ‘all’ as the pre-nominal proclitic adjectival use, due to the loss of final *-i in *tlai 多 in this position, hence *tlai winɁ 多尹 > *tla winɁ > *ta winɁ (Baxter acc. to Matisoff 1995a: 54). Alternatively, Karlgren (1956: 17) connects zhū with the wf → zhǔ6 貯褚 ‘collect’; Graham (1973: 294ff) considers zhū a dependent (‘non-adjunctive’) pronoun.

Xnote: ‘all’ which is the Mand. col. form of zhū.

Notes: ‘Be many, abundant’ [Shi], adj. ‘the many, all’ [BI, Shi], syn. of zhū and duō: in Shūjīng occurs shù yǐn 庶尹, for example. Thus ‘all the administrators’ can be duō yǐn 多尹, zhū yǐn 諸尹 or shù yǐn 庶尹. Given the OC phonological similarity of these three words, it is therefore likely that shù is cognate to duō; the initial can be explained as a devoiced *lh- (§5.5) after loss of the *t- which was felt to be some sort of pre-initial.
‘To pick, gather’ [Shi], etymology is not clear, but note → luō 捋.
A Wú dialect word for ‘ice’ [JY] is a loan from PMiao qÒɑk ‘ice’ [Wáng FS].

The second syllable in the modern word for → ěr1 耳 ‘ear’: Mand. ěr-duǒ 耳朵; Y-Táishān ³³ŋgiᴬ¹-⁵⁵tuɔiᴮ¹; K-Cónghuà ²¹ãiᴮ-³⁵tiɔᴬ². This is perh. related to the word tuǒ 橢 (tʰuâᴮ) ‘oblong, oval’ [Chuci]. It is also reminiscent of an MK word for ‘ear’: PSBahn. *toːr ‘ear’.   ||  [T] Sin S. SR tɔ (上), LR tɔ, twɔ; MGZY dwo (上) [twɔ]; ONW tuɑᴮ
‘Hanging tuft of hair’ [Li].
‘Hang on a tree’ [SW, GY].  ||  [E] ST: WB twaiᶜ ‘hang suspensively’ ᛝ twaiᴮ ‘be pendant, hang’ [HPTB: 215].  ||  [C] Perh. related to → chuí1 垂 *doi ‘droop’.
‘Rudder’ 舵 [GY], 柁 [Shiming].   ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ²¹tʰɔᴬ², K-Méixiàn tʰɔᴮ²; PMin *dâiᴮ  ||  [E] Area word: Tai: S. tʰaaiᶜ² < *d- ‘sternpost’; Old Sino-Viet. (or Viet.?) lai (Pān Wùyún 1987: 29).
‘To chop, cut’ [GY]. In some dialects, this graph is used for the syn. zhuó 斲 (under → zhǔ7 斸). Perh. related to WB tʰwa ‘mince with a knife’ (Benedict 1976: 181).

‘Slanting’ [Shi].   ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ŋɔᴬᴬ M-Xiàmén goᴬ²  ||  [E] ST has *ŋ(w)aj ~ *nwaj  parallel stems (§2.5; §5.12.1) for this etymon:  ||  (1) *ŋaj > 俄 OCM *ŋâi, WB ŋaiᶜ ‘to lean, be inclined to one side’ (Matisoff 1995a: 85) ᛝ hŋaiᶜ ‘incline, set on one side’, JP ŋaʔ³¹ < ŋak ‘slanted’, perh. WT sñe-ba (< s-ŋye < s-ŋe ?) ‘to lean against, rest on, lie down’, but WT can phonologically also be connected with the paralle stem:  ||  (2) *C-nwaj > PLB *ʔnwe ‘lean over (and fall)’ (Matisoff 1970, JAOS 90.1: 39), WB hnwaiᴮ ‘lean sideways, incline’. It is not clear if or how Lushai ŋerᴸ < ŋerh ‘be tilted, leaning’ (with final -r) is connected with the TB items.  ||  CH -> Tai: S. ŋiaᴮ ‘lean to one side’ (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 52).

Name of the moon goddess [Huainan, Hou Hanshu], later cháng-é 常娥 because the Hàn emperor Wéndì’s personal name was Héng (180-164 BC). For the legends and variant forms, see Maspero 1924: 14ff.  ||  [E] Prob. area etymon: PTai *hŋaiᴬ¹ ‘moonlight’, S. dianᴬ¹-ŋaaiᴬ¹ ‘full moon’, Po-ai *looŋᴮ²-haaiᴬ¹ ‘moonlight’ (acc. to Gedney CAAAL 6, 1976: 70, ŋaaiᴬ¹ originally meant ‘to lie face up’, perh. connected with AA: Khmer /ŋ´əəj/ ‘to raise or hold up the head’). <> Note also TB-Tamang ³ŋia ‘full moon’. The semantic extension ‘to face’ > ’moon’ is parallel to → wàng4 望; thus é2  may perh. be the s. w. as → é1 俄.   ||  [C] The first syllable may be related to → gèng1 恆 ‘waxing’ (of the moon).

‘Goose’ [Meng]. Prob. related to → yàn2 雁 ‘wild goose’, may have ended in a PCH final *-l or *-r.   ||  [T] Sin S. SR ŋɔ (平), PR ɔ; LR ɔ, ŋɔ; MGZY ngo (平) [NO]   ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ²¹ŋɔᴬ² Ke-Méixiàn ŋɔᴬ², PMin *ŋiɑ, Xiàmén giɑᴬ²
‘To move, act, change’ 訛 [Shu], 吪 [Shi]. → é7 訛 may be the same word.
‘Property, goods, riches, wares’ [Shu].  ||  [<] trans. / caus. devoicing  (§5.2.2) + exoactive of é 訛吪 *ŋroi (§4.3.2), lit. ‘what is being exchanged’, or ‘made to be exchanged’.

‘To transform, change’ [Shu], e.g. from a fish into a bird [Zhuang], people through education [Liji], raw food through cooking (fire) [Liji],   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR xwa (去); MGZY hwa (去) [xwa]; ONW huä  ||  [<] this looks like é 訛吪 with triple causative markings: devoicing (§5.2.2) + s/h-suffix (§4.3.2) + *r-’infix’ (§7.5).  ||  [E] Bodman (1980: 60) relates this word to TB: Kanauri skwal ‘to change’ ᛝ Khaling  kʰwaal ‘to shift, move’; but the phonology of the initials is not clear.

‘An earthenware utensil’ [Shi, SW] > ‘tiles (of a roof)’ [Zhuang] (Wáng Lì 1958: 568).    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋwa (上), PR, LR wa; MGZY xwa (上) [ɦwa]  ||  [<] perh. derived from huà through elimination of caus. devoicing and addition of endoactive tone B (§4.5.1), lit. ‘what has transformed’ (i.e. chemically through fire; note huà meaning: transform raw victuals into cooked food through fire).
‘False’ [Shi].

‘False, deceive, cheat’ [Shi].  ||  [E] This word is commonly considered cognate to → wéi3 為 ‘make’ (Karlgren 1956: 18). But phonologically wèi is closer to é. The phonetic wéi was prob. selected for semantic reasons, supported by the rime.  ||  [E] ST ?: WT rŋod-pa, brŋos ‘to deceive, seduce’, but the rimes do not agree. This wf may belong to → é4 訛吪  ‘change’.
‘Yoke ring’ 厄 [Shi], 軛 [Yili] > ‘straits, difficulties’ 厄軛 [Meng], 隘 [Zhuang].

‘Be narrow’ (of a lane) [Shi], ‘defile, narrow pass’ 隘阨 [Zuo] > ‘straits, difficulties’ 阨 [Meng] (also MC ʔɛk), 隘 [Zhuang].  ||  [<] exopass. of è 厄軛 *ʔrêk, lit. ‘being put in straits’ (§4.3.2).    ||  [C] A derivation is → gè4 鬲 ‘yoke’. Perhaps cognate to → yì18 嗌 ‘strangle, throat’.

‘Evil, evil-doer’ [Shi], ‘bad, ugly’ > ‘wrong, fault’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR ʔaw (入), LR  ʔawʔ; MGZY 'aw (入) [ʔaw]; ONW ʔɑk  ||  [E] ST: WT ʔag-po ‘bad’ (HST: 38). It occurs also in PTai *j-: S. jaakᴰ²ᴸ ‘difficult, bad’, in NTai *ʔj-. Karlgren (1956: 13) connects → yà1 亞 ‘second, inferior’ to this wf.
‘To hate’ [Shi], ‘dislike, abominate’ [Mo — Harbsmeier 1981: 40].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ʔu (去); MGZY 'u (去) [ʔu]  ||  [<] exoactive / putative of è 惡 (ʔâk) (§4.3).
‘Imitate, follow’ 傚 [Shu], 效[Zuo].  ||  [<] endopass. of jiào (§4.6), lit. ‘be taught’.
‘Exhaust, finish’ 醮 [Xun]; ‘thoroughly understand’ 潐 [Xun] > ‘discern, understand’ 僬 [Xun]; ‘empty a cup’ 釂 [Li] > ‘empty a cup at a wedding ceremony’ 醮 [Li].
‘Melancholy, harassed, distressed’ [Zuo], ‘haggard’ 憔 [Guoyu]; ‘deteriorate, worn out’ 譙 [Shi].

‘Be grieved’ [Shi] (the OCM initial might have been *C-s-, though, hence this word is prob. not related to the above items).    ||  [C] Acc. to Wáng Lì (1982: 218), this wf belongs to → jiāo6 焦 ‘burn’, but in spite of the semantic parallelism with the wf → jìn4 盡 (‘exhaust, burn up’) this not certain.
