‘Hard, firm’ 剛 [Shi] > ‘steel’ 鋼 [Lie].   ||  [<] terminative (§6.5.1) of → gù1 固 *kah, lit. ‘having become solid, hard’.  ||  [E] ST root *ka (→ gù1 固): WT gaŋs ‘ice’ (terminative: < ‘having become hard’ of snow, water), Lushai kʰaŋF ‘congealed, solidified’. For related and similar items, see → gù1 固 (including Table G-1) and → jiān2 堅 (including Table J-1). Perh. the wf → qiáng 強彊 ‘strong’ belongs here as well.
‘Hard (soil)’ [Zhouli].

‘Bull, stud’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *-laŋ with animal prefix *s- or *k-: Mru klaŋ ‘male’, Lushai tlaŋ ‘male’ (i.e. tlaŋR-vaalᴴ ‘young man’?) [Löffler 1966: 120]; Mikir chè-lóŋ ‘buffalo’, WT glaŋ ‘ox’ (Boodberg 1937: 363), glaŋ-po-čʰe (‘big buffalo’:) ‘elephant’. The meaning glaŋ ‘elephant’ must have been secondary because this animal is not indigenous in Tibet and only known through texts and stories relating to India. The WT word is not related to → xiàng5 象 ‘elephant’. For the OCM initial *kl-, see §8.2.2.
‘Lower intestines, anus’ [GY, JY] is perh. related to TB-WT gžaŋ (< *gryaŋ? *glyaŋ?) ‘anus’ (Unger Hao-ku 50, 1995: 157); see also → cháng6 腸.
‘High’ [OB, BI, Shi]. See → yuán1 元 for possible TB cognates.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kaw (平); MGZY  gaw (平) [kaw]; ONW kɑu
‘Height’ [Lù Démíng: Zuo, Yin] (Unger Hao-ku 21, 1983: 183).   ||  [C] Likely allofams are under → qiáo1 喬, perh. also → hào3 浩 ‘vast, rising’.

‘Grease, ointment’ [Shi], ‘fat’ (of animals, persons) [Zuo]> ‘to fatten’ (e.g. millet shoots) [Shi], ‘fertile, rich’ [Guoyu]; > ‘be glossy’ [Shi]. SW says that → zhī10 脂 ‘grease, fat’ belongs to animals with horns, gāo 膏 to animals without horns (e.g. pigs). Downer (1959: 278) reserves tone C reading MC kâuᶜ for verbal usages.
‘Lamb’ [Shi], gāo has the general meaning ‘small, of an animal’ in an ancient dialect (Wáng Lì 1982: 182f.); it is prob. not related to → gǒu 狗 ‘dog’.
‘Bow case (of tiger hide)’ [BI, Shi].

‘Bow case’ [Zuo]. These two words could be reconciled if we assume that MC tʰ- derives from OCM *lh- rather than *th-, and the div. I vocalism of gāo is due to an earlier medial *-l- (§8.2.2). Such variants may indicate a foreign loan.

‘White, brilliant’ 暠 [Meng]; ‘plain white silk’ 縞 [Shi].  ||  [E] This is prob. the same word as gǎo 皓皋 (kâuᴮ) (under → hào2 皓), although the reason for the difference in OC rimes is not clear. <> Tai: S. kʰauᴬ¹ ‘white, clear, pale’.  ||  This item is prob. not related to hè 翯 (xåk, ɣåk) ‘rich white colors of birds’, perh. rather ‘glistening’ [Shi], because the initials MC x- and k- do normally not occur in the same wf. However, → hè2 鶴 ‘crane, glistening white’ may be related.

‘To tell, report, announce, inform’ [BI, Shi]. Downer (1959: 286) reserves the tone D form LH kouk for the meaning ‘to tell’ (superiors).  ||  [E] <> KT: S. klaauᴮ¹ < *kl- ‘to say, declare’ (Li 1976: 46); S. lauᴮ² ‘to tell, recount’ ᛝ lauᴬ² ‘concise statement’ are unrelated to klaauᴮ¹ (Gedney 1976: 72).
‘Announcement, make an announcement’ (to inferiors) [BI, Shi, Shu].   ||  [<] exoactive of gào 告 (kuok, kâuᶜ) (§4.3.1), i.e. ‘announce something to someone’.

‘Dagger axe’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] Perh. area word: TB-WB kʰwan ‘long-handled chisel’ (Peiros / Starostin CAAAL 22, 1984: 125) <- Tai: S. kʰwanᴬ¹ ‘an axe, hatchet’ (used in a compound meaning long- handled battle-axe) <- AT gwal ~ qwal (Egerod CAAAL 6, 1976: 56). Possibly related to huà 廻 (ɣwaᴮ) ‘thrust’, and huá 划 (ɣwa) ‘to punt’ [Lü].

‘Song’ [Shi].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kɔ (平), LR kɔ; MGZY  go (平) [kɔ]; ONW kɑ  ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu kɔᴬ¹, Ke-Méixiàn kɔᴬ¹; PMin *kɑi  ||  [E] ? ST: Perh. related to Lushai kaiᴸ / kaiɁᴸ < kai / kaih ‘to play’ (a fiddle etc.), perh. also TGTM *ᴮgwai ‘song’, Chepang keɁ- ‘sing well’, JP kʰai³¹ ‘tell’ (a story). It is not clear if or how PVM *tkal > *tkalɁ > Viet. gáy ‘to crow’ (of a rooster) [Ferlus] may be connected.

‘To cut’ [Zuo], ‘destroy, injure’ [Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kɔ (入); MGZY go (入) [kɔ]  — [D] PMin *k̯ɑt  ||  [E] ST and area word: PTB *(s-)kat ‘cut’ (LaPolla 1994: 166), and / or WT ’gas-pa ‘to split, break’. <> PTai *kat : Lóngzhōu kaatᴰ¹ᴸ ‘to cut’ may be CH loans. <> MK *kat, *kaat ‘to cut’ (Shorto 2006 #958): NViet. kăt; Khmer kat [Huffman 1975: 16].
‘To harm, injure, harm, injury’ [BI, Shi].
‘To castrate’ [Zhuang] is added by Karlgren (1956: 12).  ||  [<] perh. r-caus. of gē 割 (kât) (§7.5).
‘Armpit’ [Li, Shiwen] > ‘armpit seam’ 澗 [Li].  ||  [E] MK: PMon *knlak, LitMon knak, Khmer kliək ‘armpit’. The syn. → yì4 腋亦掖 is prob. a different etymon.

‘To change’ [Shi]. Karlgren (GSR 931a) implies that this is the s. w. as ‘a hide’ [Shi] which is the other meaning of this graph. Wáng Lì (1982: 81) considers gé an allofam of → gǎi 改 and gēng1 更 (kɐŋ) *kraŋ ‘change’.
‘To separate’ [Guanzi].

‘Membrane’. Unger (Hao-ku 51, 1995) suggests that mò 膜 (mâk) ‘membrane’ which he sets up as OC *mrāk is a morphological variant of this word. Alternatively, gé may be a variant of, or the same etymon as → gé1 革 (kɛk) ‘hide, skin’, although the OC rimes are different (*-ək vs. *-ek).
‘(Clothes) rack’ [Tang] is perh. a cognate or variant of jià 架 (kaᶜ) ‘(clothes) rack’ [Jinshu] (so LaPolla 1994: 141). See also → gè2 格.

‘To come, go to’ [OB, BI, Shu], originally written 各.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kaw (入); MGZY  gyay (入) [kjaj]  ||  [E] ? ST: Perh. cognate to WT ’gro-ba ‘to walk, go, travel’ (which could derive from either *ɴgra or *ɴgro) ᛝ ’gro-ba-po ‘traveller’ ᛝ ’gron-pa ‘to go, travel’ ᛝ Ægron-kʰaŋ ‘inn’ ᛝ mgron ‘guest’ [Geilich 1994: 19f]. For the vocalic discrepancy, see §12.9 (3). Acc. to Baxter (1992: 329), → lù5 路 (*g-rak) could be related to the above; also → kè3 客 ‘guest’, → l 2 旅 ‘travel, lodge’, → xíng1 行 (root *kraŋ) ‘to go’.
‘To come, go to’ [Shi]. Because jiǎ is not a rime word in Shījīng, it is difficult to decide whether this character wrote a variant of gé or simply was borrowed for it.
‘Bones’ [Liji 6/10 = Couvr. I: 338]  ||  [E] <> KT: PKS *k-laːkᴰ (Edmondson/Yang 1988: 157), *tlaːkᴰ¹ (Thurgood 1988: 210) ‘bone’. See also → dú8-lóu 髑髏.
‘Haunch’ of victim [Yili] is prob. the same word as ‘bones’.
‘Deer’s horn’ [Li]. Benedict (1976: 174) compares this word with PTB *rwâ ~ *rwâk ~ *rwâŋ ‘horn’ (→ gōng9 觥). He mentions Dzorgai (Thochu) rak ‘horn’, but we should expect a MC medial w.

‘Each’ [Shi]. 各 is the original graph for → gé4 格 ‘go, come’; depicting two feet. Gé 閣 ‘one over the other’ is perh. the s. w.  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kaw (入), LR kawɁ, kɔɁ; MGZY  gaw (入) [kaw]; ONW kɑk  ||  [<] perh. derived from jǔ 舉 with the distributive suffix *-k (so Pulleyblank 1973: 122); see §6.1.2.
‘All’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] ST: PLB *ka¹ ‘all’ (HPTB: 163).

‘Tree branch’ [Nan-Bei chao], but the word may be much older because the graph, which was apparently originally intended to write ‘branch’ (‘wood’ radical), occurs already in Zhou texts.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *kaːk (STC no. 327) > PLB *Ɂkak ‘fork (of a tree), branch’, WB ə-kʰak ‘branch of a tree’, Lushai kaakᴸ (Lorrain), kakF (Weidert 1975: 17) ‘fork’ (of a tree), ‘be forked’, Kachin kʰaɁ³¹ ‘be parted, separated’.
‘Yoke’ [Zhouli] is prob. a nominal k-prefix derivation from → è1 厄軛 (§5.4).

‘To scrape’ [SW].  ||  [E] ST: TB: Lepcha hrit ‘to comb’, PLB *kret ‘scrape’ [Matisoff 1972: 48] > WB kʰrac  ‘to scrape’, Kachin kʰrèt ‘rasp, grate’ (HST: 129). Tai: S. kʰraatᴰ²  < *g- ‘to scrape, rake’ ᛝ kraatᴰ¹ ‘metal scraper or grater’.   ||  [C] Allofams are perh.: → qì 凵 ‘skillful engraving’, → qì2 契. Connection with → jié10 櫛 is doubtful.

‘Root, trunk’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kən (平); MGZY  ghin (平) [kən]; ONW kən  ||  [E] MK *d2gəl, *d2g[əə]l ‘stump, trunk’ (Shorto 2006 #1719): PVM *kəl ‘tree’ (trunk) [Ferlus], PMon *t[l]gəl ‘stump’ (of tree, mushroom, tooth), Khmer găl ‘tree trunk’ [Maspero 1912: 21]. MK -> PTai *g-: S. khoonᴬ² ‘base of tree, stump’ (irreg. tones, ‘perch’ in some Tai dialects).
‘To change’ [Zuo]. Perh. this is the s. w. as → gēng3 賡. Wáng Lì (1982: 81) relates gēng to → gǎi 改.  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kəjŋ (平), PR kəŋ ~ kiŋ, LR kiŋ; MGZY gÿing (平) [kjiŋ]; ONW këŋ
‘Again, still’ [Zuo].  ||  [<] adverb from gēng 更 (kɐŋ) ‘change’ (§5.C.4.1) (Downer 1959: 289).
‘To continue, succeed’ [Shu]; ‘take over (duties etc.)’ 更 [BI]. This is perh. the same word as → gēng1 更 ‘change’.
‘To plough’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kəjŋ (平), PR kiŋ ~ kəŋ; MGZY gÿing (平) [kjiŋ]  ||  [E] CVST 2: 67 connects this word with Lushai hreŋF ‘to clear for cultivation’.
‘Be brilliant’ (e.g. glory) [BI, Shu], ‘wide awake’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WB krañ < kriŋ ‘clear, bright’.

T_data: [T] Sin Sukchu SR kəjŋ (去) PR kiŋ (去)
Notes: ‘To wax, increase’ (of moon, plants spreading) [Shi].  ||  [E] Etymology not clear, but this word has some resemblance to → gēng1 更 *kraŋh ‘change’, and / or to MK-PVM *k-raːŋɁ ‘month’, Pearic kaːŋ ~ kɔːŋ ‘moon’.

‘Work, artisan’ 工 [BI, Shi] > ‘achievement, merit’ 功 [BI, Shu]; ‘to work, apply oneself’ > ‘attack’ 攻 [BI, Shi] (also MC kuoŋ).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kuŋ (平); MGZY gung (平) [kuŋ]; ONW koŋ  ||  [E] ? Area word: TB-WB kiuŋᴮ ‘employ, order, commission’. <> AA-OMon kloñ /kloɲ/ ‘to work’?, ‘work as a cultivator’ ᛝ klon /klon/ ‘to have charge of cultivation’.   ||  [C] Perh. → gòng2 貢 may be related.
‘Supervisor of artisans’ [Shi], a (later?) variant of 司工 [BI] (unless the graph 工 was here intended for *khoŋ).

‘A bow’ (for shooting) [OB, BI, Shi]. Foreign comparanda imply OC *kuŋ. The OC form *kwəŋ is proved by Shījīng rimes and may represent a particular OC dialect in which *u became centralized (Sagart 1999: 58).    ||  [D] PMin *kioŋ; K-Méixiàn ⁴⁴tʰiɛn-⁴⁴kiuŋᴬ¹ 天弓 ‘rain-bow’; PMin *kyŋ.  ||  [E] PMK *k[o]ŋ (Shorto 1972) > NViet. kăwŋ ‘curved’, Khmer /koŋ/ ‘to bend, arch, curved, be bent (back)’, Pear kouŋ ‘curved’ [Huffman ICSTLL 1975: 13], Khasi pyrkhuŋ ‘to bend, arch’. MK -> Tai: S. koŋ⁴ ‘to arch, bend (bow)’. MK -> PTB *kuːŋᴬ/ᴮ (STC no. 359) > WB kuiŋᴬ ‘hang over in a curve’; note also PTB *ku[ː]m ‘arched, vaulted’ (STC p. 75 n. 321). <> The following are related acc. to HPTB: 310, but unrelated acc. to Shorto 1972: TB-WB ə-kʰuiŋᴬ ‘stalk, branch’, ə-kʰuiŋᴮ ‘large branch, bough of tree’, kuiŋᴬ ‘hang over in a curve’; JP kuŋ³¹ ‘branch’; Lep. kuŋ ‘tree’, Lushai kuuŋF ‘plant, tree’ (STC: 182 n. 479).   ||  [C] Derivations are → qiōng0 穹 ‘vault, hole’, → gōng7 肱 ‘arm’.
‘Body, person, self’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *guŋ > PLB *guŋ¹ ‘body’ > WB ə-koŋ ‘body, animal body’, Rawang guŋ ‘body, animal, self’ (STC: 182 n. 479; HST: 46), JP goŋ³¹.

(Male of older generation, higher rank to whom respect is due:) ‘Father’ [Lie; Hanshu], ‘father’s brother, uncle’ [Hanshu]; ‘clan head’ [BI, Shi], a high feudal title (‘prince’, ‘duke’) [Meng].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR  kuŋ (平); MGZY gung (平) [kuŋ]; ONW koŋ  ||  [D] PMin *koŋ ‘male’; Xiàmén kaŋᴬ¹ ‘grandfather’  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. luŋᴬ² < *l- ‘parent’s elder brother, uncle’. The difference in the OC and Tai initials may be explained by a MK origin: Khmer /looɲ/ ‘chief’ ᛝ /klooɲ/ ‘dignitary higher than /looɲ/’ [Jenner / Pou 1982: xl]. <> WT kʰoŋ ~ goŋ ‘a final syllable in names of important persons such as ministers and government officials’ (HST: 96) may be a Chinese loan.
‘Male’ of animals, as in gōng jī 公雞 ‘rooster’.  ||  [E] MK *kuəŋ, *kwaaŋ ‘male animal’ (Shorto 2006 #02)
‘Impartial, fair’ [Lunyu], ‘public’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT (d)guŋ ‘middle’ is prob. cognate considering the semantic association of ‘middle’ with ‘balance’ (note zhōng 中 ‘middle, proper, right’).
‘Equal, symmetrical’ [Zhouli].

‘Arm, upper arm’ [Shi], gǔ gōng 股肱 ‘legs and arms’ (metaphor for a ruler’s ministers).  ||  [E] As the meaning of hóng (arms resting on an armrest are usually bent) illustrates, gōng implies the upper arm or whole arm bent at the elbow, i.e. bow-shaped, therefore this etymon which has apparently no outside cognate is prob. derived from → gōng2 弓 ‘bow’.
‘Armrest’ on a carriage [BI, Shi].

‘Palace, mansion’ [BI, Shi], ‘temple’ [Shi 300, 1]. (Meanings discussed by Shaughnessy 1991: 199-201).  ||  [E] HST: 98 relates the CH word to WT kʰoŋ-pa ‘inside’, STC (p. 182 n. 479) and Bodman (1980: 124) to PTB *k-yim ~ *k-yum ‘house’ (STC no. 53; HPTB: 504; for the difference in finals, see §6.7); but see gōng 公.  ||  [E] Area word: MK: Mon gloŋ ‘citadel, palace’, Khmer khlu`əŋ ‘treasury, storehouse’ [Shorto 1971: 88]. Khmer -> Tai: S. kluaŋᴬ¹ ‘house, abode of a prince(ss)’.
‘Palace’ [Shi 298, 1].

‘Drinking vessel’ of buffalo horn [Shi].  ||  [E] PMY *krɔŋᴬ ‘horn’ <- PTB (*kruŋᴬ ~) *k-rwaŋᴬ (Benedict LTBA 10.2, 1987: 17), PTB *ruŋ ~ *rwaŋ ‘horn’ (STC no. 85): Tsangla wa-roŋ ‘horn’ (of wa bovine); Chepang roŋɁ ‘horn of animal’; PTani *rəŋ ‘horn’, Garo, Dimasa groŋ ‘horn’, Lep. aróŋ, Vayu, Bahing ruŋ (CVST V: 160), JP ruŋ³³- ‘horn’, also koŋ³³ ‘tusk’; Ge-man Deng k®ăŋ³⁵. This word belongs to the same root *(k-)ru ~ *(k-)rwa as → jiǎo5 角 ‘horn’. Shorto 1972 considers an AA origin likely: PMK *draŋ.
‘To respect’ 恭 [Shi], ‘sincerely respectful’ 龔 (also MC kuŋ, kuoŋ) [BI, Han period] may be related to → gòng1 共 (i.e. < ‘respectfully joining hands’?), and / or to → kǒng2 恐 ‘fear’.

‘All together’ [Shu].  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. An OC medial *r should be assumed if related to → gōng10 恭龔. CVST 5: 57 relates this word to Western Tib.’kʰyoŋ-ba, kʰyoŋs ‘to bring’, WB kuiŋ ‘take hold of, apply hand’. An allofam may perh. be → gòng2 貢.
‘To join the hands’ 共 [Yili],  拱 [Lunyu], ‘hold round with both hands’  拱 [Zuo]; ‘manacles’ 拲 [Zhouli] (also MC kjwok). Note also MK: OMon kloŋ ‘to join in salutation’ (hands) (loan?).
‘To furnish, provide, carry out’ [Shi] (< ‘hand over with both hands’?).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjuŋ (平), PR kuŋ; MGZY  gÿung (平) [kjuŋ]
‘Tribute, present’ n. [Shu], ‘to present’ [Zuo] may perh. be related to either → gōng1 工功攻 or → gòng1 共. There may be a connection with Lepcha klóŋ ‘to grant’ (Unger Hao-ku 50, 1995).
‘Crooked’ 區 [Li] > ‘hook’ [Shi], ‘to hook’ 鉤 [Zuo], ‘hook, curved’ 句 [Li] > ‘crooked wood’ 枸 [Xun].
‘Crooked spine’ [Zhuang].
‘Bent part of slice of meat’ 胊 [Li]; ‘curved exterior part of yoke’ 軥 [Zuo].

‘Bend the body’ [Zuo], ‘humpback’ [Li].  However, not (directly) related to gōu1  句鉤枸區.  ||  [E] ST: WT dgu-ba ‘to bend’ ᛝ dgur ‘something bent’; OC *-o can derived from ST *u or *o. Syn. and likely cognate is → qū1 曲, perh. also to → quán3 卷拳 and / or → quán4 彷, → qū2 屈, → jú6 鞠鞫 ‘bend’. This wf is perh. also related to → lóu2 僂. Syn. → yū1 迂紆; → hú8 弧.

‘Drain, irrigation canal’ [Lun], ‘moat’ [Li]. The QYS final -əu has no div. II counterpart; therefore the rime may represent both OC *-o and *-ro.   ||  [<] possibly k-prefix noun of → lòu1 漏 ‘to leak’ (§5.4).

‘Dog’ [Meng], ‘puppy dog, cub of bear or tiger’ [Erya] (also written with other radicals).   ||  [D] PMin *k̯əuᴮ  ||  [E] Wáng Lì (1982: 182f) believes that the following are variants of this word (doubtful):  (1) → jū7 駒 (kju) ‘young horse’. (2) hǒu 參 (xəuᴮ) ‘calf’ is a dialectal variant for gǒu, acc. to Guō Pú. (3) → gāo4 羔  is an ancient NE dialect word for gǒu ‘young of dog, bear, tiger’ which suggest that gāo ‘lamb’ is the same etymon.  ||  Actually, gǒu is a loan or substrate word from PMY *klu² [Purnell] ‘dog’ which in turn is AA: PMon *clur, Mon *klə, WrMon cluiw, kluiw [kløw] (Haudricourt 1966; Norman / Mei 1976: 279-280; Norman 1988: 17), perh. also Bahnar k≠o ‘dog’ (K. Smith LTBA 2.1 [n.d.]: 7). For the initials, see §8.2.2. Some Himalayish forms, e.g. TB- Bahing k’li ‘dog’ (STC no. 159) may derive from the same root of presumably wide prehistoric distribution. Acc. to W. Eberhard (1968: 43-50), the dog play a significant role in Yáo mythology. Customs in the ancient state of Zhèng 鄭 in Hénán (adjecent to the Shāng and Zhōu dynasty heartland) suggest to Eberhard that their inhabitants belonged originally to the Yáo culture (ibid. p. 36).

‘Filth’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ? ST: WT bsgo-ba ‘to soil, stain, defile, infect’ (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 50). See also → gòu2 詬.  ||  [E] This wf may be related with WB kyuᶜ ‘filthy, dirty, foul’, all words from a ST stem *klo-?
‘Dirt, to sully’ [Chuci]. For the final *-t, see §6.2.1.
‘Disgrace, insult, revile’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] ST: WT ’kʰu-ba ‘insult, offend’ (HST: 98). Unger (Hao-ku 36, 1990: 50) considers this to be the s. w. as → gòu1 垢 (kəuᴮ) ‘filth’.

This root means basically ‘interlacery, trelliswork’ (Karlgren GSR 109): zhōng-gòu 中冓 ‘inner chamber’; ‘to fabricate, build’ 構 [Shu]. The original graph gòu 冓 shows apparently a wicker fish trap.  ||  [E] ? ST: JP ku³¹ ‘bed, furniture’ (i.e. wooden frame).  ||  Karlgren (GSR 109) believes that all words with the phonetic 冓 are cognate, meaning ‘intertwine, interlace’; possible allofams → gòu5 購 ‘to present’; → gòu4 遘覯姤 ‘come across’. However, the word → hù3 互枑 agrees with gòu in all but the vowel; possible TB cognates also indicate that hù is a separate root.
‘Bamboo cage’ [Chuci].

‘To come across, meet with’ 覯 [Shi]; ‘meet with’ 遘 [Shi]; ‘to cross, join (weapons)’ 搆 [Meng]; ‘come in conflict with’ 構 [Shi]; ‘second marriage, favor’ 姤 [Yi]. This may be the s. w. as → gòu3 冓 (so Karlgren), q.v. for possible allofams.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *gow (STC no. 318) > WB kuᴮ ‘cross over, transfer’, JP gau³³ ‘pass over’;  possibly also JP koɁ⁵⁵ ‘to ford’, WT kʰug-pa ~ kʰugs-pa ‘to find, get, earn’ (i.e. ‘come across’) (HST: 72). WB *kruik ‘meet with’, Chepang krus-sa ‘to meet’, WT ’kʰrug-pa ‘fight, disturb’ represent perh. parallel stems. Note that MC is ambiguous as to the presence or absence of OC medial *-r-. Karlgren (GSR 109) believes that all words with this phonetic are cognate, basically meaning ‘intertwine, interlace’.
‘To present, give’ [Guoce] is perh. cognate to WT skur-ba ‘to send, transmit, give’, WB kuᴮ ‘cross over, transfer’, and may belong to → gòu3 冓.
‘Father’s sister, husband’s mother’ [Shi, Liji], ‘wife’s sister’ [Liji] (Wáng Lì 1958: 569; K.C. Chang 1976: 89). Etymology not clear.
‘Net’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WB kʰwaᶜ ‘kind of net’ ᛝ PTB *kwan ~ *gwan ‘casting net’ (STC: 158 n. 428), WT rkon ‘net’. It is prob. unrelated to gǔ 罟 ‘net’ (under → hù3 互枑).

‘Antiquity, of old’ [OB, BI, Shi].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ku (上); MGZY gu (上) [ku]; ONW ko  ||  [E] ST: PTB *r-ga ‘old’ (STC no. 445) > WT rga-ba ‘be old, aged’; JP ləga ‘old’. Boltz (OE 35, 1992: 36ff) relates gǔ to a wf ‘hard, durable’ which includes → gù1 固 ‘secure, strong’, but WT cognates suggest that these etyma have separate ST origins. Boltz also includes → kǔ 苦 ‘duress, suffer’, et al.   ||  [C] Shī Xiàngdōng (2000: 120) adds hú 胡 LH gɑ or ɣɑ ‘advanced in years’ [Zhoushu].
‘An old one’ [Shi].

‘Male of bovine, steer’ [Yupian, GY], a post-classical word. Prob. not cognate to → gǔ7 羖 ‘ram’.  ||  [E] MK: Mod. Khmer kloḥ ‘male, virile’ ᛝ kamloḥ ‘young man’; Chrau ‘male’ ᛝ si-klo ‘husband’; Bahnar klo ‘male’, Stieng klau, klo ‘male’ ᛝ sarlau ‘husband’, Sre klau ‘man, male’. Also the Yuè dialect word lau ‘boy’ may ultimately go back to this MK etymon.

‘Valley’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST or area word: TB-WT luŋ-pa ‘valley, WB kʰyoŋ ‘valley’, JP kruŋ³³ ‘valley’. <> Tai: S. kʰlɔɔŋᴬ², Kam loŋᴬ¹, <> AA-Wa roŋ (TB loan?) (collected in Dǒng Wéiguāng et al. CAAAL 22, 1984: 119f); some TB words have final -k: Mikir arlók < r-lók ‘valley’. But PTB *grok (STC no. 122) > WT grog-po ‘deep dell, ravine’, WB kʰyok ‘chasm, gulf’ is prob. to be kept separate.
‘Valley’ [EY, GY].
‘Thigh, leg’ [Shi]  ||  [E] KT: Tai: S. kʰaaᴬ¹ < *kʰ- ‘leg, thigh’ (Li F. 1976: 44), PKS *kwa¹ ‘leg’. The Tai word is prob. not related to → qiāo1 骹 (kʰau) ‘foot’.

‘Ram’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Wáng Lì (1982: 126) relates this word to → gǔ3 牯 ‘male of bovine, steer’, as well as to the wf → jiā8 豭 ‘boar’, therefore gǔ 羖 meant originally ‘male animal’. However, jiā and gǔ differ in MC vowel and tone, therefore gǔ prob. means basical ly ‘ram’ and is cognate to → jié4 羯 ‘ram’.

‘Bone’ [OB].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ku (入); MGZY gu (入) [ku]; ONW kot  ||  [D] PMin *kot  ||  [E] Outside relations are not obvious; gǔ is usually compared to PTB *rus ‘bone’: WT rus, Lushai ruɁ (< rus), Khami lgs. (Kuki-Chin) *hrut, Rengmitca kh(r)u, Areng haw (prob. from voiceless *hr-)  (Löffler Anthropos 55, 1960: 547); Lepcha a-hrăt ‘bone’; Karen k(h)rut (STC: 155 n. 419). But we could be more confident about these associations if there were a trace of an OC medial *r. WT rus ‘clan’, see → lèi2 類.

‘The drum, to drum, strike (a musical instrument)’ [BI, Shi]; ‘musician > blind man’ 瞽 [Shi] (Karlgren 1956: 4).  ||  [E] Area word: PTai *klɔŋᴬ¹ ‘drum’ (Li F. 1976: 40), Saek tlɔɔŋᴬ¹, PHlai *laŋ¹, MK-PWa *kloɁ ‘bronze-drum’. For the finals, see §3.2.4.

‘To sell’ [Shi 264, 4], ‘to buy’ [Zuo] > ‘merchant’ [Shu 35, 5; Zuo].  ||  [E] This word could be a cognate or variant of gǔ above, but the same graph also writes a word hù (ɣuoᴮ) ‘overnight wine’ [Shi 302, 2] with which it may be related since gū means ‘buy wine’. Karlgren (GSR 49b’) has assigned readings to meanings as given above, yet traditional commentaries and dictionaries don’t agree which reading, gū or hù, goes with which meaning.   ||  [C] Perh. cognate to → jià4 賈價. Syn. → dí6 糴; → mǎi 買; → shòu2 售; → yù23 賣.
‘To buy’ (wine) [Shi 165, 6].

‘Husk of grain’ [Lü, GY]. GY also has a reading zhuó (tśjak).  ||  [E] ST: PTB *kok (STC no. 342) >  PLB *Ɂkuk ~ *Ɂguk ‘outer covering, bark, skin’ > WB ə-kʰok; WT skog-pa ~ kog-pa ‘shell, peel, rind’ ᛝ ’gog-pa, bkog ‘to tear away, take away, peel, rob’ ᛝ gog-pa ‘to scale off’ (Bodman 1980: 128); Lushai kʰok ‘peel off’ (STC: 74). The CH distinction between → kuò4 鞹 *khwak ‘leather’ (< ‘skin’?) and gǔ *kûk ‘husk’ is difficult to disentangle in TB languages.

‘Grain, cereal’ [Shi] > ‘emoluments’ [Shi]; perh. ‘auspicious, good’ [Shi] is a semantic extension, lit. ‘nourishing, supportive’. Not related to → gǔ14 穀.  ||  [E] AA or area word: PVM *rkoɁ ‘husked rice’ [Ferlus 1988: 87], Khmu /rŋk≠oɁ/, Khasi khaw, Palaung rəkaw. AA -> TB: JP n³³-ku³³ ‘rice’, Monpa kʰu ‘rice’ (HST: 87). AA -> Tai: *kau³, Yay (Dioi) *gau⁴, S. kʰau³ ‘rice, grain’ [Levy 1988: 64; Ferlus MKS 7, 1978: 13f]. <> TB-WB kok ‘rice plant’.
‘Baby’ [Xun], lit. ‘a suckler’.  ||  [E] ST: JP kroɁ⁵⁵ < krok⁵⁵ ‘to hatch’, prob. a parallel stem, see Table C-2 (under → chù4, xù 畜) for similar-looking words.
‘To suckle’ [Zuo], a Chǔ dialect word. Yán Shīgǔ [GY] also reads this graph nəuᴮ/ᶜ, prob. inspired by the standard word → rǔ3 乳. Pulleyblank (in Keightley 1983: 427) has EMC kowk, kowɁ.
‘New-born nestling’ [Zhuang], i.e. a ‘baby bird’.

‘Salt’ [Zhouli], ‘salty marsh’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] <>  PTai *klioᴬ¹ ‘salt’ (Li 1976: 45), Saek tluaᴬ¹ > truaᴬ¹. Acc. to Li F., gǔ is possibly connected with → lǔ1 鹵 (luoᴮ) ‘salty’, which is supported by modern forms like Jin dialectal kəɁᴰ²-louᶜ (Zhāng Xīng-yà YWYJ 1996.4: 10). Possible variants or allofams are → chì1 斥, → xì4 潟.

‘A poison which serves as a magic charm’ [OB, Yi, Zuo]; SW and Zhōulǐ say it is an animal in the stomach. Eberhard (1968: 149-153) says: People south of the Yangtze prepare gǔ by putting into a pot five poisonous vermin, such as a centipede, a snake, etc., which devour each other; the one left is crushed and made into a medicine which is used as a magic charm (e.g. love charm; evil magic to obtain subservient spirits, and the like).

‘Be solid, secure, sure’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ku (去); MGZY  gu (去) [ku]; ONW ko  ||  [C] Boltz (op. cit.) adds among others of the following: → kū1 枯 ‘wither’, → hú1 胡 ‘dewlap’, → gù2 固錮 ‘persistent’, → hù2 怙 ‘rely on’, → gǔ1 古 ‘old’; → gù3 故 ‘reason’.  ||  [E] Several parallel or synonymous stems have partially converged and are difficult to disentangle, unless they should all be prolific variants and derivations from one ST source (for an overview see Table G-1 (A) below; Table J-1 (B) under → jiān2 堅). As often, MK words are also mixed into this wf complex, but the nature and history of their connection with OC and TB is not certain (substrate?).  See Notes and Table G-1   Hard, congeal, dry (A) for gù1 固.  →→
‘To pour metal into cracks, caulk’ [Hanshu] > ‘block, debar, keep in check’ (Boltz OE 35, 1992: 37) [Zuo], a kind of ‘stopper’ used in metal casting [SW].
‘To shut in, stop up’ (by freezing) [Zuo], ‘to freeze’ [Zhuang].
‘Persistent’ (Boltz OE 35, 1992: 37) 固 [Meng]; ‘chronic’ (disease) 錮 [Li] is perh. the s. w. as → gù1 固 ‘solid, secure’ (so Boltz).

‘Reason, cause’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] Etymology not certain, gù may be the same word as → gù1 固 ‘be solid, secure, sure’; or may be derived from → gǔ1 古 ‘antiquity’, hence lit. ‘thing or person of former times’ (Pulleyblank, Proceedings of the 2nd Int. Conf. on Sinology, Acad. Sin. Taipei 1989: 10).

(Perh. ‘restrainer’ >) ‘Pen, stable’ [Yi, Shu], ‘manacle, handcuffs’ [Yi].  ||  [E] ST: PLB *krok ‘jail; pen, enclosure for animals’ [Matisoff TSR no. 16] (HST: 116). <> Tai: S. kɔɔk < gɔɔk ‘pen, enclosure’, kukﬂ ‘prison’.
‘To hire’ [Hànshū].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ku (去); MGZY  gu (去) [ku]  ||  [E] ST: WB ə-kʰaᶜ ‘pay for services, wages’. It is prob. an allofam of → jiǎ3 假 ‘borrow’.
‘To turn the head to, look at, regard, look after, take care of’ [Shi, Shu]. OC Tone B is indicated by Shījīng rimes (Mattos 1971: 309).
‘A sight’ n. [Shi].   ||  [<] exopass. (§4.4) of the above, lit. ‘what is seen’.
‘Melon’ [Shi].  — Etymology not clear.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kwa (平); MGZY gwa (平) [kwa]; ONW kuä

‘To scrape’ [Zhouli], ‘polish’ [Li].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kwa (入); MGZY gwa (入) [kwa]  — [D] PMin *kuot  ||  [C] A cognate is prob. → shuā 刷; see there for an overview of similar and related etyma. Prob. not related to → luō 捋 ‘scrape off’.
‘Be single, alone, unique’ [Shu], ‘orphan, alone’ [Lunyu]. <> Tai: Wuming klaᶜ² < *gl- ‘orphan’ (Li 1976: 46) is prob. a CH loan from around the Han period (*r > l).

‘Bachelor, widower’ [BI, Shi] (Unger Hao-ku 33, 1986).   ||  [<] n-nominalization of guǎ (§6.4.5).  ||  [E] ST: WT dgon-pa ‘solitary place, desert, wilderness, hermitage’ (n-nominalization) ᛝ sgos ‘private, individual’. OC *-r- can reflect different foreign elements in the initial (§7.4), therefore WT is the exact counterpart of OC, except that the WT noun refers to a place, the OC noun to a person.
‘Be solitary, alone’ [Shu].
(To walk) ‘solitary, forlorn’ adv. [Shi].

‘To suspend, hang’ [Yili].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *k(w)aːy ‘hang’ (HPTB: 214) > Tiddim kaːi ‘be suspended’ ᛝ xaːi ‘hang something up’, Lushai kʰai ‘suspend’. This etymon is reminiscent of MK-PMonic *wak ‘to hang’ (sth. to a nail) ᛝ *k-wak ‘to hook and pull, hang sth. by its hook’ (tr.) [Diffloth 1984: 167], but MK is phonologically rather distant. Prob. → xuán4 縣懸 and → qìng3 磬 are related.
‘Strange, unusual, extraordinary’ [Shu]. It seems that this word actually had the same OC rime as → guī2 傀瑰; they may be mere variants.
‘Office, magistrate, official’ [BI, Shu] is prob. the s. w. as → guān2 倌 ‘servant’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR  kwɔn (平); MGZY gon (平) [kɔn]; ONW kuɑn  ||  [D] CDC kuon¹
‘To manage’ [BI], ‘take care of’ [Li].
‘Servant, groom’ (also MC kwanᶜ) [Shi].  ||  [E] ST *kol > WT kʰol-po ‘servant, vassal’ ᛝ ’kʰol-ba, bkol ‘make someone a servant, use as a servant’ (Bodman 1980: 137; HST: 131); PL *C-kjwan id.
‘To serve’ [Shi].  ||  [<] exoactive of guān 倌 (kuân) (§4.3.2).

‘Coffin’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] ST, area word: TB-Lushai kuaŋᴴ ‘coffin, trough, groove’, Kukish *r-kuaŋ ‘coffin, boat’ [IST: 47], perh. also WB kʰoŋᴮ ‘trough, canoe’, yet see → kōng 空 ‘empty’ to which all these etyma may belong. Coffins and boats used to be hollowed tree trunks, hence some languages have the same word for both. For the discrepancy in final nasals see §6.4.2.
‘To (be) put into a coffin’ [Zuo, Li] (Downer 1959: 278).  ||  [<] exopass. of the above (§4.4).

‘A cap’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *gwa ~ *kwaːn  (STC no. 160) > WT bgo-ba, bgos ‘clothes, put on clothes’ ᛝ gos ‘dress’ ᛝ gon-pa ‘to put on, dress’ ᛝ skon-pa, bskon ‘to put on clothes’, Nung gwa ~ ga ‘to dress’ intr. Alternatively, Unger (Hao-ku 36, 1990: 48) relates the WT words to gǔn 袞 (kuənᴮ) ‘royal robe’ [Shi].
‘To put on a cap’ (manhood ceremony) [Zuo, Li].  ||  [<] exopass. (§4.4), lit. ‘(make someone to) be capped’.

‘Bar’ [Lao], ‘barrier, frontier’ [Shi]. Note the syn. → jiàn4 楗, → xián6 閑.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kwan (平), LR kwɔn; MGZY gwan (平) [kwan]; ONW kuän  ||  [D] CDC kuan¹  ||  [E] <> PTai *klɔnᴬ¹ ‘rafter, latch on door’.
‘To watch, look at, observe’ (e.g. the ocean, progress) [Shi].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR  kwɔn (平); MGZY gon (平) [kɔn]; ONW kuɑn

(1) ‘To cause to see, show’ [Zhouli].  ||  [<] exoactive / caus. of guān 觀 (kuân) (§4.3.2).  ||  (2) ‘Aspect, scene’ [Guan].  ||  [<] exopass. of guān 觀 (kuân), lit. ‘what is looked at’ (§4.4); in guàn tái 觀薹 ‘look-out tower’ [Zuo]; tone C occurs because the word is part of a compound (Downer 1959: 289).  ||  [E] This stem *kon is derived from the root under → hóu1 侯. Often the form in final -n seems to have the same meaning as the base form.
‘Tuft of hair’ [Shi].  ||  [E] AA: Mon klòn ‘crest, tuft’, has been proposed with some hesitation by Bodman (1985: 157); for the medials see §7.3.

‘To bubble’ [Xun](HST: 49).  ||  [E] ST *kol > WT ’kʰol-ba, kʰol ‘to boil’ ᛝ skol-ba ‘to cause to boil’ (Bodman 1980: 137; HST: 49). Unger (Hao-ku 36, 1990: 50) relates the WT words to gǔn 混 (kuənᴮ) ‘to bubble, boil’; Y-Guǎngzhōu kuɐn³⁵ sœy³⁵ 滾水 ‘hot water’ may be related.

‘To pierce’ (flesh, hand, foot, ear with a sharp object) [Zuo] > ‘go through the center’ [Shi], ‘to string’ [Li] > ‘tightly bound together’ > ‘be intimate with’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Together with → kuǎn 窾 ‘hole’, this etymon belongs to a ST root *kwar.
‘To connect, comprise’ [Liji].  ||  [<] endoactive (§4.5).

‘Familiar with, used to’ 貫 [Meng], 摜慣 [SW: Zuo] > ‘custom, usage’ 稲 [Shi].  ||  [E] Although this word is assumed to be related to → guàn3 貫 ‘bound together’ (hence > ‘familiar’), it prob. is a different etymon which is derived from the same ST root *-rol as WT srol ‘usage, custom, habit’, JP a³¹-ron³¹ (CVST 2: 91).
‘To wash the hands’ intr. [Shu].  ||  [E] ST: KN-Lai khoɁl ‘to clean’ (with water) [LTBA 20.2: 79], ‘to bathe’ [LTBA 21.1: 49]. Possibly the same etymon as → guàn6 灌 ‘pour libation’.
‘To wash clothes’ [Guan] (Wáng Lì 1982: 553).

‘To pour out; libation’ 祼 [Shi], 灌 [Lun]; ‘drink’ (wine) [Liji]; ‘flow into’ (rivers) [Zhuang], ‘to water, irrigate’ [Hou Hanshu].  ||  [E] ST: Chepang kʰur, Boro kur ‘to scrape’, Mikir hòr ‘to ladle out’, Ao ²a²kɯn ‘to scoop’, Rongmei n-xûan ‘to scratch’ (Weidert 1987: 19). <> PTai *guon ‘to ladle’ (water) [Luo Yongxian MKS 27, 1997: 273]. Possibly the same etymon as → guàn5 盥 ‘wash’.
‘Be bright, glorious’ [BI, Shi, Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kwaŋ (平); MGZY  gwang (平) [kwaŋ]; ONW kuɑŋ
‘Bright’ [Zhuang].    ||  [C] An additional allofam is → huáng2 煌 ‘brilliant’.

‘Be extensive, wide, broad, vast’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kwaŋ (上); MGZY  gwang (上) [kwaŋ]; ONW kuɑŋ  ||  [E] Etymology not certain, CH may be related either to TB or Tai, or both (involving some loan relationship): ST: Lushai vaaŋF < vaaŋɁ ‘be large, extensive’ ᛝ vaŋR < vaŋɁ ‘breadth, width, broad, wide’, WT yaŋ ‘wide, broad, large’ (for the WT initial, see §12.9 [2]). <> Tai: S. kwaaŋᶜ¹ is a derivation by k-prefix from S. waaŋᶜ¹ ‘unimpeded’ (Noss 1964: 49). Baxter / Sagart (1998: 60) relate this wf to → kuān 寬 ‘wide’; perh. ultimately related to the root *wa under → kuàng1 況.
‘Be extensive’ [Shi, Shu]; the Shījīng rime indicates tone A, hence it is perh. not a graphic loan for guàng 廣 (kuâŋᶜ) ‘fully, extensively’ (so Karlgren GSR 707a). Karlgren (1956: 14) adds:
‘Be vacant, desolate, neglect’ [Shi, Shu].
‘To extend’ [Meng].
‘Great, vast’ [Xun].

‘Circle’ [Li] > ‘a compass’ [Meng] > ‘regulate, admonish’ [Zuo] > ‘rule, law’ [Li].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kuj (平); MGZY  gÿue (平) [kyɛ]  ||  [<] perh. derived from *wê with the nominali zing k-prefix (§5.4).  ||  [E] Etymology not certain, but note TB-Chepang gweɁ ‘circular in shape’ ᛝ kweɁ ‘hook, fishhook’; PTB *koy ‘bend round, be curved, coil et al.’ (STC no. 307).
‘Length of the circumference of a wheel’ 嶲 [Li]; ‘vapor round the sun’ 鑴 [Zhouli] (also MC xjwie). This root prob. underlies → yíng4 營 et al.

‘Extraordinary’ 傀 [Zhouli], 瓏  [Zhuang], ‘rare, marvelous’ 瑰 (Mandarin) > ‘a kind of precious stone’ 瑰 [Shi]. It seems that this word actually had the same OC rime as → guài1 怪 ‘strange, extraordinary’; they may be mere variants.

‘To return’ (to a place where one belongs) intr. [BI, Shi] >  tr. ‘to return’ >  ‘bring home’ (a wife), ‘give into marriage’ [Shi]. Although the morphological role of the initial k- is not clear (but a k-prefix does occur, see §5.4), guī is prob. derived from → huí 回; see there for an overview of synonyms. Note the semantic paral le lism with MK: PVM *veːl ‘return’ ᛝ *k-veːl ‘village’ (i.e. where one belongs) [Ferlus]. Guī is often related to WT ’kʰor ‘turn, return’, but see the comment under → huí 回.

‘Tortoise, turtle’ [OB]. Wei-Jin poetry rimes indicate analogy to MC -jwi, but Han rimes indicate -jəu < *-u (Coblin p.c.).  ||  [E] Perhaps AA; MK *kluuʔ ‘(kind of) tortoise’ (Shorto 2006 #200): PMonic *dwii ?, Nyah Kur ‘fresh water soft-shelled tortoise’; Mon kwiɁ ‘fresh-water turtle’ [Diffloth 1984: 76]; Kharia ‘kulu. PWMiao *kiᴬ ‘turtle’; cf. Min dial. → xī16 蠵 may be a variant.

‘Spirit, ghost’ [OB, Shi]; originally: the ghost of a deceased who has returned to haunt (terrorize) the living (E. Childs-Johnson EC 20, 1995: 79ff).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kuj (上); MGZY  gue (上) [kuɛ]; ONW kui  — [D] PMin *kyiᴮ  ||  [E] Two etymolo gies have been proposed: (1) Derived from → wēi4 威 ‘to overawe, terrorize’ (Childs-Johnson) with k-nomina li zation (§5.4; Baxter / Sagart 1998: 48; 59), and endoactive tone B, lit. ‘the thing which is doing the overawing’ (§4.5.1). (2) Or related to → guī3 歸 ‘return’ (SW; Carr CAAAL 24, 1985: 61).

Name of a bronze ritual vessel, a ‘tureen’ (Shaughnessy) [OB, BI, Shi], originally prob. some kind of basket or bamboo container.  ||  [E] Possibly ST: TB-PLB *kᵂiy¹ ‘receptacle, container’ > Lahu phi, in some languages ‘nest’ [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 917]. CH ? -> Tai: S. kuay ‘basket’. The name and shape of this vessel is reminiscent of ‘turtle’ → guī4 龜 LH kwiə. The homophone guǐ 匭 ‘box, chest’ [Shu] is prob. unrelated (under → kuì1 匱; however, acc. to SW, 匭 it is also the old graph for 簋).

‘Precious’ [Yi], ‘dear, expensive, eminent’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kuj (去); MGZY  gue (去) [kuɛ]; ONW kui  ||  [D] PMin *kyiᶜ  ||  [E] ST: WT gus-po ‘costly, expensive’ ᛝ gus-pa ‘respect, reverence’ (HST: 121) ᛝ dkon  ‘valuable’.
‘To kneel’ [Zuo], ‘foot’ [Xun] is perh. connected with MK *[ ]kuul ‘knee’ (Shorto 2006 #1706): PVM *t-kuːlɁ ‘knee’, Bru rakɔːl.
‘A cord’ [Shi].
‘To bind, string together’ [Guoyu].   ||  [<] perh. causative aspiration (§5.8.2).
‘Earthenware cooking pot’ [SW]  ||  [E] Area word: AA-PWa *kɁol ‘cooking pot, pan’, AN-Malay kuali ‘cooking pot, pan’ (Bodman 1980: 137).

‘State’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kuj (入), PR, LR kujɁ; MGZY  gue (入) [kuɛ]; ONW kuək  ||  [<] k-prefix derivation of yù 域閾 (jwək) (§5.4) (Baxter / Sagart 1998: 48).  ||  [E] Guó has no obvious outside cognates. It may be related to either WB kwak ‘a circle or round spot..., confined within a local area’ (as rain); or alternatively to WT yul ‘country’. One could perh. connect the latter with yòu: WT initial y- can have dissimilated from ST *wu (§12.9[2]); the addition of the Chinese final *-k (§6.1) has preempted the putative ST final *-l; however, invoking too many rare correspondence patterns deminishes the likelihood of such an etymology.
‘Boundary, territory’ 域 [Shi], ‘threshold’ 閾 [Lun], also (xjwək).
‘Threshold’ 閾 [Lun], ‘city moat’ 淢 [Shi].
‘Park, garden’ [Shi].
‘Fruit > result’ [Yi].  — [E] Etymology not clear.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kwɔ (上); MGZY  gwo (上) [kwɔ]; ONW kuɑ
PMin *kɔiᴮ¹ ‘rice cake’, also ‘dried fruit’, hence perhaps the same word as 果 (J. Norman, p.c.).

‘Species of small wasp’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST, area word: PTB *k(l)wa-y  ᛝ g(l)wa-y  (STC n. 144) > WB kwaiᴮ ‘dammer bee’; PNorthern Naga *C-guay, Lushai kʰuaiᴴ ~ kʰɔiᴴ ‘bee, wasp’, Tangkhul Naga kʰui, Thakali koy ‘bee’, Chepang kway ‘bee’. Matisoff (1995: 64) suggests that the final *-i/-y is a ST diminutive suffix. <> Kadai: Hlai koːi, kuai, kaːi. <> MK: PVM *kweːɁ ‘bee’ [Ferlus], a Chinese loan? Semai (Aslian branch of MK) lwey [All forms from Matisoff 1995a]. Note that none of the TB forms cited by Matisoff and in STC no. 157 have a medial r or l (HST: 41). Therefore the bisyllabic OC form is not the result of dimidiation, but simply a reduplicative compound of the common type CV-lV or *CV-rV (§2.7).

‘To pass’ [Shi], ‘transgress’ [Lunyu], derived from guō next (Unger Hao-ku 21, 1983: 175).  ||  [E] Prob. ST although the vowels do not agree (WT rgal could theoretically derive from ST *gwal, but Lushai and WB forms speak against this), perh. guò may involve an unusual OC a > o shift: WT rgal-ba, brgal ‘to step over, pass over, travel through, ford’, Lushai kaiᴴ / kaiᴸ ‘to cross over, go across’ ? ᛝ kalᴴ ‘walk, travel, proceed, pass by’, WB kaiᴮ ‘exceed, surpass, excel’.
‘To pass by’ [Shu].
‘Frog’ [Taiping yulan: Mozi] is onomatopoetic, MK has similar forms: OMon kma(c) ‘green frog’.

‘Ocean, sea’ [BI, Shi]. The absense of medial w is unexpected.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR xaj (上); MGZY hay (上) [xaj]; ONW hɑi  ||  [E] Prob. related to → huì7 晦 *hmə̂Ɂ ‘dark’; in numerous Zhou texts hǎi is described as huì. In OC they were (near?) homophones in spite of the difference in MC medial w. Semantic parallelism with → míng3 溟冥 ‘ocean’ = → míng2 冥 ‘dark’ supports this etymological connection.

‘Boneless meat sauce’ [Shi], or ‘meat which has been dried, minced and pickled’ (GSR 995n). Bodman (1980: 133) compares this to WT smig ‘purple, color of clotted blood’, smug-ma ‘stale meat, getting rotten’ [Das].

The 12th of the Earthly Branches identified with the pig [OB] (the graph is the drawing of a pig), acc. to Norman (1985: 89) a loan from AA, note Viet. g≥oi ‘pig’ (obsolete), Khmer kol (sp. ko[r]) ‘pig’ (in names of years).
‘To snore’ [Six Dyn.].  ||  [E] ST: WT hal-ba ‘to pant, wheeze, snort’ (HST: 135). Syn. → hōu 齁.

‘Have in the mouth’ [Zuo] > ‘hold back, bear resentment’ 含 [Shu]; ‘to hold inside, contain’ (as life in grain) [Shi], (as life force qì8 氣 in people) 函 [Hanshu] > ‘cuirass’ 函 [Meng] > ‘envelop’.  ||  [D] The Northern Min softened initial in 含 *ğɑm may indicate OC prenasalization which is confirmed by Yáo gjɔm² < *ng- ‘hold in the mouth’ (Norman 1986: 383).  ||  [E] The final -m in etyma with these types of meanings is sound-symbolic (§2.9). The meanings of the OC allofams are also paralleled in some TB and AA words: ‘Have / keep in the mouth’:  ||  MK: Khmer /-kam/ ‘bite’ ᛝ /kham/ ‘clamp or cut with teeth or jaw..., bite’, /kum/ ‘be resentful’. <> TB-Chepang kəmh- be speechless’. ‘Put / take into the mouth’:  ||  ST: PTB *gam (STC: 166; 183) > WT ’gam ‘put into the mouth’, gams, bgams ᛝ ’kʰam-pa ‘put into the mouth’, also WT sgam ‘box’, sgam-po ‘profound’; Mru kʰam ‘take in the mouth, suffer’ ᛝ kʰam ‘box’ [Löffler 1966: 140], Miri gam ‘seize with the teeth’ (as a tiger), PTani *g(j)am ‘bite’.  ||  ‘Jaw’:  ||  ST: Mru kam ‘chin’, Chepang kəm-pət ‘gills’ (fish), ‘gill fins’; Lepcha kam ‘jaw’. <> MK *dgam, *dgaam ‘molar tooth, jaw’ (Shorto 2006 #1318): Forrest (JAOS 82, 1962: 334) cites Khmer thkéam, Stieng gam ‘jaw’, Short additional words, incl. Biat gam ‘molar’, Viet. c≠àm ‘chin’.  ||  It is not clear if the following ‘molar’ belongs to this root (note WB amᴮ, not gamᴮ):   ||  ST: PTB *gam (STC no. 50) > Chepang magam ‘molar’, Thakali kəm-sə, Lepcha fo-gam (fo ‘tooth’), Limbu hema ‘molar’; Garo wa-gum ‘tooth’ (STC: 183 n. 482; HST: 99), WB amᴮ ‘molar’.  ||  The notion ‘keep in the mouth’ is a common metaphor for emotions, therefore → kān2 堪 ‘endure’ is prob. cognate, note also the Mru field of meaning.   ||  This wf could be related to many additional items: → xián11 銜 ‘a horse’s bit’ (Bodman) and to → qián2 柑箝 ‘wooden gag’. Furthermore, Wáng Lì (1982: 605) believes it to be related to → qiǎn3 慊 ‘dissatisfied’. Perh. → dàn5 啖啗 is somehow connected with this root.
‘Put in the mouth’ 含 [Zuo] > ‘resent’ [Zuo], ‘dissatisfied’ 憾 [Li].   ||  [<] exoactive / caus. of hán 含函 (Ɣậm) (§4.3.2).

‘Jaw’ [Gongyang].   ||  [<] endoactive of hán 含函 (Ɣậm) (§4.5) (so Bodman 1980: 110), lit. ‘the thing that holds / keeps something in the mouth’. Although a regular derivation in OC, it may have been influenced by AA words for ‘jaw’ (Shorto 1972), see below.
‘Cold’ (ice, a spring, season) [BI, Shi] > ‘poor’ [Shiji]; > hánxīn 寒心 ‘disheartened’ [Shiji]. Etymology unknown.
‘To soak, overflow’ [Guan] belongs perh. to the wf → chén2 沈.
‘Sweat’ [Yi]. TB has similar looking words, note PKiranti *gʰàl ‘sweat’ (Starostin acc. to van Driem 1995: 254), or Lushai tʰlanᴸ ‘sweat’ [Weidert 1975: 19].
‘Name of a river’ in the ancient Chǔ area, can also mean ‘river’ generally as in ‘Milky way’ [Shi]. The right element in the graph was probably not phonetic, hence the initial did not include an *n.

‘To scorch’ [Shi].  ||  [E] The phonology and hence etymology is not certain. Prob. not related to → rán1 然 *nan ‘burn’ because the phonetic element in hàn has originally been chosen for its meaning ‘distress’, not for its sound (so GSR 144). Baxter apparently considers 熯 a graphic loan for a word OCB *njanɁ. The difference in the initial consonants (*h- vs. *k-) makes cognation with the syn. → gān9 乾 unlikely.
‘To burn’ [Guan], ‘dry’ [Yi].

Occurs in Shi 28 together with jié 頡 (jié... háng); SW glosses both ‘stretch the neck’, this word is thus perh. a variant of → xiàng4 項, and derived from → gāng1 亢 (kâŋ) ‘neck’. On the other hand, commentators interpret these words as ‘flying up and flying down’ (of birds).

‘Go by boat’ 杭 [Shi], ‘boat’ 航 [GY], 枇 [SW]. Whereas acc. to Yìjīng a → zhōu1 舟‘boat’ was originally a hollowed tree trunk (canoe), háng was two boats combined into one, as canoes lashed together (so SW, although Liú Yǐ-gāng YYYJ 1986.1: 169 thinks a háng was probably constructed of boards). Acc. to FY, háng is used for zhōu 舟 east of the Passes.

‘Ancient Wú words for boat’ [Yupian] are variants acc. to Mahdi (1994: 456). Egerod (CAAAL 6, 1976: 58) believes that this is the same etymon as → xíng1 行 ‘to go to’, but it prob. has an AN origin (via AA?) *qaBaŋ ‘two boats lashed together’ (Mahdi 1999: 147f). → fāng2 方 is prob. the same etymon. Syn. → chuán1 船.

‘To clear away weeds with a hoe’ 薅 [Shi], 茠 [SW: Shi].  ||  [E] ST: Chepang huɁ- ‘to weed (around plants), pull out weeds’. Unrelated to the synonym → nòu 耨, but perh. connected with → yún4 耘 *wən < *wun (?) ‘to weed’.
‘To shout, cry out’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *gaw ~ *kaw  > Kanauri ku, Nung go, Lushai koᴸ / koɁᴸ, JP gau³³, WB kʰo (HST: 51).

‘A request’ [Shi, YiZhoushu], ‘title, appellation’ [Zuo]; ‘name’ [Zhouli].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣaw (去); MGZY Xaw (去) [Ɣaw]; ONW Ɣɑu  ||  [<] exopass. derivation (§4.4), lit. ‘what is called’. The extension of the meaning ‘shout, call’ to ‘ask, request’ is parallel to → hū2 呼.
‘To shout, joyous’ [Li].

‘Be good, fine’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR xaw (上); MGZY haw (上) [xaw]; ONW hɑu  ||  [E] Perh. ST and related to → chù4, xù 畜 ‘rear, raise’; Baxter (acc. to Matisoff HPTB: 58) connects the TB words cited there to hǎo.
‘To love’ [Shi].   ||  [<] exoactive / putative (§4.3.2), lit. ‘consider good’
‘Bright, white’ [Lü]. For hào 顥 [Lü], 昊 [Shi] / Ɣâuᴮ, see under → hào3 浩.  ||  [E] Related to S. kʰaauᴬ¹ ‘white’, PHlai *kʰaːu¹ ‘white’ [Matisoff 1988c no. 294].
‘Be brilliant’ 皋 [Shi]; ‘pure, bright’ 皓 [Shi]. This is prob. the s. w. as → gǎo1 暠 (kâuᴮ).

‘Vast’ of rising waters [Shi]. The etymology of the homophone hào 顥 [Lü], 昊 [Shi] (Ɣâuᴮ) is ambiguous because it can mean ‘bright, splendid’ (of Heaven) and then be the s. w. as → hào2 皓.  ||  [E] A TB cognate is perh. WB koᴮ ‘rise up, swell, bulge’ ᛝ ko ‘lift out of place, prize up’, Lushai koᴴ ‘raised ground, mound, rise suddenly’ (waters), ‘surge’ (waves). Hào may be an allofam of → gāo1 高 ‘high’, although the vowels do not agree.

‘To drink’ 欱 [Ban Gu, Han dyn.] is cognate to, or a popular variant of, xī 用 LH  xiəp ‘to drink’ [Hou Hanshu] (Baxter, p.c.) and perh. also to → xiá1 呷. It may be of ST origin: Lushai hupᴸ ‘to drink from the hands, suck (water) from hand’.

‘Plant’ (of grains), ‘foxtail millet’  [OB, Shi] (Qiu Xigui 2000: 176).   ||  [D] PWMin *wɔiᴬ², SMin *g-: Zhāngpíng gueᴬ² ‘rice plant’  ||  [E] ? -> Tai: S. kʰaaᴬ² < *Ɣ- ‘straw, thatch grain’ (Li F. 1976: 42).
‘Being harmonious, concordant’ [Shi].
‘To harmonize, respond in singing, rime’ [Shi, Zuo].  ||  [<] exoactive of hé 和 (Ɣuâ) (§4.3.2). An allofam is perh. → kē3 科 ‘class’.
‘What, why, where’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣɔ (平), LR Ɣɔ; MGZY Xo (平) [Ɣɔ]; ONW Ɣɑ  ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ²¹hɔᴬ²  ||  [<] independent pronoun derived from hú, see §3.3.3; Matisoff (1995: 74).
‘What, where’ [Shi] is used adverbially (Pulleyblank 1995: 95).  ||  [E] ST: WT ga-na ‘where’, ga-ru ‘whither’. See also → hè1 何荷.
‘How, why’ [Shi], perh. this is simply a variant or graphic loan for hú ‘above’.
‘To what, whither?’ [Zuo], ‘how?’ [Zuo, Meng]; acc. to Dobson (LAC: 147) a fusion of hé yǐ 何以. It occurs in preverbal or pre-nominal constructions (Pulleyblank 1995: 95).
‘Why, how, when?’ used mostly adverbially [Shi] (Pulleyblank ibid.).
‘Why not?’ [Lunyu] is a contraction of hú bù 胡不 (Pulleyblank ibid.).

‘River, Yellow River’ [OB, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣɔ (平), LR Ɣɔ; MGZY Xo (平) [Ɣɔ]; ONW Ɣɑ  ||  [E] Three etymologies have been suggested for this northern word: (1) cognate to TB-WT rgal-ba ‘to pass or ford a river’ (Coblin 1986), for a parallel semantic connection of ‘ford’ with ‘river’, see → dù2 渡. (2) An Altaic loan, cf. Mongol Ɣol (Norman). (3) Derived from hú 湖 (Ɣuo) ‘lake’ (Matisoff 1995a: 71). Note also JP kʰaɁ³¹ < kʰak ‘water, river’, but the final does not agree with OC.

‘To be together, joined, harmonious’ intr. [Shi, Shu] > caus. ‘to put together, match, a companion, a mate’ [BI, Shi], ‘harmony, concordance’ [Shi, Shu]; ‘agree with’ [Meng], ‘to answer’ [Zuo]; ‘close, shut’ [Guoce]; later hé 盒 ‘box with a lid’. The graph shows an inverted open mouth facing down onto an opening.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣa (入); PR, LR ƔɔɁ; MGZY Xo (入) [Ɣɔ]; ONW Ɣɑp.   ||  [D] M-Amoy hapᴰ² ‘to join, unite, shut, to fit, agree’.  ||  [E] Three unrelated etyma hé 合 *gə̂p, → hé8 盍蓋 *gâp, and → huì1 會 *gwâts have partially converged in OC. The root kp ‘fit together, cover, meet’ (including *kap → hé8 盍蓋) is widely encountered in the area:  ||  Area etymon *kup. TB-Lushai kʰupᴸ ‘to cover with anything concave side downwards, cover with an inverted vessel...’, JP kʰup³¹ ‘capsize, turn over’ (boat), Chepang kʰup- ‘cover head’. The TB items agree semantically with the OC root *kap (> Mon kɔp), but phonologically with *kup.  ||  MK *[p]kup, *pkap (and more variants) ‘inverted, face down’ (Shorto 2006 #1238): PMonic *p[]kap, Nyah Kur pəkap, Mon həkɔp ‘to turn sth. face down, to join an obj. face to face, face down’; Khmer gwpa /kúuəp/ ‘to join, bring together, unite’, ga’pa /kup/ ‘to join, unite, meet with, visit often’, Mon inscr. sakuip /səkøp/ ‘lid’, also PVM *kəp ‘to cover’ [Ferlus]. Note also MK *gap, *gaap, *gup ‘fit, fitting, sufficient’ (Shorto 2006 #1240). Karlgren adds   xī1 翕 (xjəp) ‘to bring / get together, concordant’ [BI, Shi], but the initials are difficult to reconcile.
‘All together, all’ (as in ‘all in town know / the whole town knows...’) [post-Han].

T_data: [D] M-Amoy kʰapᴰ¹ < khap (< *khəp?) 蓋 ‘inverted’ (as a bowl).
[D] M-Amoy kap ‘with along with to unite join together’.

Notes: ‘A small gate’ 閤 [Mo] > (‘two open sides fitting together’:) ‘oyster, mussel’ 蛤 [Li].

‘To accord with, unite, assemble’ [Shi]; ‘to sacrifice to ancestors collectively’ 祫 [Li] (Karlgren 1956: 15).   ||  [<] r-causative of hé *gə̂p.  ||  [E] Alternatively, this could be a different word related to WT ’grub-pa ‘be made ready, be finished, accomplished’ (Gong H. 2002b: 202).

‘Kernel fruit’ [Shi] > ‘investigate’ [Shu] (< ‘go to the kernel’, so GSR no. 937a’).  ||  [E] ST: WT rag ‘fruit stone, bead’, Mikir rak ‘fruit stone’ (Bodman 1980: 86). Wáng Lì (1982: 249) relates this word to → gé5 骼 *krak ‘bones’ (not likely), but perhaps more plausibly with
‘Bones, skeleton’ [Zuo]. This is prob. a back formation based on a reinterpretation of final -k in hé as a suffix.

‘To dry up’ [Li] (i.e. soil, roads).  ||  [E] The relationship of these two words (hé7 涸 and hè 舐) is not certain. At least hè is ST: PLB *Ɂkrak ‘dry’ [Matisoff], and hé prob. belongs to a different stem which my be related. For more about related and similar items, see → gù1 固 (incl. Table G-1) and → jiān2 堅 (incl. Table J-1). Note MK-PWa *krɔh ‘dry, parched’ which probably belongs to MK *rɔʔ, *rɔs ‘dry’ (Shorto 2006 #160).
‘Water drying off land’ [Chuci].

(‘To put cover / lid on’:) ‘to cover (person, house), thatch’ 蓋 [Zuo]; ‘wooden leaf door’ 闔 [Zuo], ‘door leaf’ 盍 [Xun], ‘to shut’ (mouth, door and the like) 嗑, 闔 [Yi]. The meaning 盍 ‘join, unite’ (actually ‘close in on’, as crowds of friends) [Yi] is somewhat uncertain; see Shaughnessy 1997: 90f; 301.  ||  [E] Area etymon. Items under hé8 here and under hé5 合 are dificult to sort out. TB-WT ’gebs-pa, bkab... ‘to cover’, sgab-pa ‘to cover’, kʰebs < *keps or *kaps ‘a cover’ (Bodman 1980: 49); PKiranti *kapt ~ *kap ‘to thatch, cover with bedclothes’ [van Driem 1995: 252], JP mə³¹-kap³¹ ‘lid’ ᛝ gap³¹ ‘to cover’ (house) (see also HPTB: 142). Perh. also WB kap ‘join, unite, adhere’, JP kap⁵⁵ ‘to stick, adhere to, join a group’.  ||  MK *ckup, *ckəp, *ckap (and more variants) ‘to cover’ (Shorto 2006 #1237): Mon gap ‘be fit for, fit to, pleasing to’, Khmer gā’pa /koəp/, OKhmer gap ‘to meet, strike, fit, suit, match, agree, please, be pleasing...’  ||  The tone C derivative gài (LH kɑs, not kuɑs or kos) makes it clear that the OC rime was not *op. The three unrelated etyma → hé5 合 *gə̂p, hé8 盍蓋 *gâp, and → huì1 會 *gwâts have partially converged in OC.
‘A cover’ (of a car) [Zhouli], ‘lid’ [OB, Zhoushu], ‘have one’s mouth shut’ pass. [Shu]  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kai (去); MGZY gay (去) [kaj].
‘Root of a feather’ [Zhouli] is perh. related to, or the s. w. as, 拒 (Ɣɛk) ‘wing’ [SW], ‘feather’ [Yupian] (so Wáng Lì 1982: 251) which, however, apparently goes back to OCM *grək (not *grek).

‘To carry’ (on the shoulder or back; responsibility), ‘sustain’ [Shi, Zuo].  ||  [E] ST: WT ’gel-ba, bkal ‘to load, lay on’ ᛝ sgal-ba ‘to load a beast of burden’ ᛝ kʰal ‘load, burden’. To hè may belong PTB *s-gal (STC no. 12): WT sgal-pa ‘small of back’, Garo dźaŋ-gal ‘back’, JP kan ‘put on the back’ (STC), Meithei nam-gal / gan ‘back’. This etymon is distinct from PTB *m-kal ‘kidney’ (→ gān5 肝), and Tiddim Chin xaːl³, Lushai ṭʰaalᴸ < *kraals ‘groin’; WB kʰaᴮ ‘loins’.  ||  Perh. an old area word: PTai *Ɣaanᴬ² ‘pole for carrying things’, Saek kʰɔɔl⁴ (< gɔɔlᴬ) > kʰɔɔn⁴ ‘to carry on one end of a pole over the shoulder’, Mak Ɂgaan¹ (Ni Dabai in Edmondson / Solnit 1988: 91).   ||  [C] An allofam is prob. → qí6 騎 ‘ride’.

‘To bear, can, be able’ [Shi]. The original graph is a drawing (可 without 口 ‘mouth’) of an axe-handle intended to write the word → kē1 柯 (kâ) *kâi; 口 kǒu has been added to indicate that ‘axehandle’ is only ‘mouthed’, i.e. is only a phonetic loan.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR, PR, LR k'ɔ (上); MGZY kho (上) [k'ɔ]; ONW kʰɑᴮ  ||  [E] Bodman (1980: 138) compares kě to Chepang kʰaay ‘be able’.
‘Crane’ [Shi], ‘glistening white’ [Meng].   ||  [E] MK: Mon kloh ‘crane’, PEKatuic *klook ‘white’, Khmer kok ‘heron, egret’, PVM *t-lɔːk ‘white’. Perh. related to → gǎo1 暠 ‘white’.

‘Glowing red’ (face), ‘brilliant’ > ‘to manifest, fiery’ (drought) [Shi], ‘fiery red’ [SW].   ||  [E] The phonologically most plausible affiliation is with PTB *s-ryak > Kan. Bunan śrag ‘ashamed’, WT šags ‘joke, jest’ (at other’s expense) < *rhjak. Without medial *j: PTB *s-rak ~ *k-rak: PL *s-rak§, WB hrak ‘be ashamed, shy’, Mikir tʰèrák < s-rak ? ‘shy, bashful’. With initial k-: Magari kʰa-rak ‘be ashamed’ (STC no. 431), WT kʰrag ‘blood’; loaned into MK-PWa sə[ŋ]-krak ‘red’. These forms may furthermore be related to TB ones with the root *jak: Lushai zakᴸ / zaɁᴸ < jak, Kachin kəjaɁ ‘be ashamed, shy’ (STC no. 452 p. 113; p. 106, 108). The OC form goes back to a ST stem without medial *j. These TB items have also been connected with → chì3 赤 ’red’ and → sè1 色 ‘color’ (STC no. 431, 458). An allofam may be → xiá4 赮瑕霞騢 (Ɣa) ‘red’. A semantic extension of this word is perh. → hè5 赫 ‘be scary’.

‘Awe-inspiring, majestic, imposing’ [Shi] vi. < ‘be scary, scaring’.  ||  [E] Acc. to Bodman (1980: 175) this wf is cognate to PTB *krak ~ *grak ‘to fear’ > WT skrag-pa ‘afraid, terrified’ ᛝ OTib skrags ‘fear’, while HST: 78 relates the TB item to kè 恪 (kʰâk) ‘to respect, revere’ [Shi]. STC: 159 n. 430 relates both kè and xì 覤虩 to the TB etymon. This wf may be a semantic extension of → hè4 赫 ‘red’ already on the ST level: ‘red’ > ‘red in the face’ > ‘angry, scary’ / ‘ashamed’.
‘To scare’ [Zhuang].   ||  [<] exoact. / caus. of hè, lit. ‘make scared’ (§4.3.2).
‘Scary’ 虩 [BI, Yi], ‘fear’ 覤 [Zhuang].

‘Black’ [Shi]. This is a relatively late OC word which replaced → xuán1 玄 ‘black’ during the Zhou period.  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR xəj (入), LR xəjɁ; MGZY hiy (入) [xij]  ||  [<] Hēi is perh. derived from mò ‘ink’ (it cannot be the other way around: *hm- is secondary, *m- primary) meaning originally ‘to mark with ink’ (as a criminal’s face), ‘having dark markings’ (Baxter 1983); thus this word might originally have been the regular caus. of mò 墨 ‘ink, black’ (§5.2.2).  ||  [E] ST: WT smag ‘dark, darkness’, mog-pa ‘dark-colored’; Limbu mak ‘black, dark’ (of color, also the color of blood) ᛝ makt- ‘to become night’, JP maɁ³¹ < mak³¹ black’. WB hmaŋ ‘ink’ is not a CH loan but a loan translation, it belongs to → méi9 煤 ‘soot’ (note that WT also has a loan translation for ’ink’: snag).  ||  On the basis of Chinese, at least two ST roots need to be distinguished: (1) *mək ‘black, dark’ ? ᛝ *mə(k) ‘soot, black’, and (2) *mak/ŋ ‘dark’ (HPTB: 522); these have converged in PTB *mak/ŋ (in some TB languages also ‘color of blood > dark red > red’). Items of the type *mak/ŋ in CH include: → mò8 莫瞙暯 (mâk) ‘obscure’, → mù4 莫暮 (muoᶜ) ‘evening’, → mù5 墓 (muoᶜ) ‘tomb’; perh. also → máng3 芒茫 ‘obscure’, → máng4 盲 (mɐŋ) ‘blind’. Etyma meaning ‘silent’ may belong to this complex as well, incl. mò 莫嗼 (mɐk), mò 莫寞漠 (mâk), → mò15 默嘿 (mək) (perh. s. w. as mò 墨 ‘ink, black’ above). The word → huì7 晦 ‘dark’ is prob. unrelated.  ||  There are additional words with initial m- and almost any rime which mean ‘cover, dark, blind, confused, obscure’; relations may even extend to etyma meaning ‘covering vegetation: luxuriant, weeds’ (→ wú5 蕪廡). An allofam is prob. → méi9 煤 ‘soot’.

‘Ink’ [Meng], ‘black’ [Zuo], ‘black-branding’ [Shu]. Perh. the s. w. as → mò15 默嘿 ‘silent’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR məj (入), LR məjɁ; MGZY mue (入) [muɛ]  ||  [N] Because of the WB voiceless initial in hmaŋ (see below) and also because ‘ink’ appears semantically derived from ‘black’ (but see the preceding paragraph), a lost prefix has been suspected in the OC word (Sagart 1999: 214).
‘To hate, quarrelsome’ [Zuo].
‘Disobedient, refractory’ [Guoyu], ‘hate’ [Zuo].

‘Refractory, obstinate, resist’ [Yi]. The graph was prob. intended for → yǎn6 眼 ‘eye’.   ||  [C] Possible allofams: xiàn 限 (Ɣănᴮ) ‘obstacle, limit’ [Guoce]; yín 垠 (ŋjən) ‘raised border, dyke’ [Chuci].
‘Be constant, go on’ [BI, Shi], ‘earlier, anciently’ [Zhouli].  — Etymology not clear.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣiŋ (平), PR Ɣəŋ (平); MGZY Xing (平) [Ɣiŋ]; ONW Ɣəŋ

‘Crosspiece, beam, yoke, steelyard, weights’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu  SR Ɣiŋ (平), SR Ɣujŋ (平), PR Ɣuŋ; MGZY Hÿing (平) [Ɣjiŋ]  ||  [C] See also → hóng5, héng 衡橫 with which héng may be connected (so Karlgren 1956: 16). Possible allofam → liáng2 梁 ‘beam’.
‘Fishbone in throat’ [Guoyu]; ‘choke’ [Zhuang].

‘Rainbow’ [Li].  ||  [D] Dialect forms are very irregular: PMin *ghioŋᴮ, but Jiànyáng leŋᶜ¹, G-Shànggāo dial. has lɑnᴮ-luŋᴴ (Sagart 1993: 196).  ||  [E] <> PY *kluŋᴬ ‘rainbow’ (Haudricourt 1950: 559). Benedict (1986: 58) and Carr (LTBA 13.2, 1990: 105) suggest that hóng is related to → lóng3 龍 ‘dragon’ and → hóng2 紅 ‘red’.  ||  [E] The wide range of forms, incl. dì-dōng (below), speaks for a non-ST source for this etymon. <> Kam-Tai: Zhuang lgs. have tu²-tuŋ² ‘rainbow’ and the like, where tu² is a prefix added to animals and persons. Li Xu-lian (1997) reconstructs this prefix as PT *ta, among others based on forms like Wuming taﬂ and Bama tiəﬂ. Luó Yǒngxiàn (MKS 27: 1997: 272) reconstructs PTai *Druŋ: S. ruŋᶜ² ‘rainbow’. Dōng (*tloŋ) is prob. a variant of hóng (*kroŋh).
This variant survives for ex. in G-Wǔníng dial. kɔŋᶜ¹ (Sagart 1993: 170).
‘Rainbow’ [Shi, EY].

‘Pink’ (Baxter 1992: 207) > ‘red’ [Lunyu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣuŋ (平); MGZY Xung (平) [Ɣuŋ]  ||  The following tóng 彤 could be a variant which is parallel to → hóng1 虹 ‘rainbow’; as in ‘rainbow’, the form with initial MC dental stop is attested earlier than the one with the guttural initial.
‘Red’ (of ceremonial objects) [Shi], 赨 [Guan].
‘Be disorderly, disorder, trouble’ [Shi]. This word may be cognate to → hòng1 鬨 and / or be a variant of hún 渾 (Ɣuən) (under → hùn1 混渾).
‘Be great, greatly’ [Shi, Shu] > ‘great (waters)’ [Shi] is perh. cognate to → róng3 溶 (*loŋ) ‘much water’. Perh. related to → hào3 浩 .
‘To inundate’ [Meng] (Wáng Lì 1982: 379).

‘To plow crosswise, east-west’ 衡 [Shi], 橫 [Zuo]; ‘transversal, horizontal’ 衡 [Li], 橫 [Chuci].   ||  [C] This word may be connected with → héng4 衡 (so Karlgren 1956: 16). A tone C derivation is ‘be cross-grained, hard to deal with’ [Zuo] (Downer 1959: 287).  ||  [E] MK: Khmer khvēṅa /kwaaɛŋ/ ‘to cross, intersect, be diagonal, crisscross’ (-> Tai: S. kwaŋ² ‘to lie athwart, transverse, crosswise’) < vēṅa /wɛɛŋ/ ‘cut across, traverse, intersect’. The derivative gravēṅa /krɔwɛɛŋ/ ‘turn, hurl overhead...’ agrees phonologically with OC.
‘Quarrel, fight’ [Meng] is perh. related to → xiōng5 神  and / or → hóng3 訌.
‘To snore’ [JY]. — [E] ST: WT ŋur-ba ‘to grunt’ ᛝ sŋur-ba ‘to snore’. Syn. → hān1 鼾.

‘Target’ [Shi] > ‘target shooter, archer’ > ‘title of a feudal lord’ [OB, BI, Shi] > ‘border guard’ [Guoyu].  ||  [E] MK: Khmer koḥ /kaoh/ ‘to raise (crossbow) with a view to aiming’ ᛝ kpoḥ ‘be raised up, clearly visible’; or goḥ /kóh/ ‘to hit (squarely)’.

‘To watch, be on the lookout for’ [Zuo], ‘aspects (of dreams)’ [Lie].  ||  [E] Acc. to Lau (1999: 44) ‘watch’ is the fundamental meaning from which is derived hóu 侯 ‘feudal lord, border guard, target’, a tone A nominalization (§3.1); alternatively, hòu ‘watch’ may derive from ‘target’, hence lit. ‘to target’. A derivation is → guān7 觀 ‘to watch’. This stem is prob. distinct from → hòu1 后 ‘sovereign’.

‘There is, to have’, occurs only in old parts of Shījīng, commentators gloss it as → wéi2 惟唯隹維 ‘to be’ or → yǒu2 有 ‘there is’ (< ‘to have’).  ||  [E] AA: PVM *kɔːɁ ‘to be, have, there is’ [Ferlus]; PMonic *gooɁ ‘to get, possess, obtain’ [Diffloth 1984: 151]. <> TB-JP gu³¹ ‘to have’.

‘Throat’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Etymology not certain, but note TB-Chepang guk ‘throat’. AA has similar items: PMK *kɔɁ ‘neck’ (Shorto 1976: 1062) > PMonic *kɔɔɁ ‘neck, narrow part of a long object’, PSBahn. *nəkɔː ‘neck’, Viet. ko’ ‘neck’, Khmer kɑɑ [Huffman 1975]. <> Tai S. kʰɔɔᴬ² < *Ɣ- ‘neck, throat’ (Li F. 1976: 42), Saek Ɣɔɔᴬ². Alternatively, this word may possibly be related to WT mgul(-pa) ~ ’gul ‘neck, throat’ (< ’gul-ba ‘to move’), or mgur ‘throat, neck, voice’ (so Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 33). HST 112 connects WT mgul with gěn 棠 (kənᴮ) ‘neck’ [GY].

‘Monkey’ [Zhuang].  ||  [E] ST: PL *Ɂ-ko²/¹. The first syllable in mǔ-hóu 母猴, mù-hóu 沐猴 ‘macaque’ may perh. be an old pre-initial (Unger Hao-ku 31, 1985: 308). This may be supported by the PMin form whose softened initial derives from an earlier pre-nasalized one acc. to Norman 1986. V. Blazek (in Pinault et al. 1997: 236f) notes LB-Akha mjo kʰœ ‘monkey’ which he derives from PL *mjok and suggests is the source of the CH word, which in turn, citing Lüders, might possibly have been the source of IE-PTocharian *moko. For syn. see → yóu8 猶.

(‘Head’ in society:) ‘sovereign, lord’ [Shi], ‘queen’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] Hóu1 侯 ‘target > archer, feudal lord’ is often considered cognate (e.g. Mei Tsu-Lin in Thurgood 1985: 335f). Though possible, these two words seem to represent two different concepts and thus derive from different roots. This is supported by the consistent distinction of these near synonyms in literature. The hòu 后 under consideration here has the basic meaning ‘head’; it is thus a ST etymon *go which is cognate to WT go ‘headman’ ᛝ mgo ‘head’. This word is prob. a tone B derivation from the following items, lit. ‘the person which is functioning as head’. This stem may perh. also be cognate to → yuán1 元 ‘head’.
‘Arrow with metal point’ [Shi]. In Shījīng the word rimes both in *-o and in *-oh (Baxter 1992: 763).   ||  [D] Acc. to FY 9,4, this is a Han period Yangtze-Huái dialect word for ‘arrow’.
(‘Head’ = ‘tip’ of a feather:) ‘root of a feather’ 翭 [SW]. But Matisoff 1985a: 437 relates this word to WT sgro ‘a large feather, quill-feather’.

‘Behind, after’ [Shi], ‘follow’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣəw (上); MGZY Xiw (上) [Ɣiw]; MTang Ɣəu, ONW Ɣou  ||  [E] ST: PTB *ok > WT ’og  (not Ɂog) ‘below, afterwards, later, after’; PLB *Ɂok ‘lower side, below’ > WB ok ‘under part, space under’ (HST: 41); Limbu yo ‘down, below, downhill’. For tone B in CH, see §3.2.2.
‘Be behind, attend, support’ [BI, Shi], also 候; ‘to put afterwards’ [Zuo] (Downer 1959: 280).   ||  [<] exoact. / tr. of *goɁ above (§4.3.2)
‘Thick’ > ‘generous’ [BI, Shi].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣəw (上); MGZY Xiw (上) [Ɣiw]
‘Thickness’ [GY] (Unger Hao-ku 21, 1983: 183).

‘To call, shout’ [Shu] > ‘to ask (request), be asked’ [OB, BI]. The next word hū suggests that the active verb ‘shout, call’ had originally tone A, and that the tone C form was a exopass. derivation (§4.4), lit. ‘be asked, requested’. Also in tone C is the meaning ‘cry out’ [Zuo] (Downer 1959: 286: restricted meaning). For a semantic parallel ‘shout’ > ‘request’, see → háo 號.
‘To shout’ [Zhouli], ‘abuse’ [Meng].

‘Dried slice of boneless meat’ [SW], ‘big slice of dried meat’ [Liji, Zhouli], Yáng Xióng is quoted as saying ‘dried bird meat’. This word makes the impression of a loan like many words which relate to everyday life and which appear first in Han period ritual books.

‘Dewlap of an animal’ (which hangs down from the chin) [Shi, SW] > ‘beard’ 鬍 [Han texts] (Wáng Lì 1982: 144). Acc. to Boltz (OE 35, 1992: 37); this word is cognate to kū 枯 ‘desiccated’ and ultimately to → gù1 固 ‘solid’.
‘Steppe nomads’, general term [Zhouli] (Pulleyblank EC 25, 2000: 20), etymology unknown.

‘Butterfly’ [Zhuang].  ||  [E] ST: The TB forms vary: Lepcha ha-kljóp ‘a species of butterfly, Buprestis bicolor’, WT pʰje-ma-leb < pem-a-lep. The second syllable *lêp belongs either to the wf → dié 牒; or to PTB *lyap ‘glitter, flash’, see → yè6 燁. (Yan Xiuhong ZGYW 2, 2002: 154 has an extensive discussions of húdié).
‘Butterfly’ [Yupian] is a variant of húdié (Bodman). The first syllable is glossed ‘butterfly’ in SW, it survives in Y-Guǎngzhōu kapᴰ¹ ‘butterfly’, -> Jap. kai < *kapi (Bodman 1980: 146).
‘Bow’ [Yi], ‘bend, curved’ [Zhouli]. Syn. → gōu1 句鉤枸區.  ||  [E] This wf belongs to → yū1 迂紆 *Ɂwa; gū looks like a derivation from yū with the nominalizing k-prefix (§5.4).
‘Curved bone, big bone’ [Zhuang].
‘Fox’ [Shi].  ||  [E] PTB *gwa ‘fox’: OTib ɦo (Coblin LTBA 17.2, 1994: 117), Tib. dial. *gwa, WT wa (STC p. 34 n. 111), Bunan goa-nu ~ gwa-nu.
‘Bottle-gourd, flask’ [Shi], ‘teapot’.  ||  [E] <> Perh. Tai: S. kaa¹ ‘kettle, earthen-ware teapot’.

‘Tiger’ [OB, Shi]. The name of this dangerous animal is subject to taboo. It was there-fore apt to be replaced by a different word, or at least undergo some modification. One way is to add a prefix or word which indicates respect, hence Mand. lǎo-hǔ 老虎 ‘old (= venerable) tiger’; the prefix yú < *Ɂa in yú-tù etc. served the same purpose in the OC dialect word, see below and → ā 阿. The other method is to distort the pronunciation by using a dialect word as in hǔ whose phonology indicates a possible rural or vulgar origin (voiceless *lh- > MC x-, §5.6).  ||  [D] The regular OC equivalent of foreign *kl- is expected to be a voiceless *lh- > MC śj- or tʰ-. Such forms are found in old dialects (Pulleyblank 1983: 427): (1) yú-tù 於菟(Ɂjwo-tʰuoᶜ) [Ɂiɑ-tʰɑh] OCM *Ɂa-lhâk is a Chǔ dialect word recorded in the 5th cent. BC Zuǒzhuàn. The Hòu Hànshū has a variant yú-shì 於瑙  (Ɂjwo-śjäk) [Ɂiɑ-śiak] OCM *Ɂa-lhak. The FY has a further graphic variant yú-tù 於睚 to which Guō Pú adds that south of the Yangtze, the pronunciation of tù is like gǒu-d`ou 苟竇 (kəuᴮ-dəuᶜ), i.e. a hypothetical OCM *kôɁ-lôh which comes close to AA forms.  ||  Some modern interior Min dialects have *kʰoᴮ, but the stop feature is prob. secondary.  ||  [E] PAA *kalaɁ ‘tiger’ > PMK *klaɁ (Shorto 2006 #197) > OKhm *klaa (> later Angkorian Khm. khlaa; -> Tai: S. kla²), PMonic *klaaɁ [Diffloth 1984], Munda kula, Kharia ki’ÂɔɁ (Norman a. Mei 1976: 286-288; Benedict 1976: 97; Pulleyblank 1983: 427). PVM *k-haːlɁ, Khmer khaːl ‘tiger’ (in the name of a year) could be related. <> MK -> PTB *k-la (Matisoff 1995a: 52), PL *k-la², OBurm. kla, WB kyaᴮ (IST: 334), Monpa khai-la looks similar to PVM.
‘Amber’, lit. ‘tiger’s soul’ [Tang dyn.: Li Bai], a loan word from a western or southern Asiatic *≈arupah ‘amber’ (Boodberg 1937: 359).

‘Door(leaf) > household’ [Shi; ‘opening’ [Liji].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣu (上); MGZY Xu (上) [Ɣu]; ONW Ɣo  ||  [E] ST: PTB *m-ka ‘opening, mouth’ (HPTB: 173) > PLB *Ɂga¹ ᛝ *ga³ ‘open, divaricate, spread’ [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 230], WB tam-kʰaᴮ ‘door’, NNaga *gaᴬ ‘door’, WT sgo ‘door’ (HST: 66; WT o can derive regularly from TB *a). It is tempting to derive 戶 from → hù3 互枑 ‘barrier’, yet the latter agree more closely with a different TB etymon (Lushai kʰaar).
‘To rely on’ [Shi] is cognate to → gù1 固 ‘solid, secure, sure’.

‘Intertwining, crossing, barrier, a stand’ (of crossing sticks) [Zhouli]; ‘each other’ 互; ‘railings, fence’ 枑 [Zhouli].  ||  [E] ST: Lushai kʰaarR < kʰaarɁ ‘a dam or weir, roughly constructed of leafy bows or bamboo lattice-work’ (sometimes used for catching fish); WB ka ‘make a barrier, cover on the side, put up fence’ ᛝ ə-ka ‘side of building, external part’. For TB final r, see §7.7.5.  ||  The wf → gòu3 冓 agrees with hù in all but the vowel. Putative TB cognates seem to confirm that these are two separate roots.

‘A weir, fish stakes for catching fish’ (properly written with radical 竹 instead of 水) [GY]. This could be the s. w. as hù 扈 ‘to stop, prevent’ [Zuo], but is prob. unrelated to → hù1 戶’door’.  ||  Both tone B words hù 滬 and gǔ 罟may be nominal derivations from hù 互.
‘Net’ [Yi] is prob. unrelated to → gū4 罛 ‘net’.  ||  Both tone B words hù 滬 and gǔ 罟may be nominal derivations from hù 互.
‘Writing tablet’ [Li]. — [E] <> Tai: S. smut ‘book’ (Unger Hao-ku 39, 1992).
‘Guard, protect’ [Lüshi] is prob. cognate to WT ’gogs-pa ‘to prevent, avert’ (HST: 89).
‘Wide, vast’ [Li] is perh. a ST word: WB kaᴮ ‘be stretched apart, widen; breadth, width’.

‘Flower’, originally a noun (see Wáng Lì 1982: 142 for a discussion of this wf). The graph (whose OC rime should be *-ai) has been borrowed for an etymon in OC *-a).  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR xwa (平); MGZY hwa (平) [xwa]; ONW xuä  ||  [E] TB languages often alternate initial labial stops *p, *b with *w, also in the root for ‘blossom, flower’ *bar (→ pā 葩, → bàn 瓣) (Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 144-146). Huā may be an example of the ST *bar ~ *war variation (for the metathesis of the final *r, see §7.7.3). Alternatively, note AA-OKhmer /pkaa/ ‘flower’; the complex AA initial might have been the reason for the CH development.
‘To be in flower’ intr. > blossom, flower’ [Shi], originally a vb. (Wáng Lì).
‘Flower’ [Zhuang], the graph is sometimes thought to write huā 花.
‘Slippery’ [Zhouli].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣwa (入); MGZY Xwa (入) [Ɣwa]  ||  [E] ST: JP gum³¹-rut³¹ < gu-mrut ‘slippery’.
‘Birch’ [Yupian, JY].  ||  [E]  ST: WT gro-ga ‘bark of birch’ (Unger Hao-ku 33, 1986; HPTB: 175).

‘Speech, lecture’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣwa (去); MGZY Xway (去) [Ɣwaj]  ||  [E] Sagart (1999: 113) derives this word from → yuē1 曰 ‘to say’. It is prob. cognate to WT gros ‘speech, talk, advice’ (Gong in W. Wang 1995: 47).

‘Painted, with a design’ adj. [BI, Shu] > ‘to draw a design, depict’ [Meng].   ||  [T] MGZY Xway (去) [Ɣwaj]; ONW Ɣuä  ||  [<] exopass. of huò 畫 (*wek) (§4.4).  ||  [E] MK: OKhmer gur ~ gvar ‘to draw a line, make a drawing’ [S. Lewitz, AA Studies 2, 1976: 742], with OC final -k added which caused the metathesis of the MK final r (§6.1): *gwer + k > gwrek. Alternatively, *wek alone could be the simplest OCM form (§9.1.4). The vocalic discrepancy has parallels, see §11.1.3.
‘To delineate, mark off, plan’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣuj (入); MGZY Xway (入) [Ɣwaj]
‘To cut’ (with a knife) [SW], cut open, mark off’ (Wáng Lì 1982: 270).
‘To destroy, ruin’ [Zuo] (Baxter 1992: 218).
‘To be ruined’ [Shi].   ||  [<] endopass. of huài 壞 (kwăiᶜ) (§4.6).

‘To turn round, turn back, hesitate’ 桓 [Yi], 垸 [Huainan].  ||  [E] This root prob. derives from ST *war or *wor: WT ’kʰor ‘circle’ ᛝ ’kʰor-ba < OTib ~ kʰord ‘to turn around’ ᛝ sgor-mo ‘round, a circle, globe’; Lepcha var ‘to make a circuit, go round’ ᛝ vor ‘to surround’ ᛝ van ‘turn towards’. See under → huí 回 for synonyms.

‘To change’ [Lie], ‘exchange’ 換; ‘round’ 輐 [Zhuang], Mand. huǎn!, QYS also ŋuânᴮ/ᶜ; the latter graph writes QYS ŋuân, Mand. wān ‘to cut so as to round off corners’ 刓 [Chuci], 筮 [Zhuang].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣwɔn (去); MGZY Xon (去) [Ɣɔn]; ONW Ɣuɑn

‘To turn round’ (as a wheel) [Li]. Rú Chún, annotator of the Hànshū (3rd cent. AD), remarks that in eastern dialects, the word 桓 was pronounced like hé 禾 OCB *gwaj < *goj (Baxter 1992: 296), therefore huà 輠 is apparently a dialect variant.
‘Pillar’ [Li] > huán-huán ‘pillar-like’ (trees) [Shi] > ‘valiant’ [BI, Shi]. Perh. s. w. as → huán1 桓垸 ‘round’.

‘To turn round, return’ 還 [Shi]. Prob. the same etymon as huán 環鐶寰 (under → yíng4 營).  ||  [T] Sin S. SR Ɣwan (平); MGZY Xwan (平) [Ɣwan]; ONW Ɣuan  ||  [E] AA: Khmer (ravā’na:) raṅvā’na /ruŋwoən/ ‘repayment, return, recompense, fee, dues’. The AA relative explains the *r in the OC initial. See under → huí 回 for synonyms.
‘Deceit’ [Shu], ‘magic, illusion’. Bodman (1980: 86) compares this to WT rol-ba ‘to practice sorcery, playfulness’.
‘Servant’ [Guoyu] > ‘officer, official’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] ST: PLB *gywan¹ > WB kywan ‘slave, servant’ (WB medial y can derive from earlier r).

‘Blood’ [Zuo, Xi Gong 15, quoting Yi 54,6]. This rare word’s occurrence in a traditional saying indicates that it is not part of the active vocabulary of OC, but a survival from a substrate language.  ||  [E] MK *jhaam, *jhiim ‘blood’ (Shorto 2006 #1430): PNorth Bahnaric *maham, PMnong *mham, Asli maham (Benjamin 1976: 103), Khmu maːm < *mh-; without m-infix: PVM *Ɂa-saːmɁ, Khmer jham, PMonic *chim, Katuic *Ɂə(ŋ)haːm, Mundari ma˜jɔm. The MK root was *jhaːm (Diffloth 1977: 50), or -TSɑm (Ferlus, MKS 7, 1978: 18). -> PMY *ntšhjaamᴮ (Mei 1980; Bodman 1980: 120). CH has final -ŋ because initial and final m are mutually exclusive. The OC initial was probably a voiceless *m- which can derived from, among others, a prehistoric cluster with either *h or *s.

‘Be august, stately’ [BI, Shi], ‘royal, imperial’.  ||  [E] Etymology not certain, possibly originally meaning ‘royal’ (derived from ‘royal palace’), belonging to the AA etyma *waŋ under → yíng4 營. Tai luaŋ ‘royal’ is a loan from Khmer (h)luːəŋ ‘king, royal’. This word may early have converged with the homophone → huáng2 煌 ‘brilliant’. Bodman 1980: 107 connects huáng with → wáng2 王 ‘king’.
‘Be brilliant, splendid, magnificent’ 煌 > ‘brown and white’ (of a horse) 皇 [BI, Shi]. Perh. → huáng1 皇 is the same word; → guāng1 光 ‘bright’.

‘Be yellow, brown’ [OB, Shi] is one of the ancient basic color terms (Baxter 1983).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣwaŋ (平); MGZY Xong (平) [Ɣɔŋ]; ONW Ɣuɑŋ  ||  [E] ST: WB waŋᴮ ‘brightly yellow’ ᛝ wa ‘yellow’.

‘Semicircular jade insignium’ [Zhouli].  ||  [E] Probably MK: Khmer va’ṅa /wuŋ/, OKhmer vaṅ ‘ring, orbit, disc, round...’, Bahnar uāŋ. AA -> TB-Lepcha vyaŋ ‘ring’. Perh. related to items under → yíng4 營.
‘Leech, water leech’ [SW, EY]. The first syllable → mǎ2 螞馬 in Mand. mǎ3-huáng 馬蟥 is prob. an old prefix (Unger Hao-ku 31, 1985: 308; Mei Tsu-Lin).

‘Ashes’ [Zhuang], ‘charcoal’ [Li].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR xuj (平); MGZY hue (平) [xuɛ]  ||  [E] This is prob. an iterative derivation of → méi9 煤 ‘soot’ (ashes consist of many sooty particles) (§5.2.3) and cognate to items mentioned there. Alternatively, the word may be related to TB-Lushai muutF / muɁ ‘to smolder’.

‘Flame, brightness’ 煇 [Yi]; ‘light, brightness’ 暉 [Yi]; ‘bright’ 輝 [Meng].  ||  Perh. yùn  煇 (juənᶜ)  LH  wunᶜ, OCM  *wəns  ||  ‘Brightness’ [Zhouli] (Wáng Lì 1982: 508f); ‘halo’ [Lü] could either be the same etymon, or be related to → yùn2 運暈 ‘revolve’.
‘Be brilliant, bright’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *hwa-t  > WT ’od; Matisoff (1997: 44f; LL 1.2, 2000: 146) sets up a large ST wf that also includes → fán5 燔.
‘Rope’ [Yi]. The graph writes also a different word, see under → huī4 麾.  ||  This word is shared with Tai: S. maiᴬ¹ < *hm- ‘thead, silk’.

‘Signal flag’ [Zuo], ‘to signal’ [Shi].  ||  [E] The area word → xuè2 糅 ‘wink with eyes’ has prob. influenced the CH meaning of huī 麾. Huī 麾 *hmai looks like a conflation of huī 撝 *hwai ‘to signal’ (under → wēi2 逶) and huī 徽 *hməi ‘to signal’.
‘To signal, display’ [Shu], ‘a flag’ [Li] is apparently a vocalic variant.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *s-mwəy (HPTB: 195) > WB hmweᶜ ‘whirl about, twirl’, Lushai hmuiR < hmuiɁ ‘spinning wheel’.
‘To destroy’ 墮 [Shu], 隳 (e.g. city walls) [Lüshi].

‘To destroy, ruin’ [Shi], ‘perish’ (people) [Hanfei], ‘lose’ (e.g., teeth) 毀; ‘destroy’ (by fire), ‘blazing fire’ 燬 [Shi]. This is an ancient dialect word for ‘fire’ in Qí 齊 [FY 10: 6 — written 𤈦 but pronounced 毀]. This word also occurs in Tai: S. maiᶜ¹ < *hm- ‘to burn’.
‘To burn’ [SW: Shi], a phonological variant of huǐ above (Baxter 1992: 417). See also  → huǒ1 火 ‘fire’.

‘To revolve, swerve, deflect’ [Shi], ‘go round by’ [Zuo]; ‘go up against a stream’ 洄 [Shi]. Also written 迴徊. Downer (1959: 285) reads ‘go around, go by way of’ in tone C which implies an ‘effective’ meaning.  ||  [C] Allofams are → guī3 歸 ‘return’; → wéi6 違 ‘turn against’ from which huí is derived.  ||  [E] Many CH and TB words for ‘round, turn’ look similar. Most have initial *w- and foreign final -n, -l, -r, or -i, and therefore they are difficult to sort out, so that Bodman, Karlgren, Wáng Lì and other investigators have connected them in different ways. The merger of earlier final *-l and *-r into either OC *-n or *-i makes it impossible at the moment to find a rational way of associating foreign with OC items:   ||  (1) OC *-wan > MC rime -uan, -jwɐn / -jwän < OC *-uan, *-wan, *-on can derive from earlier ST or foreign -wan, -war, -wal, -(w)on, -(w)or, -(w)ol; given the latitude of sound correspondences, the vowels could in some words even have been e or u, beside a and o. See → yuán5 員圓圜, → yuán7 園, → huán1 桓垸, → huán3 還, huán 環鐶寰 (under → yíng4 營).  ||  (2) OC *-wən or *wun  MC rime -uən / -jwən < OC *-un / *-wən can derive from earlier ST or foreign -un, -wun, -wən, -ul, -wul, -wəl, -ur, wur, -wər; given i ~ u interchanges when in contact with labials, the foreign rime could also have been -win, -wil, -wir. See → yún5 雲, → yùn2 運暈   ||  (3) OC *-wəi or *-wui  MC rime -uậi / -jwei < OC *-wəi or *-(w)ui  can derive from earlier ST or foreign -ui, -wui, -wəi, -ul, -wul, -wəl, rarely also from -ur, wur, -wər. See → huí 回 (above), → wéi6 違, → guī3 歸; → wéi5 圍, → wèi7 衛   ||  (4) Unusual (‘marked’) rimes can be associated with outside cognates somewhat more confidently:  ||  OC *-weŋ See → yíng4 營, → yǒng7 禜; and → yíng5 縈, → yīng4 嬰  ||  OC *-win See → jūn2 鈞  ||  TB languages have additional words of this general shape and meaning, often with initial k. This k complicates the process of etymological identification even further because it may or may not have been a removable element, like a prefix. Such items include: (1) Lushai kuaiᴸ / kɔiɁᴸ ‘bend, pull down’, WB kweᴮ ‘bend around’. (2) Lushai kualᴸ ‘coil’, WB kʰweᴮ. (3) Lushai kulᴴ / kulɁᴸ ‘be bent’. (4) Lushai kʰɔɔrR ‘double up, roll up’ (→ quán3 卷拳?). (5) WT ’kʰor ‘circle, turn’, Lepcha var, vor, note also AA-Khmer vāra /wíiər/ ‘go around, circle, revolve’. (6) Lushai inᴸ-kʰerɁᴸ ‘twisted together’. (7) Lushai hrual ‘roll up in the hand’ ? ᛝ Lepcha rol ‘roll’.  ||  Furthermore, note AA: PVM *veːl ‘return’ ᛝ *k-veːl ‘village’, Bru kəwir ‘to stir’ [Huffman 1975: 13].
‘Be awry, crooked, perverse’ [Shi].

‘Snake’ 虺 [Shi], 虫 [OB, SW, Shanhaijing], ‘reptile-amphibian’ [Western Han] (Yates EC 19, 1994: 91 [apparently not ‘insect’]). Since 虫 is a basic graph, the word must be very old.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *b-ruːl (STC no. 447) > WT sbrul < s-mrul?, PLB *m-r-wiy¹ [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 1338] > WB mrwe ‘snake’, KN *m-ruul, Lushai ruulᴴ < ruul (Shī Xiàngdōng 2000: 196), Chepang ru ‘snake’. MC xjweiᴮ is a regular equivalent for TB / ST protoforms like *s-mrul, *Ɂmrul or *hmrul. As to foreign initial b- for CH m-, see §5.12.2. MK-PWa *mɔy ‘cobra’ looks like a loan from a LB language. The syn. and ordinary word → shé2 蛇 ‘snake’, lit. ‘the winding thing’, is due to taboo (see → hǔ1 虎 ‘tiger’ for another tabooed animal).

‘To join, come together’ (two rivers, people) [Shi] > caus. ‘to bring together, join’ [BI, Shi]. → huì2 會 ‘lid’ is a late semantic extension.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɣuj (去); MGZY Xue (去) [Ɣuɛ];  MTang guɑi, ONW ƔuɑC  ||  [<] endopass. of guì 會襘 (kuâiᶜ) (§4.6).  ||  [E] This group is derived from → kuò1 括 *kot or *kwat (Sagart 1999: 56). The basic ST meaning seems to be: put arms / belt / band around something and connect / tie it. The three unrelated etyma → hé5 合 *gə̂p, → hé8 盍蓋 *gâp, and huì 會 *gwâts have partially converged in OC.

‘Keep together (hair)’ tr. 會 [Shi], ‘bind up hair in a knot’ 嬉 [Yili] (also MC Ɣuât; also written with the phonetic of → kuò1 括); (adding up:) ‘calculation, account’ 會 [Li] (Karlgren 1956: 10); ‘joining point of the two ends of a collar or belt’ 襘 [Zuo] (Wáng Lì 1982: 487).

‘Lid, cover’ [Yili].  ||  [E] This is a late [Yili] semantic extension from → huì1 會 ’join, come together’, formed in analogy to the common association of ‘join’ with ‘close, lid’ in the wfs → hé5 合 and → hé8 盍蓋. The former hé5 合 *gəp is related to PTB *kup (hence PCH *gup > *guəp > *gəp), the latter hé8 盍蓋 to PTB *gap (hence PCH, OC *gap). There is no ST, AA or PCH simplex *gop from which huì might have been derived.
‘To understand’ [Tang], later ‘can’, aux. vb. expressing potentiality (Norman 1988: 125).

‘Can’, aux. vb. expressing potentiality [Tang], later replaced by the above huì. It is not clear if this and the above word are variants or cognates, but their similarity is suggestive. This word survives in M-Jiànyáng haiᶜ, Fúzhōu aᶜ², Xiàmén ueᶜ².

‘To present, assign, valuables, dowry’ [BI, Shi]. The earlier phonetic was měi 每 *mə̂Ɂ, hence the OCM form (Schuessler 1987: 257; Baxter 1992: 352), but the word might have changed to *hwəɁ under the influence of yòu 侑 *wəh ‘to offer’ (under → yǒu2 有).
‘To instruct’ [BI, Shi] is related to → mǔ3 姆 ‘teacher’.    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR xuj (去); MGZY hue (去) [xuɛ]  ||  [E] ST: PL *s-ma² ‘to teach’; CVST 1: 26 adds WT smo-ba, smos ‘to say’.

‘Be dark, darkness’ (of sky, clouds) > metaphorical ‘dark’ [Shi], ‘night time’ (vs. míng 明 ‘day time’) [Guoyu], ‘last day of the lunar month’ [Chunqiu].
