Shījīng rimes indicate tone B (Mattos 1971: 309).  ||  [E] Prob. MK: OKhmer kmval /kmuuəl/ ‘be cloudy, overcast, dark, beclouded, be as black as a cloud’. For the absence of final *-l in CH after a MK long vowel, see §6.9. Since the word refers primarily to meteorological and natural conditions, and seems to be related to a synonymous and (mutatis mutandis) homophonous MK etymon, it is prob. not related to ST → méi9 煤 ‘soot’, → hēi 黑 ‘black’, → mén3 悶 ‘unconsciously’. A cognate is prob. → hǎi1 海 ‘ocean’.

‘Category, class’ [Yi], ‘numerous’ [Shi]. If related to → lèi2 類, this may perh. be a form which has treated the initial *r as a prefix and dropped it (§10.1.3). The same graph huì also writes → huì9 彙 ‘porcupine’ which has possibly a similar variant in the initial.

‘Porcupine’ [SW]. The same graph also writes a word → huì8 彙 ‘category’ which is perh. a variant of a word with initial l-: → lèi2 類 (§10.1.3).  ||  [E] Perhaps from MK *[r]kus, *[r]kuus, *[r]kuəs, *[r]k[iə]s ‘porcupine’ (Shorto 2006 #1883; p.33) >  Lushai kuɁᴸ < kus ‘porcupine, quill of a p.’ In CH the foreign initial k was perhaps ignored as a prefix. Cantonese has the curious form lœyᶜ² (Bodman 1980: 89).

‘Beard of chin’ 顪 [Zhuang], GY also: ‘jiá 頰 jaw, cheek’; ‘snout’ 喙 [Zuo; JDSW xjwɐiᶜ], ‘mouth’ [SW] (the last graph has additional readings which prob. belong to the meaning ‘to pant’). For MC x-, see §5.6. The meanings of these homophonous graphs slide gradually into each other (‘jaw’ written with ‘beard’), therefore this seems to be one etymon, although ‘beard’ might have entered OC via KT (note the identical meanings), while ‘snout’ might have been inherited from ST, unless it is a TB loan. For semantics, note that a ‘schnauzer’ is not noted for its snout (which all dogs have), but for its striking mustache.  ||  [E] KT: S. nuatᴰ¹ᴸ < *hn- ‘beard’ which appears to have come ultimately from some Burmese-like TB lg.: WB hnut ‘mouth, womb’, used in composits for ‘beard’. Since there is no hint of a nasal initial in OC, Tai is unlikely to have been the borrower. Huì seems to be related in a roundabout way to → xū4 須鬚, see there for more TB cognates.

‘Relations by marriage, wife, in-laws’ [BI, Shi]; ‘wife’s father’ [EY, Zuo], ‘wife’s family’ [SW]; hūn-yīn 婚姻 ‘relatives’ [Shi], ‘marriage’ [Li]. Wáng Lì (1982: 508) quotes from Han-period literature: ‘wedding’ is called hūn because the ceremony takes place at dusk hūn 昏 (under → mén3 悶) [SW, Shiming, Baihu tong], but this looks like a folk etymology. One may speculate instead that hūn ‘dark’ signifies ‘female’, like its synonym → yīn5 陰 ‘dark’.

‘Spiritual soul’ [Zuo] as opposed to → pò4 魄 ‘animal soul’. Since pò is the ‘bright’ soul, hún is the ‘dark’ soul and therefore cognate to → yún5 雲 ‘cloud’ (Carr, CAAAL 24, 1985: 62), perhaps in the sense of ‘shadowy’ because some believe that the hún soul will live after death in a world of shadows (Wolfram Eberhard Guilt and Sin in ancient China, 1967: 17).
‘Chaos’ 混 [Lao], ‘muddled, confused’ 渾 [Lao], ‘abundantly flowing’ 混 [Meng] (some commentators also read LH kuənᴮ 混).
‘Disturbed, troubled by’ [Zuo] > ‘troubled, disorderly’ 溷 [Chuci] > ‘suffer, grief’ 慁 [Guoce].
‘Sound of running water’ [Xun], ‘chaotic’ [Zhuang]. A variant is apparently → hóng3 訌 LH goŋ ‘disorderly, trouble’.

‘Be distressed’ [Shu], ‘distress, exhaust’ [Zuo], ‘fatigue’ [Li].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR k'un (去); MGZY khun (去) [k'un]; ONW kʰon  ||  [E] Perh. related to Mand. kùn 睏 ‘sleepy’. Alternatively, this word may be derived from → kùn1 困 ‘obstruct’ [Yi], as emotions are often expressed by concrete notions, but this is not likely in light of hùn 溷慁 above. HST: 63 related this word to WT kʰur ‘burden, load’. A further cognate may be → jiǒng4 窘 in which case this and the doublet of hún point to a PCH final *-uŋ.

‘To keep alive, life’ [Shi] has prob. nothing to do with ‘moist’ (so GSR 302m) because this graph with the water radical was prob. intended to write guō 活 (kuât) LH kuɑt ‘to purl’ (as running water) [Shi]. The etymology is possibly AA: Wa-Lawa-Bulang *gɑs ‘alive’ (of plants), Aslian languages gɔs ‘to live’.
‘Fire’ [OB, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR xwɔ (上); MGZY hwo (上) [xwɔ]; ONW huɑ

This is a Han-period dialect word for ‘fire’ in Wú 吳 [Xù Fāngyán p:4]. See also → huī6 墮隳.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *mey (STC no. 290) > WT me, OTib. smye; Chepang hmeɁ; PLB *Ɂmey² [Matisoff], PL *C-mi²  [Bradley], WB miᴮ, Lushai meiR < meiɁ. The relationship with → huī6 墮隳, if any, is not clear (dialect? convergence?).
‘Many’, an old Han-period dial. word in the outlying areas of Qí and Sòng and in the region between Chǔ and Wèi [FY 1.21]. It survives in Mǐn dialects: PMin *oiᶜ ~ *uaiᴮ  ‘many’ (Norman 1983: 204).
‘To deceive, delusion, doubt’ [Lun]. Etymology not clear.
‘To bind’ [Zhuang].  ||  [E] ST: WT ’grogs-pa ‘to bind, fasten, tie, be associated with’ ᛝ grogs ‘friend, associate’ (HST p. 42).
‘To reap, cut, harvest’ [Shi], Mand. also ‘capture’.
‘To catch, take, hit, succeed’ [Shi].
‘A trap’ [Shu] – an early general tone C derivation of the above (§3.5).   ||  [C] This wf may be related to → jué12 攫.

‘Be hungry, starve, hunger, famine’ [Shi].  — [T] ONW ki  — [D] PMin *kue  ||  [E] ST: WT bkres ‘be hungry’, JP kyet³¹ ‘hungry’, Lepcha krít, Chepang kray- ‘to hunger’, Mru krai (Löffler 1966: 148). A possible allofam is → jìn6 饉殣 ‘famine’.
‘Famine’ 饑饉 [Shi]. This word is distinct from jī above (Wáng Lì 1958: 550); for the difference in vowel,  see §11.7.1-2.
‘To draw water’ [Yi].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *kaːp (STC no. 336): PLB *C-kap, WB kʰap ‘dig up, draw water’; Garo ko ‘draw water’; Dimasa kʰau ‘pluck, gather, draw’ (water) (HST: 66).

‘Odd (number) 奇 [Yi], 畸 [Xun]; ‘unique, irregular’ 奇 [Li].  ||  [E] This seems to be a ST etymon: WB kʰai- < kaiᴮ ‘remarkable’ (obsolete).   ||  [C] An allofam is prob. → jǐ3 掎 ‘pull aside’. Because of the  occasional *-ai ~ *-e vacillation in wfs (§11.3.3), → qǐ5 企跂 ‘stand on tiptoe’ may also be related.
‘Strange, extraordinary’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR gi (平); MGZY ki (平) [gi]

‘Foundation, base, settlement’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjej (平), PR, LR ki; MGZY gi (平) [ki];   ||  [N] This can hardly be related to the TB items under → jǐ 几机, nor to Lushai keᴸ ‘foot, leg, wheel’ (→ zhī4 支枝肢) because the vowels are different.
‘Winnowing basket’ [OB, Shi]. Unger (Hao-ku 38, 1992: 79) relates this word to lí 梩 (lji) ‘basket’ [Meng] and suggests a possible connection with → qǐ2 杞 ‘willow’.

‘Chicken, fowl’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjej (平), PR, LR ki; MGZY gÿi (平) [kji]; ONW kėi,  ||  [D] PMin *kei, K-Méixiàn kaiᴬ¹. A Han dialect form of the Chén-Chǔ-Sòng area was zhī 切 (kjie 4) [kie] [FY 8, 4].  ||  [E] Area word; since its origin is onomatopoetic, phonological correspondences are not regular: PTai *kəiᴮ¹ ‘chicken’ (Li F. 1976: 42), PKS *kaːi⁵, Kadai *kiᴬ. <> PMY *kai  (Downer 1982) <> PVM *r-ka ‘chicken’ (on the vocalism, see §11.1.3).

‘To collect, accumulate’ [Shi] > ‘to block’ [Zhuang].  ||  [E] ST: WT rtseg-pa ‘to put on top, pile up, stack’. Sagart (1999: 214) suggests that possibly → cè4 冊策筴 ‘bamboo slips > document’ is related. Perh. related to → zī7 資.
‘To collect, store, wealth’ [Shi] > ‘provisions’ [Zuo].  ||  [<] exopass. derivation (§4.4), perh. also the verbal meanings (‘be heaped’?).

‘To twist, spin’ (to make thread) [Shi] > ‘achievement, result’ [Shu] is perh. an s-iterative of → xì1 係繫 *keh ‘bind, tie up’ (§5.2.3), with final -k (§6.1); yet PCH *s-k- is expected to yield MC kʰ-.
‘To ascend, rise, the mist rises’ [ Shi].
‘To lift, disappear’ (of clouds), ‘clearing sky’ 霽 [OB, Shu] > ‘to stop’ 濟 (of wind) [Zhuang], (of thoughts) [Shi].
‘Carry a vessel to the lips’ [Shu].   ||  [C] A possible allofam could be → jì16 懠 ‘angry’.

‘Be imminent, close to, near, at imminent risk’ [Shi, Shu], ‘first sign of happenings, details’ 幾 [Shi, Shu]; ‘auspicious, omen of good or evil’ 禨 [Lie]. Karlgren (1933: 28) relates this word to → jìn1 近 ‘near’.
‘Border’ (on garment) 幾 [Li], ‘threshold, royal domain’ 畿 [Shi]. Prob. not related to → jī12 幾 ‘close to’ as Karlgren believed (1956: 10).
‘Border, a field of a certain size (1,000 sq. li)’ 圻 [Zuo]. → qí2 祈 is cognate or the same word.

‘Mechanical device’ 機 [Zhuang], 璣 [Shu]. Karlgren (1956: 5) considered this the s. w. as → jī12 幾 which is glossed as ‘small’, but jī 幾 really means ‘be imminent, close to, first sign, detail’. Instead, jī is perh. cognate to → qǐ7 綮, thus meaning originally a contraption with hinges or joints, i.e. with moveable parts.

‘Reach to’ [BI, Zhuang], ‘search, research, examine, comprehend’ [Shu], ‘calculate’ [Li]; ‘divine by tortoise-shell’ 葉 [SW: Shu]; zhī 支 (tśie) [kie] ‘to calculate’ [Da Dai Liji] is prob. a variant if not simply a graphic loan.
‘To calculate’ [Zuo]. OCB is based on the assumption that shí 十  *gip is phonetic.
‘Examine, inspect’ [Meng] > ‘blame’ [Zuo].
‘Beat, strike’ (a musical instrument, object) [Shi].
‘Carriages knocking against each other’ [Zhouli].
‘Beat, rub’ [Zhouli].

‘To come to, reach to, together with, and’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR gi (入); MGZY ki (入) [gi]; ONW gip.   ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ²²kʰɐpᴰ²  ||  [E] This word could be connected either with WB kʰap ‘arrive at’, JP kʰap⁵¹ to carry, reach’ (CVST 5: 50). Or, less likely, with WT ’grub-pa, grub ‘to make ready’ ᛝ sgrub-pa, bsgrubs ‘to complete, achieve’ ᛝ grub-pa ‘complete’.   ||  [C] Items under → jì4 暨 could be tone C derivations (Yú Mǐn 1948: 45; Baxter 1992: 351), but see there.
‘Auspicious, lucky, positive’ [OB, BI, Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT skyid-pa ‘happy’ (HST: 87).
is in some southern dialects the second syllable in the word for ‘ear’: Y-Dōngguǎn ŋɐi¹³-kɐk⁴⁴ 耳吉, K-Dōngguǎn ²¹gi-²²kit.
‘To run robustly, straight, unswerving’ (of horses) [Shi].
‘To straighten the neck’ (of birds) (meaning not certain) [Shi].

‘Highest point, ridge of a roof, extreme, reach the end, come to, attain’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR gi (入); MGZY ki (入) [gi]; ONW gik  ||  [E] ST: PLB *kak ‘expensive, intense, at its peak’ (Matisoff 1972: 31; STC: 166 n. 444).
‘Be urgent’ [Shi]; ‘to die’ [Li], ‘execute, kill’ 殛 [Shu]. This word is prob. not a variant of → jí12 急 (kjəp) ‘be urgent’ (as is sometimes suggested).

‘Be sick, suffering, defect, evil’ [OB, Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dzi (入); MGZY tsi (入) [dzi]; ONW dzit  ||  [E] ST *tsik ‘to smolder’ > ‘burn’ / ‘be ill, illness’ / ‘anger’, PTB *m-(t)sik ‘burn, angry’ [HPTB], WT ’tsʰig-pa ‘to burn, destroy by fire, glow; to be in rut, be inflamed, feverish’ (Bodman 1980: 158); perh. Chepang ɉik- ‘be sick, injured, hurt’. Prob. not related to jì 癠 ‘sick’ (under → jǐ5 擠). Less likely comparanda: WT sdig-pa ‘sin, wickedness’ (Bodman 1980: 158). AA items look somewhat similar: PBahn. *ɉiɁ, Wa-Lawa-Palaung *siɁ ‘sick’. STC (170 n. 455) relates this word to PTB *tsa ‘hot, pain’, but the vowels differ (i vs. a), see → zāi1 災.
‘Detest’ [Shu] (Karlgren GSR 923c), ‘to hate’ 疾 [Shu].  ||  [E] ST *tsik: WT tsʰig-pa ‘anger, indignation’; LB-Lahu yˆɨɁ, Motuo Monpa ro tsik ‘angry’ [HPTB: 344f].
‘Be jealous’ [Chuci].
‘Coaled part of burning torch, to burn or scorch earth...’ [Guanzi].

‘To approach, go to, apply’ > ‘on the point of’ [BI, Shi, Shu]; jí-wèi 即位 ‘to take one’s place, seat, ascend the throne’ [BI].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tsi (入); MGZY dzi (入) [tsi]  ||  [E] MK: Khmer jita /cit/, OKhmer jit /ɉit/ ‘to be near to, to the point of, be close’ ᛝ bhjita /pcit/ ‘to bring near, draw up (a chair), to set (two things together), join, attach, to apply’.
‘Be close to’ [Xun], ‘eager, impatient’ [Lun]. 切 also writes a homophone which is cognate to → jié9 節.

‘Familiarity’ [Shu], (a ruler’s) ‘favorite’ (person) [Shu]. The homophones → nì2 昵 ‘glue’ and → nì4 衵 ‘underwear’ are prob. not related.  ||  [E] MK: Khmer jaṃnita /cumnit/ (i.e. etymologically ɉ-n-it) ‘nearness, closeness, proximity, familiarity with, intimacy’. The AA nominal n-infix is taken in CH for the root initial, perh. because of the original voiced initial and the paronomastic attraction to → ěr7 邇 (ńźieᴮ) ‘near’. The CH words jí and nì are thus allofams in an AA wf.  ||  [C] A possible allofam could be → qīn5 親. Syn. are → ěr7 邇, → ní1 尼, → nì9 暱.
‘Masonry’ [Li]; however, the traditional gloss ‘masonry’ is spurious (Pulleyblank 1999: 166), therefore there is no connection with WT rtsig-pa ‘to wall up, a wall, masonry’ (Bodman 1980: 158).
‘Jujube, thorns’ [Shi] is written in a Shījīng variant as:
‘Be urgent, hurrying’ [Shi], ‘hasty, distress’ [Zuo] is not a variant of jí 亟 (kjək) ‘be urgent’ (under → jí5 極). Etymology not clear.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ki (入); MGZY gi (入) [ki]; ONW kip

‘Come together and settle (of birds), perch’ [Shi] > caus. ‘to collect together, unite, settle, achieve’ 集 [BI, Shi], 輯 [Shi].  ||  [E] MK: Khmer cwpa /cùuəp/ ~ jwpa /cúuəp/ ‘to join’, intr. ‘to meet, come together, encounter’ ᛝ prajcwpa ‘to meet one another’. <> The following is prob. a different etymon with the basic meaning ‘close’: PTB *tsup > PLB *tsup ~ *Ɂtsup [Matisoff 1972: 40] > WB cʰup ‘clench fist’, Kachin tsup ‘to gather’ (as mouth of sack), ‘close hands’ (as in catching a ball) (HST: 84). KN-Lai fuu / fuut ‘to perch’ [LTBA 21.1: 18].   ||  [C] This wf has perh. converged with → jì10 揖. Baxter (1992: 350) adds cuì 萃 (dzwiᶜ) ‘collect’ (under → zāo2 遭).
‘Brought together, mixed’ [Shi], ‘variegated’ [Li] (Karlgren 1956: 13).
‘Spine’ [Li] > ‘fundamental principle, reason’ [Shi].
‘Emaciated’ [Yi] > ‘meagre, poor’ (soil) [Guoce] > ‘suffering’ 瘠 [Shu]; 膌 [Guan] (Karlgren 1956: 10). Perh. → zì3 胔 ‘bones with meat on’ is cognate.

‘Walk with small steps’ [Shi]. This may be the same etymon as → jí16 踖, see §11.3.2.  ||  [E] This is a vocalic variant of → jí16 踖 (§11.3.2). The same doublets are found in ‘footprint, track’ → jì21 蹟 which may be cognate.
‘Trample, oppress’ [Zhuang] (Karlgren 1956: 10).
‘To trample’ [Lie].

‘Walk reverently’ [Lunyu]. This may be the same etymon as → jí15 蹐, see §11.3.2.  ||  [E] ST *tsjak: WT ’čʰags-pa, bčags ‘to tread, walk, move’. Perh. also connected with MK *jak ‘to tread, step out, set out’ (Shorto 2006 #301): Semai /jak/, ‘to trample’, WrMon jak ‘to march, travel’, Sre jaʔ ‘to tread on, trample’ (‘j’ = dž, ‘c’ = tš).  ||  The ST medial *-ia- (*-ja-) explains the *tsiak ~ *tsek doublets (→ jí15 蹐; §11.3.2). The same doublets are found in ‘footprint, track’ → jì21 蹟 which may be cognate.
‘To trample’ [Li].
‘Reverent demeanor, do with attentive movements’ [Shi].

‘To cultivate’ (field, garden, rice) [OB, Zuo] > ‘perform the ploughing ceremony’ [OB] > ‘sacred field’ 藉 [SW] (Bodde 1975: 231ff) > ‘register of field revenues’ 籍 [Shi] > ‘a record, writing tablet’ 籍 [Zuo].  ||  [E] MK *jiik, *jiək ‘break ground for cultivation’ (Shorto 2006 #300): OMon jik ‘to harrow, break up for planting, to cultivate’; Old Khmer jyak ‘to dig, dig over’, (Palaungic) Praok ciak ‘to dig, break ground by digging’. Occasionally, we find OC *a for foreign e or i, see §11.1.3.
‘To row’ [Shi], ‘oar’ occurs also in JP šap < tšap ‘oar’ (Benedict HJAS 5, 1940: 111 no. 59).

‘Stool, small table’ 几 [Shi], 机 [Zuo, Li].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *kriy (STC no. 38) > PL *kre¹ > WB kʰre ‘foot, leg’ ᛝ ə-kʰre ‘foundation, foot’, WT kʰri ‘seat, chair, throne, couch’ (HST: 54), Lepcha hri ‘chair’. <> AA-Khmer grē /krɛɛ/ ‘bed, bench’ could be a loan from some ST language, perh. OC (so Pou / Jenner, J. of Oriental Studies 11, 1973.1: 1-90).
‘Self’, reflexive personal pronoun [Lun].  — Etymology not clear.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjej (上), PR, LR ki; MGZY gi (上) [ki]

‘Pull by one leg’ [Zuo], ‘pull aside’ [Shi]; ‘stand around close to door’ 踦 [Gongyang].  ||  [E] ST: WB kai ‘oblique, sidewise’ (Matisoff 1995a: 84). An allofam is prob. → jī4 奇 ‘odd’, also possibly → jì5 癩 ‘stand’, and → qǐ5 企跂 ‘stand on tiptoe’ which has, however, a different OC rime (*-e).
‘Slanting’ [Xun, also MC kjie 3]; ‘one-footed’ 踦 [Guoyu]; ‘one horn turning up, one down’ 觭 [Yi].

‘Muntjac’ 麂 [post-Zhou-Han]; acc. to GY, 勉 [OB] writes the same word.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *d-kiy (STC no. 54): PL *kye’ ‘barking deer’; WB khye, gyiᴬ ‘barking deer’, JP tʃə³³-kʰji³³ ‘muntjac’, kʰyi¹-maɁ¹ ‘a kind of muntjac’, Lushai saᴴ-khiᴸ < -kʰiɁ/h ‘barking deer’.

‘To push’ [Zuo], ‘urge, press, press out’.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *tsyir ~ *tsyur ‘squeeze, wring’ (HPTB: 397): WT ’tsʰir-ba ‘to press, press out’ (Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 33); Bahing tśyur ‘wring’, Kanauri tsŭr ‘to milk’.    ||  [E] Alternatively, the OC stem may derive from earlier *st(ə)i in light of the possible allofam dǐ 抵 (tieiᴮ) [teiᴮ] ‘push away’ [Dadai Liji].
‘Disease’ [Li], ‘suffer’ (Unger) < ‘be pressed’ ?  ||  [E] TB-WT gzir-ba ‘be pressed, troubled, suffer’ (Unger). Prob. not related to → jí6 疾 ‘sick’, but a possibleallofam could be → jì16 懠.
‘Many’ [Shi] (Baxter 1992: 462).
‘Large number’ [Shi].

‘Few, how many’ [Shi]. Karlgren (1956: 7) considers this cognate to → jī12 幾 which is glossed as ‘small’, but jī 幾 really means ‘be imminent, close to, first sign, detail’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjej (上), PR, LR ki; MGZY gi (上) [ki]; ONW ki  ||  [E] <> PTai *kiiᶜ ‘several, how many’ > S. kiiᴮ¹ (B is irregular), Saek kii³; prob. borrowed from CH together with the numerals.

‘Louse’ [Hanfei] is also an old dialect word for ‘leech’, still used in Mǐn (Norman 1983) which is prob. related to the old dialect words mǎ-qí 馬蜞 or 馬耆 ‘leech’.  ||  This is prob. derived from a ST etymon ‘to bite’, note KN *m-kei ‘to bite’; for a semantic parallel, see → zhì2 蛭 ‘leech’ and → dié2 咥 ‘bite’.

‘A small and weak woman’ [SW] (物 wù ‘thing’ in the SW gloss is thought to be an error for 弱 ruò ‘weak’), perh. a euphemism for the later attested meaning ‘singing girl, prostitute’ [Jinshu, i.e. post-Han]. A hypothetical OC form may have been *kre.  ||  [E] This appears to be a loan from early Vietnamese (the ancient Yuè in southern China): MK-PVM *keːɁ ‘woman’ > Viet. cái / gái ‘feminine’ [Ferlus]; elsewhere in MK: PWa *krih ‘girl’, PNBahn. *kadrì ‘female’ [K. Smith 1972: 64]. Alternatively, Wáng Lì (1982: 108) following earlier commentaries relates this word to jì 技 (gjeᴮ) ‘skill’, but this may be folk etymology. Also other foreign words for ‘girl, woman’ refer to a someone of low standing, see → bì 嬖, → tái3 嬯臺.

‘To complete, have done’, mark of completed action [OB, BI, Shi, Shu].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjej (去), PR, LR ki; MGZY gi (去) [ki]; ONW ki  ||  [<] exopass. (perfective) of qì 訖 (kjət) ‘to finish’ (§4.4); the perfect is implied in the passive meaning of tone C. Perh. cognate to → jì4 暨 ‘to reach’, but see there.  ||  [E] ST (?): Mru ki ‘complete’ (Löffler 1966: 129).
‘To finish, cease’ [Shu].

‘To reach to, bring with, concur with, together with, and’ [Shu].   ||  [<] exoactive ? of → jí1 及 (gjəp) (Baxter 1992: 351). Or less likely ᛝ → qì3 迄 (xjət), → jì3 既 (kjəiᶜ) (the MC vowels do not agree).
‘To stand’, has replaced → lì3 立 in southern dialects: Xiàmén kʰiaᶜ², Fúzhōu kʰieᶜ², Jiàn’ōu kyɛᴮ² (Norman 1988: 197). Perh. related to → jǐ3 掎 in the sense of ‘standing around’.
‘To commit to one’s charge’ [Lun], ‘entrust to, communicate’ [Li], Mand. ‘send’ (a letter).  ||  [E] ? ST: perh. cognate to WB khaiᶜ ‘to bring’, Lushai kʰaiᴸ ‘to give a present’.

‘To warn, detest’ 惎 [Zuo], 誋 [SW] > (‘be warned’:) ‘cautious’ [Shi], ‘show respect for’ [Zuo], ‘taboo’ 忌 [Zhouli] > ‘dread, hate’ 忌 [Shi]. Wáng Lì (1982: 86) relates this word to → jiè9 戒誡 ‘guard against’.

‘Leading thread, regulate’ [Shi], ‘follow up, continue’ [Shu]. Unger (Hao-ku 38, 1992: 77) relates this word to WT ’kʰrid-pa, bkri ‘to conduct acc. to order’ [Das] ᛝ kʰrid ‘row, order, serial order’ [Das]; and to → lǐ5 理 (ljiᴮ) ‘regulate’.
‘To record, remember’ [Shu].
‘Youngest, young’ (of persons) [BI, Shi] > ‘last of a series’ [Zuo], ‘season, three-month period’ [Tang period]  — [E] Etymology not clear.   ||  [D] PMin *kieᶜ ~ *kyiᶜ ‘season’
‘To cluster together, to crowd’ [Shi].

‘To gather up’ 輯 [Li]; ‘to fold up, gather in’ (wings) 戢 [Shi]; ‘be crowded together’ (as horns of sheep) 濈  [Shi].  ||  [E] ? AA: PMonic *cap, Nyah Kur ‘(bird) to settle on, perch’, Mon *cɔp ‘to adhere to, cleave to’; OKhmer /ɉap/ ‘touch, join, meet, cling, adhere’.  ||  This word has perh. converged with → jí13 集輯. Perh. → zhí7 蟄 (ḍjəp) ‘cluster together, hibernate’ belongs here.
‘A kind of millet’ (Panicum miliaceum, not glutinous).  ||  [E] Perh. TB-WB cʰap ‘millet’ (Luce, Sagart 2002 ms: 8).
‘To hope’ 冀 [Zuo]; ‘to long for’ 覬 [Zuo] is prob. cognate to → xī12 希睎 (so Wáng Lì 1982: 393).  ||  [E] Perh. ST: WT bkri-ba ‘try to acquire, search for’ (CVST 5: 66).
‘To ford, to cross’ (a river) vb. [Shi] > ‘to help across, help over’ (e.g. difficulties) [Shu] > ‘to help’ (people) [Lunyu], ‘contribute’ [Zuo], ‘achieve’ [Yi].

‘A ford’ n. [Shu].   ||  [<] nominal n-suffix derivative from jì ‘to ford’ (§6.4.3).  ||  [E] MK: Mon inscr. cnis [cnøs] > cnih ‘a ghat, place of access to river..., landing place’ < n-infix nominalization of cis [cøs] ‘to go down, descend’ vb. (e.g. down the bank to the river, also general). The Mon vowel is closer to CH than the Khmer cognate: cuḥ [cuh] ‘go down’, perh. also Viet. xìu [sìu] < ž- ‘go down’. Thus both Mon and OC derived a noun from the verb with a nominalizing affix, Mon with the MK n-infix > cnis ‘ghat’, OC with the ST n-suffix jīn 津 ‘a ford’. Perh. → xī2 西栖 ‘nest, west’ belongs to this wf. The ST syn. for ‘ford, cross’ is → dù2 渡.

‘Angry’ [Shi]. Etymology not certain. The notion ‘angry’ can derive from ‘rise’ (cf. Mand. qǐ 起), hence perh. cogn. to → jī11 隮 ‘rise’. Or jì could derive from ‘sick’ and be related to jì 癠 (under → jǐ5 擠).

‘Footprint, track’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [N] In Han and Wei-Jin poetry these two words rime in *-ek  (Luo / Zhou 1958; Ting 1975), but *tsiak occurs in Shījīng. See §11.3.2. The root initial was OCM *j- as the phonetic of 跡 (GSR 800) and TB cognates indicate (§9.2); a ST medial *-ja- (*-ia-) explains the OC *-iak ~ *-ek doublets. Possible allofams are → jí15 蹐 and → jí16 踖 ‘walk, step’, prob. as a result of paronomastic attraction.  ||  [E] ST *C-jak: TB-Limbu yok² ‘trace, track’, Lushai hniakᴴ ‘footprint, hoof-mark’.
‘Footprint, track’ [Shu] (also written with radical 162).
‘To continue, perpetuate’ [Shi] is the s. w. as xì 係繫 *keh (under → xì 系繫 *geh).
‘To add, attach, hit’ [Shi].

‘To yoke’ [Shi].  ||  [<] exopass. of jiā: ‘be attached to’ (§4.4).  ||  [E] ST *kral: WT bkral-ba ‘to impose, place upon’ (tax), ‘appoint to’ ᛝ kʰral ‘tax, burden’ (HST: 36). WB kaᶜ ‘to harness, saddle’ is apparently a CH loan.

‘Be good, fine, excellent > consider fine, approve’ [Shi], ‘happy’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] ST: This word is prob. shared with TB, although the rimes do not agree: WT bkra-ba ‘beautiful, blooming’, bkra-šis ‘happiness, prosperity, blessing’ (šis ‘good luck, fortune, bliss’); Lushai ṭʰaᴸ / ṭʰatᴸ < tʰraah / ṭʰrat ‘be good, nice, virtuous, be advantageous’.
‘Be good’ [Lao] appears to be a vocalic variant of the above.
‘To congratulate’ [Shi] (Karlgren 1949: 90 derives this word from gě next).
‘Be well, passable, suitable’ [Shi]. Alternatively, gě may belong to kě 可 (under → hè 何荷) (so Wáng Lì 1982: 431).

‘Be on both sides’ [Shi], ‘support’ [Shu], ‘press between’ [Zuo], ‘tweezers’ [Zhouli].  ||  [E] Area word: PMY *nGep, PTai *g-: S. kʰɛɛpᴰ² (CH loans?). <> TB-JP lə⁵⁵-kap⁵⁵ ‘tweezers’. <> AA: Mon inscr. sakep /səkep/ ‘tongs’.   ||  [C] → xiē1 脅 (xjɐp) ‘sides of body, ribs’ belongs to this root, as could → jié1, jiā 梜 ‘chopsticks’. Wáng Lì (1982: 597) proposes that synonyms under → xié1 挾協 are possibly related.
[T] ONW Ɣäp  — [D] PMin *h̯ap   ||  ‘Narrow’ [Li] (Karlgren 1949: 90).  ||  [<] endopass. of jiā 夾 (kăp) ( §4.6).

‘Grasp, hold’ [Shi]; ‘clasp under the arm, hold on to’ [Meng], ‘encompass, embrace, all round’ [Shi], 浹 [Zuo].  ||  [E] This word is prob. not related to the synonym → xié1 挾協 and the other stems listed there, because MC ts- rarely, if ever, derives from an earlier cluster *sk-.

‘House, household, family’ [OB: Sōrui p. 272; Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kja (平); MGZY gya (平) [kja]; ONW kä  ||  [E] ST: WT mkʰar ‘house, castle’. Beyer (1992: 114) includes the WT word in a wf ‘be penned up, be confined’.
‘To give a girl in marriage’ [Shi].  ||  [<] exoactive of jiā (§4.3) > ‘to marry’ (of a woman).  ||  [E] CH -> White Tai xaaᴮ¹ < *x- ‘id.’ (Li F. 1976: 40).

‘Male pig, boar’ [Zuo, SW]; a Northeastern dialect word for → zhū4 豬 [ṭɑ] *tra ‘pig’ [FY]. Given the homophone jiā ‘male deer’ [SW], this may be a more general etymon for ‘male’ of an animal and may also be cognate to → gǔ7 羖 ‘ram’ (so Wáng Lì 1982: 126). If SW is correct that 豭 is an abbreviated phonetic in → jiā7 家 *kra   ||  ‘house’, then the word must be much older than Zuǒzhuàn, while zhū may be an early dialect word.

‘Shell, (finger-)nail, armour’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kja (入); MGZY gya (入) [kja]; ONW käp    ||  [D] PMin *kɑp ~ *kap  ||  [E] ST: WT kʰrab ‘shield, fish scales’, Lepcha hróp (< *kʰrap) ‘armour, scales’  ‌(Bodman 1980: 142). Note also MK *krcaap ‘scales of fish’ (Shorto 2006 #1244a). The relationship with Tai: S. lepᴰ²S < *dl- ‘finger- or toenail’  ‌(Li F. 1976: 45) seems questionable. Jiǎ is prob. not related to → jiè1 介.
‘Leather jerkin or cuirass’ [Guan] (HST: 131).

‘Be great’ (of Heaven, rulers), ‘abundance’ [BI, Shi]. Wáng Lì (1982: 144) relates → xià5, shà 廈 ‘building’ to this wf.  ||  [E] Perh. related to → xián8 閑 ‘be large’ and → jiè2 介价 ‘increase’. Shī Xiàngdōng 2000: 27 relates this word to WT rgya ‘wide, broad’.
‘Be great’ (of ruler) [Shi].

‘To borrow’ [Zuo] > ‘simulate’ [Meng] > ‘deception, false’ [BI, Shi, Li].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kja (上); MGZY gya (上) [kja]; ONW kä  ||  [E] ST: WT kar-skyin ‘a loan’ (Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 32). An allofam is prob. →  gù7 雇.
‘Grain, to sow’ [Shi].  ||  [E] <> KT: PTai *klaᶜ¹ ‘young rice plant’ (Li F. 1976: 40), Saek tlaa³ > traa³ ‘rice seedlings’, PKS *kla³ ‘rice seedling’. The medials do not agree, see §7.3.

‘Price’ 賈 [Lunyu], 價 [Meng].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kja (去); MGZY gya (去) [kja]  ||  [E] ST: WB ə-kyaᶜ ‘price’; Lushai kʰaarR ‘to buy the whole, buy in large quantities’. <> Tai: Saek khaa⁵ < gaaᴮ ‘value, price’ ᛝ khaaﬂ < kʰaaᴮ ‘engage in trade’. CH -> P-Miao *ɴqaᶜ [Wáng Fushi 1979] ‘price’ (Sagart). Perh. related to → gǔ11 賈.

‘Pointed, sharp’ 尖 [GY], ‘thin, slender, sharp-pointed’ 鑯 [Zhouli].  ||  This word is prob. cognate to xiān below; or it might have been influenced by words for → zān 簪 ‘pin’; it is possibly related to 殲 ‘to cut down (people)’ [Shi] (Wáng Lì 1982: 616). See → yǎn4 剡覃 for the semantic association of ‘sharp’ with ‘cut’.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *syam > WB sa≥m, Gyarung śom ‘iron’, Nung śam ‘iron, sword’ (STC: 53). The wf → yǎn4 剡覃 represents a different stem (STC: 171 n. 457 relates xiān to PTB *s-ryam).
‘Sharp’ [Mo] has been borrowed by PTai *s-: S. siamᴬ¹ ‘spade, hoe’ ᛝ siamᶜ¹ ‘to sharpen to a point’.

‘Firm’ (e.g. fruit, bows), ‘solid, strong’ (e.g. ice) [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjen (平); MGZY gÿan (平) [kjɛn]; ONW kėn  ||  [E] ST *kin/ŋ: WB kyañ ‘feeling of numbness’, JP kyin ‘stiff, aching’ [Matisoff 1974 no. 15], Lushai kʰiŋF < kʰiŋɁ  ‘dry out, get hard’ (of ouside of meat etc.). For related and similar items, see → gù1 固 (incl. Table G-1) and Table J-1. See Table  J-1  Hard, congeal, dry (B)  →
‘Firmly believe’ tr. [Zhuang]. Aspiration as well as medial *r are unexplained, unless this is a different etymon related to AA-Mon kriŋ (krɔŋ) ‘stiff, hard’.
‘Solidly, earnestly’ [Shu].
‘Shoulder’ [Shi], ‘to shoulder, carry’ [Shu] is shared with PKS *k-xiːn¹ ‘arm’, PTai *kh- > S. kʰɛɛnᴬ¹ ‘arm’.
‘Villain, wickedness’ [Shu].  ||  [<] perh. a k-prefix noun derived from a hypothetical root *ran (§5.4).
‘To vilify, slander’ [Lun].  ||  [<] perh. an s-causative / tr. derived from a root *ran (§5.2.1).

‘To be in the middle, be inserted’ [Shi], ‘crevice, interstice’ [Zhuang].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjan (平);  MGZY (gÿan >) gyan (平) [kjan]; ONW kän  ||  [E] ST: Lushai inᴸ-kaarᴸ ‘the space, interval or distance between, difference’ ᛝ inᴸ-kaarᴴ-aɁᴸ ‘to come between’; PLB *gra² > WB kraᴮ ‘have space between, be apart’ ᛝ ə-kraᴮ ‘crack, opening’ (-> MidMon /əkra/ ‘interval, (space) between, within’) ᛝ kʰraᴮ ‘be between, divide, different’.  ||  Bodman (1980: 87) relates this wf to the WT items under → chǐ1 拸 (*hral ‘split’). → xián5 閑閒 ‘leisure’ is sometimes thought to be related to jiān.
‘To put in between, insert, alternate, supersede’ [Shi], ‘to separate, differences, meddle between’ [Zuo].  ||  [<] exoactive of jiān 間閒 (§4.3).

‘To combine, at the same time’ [Shu, Yi], ‘grasp, hold together, all-embracing’ [Meng, Mozi].  ||  [E] MK *ckiəm, *ckəm, *ckaim ‘grasp, hold’ (Shorto 2006 #1312): PMonic *ckiəm, OMon ckem ‘to grasp, pick up’ [Diffloth 1984: 215], OMon ‘handful’ ᛝ pkom ‘to collect together’, Aslian cəkam  etc. ‘hold’ [Benjamin 1976: 109]; PVM *gəmᴬ ‘to hold’, Khasi kem ‘to arrest, seize, wrestle’. MK -> Lushai kimR ‘entire, be complete’. Perh. → qín5 擒 is connected.

‘To seep into, get wet, moisten, soak’ 漸 [Shi, Shu]; ‘to moisten, enrich, benefit’ 瀸 [Lü], ‘to soak’ [Liji].  ||  [E] MK: Khmer jāṃ /coəm/ (darkened by water:) ‘wet, soaked, permeated, steeped’ (also ‘dark’). Khmer ? -> Tai: S. čomᴬ¹ ‘to sink, submerged’, Saek cɔm / camᴬ¹ ‘to sink’.

‘Gradually, to advance gradually’ [Shu, Yi] (< ‘drop-wise’, so Karlgren GSR 611f).   ||  Jiān is possibly the same etymon as → jiān9 熸 ‘extinguish’; or it might have originated in OC as a variant of jìn 浸 (→ chén2 沈, see there for further comments).
‘Extinguish’ [Zuo]. This word and its derivatives may be connected with → jiān8 漸瀸湛; see also → chén2 沈 for comments.
‘Go into water, wade’ [Guoyu], ‘lie at bottom of water, be soaked (in pleasure)’ [Shu].
‘To hide, secretly’ [Zuo].
‘Bow and arrow case’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] Perh. related to WT rkyal-pa  ‘leather sack, bag’ (Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 30).
‘Arrow case, quiver’ [Shiji] may be related to jiān, but then the WT connection is doubtful.

‘Child, son’ [JY].  ||  [E] AA: PVM *kɔːn ‘son’, Viet con [Ferlus]; Mon kon ‘child’ (Norman 1988: 231). It is a substrate word in Mǐn and other southern dialects: PMin *kiɑnᴮ > Jiàn’ōu kyeŋᴮ¹, Fúzhōu kiaŋᴮ¹, Xiàmén kiãᴮ¹. According to Chén Zhōngmǐn (LTBA 22.2, 2000: 21ff) jiǎn was used instead of the northern → zǐ1 子 and → ér4 兒 as a diminutive in Mǐn and other southern dialects where occasionally it left traces only in the tone.  ||  Syn. → zǐ1 子; → kūn2 昆.
‘A measure, a control’ [Xun].
‘Restricted, frugal, moderate’ [Zuo, Meng].   ||  [<] endopass. of jiǎn (§4.6).  ||  [E] ST: Lushai kaamᴴ ‘to decrease’ (as water, wages etc.) ᛝ kiamR ‘to lessen, to reduce, decrease, diminish’.
‘Decrease, abridge, moderate’ [Li] belongs perh. to → liǎn1 斂.
‘To select’ [Yi Zhou].  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. klanᴮ¹ ‘select’ (as jewels) (Manomaivibool 1975: 168).
‘To lift’ [Zhuang].  ||  [E] This wf may be related to WT ker-ba ‘to raise, lift’, but TGTM *¹ʰre/hreː ‘to raise’ as well as the MC initial xj- indicate that the phonology is rather complex.
‘To lift’ [Zuo].
‘To see, visit’ [OB, BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjen (去); MGZY gÿan (去) [kjɛn]; MTang kian < kian, ONW kėn

‘To appear, show up’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [<] endopass. of jiàn 見.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *m-kyen (STC no. 223) > WT mkʰyen-pa ‘to know’, PTani *ken ‘know’, NNaga *C-kʰyeŋ. The ST semantic range is similar to PIE *vid- ‘to see, know’. Sometimes → xiǎn6 顯 is thought to belong to this wf.
‘To look like, look as if’ [Shi].
‘To set up, establish’ [Shi] is perh. cognate to → jiàn3 健.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjen (去); MGZY gen (去) [kɛn]
‘Strong’ [Yi], Mand. ‘healthy, strong’. Perh. endopass. of → jiàn2 建 (§4.6) in the sense of ‘firmly established’. Not related to TB-WT gar-ba ‘strong’, see under → gù1 固.

‘Door bar, bolt’ [Lao]. Syn. → guān5 關, → xián7 閑.  ||  [E] This word could be compared to Lushai kalɁᴸ ‘to wrench, plait, lock’ ᛝ kalɁᴸ-naᴴ ‘a lock’ (Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 31), but the basic meaning in Lushai is ‘turn, twist’.

‘Sword’ [Zuo, under the year 650 BC].  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. This mid Zhou period word could be derived from → yǎn4 剡覃 ‘sharp’ (implied by Wulff, Geilich 1994: 110, 263), the initial k- would then be a nominalizing prefix (§5.4). Alternatively, swords seem to have originated in the ancient southern state of Wú (Sūzhōu area), which was famous for its sword smiths. From there the word, of unknown provenance, may have entered OC as well as PVM as *t-kiəm [Ferlus].
‘Entwine’ [SW: Shu] is a ST word: WT sdom-pa, bsdams ‘to bind, tie up’.  ||  Perh. cogn. to → cán 蠶 ‘silkworm’ (HST: 43).

‘Grass, fodder’ [Zhuang] > ‘straw mat’ [Chuci] > ‘put on display’ (loot), ‘offer, present’ [Shi]. Wáng Lì (1982: 289) relates this and other words to → xí1 席 ‘mat’.   ||  [D] PMin *tsanᶜ ‘straw mattress’
‘Grass, herb’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] STC (p. 49; 158 n. 428) suggests that this may be cognate to WT rtswa ‘grass’.

‘To mirror’ 監 [Shu], 鑑 [Shi]; ‘mirror’ 鑑 [Zuo].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjam (去), PR (kjan), LR kjen; MGZY (gÿam >) gyam (去) [kjam]  ||  [<] exopass. of jiān 監 (kam), ‘see oneself’ (§4.4). → jìng6 鏡 (kjɐŋᶜ) ‘mirror’ seems to be a variant. Bodman (1980: 148) adds hàn 鑑 (under → làn1 濫) to this group.
‘To see, look at, inspect’ [Shi]. The items under → kān5, kàn 勘 may be variants of this word.

‘To see’ [Guoce] (Bodman 1985:159) is perh. only a col. variant of the preceding item (Zhāng Xīngyà YWYJ 1996.4: 11).  ||  [E] ST: JP mə³¹-ram⁵⁵ ‘to observe, view’, WB krap ‘superintend, watch over and direct’.
‘Railing’ [Chuci], ‘cage’ [Zhuang].  ||  [E] ST: PLB *kram¹ ‘fence, garden’ > WB kʰram ‘fence, enclosure’ ᛝ ə-ram ‘fence forming an enclosure’; prob. also WT kʰram ‘notched wood’ (HPTB: 253; 299).

‘Yangtze River’ [Shi], in Shījīng only its mid-section (Norman / Mei 1976: 283).  ||  [E] MK: PMonic *krooŋ [Diffloth 1984: 132], LitMon kruŋ, Bahnar kroŋ (Norman a. Mei 1976: 280-283; Benedict 1976: 76; Norman 1988: 18); Viet sôŋ ‘river’ < *kr-; also Malay kroŋ. → chuān1 川 and its cognates may ultimately be a variant of this etymon. For a syn. see → táng1 唐.

‘Smaller river which flows into a larger river, lake or sea’ [Náncháo period, 6th c. AD].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjaŋ (上);  MGZY  gyang (上) [kjaŋ]  ||  [D] An ancient Wú dialect word which spread into the Chǔ region; the word survives in river names in the former Wú-Chǔ area (Jiāngsū, Jiāngxī, Zhèjiāng, Anhuī, Húběi, Húnán); the Huái River marks the northern limit of this word; later > ‘harbour’ (Lǐ Xiǎofán / Chén Bǎoxián, FY 2002.3: 201-216). The irregular Mand. form originated in southern dialects where velars have not palatalized. The role of tone B is not clear.

‘Take (something or someone along), hold, support’ [Shi, Shu]; perh. the meaning ‘to offer, offering’ (in sacrifice) [Shi] is a semantic extension (< ‘take along’).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tsjaŋ (平); MGZY (dzÿang >) dzyang (平) [tsjaŋ]; MTang tsiaŋ < tsaŋ, ONW tsaŋ  ||  [E] ST: WT ’čʰaŋ-ba ‘to hold, keep’ (HST: 94).
‘To lead’ [Shi, Meng] > ‘leader, general’ [Zuo].  ||  [<] exoactive / caus. of jiāng (§4.3).
‘To beg, pray, ask’ (for help, gift, not to do something) [Shi].   ||  [<] caus. aspiration of jiāng 將 (§5.8.2).

‘Be on the point of, about to, intend to, going to’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] MK: OKhmer caṅ /cɔŋ/, Khmer ca’ṅa /cɑŋ/ ‘to want, desire, hope for, be willing to, about to, on the point of’. Allofam → qiě 且 ‘about to’ (Pulleyblank 1962: 233).
‘Limit, boundary, to delimit, territory’ [BI, Shi], variant or allofam of → jìng6 竟境.

‘Ginger’ [Lunyu].   ||  [E] Area word: TB-WB kʰyaŋᴮ ‘ginger’ (HPTB: 302); SChin-Areng kachiŋ [Löffler Anthropos 55, 1960: 526]. <> AA: PVM *s-gəːŋ ‘ginger’ [Ferlus], Wa-Lawa-Bulang *s[ŋ̇]kiŋ. Note also PTai *xiŋᴬ¹: S. kʰiŋ², KS siŋ ‘ginger’, IN t’aɁaŋ ‘sharp’ (tasting) (Benedict AT: 48; 1976: 90).

‘To fashion, cut out, make’ vb. (as a sculpture, out of wood or the like) [Chuci] > ‘to form, cultivate’ (one’s personality through education) [Huainan], jiàng-rén 匠人 (‘woodworking man’:) ‘carpenter’ [Meng]; 匠 ‘carpenter’ n. [Zuo] > ‘artisan’ [Lunheng]; also ‘stone cutter’ (as a name in Zhuāngzǐ implies); jiàng-rén 匠人 ‘official in charge of woodworkers’ [Zhouli].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dzjaŋ ( 去); MGZY (tsÿang >) tsyang (去) [dzjaŋ]  ||  [E] MK: Khmer cāṃṅa /caŋ/ ‘to dress (wood, stone), rough out, trim...’. The verbal function in Khmer makes it unlikely that this is a loan from CH where the typical use is nominal. Jiàng is sometimes thought to be related to WT byaŋ-pa ‘skilled, experienced’ (→ fāng4 方) (Bodman 1980: 150), therefore the MC initial is conjectured to derive from *sb-, but this would be unusual and improbable; nor are the semantics compelling.

‘To descend, get down’ [BI, Shi], e.g. cattle from hills, person from carriage; metaphorically: send down blessings, misfortune etc.  ||  [E] There are no unambiguous outside cognates. Some languages have initial l-: Tai: S. loŋᴬ² < *dl- ‘to descend’. <> TB-Chepang glyuŋh- ~ gruŋ- ‘to descend’ ᛝ gruŋɁ- ‘droop, drop down (object in flight), descend (in angle)’. It is not clear if / how the following may be related: TB-Lai trùm / trúm ‘descend’ ᛝ tʰrúm / tʰrumɁ ‘to put down’ [VanBik LTBA 25.2, 2002: 99] (KN tr- can derive from *kr-). Sino-Viet xuóng [su´əŋ] ‘to descend’ is an OC loan (SV s- < *kr-).
‘To submit’ [BI, Shi], intr.

‘To cross, mix with, mingle, associate with’ [BI, Shi], ‘exchange’ [Yi], ‘join’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *ryaw (STC no. 207) > WB roᴮ ‘to mix, mingle’, Kachin yau ‘be mixed’ ᛝ kəjau ‘to mix, intermix’. Cf. Chepang ljawh-Ɂo ‘mixed’. <> PYao *klaau³ ‘to pay’.
‘To compare’ [Li, Meng], ‘foot-fetters, cangue’ [Yi].   ||  [<] *krau + caus. s/h-suffix (§4.3), lit. ‘make cross over, cross each other’.
‘Mixed, confused’ [Zhuang].   ||  [<] *krau with endopass. voicing (§4.6).
‘Verifications, checking’ (i.e. cross-checking) [Qin laws] (Yates EC 20, 1995: 359).  ||  The word → jiǎo1 祷 ‘burn on a pyre of crossed logs’ is prob. not related.

‘To shout’ [Zhuang]. See also → yāo4, jiāo 咬.  ||  The OC medial *r is confirmed by WB kro ‘shout, call out’, Lahu kù < *kru [STC: 19], this word occurs also in MK languages: PNBahn. *krò ‘cry’ (WB loan?).

‘Scaly dragon’ [Lü], ‘alligator’ [Li]; in later folklore jiāo refers to mermaids (Eberhard 1968: 378); additional definitions and etymological suggestions have been discussed by Carr (LTBA 13.2, 1990: 126 etc.). There may possibly be a connection with TB: WB kʰruᴮ ~ kʰyuᴮ ‘mermaid, serpent’, WT klu ‘naga, water spirits’. However, phonologically OC and TB are far apart.

‘To roast, burn, scorch’ tr. 焦 [Zuo], 燋 [Li].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tsjew (平); PR tsjaw; MGZY dzÿaw (平) [tsjɛw]  ||  [D] The graph 焦 is used for a Mǐn synonym: PMin *tauᴬ ‘dry, scorch’: Amoy taᴬ¹; this item is cognate to PVM *trawᴮ ‘dry’ (Bodman 1980: 178).

‘Firewood’ [Zuo], ‘gather firewood’ [Shi], ‘to burn’ (fuel) intr. [Gongyang].  ||  [<] endopass. of jiāo tr. (§4.6), i.e. ‘something that burns itself’.   ||  [D] This is the Mǐn word for ‘wood, firewood’: PMin *dzʰau: Xiàmén lit. tsʰaiᴬ², col. tsʰaᴬ² ‘grass and trees for fuel’, Jiàn’ōu tsʰauᴬ². This word is conventionally written → chái1 柴.
‘A torch’ [Zhuang] (Wáng Lì 1982: 219).

‘Torch’ [Li] (Karlgren 1956: 12).  ||  [E] ST: PTB *tsyow (STC no. 275) > WT ’tsʰod-pa ~ ’tsʰo-ba ‘cook in boiling water, bake’ ᛝ btsos, rtsos ‘to roast’, Kachin tsʰu ‘boil’, Lushai soᴴ ‘boil’; Garo so, Dimasa sau ‘burn’. Possible allofam → jiào7 僬潐醮.
‘Frost’ [Chuci].  ||  [E] MY: PWMiao *klau⁷ (P), *qÒɑk (Wáng F.S.) ‘ice, snow’. For semantics, compare shuāng 霜 (under → liáng3 涼).
‘To chew’ [SW], also Mand.
‘To chew’ [Li].

‘Status / rank in the nobility, dignity’ [BI, Shi] seems to be related to the above (i.e. rank defined by agricultural revenues, i.e. food?). The semantic field ‘eat ~ live off revenues’ is parelleled in MK: PMon *caaɁ ‘to eat’, Mon ‘eat, live on, by the revenues of, to govern’ (under → jǔ1 咀).

‘Burn on a pyre’ [OB, SW], esp. in a rain ceremony.  ||  [E] SW implies that jiǎo is related to → jiāo1 交 ‘cross’, i.e. a pyre of crossed logs, but the semantic connection with ‘crossed’ may be due to the graphic element. TB cognates suggest that jiǎo actually means ‘dry over fire, burn’: WB kro ~ kyo ‘to fry’, JP krau³³ ‘dry up, overdry’ ᛝ kə³¹-rau³³ ‘dry over a fire’. Jiǎo may be cognate to → liào2 燎 ‘burn’.

‘Be beautiful, handsome’ [Shi].  ||  Related is perh. the second syllable in yǎo-jiǎo 窈糾 (Ɂieuᴮ-gjäuᴮ 3, -kjäuᴮ 3) ‘be elegant, beautiful’ [Shi], variant: → yǎo6-tiǎo 窈窕 (Ɂieuᴮ-dieuᴮ) ‘be beautiful’ [Shi].
‘Be fine, lovely’ [Shi], 嫽 [GY].
‘To twist’ [Li], ‘strangle, pressing, intense’ [Zuo], ‘entangle’.
‘Bind round, wrap’ [Li], ‘entangled’.   ||  [C] Allofam is perh. → jiǔ3 糾 etc.

‘Horn’ [Shi], ‘sharp angle, corner’. Zhāng Xīngyà (YWYJ 1996.4: 9f) has collected archaistic bisyllabic dialect words for ‘horn’, incl. Wú-Sūzhōu, Níngbō, Shàoxìng kɔɁlɔɁ.  ||  [E] ST stem *kru to which OC has added a final *-k (§6.1): PTB *kru(w) > WB kʰyui, kʰrui ‘horn’ (STC no. 37); the root is PTB *ru ~ *rwa as in WT ru ~ rwa ‘horn’. A TB final *-ŋ variant is reflected in → gōng9 觥.  ||  Bodman (1980: 167) compares the TB word with qiú 觩 (gjəu) ‘long and curved, horn-like’ [Shi] (under → qiú7, jiū 虯 觓觩) which, however, is derived from the meaning ‘twist’; HST: 58 relates jiǎo to WT kʰug ‘corner, angle’ (but see → jú6 鞠鞫). Sagart (1999: 161) relates jiǎo to → lù11 鹿 ‘deer’; lù is a rare reading for 角. <> PTai *khəuᴬ¹ ‘horn’ has apparently no connection with CH.
‘A horn-shaped bar on a carriage’ [Shi] (Wáng Lì 1982: 294).
‘A kind of boiled dumpling’, etymologically same word as jiǎo 角 ‘horn’, so named for its horn-like shape (Norman 1988: 77).
‘Leg, foot’ [Xun] is a common word in Mand. and most dialects: Yuè kœkᴰ³, Kèjiā kiɔkᴰ¹. Mǐn *kʰauᴬ¹ 骹 ‘foot’ (→ qiāo1 骹) is unrelated. Etymology not clear.
‘Martial, vigorous’ 蹻 [Shi]; ‘energetic’ 橋 [Zhuang] is perh. the same etymon as jiǎo 憍 ‘high’ (under → qiáo1 喬) (so Wáng Lì 1982: 204).
‘Vigorous (horses)’ [Shi].
‘Lifting the feet high, strong-looking (horses)’ [Shi].    ||  [C] These items may belong to the wf. → qiáo1 喬 ‘high’.

‘To disturb’ tr. [Shi]  ||  [E] ST: PTB *grok ~ *krok (STC no. 473): WT dkrog-pa = skrog-pa ‘to stir, churn, rouse, scare’; PLB *krok ‘be afraid’ > WB krok ᛝ PLB *Ɂkrok  > WB kʰrok  ‘frighten’ (HST: 127).   ||  [C] This word could possibly be related to → lù12 摝. Perh. jiǎo belongs to → xué 學.
‘To call out, shout’ [Shi], ‘clamor’ [Zhouli]. Prob. s. w. as → jiào4 噭, but distinct from → zhào1 召.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjew (去);  PR kjaw; MGZY gÿaw (去) [kjɛw]

‘To shout’ [Li], ‘cry, weep’ [Gongyang]. It is difficult to believe that jiào 噭 *kiâukh ‘shout’ and → jiào3 叫嘂 *kiûh ‘shout’ are not the same word in spite of their different OC rimes; at least they must have been variants. → zhào1 召 ‘call’ is a different etymon.
‘To teach, instruct, set an example’ [Shi], ‘allow’ (to grow) [Guoyu – Harbsmeier 1981: 40].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjaw (平去); MGZY (gÿaw >) gyaw (平去) [kjaw]; ONW käu.
‘Hair-knot’ [no pre-Han ex.].

(‘Cut’ >) ‘regular division’ [Li], ‘knots or joints on bamboo or other plants’ [Shi], ‘degree, rank’ [Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tsje (入); MGZY dzÿa (入) [tsjɛ]; MTang tsiar < tsiar, ONW tsėt  ||  [E] ST *tsik: PTB *tsik (STC 64): WT ’tsʰigs ‘joint, knot, knee’; Garo tśik, Lepcha tśak ‘joint’; PLB *Ɂdzik > WB cʰac ‘a joint’ (Bodman 1980: 139).  ||  Perh. not related to jié 截 (dziet) [dzet] *dzêt  (‘To cut, trim’ >) ‘restrain, govern’ [Shi] (Unger Hao-ku 39, 1992) because of the different OC vowels. An allofam may be → xī13 膝 *sit ‘knee’.
‘To cut’ [Shi]. This graph also writes a homophone which is cognate to → jí7 即.

‘Comb, to comb’ 櫛 [Shi], ‘to scrape’ 奚 [Zhouli].  ||  [E] The several words for ‘comb’ in CH and TB look somewhat similar, but precise phonological correspondences are elusive. Jié appears to be close to PTB *m-si(y) ‘comb’ (STC no. 466) > JP pə⁵⁵-si⁵⁵ ‘comb, rake’ ᛝ məsìt ‘to comb, rake, brush’; Mikir iŋtʰi < msi ‘comb’, Lepcha pŭr-šit [pər-sit] ‘brush’ [Bodman ICSTLL 1987: 17]. Although an additional final consonant like -t here is not unusual for CH, the initials are rather different. Syn. → shū3 梳.

‘To put around and measure’ (e.g. a tree) [Zhuang].  ||  [E] This wf belongs to the ST root *ke ‘concave’ (of body parts etc.), see → jǐng2 頸 ‘neck’ and Table J-2 there.  → ||  ST *ket ‘waist > put around the waist > belt’: WT rked-pa ‘the waist, loins, middle’ (IST: 66), rked-rgyan ‘belt ornament’; JP ʃiŋ³¹-kjit⁵⁵ ‘waist’. CH xié OCM *khet, Tibetan *rket and JP *s-kit may all go back to the same ST etymon *s/r-ket. Without final *-t: Tamang (¹)keː ‘belt’. Lepcha a-rek ‘girdle’ cannot be related unless it is a mangled loan from a WT word like rked which has undergone a metathesis of the type described in §2.8.3 (*rket > *reket > rek).
‘Belt’ [Zhuang]. Alternatively, this word could belong to → jié6 結 *kît ‘to tie’ (Unger Hao-ku no. 74, 11. 2001), though the vowels do not agree.
‘Of surpassing quality’ [Shi] > ‘hero’ 桀 [Shi], 傑 [Meng].  ||  [E] This wf is prob. cognate to TB-Lushai hratF < hraat ‘brave, resolute’; or alternatively to WT gyad ‘champion, athlete’ (HST: 93).
‘Martial, martial-looking’ [Shi].

‘To loosen’ [Meng], ‘explain’ [Zuo], ‘divide’ [Guoyu], ‘cut up (an ox)’ [Zhuang].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjaj (上); PR, LR kjej; MGZY gyay (上) [kjaj]; ONW këi  ||  [E] ? Area stem *C-re: TB-Chepang greh- ‘to sever, chop off, cut cleanly’, perh. also PLB *priy² ‘unfasten, untie’ > WB pʰre ‘untie, unroll, appease’ ᛝ ə-pʰre ‘answer to question, key’. <> Perh. MK: Khmer rāya /ríiəj/ ‘to break up, scatter, disperse, divide up....’ ᛝ srāya /sraaj/ ‘to undo (knot), untie, loose... untangle, unravel, solve, clarify, interpret’ (dream). The MK - OC vowel correspondence is regular, and a MK origin could account for the differences in initial consonants.
‘Be slack, idle, careless’ intr. [Shi]; ‘understand’ [Li]; syn. → huì3 會.  ||  [<] endopass. of jiě  解 (§4.6).
‘Lazy, remiss’ [Xiaojing]; ‘be slack, idle, careless’ = Ɣaiᴮ [Shi].
‘Be carefree and happy’ [Shi].

‘Scale’ (of animals) [Li] > ‘armour’ [Shi] > ‘armoured men’ [Shi] > ‘to assist’ [OB, Shi].   ||  [E] ST: jiè is often thought to be cognate to → jiǎ1 甲 (so LaPolla 1994: 141; Yú Mǐn 1948: 43), but jiè agrees phonologically rather with TB-WB ə-kreᴮ ‘scales of a fish’. <> PTai *kletᴰ¹S  ‘fish scales’ is perh. a Chinese loan. Possible allofam → jiè3  疥.

‘To increase, become great’ (of army, blessings, old age, person) [Shi]. This word is prob. related to → xián8 閑 *grên ‘be large’, and perh. derived from → jiǎ2 假嘏 *kraɁ ‘great’ (but the OC vowels differ). Shī Xiàngdōng (2000: 24) relates this word to WT rgyas-pa ‘to increase’; OC *e is the equivalent of foreign *ya/*ja (§11.3.2).

‘Itch, scabies’ [[Li] is prob. derived from, or cognate to, jiā 痂 (ka) *krai ‘scabies’ [SW] (so Wáng Lì 1982: 432), hence < *krai-(t)s. Alternatively, it could perh. be the same etymon as → jiè1 介 ‘scales’.
‘Mustard plant’ [Li].  ||  [E] <> PTai *kat: S. kaatᴰ¹ᴸ ‘mustard plant’; Mid. Korean kas id. (Miyake 1997: 189).
‘Boundary, limit’ [Shi] looks like the s. w. as, or variant of, the LH homophone → jiè6 屆 ‘arrive, limit’ (difference in OC vowels *e vs. *ə, §11.7.2).

‘To end up, arrive, end, limit’ [Shi] is prob. related to → jiè5 界 ‘limit’, and may be the same as → jiè1 介 ‘armour’ in the sense of security encirclement, and thus be a deriva- tion from → jiè9 戒誡 *krəh ‘guard against’.
‘To borrow’ [Zuo]

‘To lend’ [Lunyu] (Takashima 1996 II: 130: Herforth 1984).  ||  [<] exoactive of jiè 借 (tsjäk) (§4.3)     ||  [C] This set belongs prob. to the wf → cuò3 錯, whose basic meaning is ‘to cross, exchange’.

‘To present’ [Zuo], ‘contribute, aid’ [Li], ‘avail oneself of, depend on’ [Zuo], ‘bedding or mat of straw as support for sacrifices or gifts’ [Yi]. This word could either be derived from → jū5 苴 ‘straw’ (so Wáng Lì 1982: 167), or be cognate to WT ’ǰags-pa ‘to give, present’ (so Bodman 1980: 150).
‘To guard against, be on guard, take care, admonish’ [BI, Shi], ‘notify, invite’ [Zuo]; ‘to warn’ [Yi], ‘prohibit’ 誡 [Xun].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kjaj (去), PR kjej; MGZY gyay (上) [kjaj]; ONW këi
‘To frighten, overawe’ [Zhuang].   ||  [C] Wáng Lì (1982: 86) relates this wf to → jì7 忌誋惎 ‘warn’. Possible derivations may be → jiè1 介 ‘armour’ and / or → jiè6 屆 ‘limit’.
‘Axe’ 斤 [BI, Zuo].   ||  [E] ? ST: PLB *gyan² ‘pick-axe’ (Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 139). It may also be connected with PMY *cwIːn¹ ‘axe’ (Wáng FS), and / or PTai *xwaan, PKS *kwan (Matisoff).

‘Today, this (day, year)’ [OB, BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kim (平), PR, LR kin; MGZY gim (平) [kim]; ONW kim.  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. Unger (Hao-ku 33, 1986) suggests cognation with WT lhem ‘now’, but see → yán2 炎. Alternatively, the word’s root may be → qí7 其 *gə ‘this’.

‘Metal’ [BI, Shu, Shi], ‘bronze, gold’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kim (平), PR, LR kin; MGZY gim (平) [kim]; ONW kim.   ||  [D] PMin *kim ‘gold’; Y-Guǎngzhōu ⁵⁵kɐmᴮ¹  ||  [E] Benedict (HJAS 4, 1939: 223) connects jīn with PTai *Ɣəmᴬ² ‘gold’ ᛝ S. kaːmᴮ¹ ‘bright, striking’ (used to describe rubies or pure gold), ‘blood-red’ (looks like a loan from Cantonese). Note the similarity with the wf → tǎn5 黮.
‘Sinew’ [Meng]. <> PTai *Ɂ±ienᴬ¹ ~ ᴬ² ‘tendon, sinew’ is perh. related.
‘Sinew’ [Chuci].   ||  [C] Prob. not related to → qiān7 牽 ‘pull tight’ and → jiān2 堅 ‘solid, strong’.

‘Halo around sun’ [Zuo] appears to be related to WT kʰyim ‘halo around sun’ ᛝ ’kʰyims-pa ‘be encircled by a halo’ ᛝ ’gyim-pa ‘circumference’ (Bodman 1980: 58). However the initials are difficult to reconcile.

‘To bind tight’ [Chuci, SW]. Acc. to SSYP: 211, this is the only word with a velar initial k- in chóngniǔ div. IV and is prob. a southern (note Chuci!) non-palatalizing dialect variant of the regular palatalized form zhěn 紾 (tśjenᴮ) ‘to twist (someone’s arm)’ [Meng] (so Yupian; Schuessler 1996, JCL 24.2).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kin (上); MGZY gÿin (上) [kjin]; ONW kiin  ||  [E] ST: Lushai kʰirɁᴸ < *kʰirh ‘to tie / bind arms behind the back; carrying cords twisted around a load’, NNaga *C-kʰyin ‘to tie’. Perh. also connected with WT ’khyil-ba ‘to wind, twist’. Prob. unrelated is the TB etymon WT ’gril-ba ‘be twisted, wrapped around’, WB kʰyañ ‘bind, fasten’ ᛝ kʰyañᴮ ‘thread’ (< *krin) (note also cañᴮ ‘bind, tie together’), JP kren³³ ‘to tighten’ (a rope). An allofam is perh. → qiān7 牽.

‘To be near, imminent’ [Shi]. Karlgren (1933: 28) relates this word to → jī12 幾 ‘imminent’.    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR gin (上去); MGZ  kin (上去) [gin]; ONW gin  ||  [E] This etymon also occurs in PVM *t-kiɲ ‘near’ [Ferlus].
‘To come near to, approach, keep close to’ [Shi].  ||  [<] exoactive / caus. derivation (§4.3).

‘To soak, overflow’ [Shi].   ||  [E] <> TB: WB chip ‘poison, venom’, or WB cim ‘steep, soak’ (HST: 136) ᛝ cimᶜ ‘transude, ooze through’. <> Tai: čim³ ‘to dip into, immerse’. This word is probably unrelated to the ones mentioned under → chén2 沈.

[D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ³³kɐmᴬ¹   ||  ‘To prohibit’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *krim (STC no. 379): WT kʰrims ‘rule, right, law’ ᛝ ’kʰrims ‘fear, terror, awe’ (HST: 127), WB krimᴮ ‘terrify’. In light of the WT cognates, → lǐn3 廩懍 ‘shake, fear’ is perh. also related (so Shī Xiàngdōng 2000: 117). <> Unclear remains the relationship, if any, with MK-Khmer /praam/ ‘to prohibit, forbid’.

‘To exhaust’ > ‘entirely, all’ [Shi].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dzin (上去); MGZY tsin (上) [dzin]; ONW dzin  ||  [E] ST: WT zin-pa ‘be finished, be at an end’ (STC: 170 n. 455), Lushai seeŋᴴ / seenᴸ ‘use up, consume, spend’ (money, strength), ‘completely, entirely’.
‘Ashes, combusted’ [Shi] (Wáng Lì 1982: 540).  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR zin (去); MGZY zin (平) [zin]  ||  [<] exopass. of jìn 盡 (dzjenᴮ, tsjenᴮ) (§4.4), lit. ‘what has been combusted’
‘To advance, enter’ [Shu] > caus. ‘bring / send forward’ [BI, Shi, Shu].  — Etymology not clear.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tsin (去); MGZY dzin (去) [tsin]

‘Famine’ 饉 [BI, Shi] > ‘die of starvation’ 殣 [Zuo].  ||  This word could belong to → qín3 勤慬 (gjən) ‘toil’ (so Karlgren 1949: 92), but more likely it is cognate to WT bkren ~ bgren ‘poor, hungry’ and thus to → jī2 飢 ‘hungry’ (so Karlgren 1933: 28; Bodman 1985: 151).

T_data: [D] PMin *ğimᴮ > Amoy kimᶜ² Jiàn’ōu keŋᴮ² Jiànyáng kiŋᶜ¹
Notes: ‘Aunt’ [JY], fusion of jiùmǔ 舅母.

‘Mound, hill, capital city, great’ [BI, Shi]. A semantic parallel is → qiū1/2 丘.  ||  [E] MK: Khmer /kraŋ/ (in toponyms:) ‘steep knoll, bluff or crag overlooking a plain’ < OKhmer rāṅ /raŋ/ ‘rise up, be stiff or strong’.
‘Be great’ [Shi].
‘Whale’ [Zuo] (Wáng Lì 1982: 346).
‘Be fearsome, terrible’ (drought) [Shi].
‘Be cautious’ (approaching an abyss) [Shi]. This item looks like a vocalic variant of → jīng7 驚.
‘Be careful, attentive, observe carefully’ [Shi]. Variations in final nasals n ~ ŋ have parallels (§6.4.1-2), the final OC *-əŋɁ does not occur (§3.2.4).

‘Thorny shrub’ [BI, Zuo], original name of the ancient state of Chǔ 楚 ‘briar, shrub’ [SW].  ||  [E] ? MK: Khmer jrāṃṅa /creəŋ/ ‘to bristle’ > jajrāṃṅa /ccreəŋ/ ‘to be all bristly’ [Jenner / Pou 1982: xxv] ᛝ prēṅa /praaɛŋ/ ‘bristles’ (of pig, boar etc.), ‘bristle brush’. The CH initial k- could be an alternate prefix, such as one forming nouns in Khmer.

‘To pass through’ [Zuo], ‘flow through, communicate’ [Zhuang] > ‘to take as a norm, plan, practice’ [BI, Shi] > ‘a warp’ (in weaving) (‘what is being passed through’?) [Zuo], but see next.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kiŋ (平); MGZY gÿing (平) [kjiŋ]; MTang kieŋ < kiŋ, ONW kėŋ  ||  [E] ? ST: WB ə-kʰyaŋᴮ ‘diameter’ (CVST 3: 24), WT kyaŋ ‘straight, slender’. Wáng Lì (1982: 320) suggests that ‘warp’ is cognate to → gāng3 綱 ‘guiding rope’, however gāng and jīng each belong to wfs with different semantic foci.

‘A warp’ 經 [Zuo] (the JY has this alternative tone C reading); ‘small path, short-cut’ [Lunyu], ‘diameter’ [Li], ‘go, travel’ 徑 [Zuo]. Karlgren suggests that ‘gone far away’ 逕 [Zhuang] is the s. w., but it may instead belong to the wf → jiǒng2 泂迥 ‘far’.   ||  [<] exopass. of jīng 經 (kieŋ) (§4.4), lit. ‘what is being passed through’: ‘a warp’.
‘Ravine, defile’ [Zuo].  ||  [<] endopass. of jīng 經, lit. ‘what one passes through, is passed through’.   ||  [C] A further allofam may be → xíng2 刑形 ‘law, model’.
‘Be luxuriant (vegetation)’ [Shi] is perh. only a graphic variant of → qīng1 青 ‘green, blue’, in spite of the difference in pronunciation (Baxter 1983).

‘Be afraid, attentive’ sv. [Shi] > caus. ‘to scare, alarm’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kiŋ (平); MGZY ging (平) [kiŋ]; ONW keŋ  ||  [D] This is the word for ‘to fear’ in southern dialects: PMin 惊 *kiaŋ > Amoy kiãᴬ¹, Fúzhōu kiaŋᴬ¹ ‘be afraid’.  ||  [E] ? MK provides an etymological explanation: Khmer rēṅa /rɛɛŋ/ ‘be stiff, rigid, hard’ > OKhmer krēṅa /krɛɛŋ/ ‘be stiff or rigid with fear, to fear, afraid of’. Khmer -> Tai: S. kreeŋᴬ¹ ‘to fear’ (alternative: Manomaivibool 1975: 168). Löffler (1966: 141) relates jīng to Mru riŋ ‘respectful’. A possible variant is → jīng2 兢.
‘Be cautious, careful, respectful’ sv. [Shi]; ‘to warn, be careful about’ [Shi].  ||  [<] ‘to warn’: exoactive / caus. (§4.3).
‘To warn, admonish, be on one’s guard’ vt. 警 [Zuo] (儆 in addition QY gjɐŋᶜ).   ||  [<] ‘be on one’s guard’: endoactive of jīng (§4.5)
‘A well’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tsiŋ (上); MGZY dzing (上) [tsiŋ]

‘Pitfall’ 侖 [Shu], ‘pit’ 阱 [Li] (Karlgren 1956: 10).  ||  [E] This last word (jǐng 阱) could be related to WT sdiŋs ‘cavity, depression’ (HST: 118), whereas jǐng ‘well’ is prob. cognate to WT rdziŋ ‘a pond’. Therefore, the two CH word may be unrelated.

‘Neck’ [Zuo], unlike → lǐng 領 also figuratively ‘neck’ of a vessel, jug etc.   ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ³⁵kɛŋᴮ¹, Táishān ⁵⁵kiaŋᴮ¹, but Mand. bózǐ 脖子 ‘neck’.  ||  [E] Wáng Lì (1982: 321) considers this wf cognate to → gāng1 亢 ‘neck’ and the allofams there. PMY *klaːŋᴬ ‘neck, throat’ is prob. related to the latter rather than to jǐng. Since there is no trace of an *r in the OC initial, jǐng is prob. not related to → lǐng 領 ‘neck’, but belongs most likely to the ST root *ke to which also belongs → jié12 絜.   ||  ST *ke(-C) ‘concave’ (of part of the body and the like): WT rke-ba ‘lean’ ᛝ rked ‘waist’ (Beyer 1992: 117), see → jié12 絜 for more; JP keɁ⁵⁵ < kek⁵⁵ ‘concave’ (of the neck, a jug) (STC no. 251), ‘indentation, pit’; Chepang kəyk ~ kek ‘neck’; NN *C-geŋ ‘waist’, SChin-Khami (Awa) ken ‘waist’, Chepang keŋɁ- and kiŋh- ‘be constricted, narrow-waisted’ ~ kiŋɁ- ‘be constricted, narrow’ (waist). See Table J-2 for synopsis.  Table J-2  for jǐng2  頸  →
‘Cut the throat, cut off the head’ [Zuo] (Karlgren 1956: 16).
‘Long-necked’ [Zhouli] is prob. connected with this wf. The alternative connection with jiān 肩 [ken] *ken ‘shoulder’ seems semantically less likely.

‘Bright’ [Zuo], ‘measure by the shadow’ [Shi]. The semantic association between ‘light’ and ‘shadow’ is also found in the wf → yīng1 英. A derivation is prob. → jìng6 鏡 ‘mirror’. Syn. → liàng 亮, → yīng1 英 .

Xnote: ‘finger’ in Mǐn words: Taipei tsʰiuᴮ-tsãiᴮ  手□ tsaŋᴮ-tʰauᴬ² or tsiŋᴮ-tʰauᴬ² □頭 ‘finger’. Bauer (CAAAL 28 1987: 61) compares the element jǐng with ziːŋᴬ² ‘finger’ in Li lgs. on Hǎinán.

Notes: ‘Be quiet, tranquil, peaceful, to rest’ 靖 [Shi]; ‘to stop, keep qiet’ 靜 [Lü]. HST: 55 adds jìng 靜 in the sense of ‘pure’ to this wf.  ||  [E] Perh. MK: OKhmer siṅ /siŋ/ ‘to stay in / at, abide, be still, contemplative...’ Note also TB-JP sim³¹ ‘quiet, peaceful’, but the difference in finals remains unexplained.
‘Boundary, limit, border’ 竟 [Zuo]; 境 [Meng] is an allofam of → jiāng6 疆.
‘Come to an end, entirely’ [Shi].

‘Mirror’ [Dadai Liji].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kiŋ (去); MGZY ging (去) [kiŋ]; ONW keŋ  ||  [D] PMin *kiaŋᶜ > Amoy kiãᶜ¹, Fúzhōu kiaŋᶜ¹  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. Baxter (p. c.) derives jìng from → liàng 亮 ‘light’ with the nominalizing k-prefix (§5.4); alternatively, the word may be cognate to → jǐng3 景 ‘bright’. Perh. the late word jìng is a re-etymologization of the nearly identical word → jiàn15 監鑑 (kamᶜ) ‘mirror’.

‘Distant’ 泂 [Shi], 迥 [SW] (also read xiòng; GY also has kiweŋᴮ for 迥).  ||  [E] MK: Khmer vēṅa /wɛɛŋ/  ‘be far, distant, long’ ᛝ lveṅa /lwéeŋ/ ‘be far off, distant, remote’ ᛝ chveṅa /cwèeŋ/  ‘be situated in the off side, be abnormal, queer, excentric, unorthodox, left (hand)’. For a possible semantic parallel in OC, see → kuáng 狂. The root is perh. also encountered in PTB *wiy > WB weᴮ ‘far’, PL *we² ‘be far, dull’; possibly also Kanauri rwi ‘high’. The relationship with → jiǒng3 憬 and → yǒng1 永, if any, is not clear.
‘High, distant’ [Chuci].
‘Out-lying parts, far from the capital’ [Shi].  ||  [<] k-prefix noun of jiǒng 泂迥 (Ɣiweŋᴮ) (§5.4) (Baxter a. Sagart 1998: 48).
‘Far away’ [Shi] is prob. a variant of the stem as final nasals can alternate after front vowels (§6.4.1).

‘Be far away’ [Shi]. The relationship with similar items → jiǒng2 泂迥 and → yuǎn1 遠 is not clear. Sagart (1999: 104) derives jiǒng from → yǒng1 永 ‘be long, distant’. A derivation may be → kuáng 狂, although the MC vowels do not agree.
‘Be distressed, bothered’ [Shi]. This word looks like a variant of → qióng1 邛 (gjwoŋ) LH gioŋ ‘be distressed’. Otherwise, this word may belong to → hùn1 混渾.

‘To search into, investigate’ [Shi].  ||  [E] <> PTai *gwaᶜ² ‘to search for’. The Tai form points to OC *gwə. The phonetic elements in the above words (九求) may be ambiguous, they both could write words of the OC type *ku and *kwə.  ||  Carr (Language Studies [Otaru Univ.] 1993.3: 34) also relates kǎo 考 (kʰâuᴮ) LH kʰouɁ *khûɁ ‘to examine’ [Shi] to jiù above.

‘To save, help, relive’ [Shi]; in this word tone C *-h appears to be the common derivative suffix which forms exopassives (< ‘having been successfully searched for’?), but the final *-h in jiù 究 above cannot have the same function.  ||  [E] This word is shared with PLB *N-gu¹: WB ku ‘help’, Lahu gu ‘prepare, practice’.
‘To seek for, ask for’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR giw (平); MGZY kiw (平) [giw]; MTang geu < giu, ONW gu

‘Pigeon, dove’ [Shi] is today’s meaning, but what bird it referred to in ancient texts is not certain.   ||  [D] For taboo considerations, some southern dialects have an aspirated initial (A. Yue Hashimoto, p.c.): Y-Guǎngzhōu and Hongkong kɐuᴬ¹ ~ kʰɐuᴬ¹, Fóshān, Nánhǎi et. al. kʰ-; also M-Xiàmén kiuᴬ¹ ~ kʰiuᴬ¹.  ||  [E] ST: Because of *ku’s onomatopoetic nature there are variant forms in ST, some with medial -r-, some without: PTB *kuw (STC no. 495) ‘dove’ > Miri pəkü, Meithei kʰu-nu, ‘pigeon’ (STC: 185; HST p. 118); PTB *m-krəw: PLB *N-kruw² > WB kʰui ~ kʰyui ~ kʰrui, Kuki *m-kʰru > Khami iŋ məkʰru. The Tai word looks like a loan from a Yuè dialect, yet PTai also had a medial *-r-: S. khauᴬ¹ < *khr-, *hr- ‘dove’.

‘Nine’ [BI, Shi]. The graph was apparently invented for a word ‘to bend’ → jú6 鞠鞫; in WT the words for ‘nine’ and ‘to bend’ are also homophones (dgu).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kiw (上); MGZY giw (上) [kiw]; MTang keu < kiu, ONW ku,   ||  [D] PEMǐn *kəuᴮ¹: M-Xiàmén, Fúzhōu kauᴮ; PWMǐn *kiuᴮ¹; Y-Guǎngzhōu ³⁵kɐuᴮ¹  ||  [E] ST: PTB *s-kwa (HPTB: 24) ~ *d-kəw (HPTB: 140): Lushai kuaR < kuaɁ (< *Ɂ, not *-h < *-s) (kɔᴸ) [STC no. 13] (for the rime see §10.2.3). Tamang ²kuː ‘nine’, WT dgu; PLB *guw² [Matisoff], PL *go² [Bradley]; WB kuiᴮ; Garo sku. <> PTai *k±iəuᶜ¹: S. kauᶜ¹ ‘nine’ looks like a Cantonese loan.

‘Long time, long time ago’ [Shi] > ‘wait’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kiw (上); MGZY giw (上) [kiw].   ||  [D] M-Xiàmén kuᴮ; Y-Guǎngzhōu ³⁵kɐuᴮ¹  ||  [E] <> MK: Wa-Lawa-Bulang *-[ŋ]-koɁ, it may be a CH loan.

‘To twist, plait’ [Shi], ‘unite’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] <> KT: The outside connections suggest an original *klju: PTai *kliəuᴬ¹ (?): S. kliauᴬ¹ ‘to wind around, twist a string’, Saek tlɛɛuᶜ¹; note however PTai *kiəuᶜ¹ : S. kiauᶜ¹ ‘to wind around, twist’.  ||  This wf is perh. ultimately ST: TB-WT gčud / lčud-pa, gčus / lčus,  gču / lču (< *hlju?) ‘to twist, twine, plait, braid’ ᛝ gčus ‘screw’, WB kʰyu ‘twist off (fruit) with pole’, Lushai kiiuᴸ ‘elbow’ [Weidert 1975: 8].  ||  Many variants are found under GSR 1064 and 1069. Baxter (1992: 513) adds → miù1 謬 ‘to lie’ to this group. Allofams are → qiú7, jiū 虯觓觩, and perh. → jiǎo3 絞.
‘To twist’ 繆 [Li], 樛 [Yili], ‘down-curving (branch)’ [Shi].   ||  [D] Sagart (1999: 105) connects jiū to a Xīnzhōu 欣州 (Jìn) dialect word kəɁ-liɔ ‘awkward (of a person’s behavior), curved’.
‘Leek’ [Shi]. Unger (Hao-ku 36, 1990: 48) relates this word to WT sko(-tse) ‘wild onion’.

‘Wine’ 酉 [OB, BI], 酒 [Shi]. The word was also read in tone A in Shījīng (Mattos 1971: 309).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tsiw (上); MGZY dziw (上) [tsiw]; MTang tseu < tsiu, ONW tsu  ||  [N] The MC tsj- ~ j- alternation in 酒 ~ 酉 (GSR 1096) has parallels and points to an original OC root initial *j- (not *l-) in such series (see §9.2). Curiously, in its sense of ‘cyclical character’, yǒu’s 酉 Tai counterparts (Tai rau) and Han dynasty paronomastic glosses indicate an OC *r- initial. This has led to the identification of (yǒu /) jiǔ ‘wine’ with PTB *ru ‘wine’. However, the latter belongs to → láo3 醪 *ru ‘wine’.  ||  [E] ST *ju: PTB *yu(w) ‘wine’ (STC no. 94), BG-Tiwa chû ‘rice beer’.
‘Wine-master’ [Li], ‘old wine’ [Zhouli, SW] (Karlgren 1956: 11). This is a tone A nominalization derived from jiǔ (§3.1).

‘Mortar’ [Yi].   ||  [D] PMin *gʰ- > Xiàmén kʰuᶜ², Fúzhōu kʰouᶜ². In some Mǐn dialects the word for ‘mortar’ is the Mand. equivalent jiù-kū 臼窟 where kū means ‘depression’, then kū is re-interpreted as ‘mortar’ and jiù acquires the meaning ‘pestle’ (Branner 2000: 109).  ||  [E] MK *ɡuul ‘mortar for pounding rice’: Proto-Semai *ɡuul, (Khmuic) Kammu-Yuan kwùal, Thin ɡuɤ̆l [Shorto 2006 # 1715]; perhaps also PVM *t-koːlɁ > Viet. côí ‘rice mortar’ [Ferlus] (for absence of the coda in OC, see ¤6.9).

‘Maternal uncle’ [Shi]: ‘mother’s brother, husband’s or wife’s father’.    ||  [D] PMin *giuᴮ > Xiàmén kuᶜ², Fú’ān kouᶜ²  ||  [E] ST: PTB *kuw > WT Ɂa-kʰu ~ kʰu-bo ‘paternal uncle, husband’; WB kui ‘honorific affix; brother’ (HST: 154), JP gə³¹-gu³¹ ‘uncle’. STC (158 n. 428) relates the TB root to → kūn1 昆 ‘elder brother’. This word may be derived from → jiù3 舊 ‘old’ (so Sagart 1999: 165f).

‘Old (not new), ancient’ [Shi]. The OC rime and tone are revealed by Shījīng rimes.   ||  [T] MTang geu < giu, ONW gu  — [D] PMin *giuᶜ  ||  [E] This word is prob. shared with PTai *kəuᴮ ‘old, ancient’.
‘An owl-like bird’, the same as xiū 鵂 below’ [SW], is considered related to → xiāo3 梟 in HST: 115.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *ku ~ *gu > WB kʰu, Lisu gu; Kachin u-kʰu; Mikir iŋkʰu (STC: 185).
‘Owl’ [Zhuang]. Because of the onomatopoetic nature of these words, exact phonological correspondences cannot be expected.

‘To dwell, settlement, tranquil, comfortable’ [Shi], ‘sit down’ [Lun]. Shījīng rimes indicate a very early form *kaɁ; later *kaᴬ and *kah are equally common (Mattos 1971: 309). This may be an OC phonological variant of → chǔ3 處.    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ky (平); MGZY  gÿu (平) [ky]; MTang ky < kø, ONW kø < kio (?)  ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ⁵⁵kœyᴬ¹, Táishān kui³³; M-Amoy ⁴⁴kuᴬ¹
‘To squat’ 踞 [Zuo]; ‘abode, dwelling, position’ 居 [Shi] (Baxter 1992: 312).   ||  [<] ‘abode’: exopass. of jū 居 (kjwo) (§4.4), lit. ‘what is dwelled in’.
‘Straw’ [Shi] > ‘straw as bottom in shoe’ [Chuci] (also read MC tsʰjwo, tsjwo); ‘bedding or packing of straw (for objects presented)’ [Zhouli].
‘Bedding or packing of straw (for objects presented)’ [Zhouli].  ||  [C] An allofam is perh. → jiè8 藉 ‘mat or bedding’ (so Wáng Lì 1982: 167).
‘Both, all, together’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] ? ST: WT kʰyu (-bo/-mo) ‘flock, herd, company’ (so HST: 89; Karlgren 1956: 9).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ky (平); MGZY gÿu (平) [ky]; MTang ky < kuo, ONW kuo
‘Be complete, be together’ [BI, Shi] > ‘to provide, arrange’ Zuo] > ‘an implement, utensil’ [BI, Zuo].

‘Colt, young horse’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] Jū is the same etymon as → gǒu 狗 ‘puppy dog’ acc. to Wáng Lì (1982: 182); however, gǒu which comes from a non-ST language, is not a homophone of jū. It is more likely that jū is cognate to PTB *ku(r) or *kor ‘horse’ (HPTB: 385) in Monpa kur-ta < ku-rta ‘horse’ (rta <- WT ‘horse’), Tani *kɯ, JP kum-ra < ku-mra[ŋ] ‘horse’ (mraŋ ‘horse’); Lushai saᴸ-kɔrR ‘a horse, pony’ (but acc. to Lorrain p. 400 this word is derived from kɔrR ‘coat’), Mru kor-ŋa [Löffler 1966: 123]. For the loss of final *-r, see §7.7.5. Alternatively, one may consider jū cognate to → qū4 驅 *kho ‘to drive’ (a horse), ‘gallop’.

‘Orange’ (fruit) [Shu].  ||  [E] <> MK-Khmer kwic ‘tangerine’. A less likely connection is MK *kruuc, *kruəc ‘citrus’ (Shorto 2006 #846): Khmer krōč ‘citrus fruit’, P-Hre-Sedang kruč (Bodman 1980: 96) -> WB hrok ‘citrus’.
‘To nourish, suckle’ (a child) [Shi].  ||  This is prob. a vocalic variant of the wf → gǔ14 穀 ‘suckle’, see Table C-2 (under → chù4, xù 畜) for parallel stems.

‘To bow, bend’ (the body) 鞠 [Lun], ‘concave side of river bend’ 鞫 [Shi].  ||  [E] ST *kuk: PTB *kuk ~ *guk > WT ’gug(s)-pa, bkug, dgug ‘to bend’ ᛝ dgu id., Bahing kuk- ‘to bend’ tr. ᛝ guk- ‘to bend’ intr., PLB *gok ‘crooked, bent; return, go back’, WB kok ‘crooked, not upright’ ᛝ ə-kok ‘a crook’ (Matisoff TSR no. 2; STC: 77, 125, 159; HST: 41-42); Kuki-Naga *m-kuːk ‘knee’ (STC: 120). The Chinese items could also be cognate to WT ’kʰyog-po ~ kʰyog-po ‘crooked, bent’ ᛝ gyog-pa ‘curved, crooked’ (so Bodman 1980: 161). Prob. related to → gōu1 句鉤枸區. A variant with OC rime  *-ok is → qū1 曲. Another wf with OC *o ~ *u variation is → rú4 懦臑.

‘To chew’ [Guan].  ||  [E] Area word: ST *dzaɁ >  PTB *dzaɁ > Garo chaɁ ‘eat’, Chepang jeɁ-sa ‘eat’, WT za-ba, zos / bzas ‘to eat’ (STC p. 28) ᛝ zas ‘food’; PL *dza²  ‘to eat’ ᛝ dza¹ ‘food’, WB caᴮ ‘to eat, corrode, wear out’ ᛝ ca, ə-ca ‘food’. Kuki-Naga: *dza(k) ‘eat’ (STC p. 101 n. 289). <> PMK *cyaɁ (Shorto 1972): Mon ca ‘eat’, OKhmer cya /ciiə/ ‘to eat’, PSBahn. *saː ‘eat’.

‘To eat, eat together’, is a Han period Chǔ dial. word [SW; FY 1,31] which suggests a foreign origin. Occasionally CH words have a final -k for a TB open syllable (§6.1). Another derivation from the same root is → cān2 餐.

‘To eat’ [BI, Shi], ‘food’ Guoce], ‘meal’ [Zhuang].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ts'an (平); MGZY  tshan (平) [ts'an]  ||  [<] nominal n-suffix derivation from the ST root *dza.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *dza ‘to eat’> WT bzan ‘food’, gzan-pa ‘to eat’ (STC: 159 n. 428). Alternatively, cān could be  cognate to WT ’tsʰal-ba (< N-tsal) ‘to eat’ ᛝ tsʰal-ma ‘breakfast’ (so Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 30; HST: 69). Since MC tsʰ- = WT gs- (§5.9.1), the first possibility seems preferable (WT aspiration as in tsʰal is non-phonemic).
‘Food’ [Shi].   ||  [<] exopass. of cān, lit. ‘what is eaten’ (§4.4).

‘Round basket’ 筥 [BI, Shi], 籧 [Li].  ||  [E] Prob. ST: TB-PLB *kak, WB kak ‘large wicker basket’; JP kaɁ⁵⁵ ‘open wicker basket’; Akha kʰa, Lisu hka²-tu³ ‘rough, loosely woven’ (Matisoff TSR no. 7; HST: 39). The earliest graph 筥 implies an *r in the OC initial, though.

‘Carpenter’s square’ [Meng], ‘rule, law’ [Lun]; ‘troops drawn up in a square’ 拒 [Zuo].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ky (上); MGZY gÿu (上) [ky]; MTang ky < kuo, ONW kuo  ||  [E] Possibly related to TB-WB kyaŋ- ‘carpenter’s square’ (for finals, see §3.2.4), or to WT grwa ‘angle,corner’. Allofam → kuāng4 筐 ‘square basket’.
‘Carpenter’s square’ [Xun].  ||  [<] nominal t-suffix (§6.2.1).

‘Gutter’ [Zhouli].  ||  [E] ST *(k)wa- ‘passage through’: Lushai kuaᴸ ‘a hole, burrow, cavity’ ᛝ kuaᴸ / kuakF ‘be open or clear (as way, path, road etc.), to open (up), make way through’; WB ə-waᶜ ‘opening of door, hole’. Allofam is prob. → qú5 衢 ‘crossroads’.

‘Canal’ [Li] may be the s. w. as → qú5 衢 ‘crossroads’ (note the TB / ST field of meaning below). We should expect MC gju which is implied by the phonetic jù 巨 and the cognates, but the MC rimes -ju ~  -jwo have merged in almost all dialects and have already mingled in some phonetic series.
‘Watering channel, drain, canal’ [Shu]. For the final dental, see §6.2.1.

‘A hole’ [Shi] > ‘opening, breach, gate’ [Li] > ‘look-out tower over the gate’ [Shi].   ||  [<] aspiration for hollow objects (§5.8.6) plus t-suffix (§6.2.1) of the ST stem, therefore prob. unrelated to → jué9 撅闕 ‘excavate’.

‘To rise, surge, start; lift, promote’ [Shi].  ||  [E] This may be cognate to WT ’kʰyog-pa, kʰyag ‘to lift, carry’ (HST: 103) ᛝ skya-ba, bskyas ‘to carry’. Alternatively, Baxter / Sagart (1998: 48) relate this word to → yú11 舁 ‘to lift’.  ||  If the root should be *ka or *kja, then → jiē7 揭 and → jiǎn9 攓 may represent forms with additional final consonants. However, a root *ka is so common that many a meaning can be associated with it, and ‘lift’ is also a rather broad concept.

‘To leak, ooze’ [Li].  ||  [E] ST: WT ’dzag-pa, (g-)zags ‘to drop, drip, flow out’ ᛝ ’tsʰag-pa, btsags ‘to cause to trickle, strain’; PLB *ɴtsakᴴ ‘to drop, drip’ [Matisoff TSR: 44], WB cak ‘fall in drops’ ᛝ ə-cak ‘a drop’ (HST: 152; for CH tone B, see §3.2.2). Loaned into PVM: *k-ɉɔh ‘to drip’ [Ferlus].
‘Marshy ground’.
‘Ricecake’ [Chuci] could be related to WT mna’ ‘cake’; cf. Tai: S. ka-nom ‘cake’ [Unger Hao-ku 33, 1986].

‘To dread, feel apprehension’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR gy (去); MGZY kÿu (去) [gy]; MTang gy < guo, ONW guo  ||  [E] Li F. (1976: 46) relates this word to Tai: S. kluaᴬ¹ < *kl- ‘to fear’, and refers also to WT ’gul-ba ‘to tremble’.  ||  [E] The root of this wf is apparently *wa- as indicated by yǔ-yǔ, by the QY initial xj- in jué, and by the loan graph wàng 迋. For the final -ŋ in the last two items, see §6.5.2.
‘Be anxious, careful’ [Shi], ‘frightened glance’ [Li].
‘Be circumspect’ [Liezi].
‘Anxious look’ 矍 [Yi] (also MC kjwak); ‘scared’ 戄 [Zhuang].
‘To fear’ 匡 [Liji], kuāng-kuāng 恇恇 ‘to fear, dread’ [Hou Hanshu].
‘To frighten, scare’ [Zuo].

‘To grasp, depend on’ [Shi], also later written 据. Alternatively perh. related to → jué12 攫 OC *kwak, although the rimes do not agree.    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ky (去); MGZY gÿu (去) [ky]; MTang ky < kø, ONW kø < kio (?)
‘To grasp’ (a plant) [Shi].
‘To grasp, seize’ (people, horses) [BI, Shi]. The vowels differ, though (§11.1.5).

‘To collect, store’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dzy (上去); MGZY tsÿu (上去) [dzy]; MTang dzy, ONW dzuo  ||  [E] ST *tso: WB cuᶜ ‘to collect, gather together’, WT ’tsʰogs-pa ‘to assemble, gather, meet’. Downer (1959: 275) determined the MC reading dzjuᴮ for the verb, tone C dzjuᶜ for the nouns ‘collection, stores; masses, group’ [Zuo] which is an exopass. derivation (§4.4). Bodman (BIHP 39, 1969: 340) adds this word to zú 卒 (under → zāo2 遭).  ||  [E] ST: WT ’dzog-pa, btsogs ‘to heap together, mix up together’ ᛝ ’tsʰogs-pa, tsʰogs ‘to assemble, meet’ ᛝ tsʰogs ‘assemblage, crowd’ ᛝ sogs-pa < OTib. stsogs-pa, bstsogs ‘to accumulate, gather together’ (HST: 108).

‘Clan, clansmen’ [BI, Shi], a minimal segment of a lineage → zōng1 宗 (Chang K.C. 1976: 70) (Wáng Lì 1982: 197; CVST 4: 32). Affiliation with jù is likely in light of etymological parallels in WT (see below) and zú 卒 ‘group’ (→ zāo2 遭).
‘Collect, accumulate, highest degree’ [Gongyang, Guoce] (Baxter 1992: 239). Yú Mǐn (1948: 43) relates zuì to → jí13 集輯 ‘collect’.   ||  [T] MTang tsuɑi, ONW tsuɑC
‘To collect’ [Shu], ‘thicket’ [Meng] (Wáng Lì 1982: 197). Acc. to Benedict (1976: 178) and Bodman (BIHP 39,1969: 334), this is an s-prefix derivation of → tóng1 同 ‘join’, but see §5.7.
‘Sheaf, bundle’ [Guoyu], ‘numerous’ [Zhuang].

‘To roll, roll over, turn over’ 卷 [Shi]; ‘to scroll’ 捲.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kyen (上); MGZY gÿon (上) [kyɔn]  ||  [E] ST: Lushai hrualᴴ ‘roll up in the hand, twist’. Prob. an allofam of → quán3 卷拳, but see there. The Tai word is prob. a CH loan: Wuming klianᶜ¹ ‘roll, scroll’ (Bodman 1980: 108), Mun gluanᶜ² ‘roll up’ (Haudricourt 1950: 563).
‘Fat’ (of bird meat) [Lüshi]  ||  [E] Perh. ST, a nominal n-suffix form related to WB cʰu ‘be fat, obese’ < PTB *tsow (STC no. 277). This stem may be related to → sāo4 臊 ‘fat’.
‘Fat’ (of bird) [Chuci], later ‘fat and rich broth’.

‘Tired’ [Lunyu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR gyen (去); MGZY kwÿan (去) [gyɛn]  ||  [E] Bodman (1980: 150; also HST: 151) compares the CH word to WT kyor-kyor ‘feeble, weak’ ᛝ kʰyor-ba ~ ’kʰyor-ba ‘to reel, stagger, walk as if weak’. CVST (5: 17) connects the next word with Lushai kʰɔlɁᴸ ‘troublesome, tiresome, harsh’:
‘Be exhausted’ [Shi].

‘To cut off’ [Zuo], ‘bite off’ [Meng], ‘decide’ 決 [Guoce] > ‘farewell words’ 訣 [Lie]. This may be the same word as → jué2 決. An allofam is → quē 缺.    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kye (入); MGZY  gwÿa (入) [kyɛ]; ONW kuėt

‘To open’ [Zhouli] > ‘open a passage’ [Shu]. This may be the same word as → jué1 決.  ||  [E] ST: WB kyuiᴮ ‘be broken’ ᛝ kʰyuiᴮ ‘to break in two’ ᛝ kʰuiᶜ ‘defective, wanting, incomplete’ (Matisoff ICSTLL 1978: 150). Allofam → quē 缺 ‘break, splinter’.
‘To divide, make a breach’ [Yi].  ||  [<] perh. a double caus. formation of jué (tone C §4.3; and initial *r-causative §7.5)

‘A superior type of horse of the northern barbarians’ [Xu Guang, Shiji; mis-identified in SW] (Pulleyblank 1962: 245). The word’s source is unknown, yet it shows some similarity with IE-Tocharian B yakwe ‘horse’ (< PIE *ekuos) (Pokorny 301).

‘To wink with eyes’ [GY, Liùshūgù 六書故], i.e. beckon (with the eyes)’.  ||  [E] Perhaps MK *gwac, *gwaac ‘to beckon’ (Shorto 2006 #868): Central Sakai gawet, giwet, Khasi kʰawoit ‘beckon with hand’. See → huī4 麾 for possible variants; additional syn. → xuè2 糅.
‘Stone’ [Xun] acc. to commentaries; prob. related to Tai: S. kʰotᴰ² < g- ‘a stone lodged in a tree’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 236).

Third person pronoun ‘he, she, it, they, his, her...’ [BI, Shi, Shu], occasionally it also serves as possessive for the first and second persons in classical Chinese (Takashima JAOS 119.3, 1999: 404-431). Bodman (JAOS 68, 1948: 52-60; 1980: 161) relates this word to WT kʰyod ‘you’.
‘Fern’ (edible, Pteridium aquilinum) [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT skyas-ma, skyes-ma  ‘fern’ (Unger Hao-ku 39, 1992). It also occurs in PTai *kuət > *kuutᴰ¹ ‘kind of edible fern’ (Diplazium esculentum).

‘To excavate’ 闕 [Zuo] > ‘pull up, dig out’ 撅 [Yi Zhoushu].   ||  [E] ST: *r-ko-t (STC no. 420) > WT rkod-pa ‘excavate, dig’ ᛝ rko-ba ‘to dig’ (HST: 63); JP got³¹ ‘dig’. This item may be related to → kū4 堀窟.
‘To wake up’ intr. [Shi], ‘get insight’ [Lunyu], ‘grateful’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] ONW käk

‘To wake up’ intr. [Zuo: Cheng 10, 5] is supposedly the reading of this graph in the sense of ‘wake up’ intr. in Shījīng, Zuǒzhuàn and elsewhere, but the Shījīng rime requires OCM *-k, not *-kh (Baxter 1992: 611), which would agree with the intr. use. The tone C reading may therefore be a later innovation.   ||  [C] Possible allofams: → jiǎo12 攪; → lù12 摝.
‘To seize’ [Li], may be related to → huò4 穫, or alternatively to → jù6 據 OC *kah although the rimes do not agree.  ||  [E] ST: WT ’gog-pa, bkog ‘snatch, seize, take away’ (HST p. 130).

‘Be well balanced, equal, alike’ 均 [Shi] > ‘weight of 30 jin’ 鈞 [BI, Meng], ‘soldiers’ uniform’ 袀 [Lü].   ||  [<] k-prefix noun of → yún1 勻 *win ‘even, uniform’ (§5.4) (Baxter / Sagart 1998: 47).  ||  [E] ST: PTB *kyiːn ‘weigh’ > WB kʰyin ‘weigh, plumb, level, a balance’, Lushai kiːn [HPTB: 277]. Perh. jīn 斤 (kjən) LH kin ‘a weight’ [Han period and later] is a popular variant.

‘Potter’s wheel’ [Zhuang].  ||  [<] k-prefix noun of xún 旬 *s-win ‘all round, cycle’, lit. ‘the rotating thing’ (§5.4).  ||  [E] This wf could equally well belong to either ST *wir (→ yún5 雲) or PAA *wil, the two may have converged in China. PAA *wil seems on balance more likely given the field of meaning in OC and AA (incl. ‘go everywhere, roam, patrol’), and the prehistoric Lóngshān culture origin of the pottery wheel in eastern China (AA?). AA-Khmer /vil/ ‘to turn, revolve, rotate’ ᛝ /kravil/ ‘ring, circle, loop’ ᛝ kravēla /krawaaɛl/ ‘to revolve, go around, go to and fro, roam, patrol, explore’ ᛝ chvēla /cwaaɛl/ ‘to turn, spin, go back and forth, come and go’; Santali gɛrwɛl ‘ring’. This root **wil is prob. connected with → wéi5 圍 *wel.  ||  Jūn may possibly be the same word as → jūn1 均鈞 ‘well balanced’. For an overview of synonyms, see under → huí 回.

‘Everywhere, all round’ [Shi] > ‘ten day cycle, ten (days)’ [OB, Shu], e.g. xún yǒu wǔ rì 旬有五日 (ten / and / five / days) ‘...(after) 15 days...’ [Zuo: Wen 16, 6].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR zyn (平); MGZY zÿun (平) [zyn]  ||  [<] s-iterative of a root *win ‘rotate’ (§5.2.3). ‘Rotate’ as a metaphor for cyclical time like the ‘ten day cycle, week’ has parallels in TB languages, e.g. Lahu qh`ɔ ‘return’ > ‘year’ (Matisoff D. of Lahu: 310). For synonyms, see under → huí 回.
‘Go everywhere, publish throughout’ 徇 [Zuo]; ‘devote oneself, wholly given up to’  [Zhuang] > ‘accompany in death’ 殉 [Zuo], 侚 [QY].

‘Ruler, lord, lady’ [BI, Shi] > ‘treat some one like a lord’ tr., ‘function as ruler’ intr. [Shi]; jūn-zǐ  君子 ‘son of a ruler, gentleman’ (A. Waley).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR kyn (平); MGZY gÿun (平) [kyn]; ONW kun  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. Perh. related to MK: Mon kmin, kmun /kmøn/ ‘to exercise royal power, be king, reign’. Mei Tsu-Lin suggest an alternative etymology, see → yuán1 元. Baxter / Sagart (1998: 47) suggest that jūn is a derivation by k-prefix from → yǐn1 尹 LH winᴮ ‘straight, administer’, but the rimes do not agree.

‘Troops, army’ [Shi] > ‘encampment’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. Perh. ST: WT g-yul ‘army, battle’ (Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986, 30); since jūn is in a *w-initial phonetic series, k- may be the nominalizing prefix (§5.4), note also the frefix g- in WT g-yul; regarding WT y- for CH and foreign *w-, see §12.9. Alternatively, jūn could be a derivation from → yùn2 運暈 ‘be on the move’; or be related to → qún 群.
‘District’ [Zuo].   ||  [E] Perh. ST: WT kʰul ‘district, province’ (Gong 1995).
‘Be deep’ > ‘profound, wise’ 浚 [Shi] > caus. ‘to deepen’ 濬 [Shu] > ‘to ladle out’ [Zuo], ‘dig out’ 浚 [Meng]. Etymology not clear.

‘To open the way, open access to, set free’ [Shi, Shu], 闓 (also read MC kʰậiᴮ) [Guan], replaced → qǐ6 啟 ‘to open’ because this was the Hàn emperor Jǐng’s personal name (157-150 BC).
