‘Sour’ [Shu].  ||  [E] ST and area word: PTB *suːr ~ *swaːr ‘sour’ (STC no. 42) > Kan. sur-k, Lushai tʰuurR < tʰuurɁ, Mikir tʰor ‘sour’; AA-Khmer [cuur], OKhmer jūr ‘sour’ is perh. connected.
‘Garlic’ [Dadai Liji]  ||  [E] ST *swa-n (HPTB: 177): PL *swan¹/² ‘onion’, WB krak-swan.

‘To calculate, count’ [Yili] > ‘reckon, take into account’ [Lunyu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR swɔn (去); MGZY son (去) [sɔn]; ONW suɑn  ||  [E] Etymology is not clear. A connection with WT ’čʰor-ba, šor ‘to count’ has been suggested (Gong Hwang-cherng 1991); but WT š- would derive from earlier *sy-.

‘To pacify, comfort’ [Shi], ‘tranquil’ [Shu], ‘walk slowly’ [Shi].  ||  [WFE] ST has *ŋ(w)al ~ *nwal parallel stems (§5.12.1) for this etymon:  ||  (1) *C-nwal >  綏 *snui, WT rnal ‘rest, tranquility of mind’ ᛝ mnal ‘sleep’, perh. also ᛝ ñal-ba, ñol ‘lie, down, sleep’ ᛝ mñel-ba ‘get tired’ ᛝ ñel-ba ‘be ill’ ᛝ mñald-po ‘fall ill’ (Bodman 1980: 70; HST: 124); KN-Lai nuar / noɁr ‘be slow’ [LTBA 20.2: 112].   ||  (2) A ST parallel stem *ŋwal is represented by → wò2 臥 (§5.12.1).
‘Peaceful’ [SW: syn. 安], ‘to stop’ [Erya] (Baxter 1992: 417).

‘Marrow’ [Kuoce].   ||  [D] M-Xiàmén col. tsʰeᴮ¹  ||  [E] ST *swai is prob. related to ST *s(-)wi ‘blood’, see → xuè1 血 ‘blood’ (Matisoff LTBA 15.1, 1992: 168-177). Some TB languages have a cognate of xuě as well as of suǐ, one meaning ‘blood’, the other ‘marrow’, but not always the same ones: NNaga-Chang si ‘blood’ (ᛝ xuě), hai ‘marrow’ (ᛝ suǐ); JP sai³¹ ‘blood’, lə³³-sui³³ ‘marrow’ (Matisoff op. cit. p. 169).

A Min word: Xiàmén suiᴮ¹ ‘pretty, beautiful, lovely’. Norman (p.c.) suggests that this word may perh. be the same as Mand. shuǐ  水 ‘water’ which is found in the sense of ‘pretty’ (‘pretty much’) in certain expressions. But note also Tai: Siam suuiᴬ¹ ‘beautiful’.

‘Year’ [OB, BI, Shi], ‘planet Jupiter’ [Zuo] (Shaughnessy 1991: 99), ‘year’ (of age) [Meng]. Shānhǎijīng implies that ‘Jupiter’ was already named suì at the beginning of the Zhou dynasty.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR suj (去); MGZY sue (去) [suɛ]; ONW  suei  ||  [D] PMin *hueᶜ ‘year’ (of age) does not agree with the rest of Chinese dialects; perh. there is a Tai connection.   ||  [<] Prob. derived from → yuè4 越 ‘pass over’ (Mei Tsu-Lin Tsing Hua Journal of Chinese Studies 12.1, 1979: 117-32) with the iterative s-prefix  (§5.2.3); the original sense was either ‘travelling = passing planet’ = ‘Jupiter’ > ‘Jovian cycle’ > ‘year’ (Takashima 1996 II: 131), or ‘passing time period’ = ‘year’ > ‘year star, Jupiter’ (Mei). Alternatively, suì may be derived from a word like → yuán5 員圓圜 *wan < ST *val ‘circle’, then lit. ‘start the circle again’. In CH and many TB languages temporal units are seen as recurrent cycles; note zhōu 周 ‘circle’ > ‘week’.  ||  [E] Mei Tsu-Lin relates suì further to WT skyod ‘to go, walk; go down, set’, but see → yuè4 越. The connection with PTai *xuap > S. kʰuapᴰ¹ᴸ ‘year’ (of age of children) is not clear. Acc. to Bodman (1980: 66) Tai could be a loan from Chinese (OC *-ts from *-ts or *-ps). Note the Mǐn form which seems closer to Tai. Or, contrary to the preceding paragraph, the CH word might have originated in Kam-Tai, but an internal CH etymology is preferable.

‘To advance, accomplish, achieve’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [WFE] ST: PLB *s-yuy  has a grammaticalized function; ‘Kamarupan’ *s-yuy ~ *m-yuy ‘to follow’ (Matisoff), Kuki-Naga *jwi ‘follow’ > Lushai zuiF, Siyin jui.   ||  [C] An allofam may possibly be → duì7 隊 (so Sagart 1999: 85). This wf *wi(t) is distinct from others which all share a root *lu ~ *ju: → l1 律, → yóu2 由, → shùn1 順.
‘To follow, go along’ [BI, Shi]. This is prob. cognate to the preceding word (so Matisoff LTBA 15.1, 1992), but the rimes do not agree.
‘To follow, come to, to the point of, thereupon’ [BI, Shi, Shu].
‘Ear of grain’ [Shi], 穟 [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: Lushai vuiᴸ /vuiɁᴸ < vuis ‘to ear’ (of grain, grass), ‘come into ear’, Kuki-Chin languages *vui.

‘Grandchild’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] ? ST: PTB *śu(w) (so STC: 158) > Mikir, Meithei, Dimasa etc. su, Bodo sou, JP ʃu⁵¹ ‘grandchild’, Lushai tuF ‘id.’ (for the initial, see §12.3). The MK synonyms may be look-alikes: PMK *cuuɁ ‘grandchild’ (Shorto 1976: 1062) > OMon cow, Khmer /cav/, Palaung su ‘grandchild’ < *cu (*c- > s- is a Palaungic innovation).

‘Cooked rice’ [Shi], ‘(warm) evening meal’ [Meng] may perh. be a variant of → xín0  尋爓 [sim] *s-ləm (PTB *slum) ‘to heat’ (food) with labial dissimilation of the final nasal -m rather than vocalic dissimilation (§6.7), but this is not likely.

‘Diminish, subtract’ [Yi], ‘damage’ [Lunyu].  ||  [E] Sagart (1999: 70) derives this word from → yǔn2 隕殞霣 *winɁ ‘fall, drop’. There is no MC syllable like siwen in div. 4, therefore a front vowel i might have been lost early in OC *sûnɁ (from *suinɁ ?).  ||  [WFE] ST: TB cognates are perh. WT sun-pa ‘be tired of, weary, renounce, resign’, WB sun ‘fail, fall behind, turn away’ ᛝ sunᴮ ‘spent, expended’.   ||  [C] Sagart (1999: 82) suggests that this word family may be related to xún 循馴 (under → shùn1 順).
‘To withdraw, yield, be compliant’ 遜 [Shu] (Mand. xùn); ‘humble’ 巽 [Yi] (Mandarin sùn).

‘To be straight, upright’ [Meng], ‘vertical, longitudinal’ [Li].  ||  [E] AA: OMon: crok /crɔk/ ‘to set / plant upright’ (flags, umbrellas etc.); perh. related to Khmer jara /cɔɔr/ ‘be straight’ ᛝ jhara /chɔɔr/ ‘to stand, be standing, upright, erect, straight, vertical’, in which case the OC form would be the result of metathesis of the r before a final -k, i.e. < *sur-k (§6.1).

‘Place, position, situation’ [BI, Shi]. The function as an indefinite substitute for the post-verbal element (Dobson, LAC: 157), as in yǒu suǒ guī 有所歸 ‘have a place to return to’, or suǒ qù 所去 ‘what [the subject] rejects’, is derived from the noun ‘place’ (Pulleyblank 1995: 68). → yōu1 攸 provides an exact semantic parallel.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ʂu (上), LR ʂwɔ; MGZY (zhu >) shu (上) [ʂu]; ONW ṣø < ṣo  ||  [E] ST *sra > PTB *sra (HPTB: 78): JP ʃə³¹-ra³¹ ‘place’ (< *s-ra; Matisoff in STC: 171 n. 457), WB ra ‘place, situation, thing, subject’, Mru ra ‘place’ [Löffler 1966: 146], Dulong sə̂®`ɑ ‘thing’ [LaPolla LTBA 24.2, 2001: 2]. TB cognates to this word and to shì 事 ‘affair, thing’ (→ shì2 士仕) are difficult to distinguish. It is not clear if and how WT sa ‘place, earth’ and / or Zhangzhung slas ‘earth’ are related; WT sa is also often associated with → shā1 沙 *srai ‘sand’ – not likely.

‘Rope’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR saw (入), PR, LR sawɁ; MGZY saw (入) [saw]; ONW sɑk  ||  [E] AA: PVM *ɉaːk ‘rope’ [Ferlus], PMonic *ɉook ‘creeper, vine, rope’ > Mon ‘string, cord’. AA -> Tai: S. čʰ¨ıakᴰ²ᴸ < PTai * ǰ- ‘rope’, Saek saakᴰ² < z- ‘vines, rope’. In Mǐn and other southern dialects, this is the common word for ‘rope’ (as opposed to → shéng 繩 in the north). OC must have borrowed this word because foreign / ST *z- > OC s-, whereas OC *s- is not expected to become a voiced initial elsewhere. For a possible parallel development, see → xiāo2 消銷. Also the narrowed CH meaning ‘rope’ speaks in favor of a foreign origin.

‘Small’ (birds), ‘petty’ [Shi]; ‘fragments’ [DuànYùcái], Mand. ‘trivial, petty’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR swɔ (上); MGZY swo (上) [swɔ].  ||  [E] ST: JP soi³¹ ‘small, weak, paltry’, WB swai ‘slender and tapering’. Alternatively, the word may be related to TB-Lushai nɔiR < nɔiɁ ‘small pieces, fragments’ ᛝ nɔiᴴ < nɔi ‘odd bits and pieces left over’. Pulleyblank (JCL 21.2, 1994: 367) suggests that suǒ is derived from → xiǎo1 小 ‘small’ – very speculative.
‘Small, trifling’ 脞 [Shu]; ‘rubble’ 掃 [GY].

Mand. ‘he’ 他, ‘she’  她, ‘it’ 它.    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR t'ɔ (平), PR t'a; MGZY tho (平) [t'ɔ]  ||  [D] A col. word derived from → tuō1 他 ‘other’, southern dialects: Y-Guǎngzhōu ⁵⁵tʰaᴬ¹, K-Méixiàn tʰɑᴬ¹. Some Mand. dialects have the expected tʰɔᴬ¹.
‘Babble’ 沓 [Shi], ‘babble, garrulous’ 誻 [Guoyu].   ||  [E] ST: WT lab-pa ‘to tell’ ᛝ lo ‘talk, rumor’ < lop (HST: 145); or alternatively related to WT dob-dob-pa ~ čab-čob ‘talk nonsense’.
‘Garrulous’ [Xun].

‘To touch, adjoin’ 眔 [BI], ‘together with, and’ 遝 [BI]; ‘join, unite’ 沓 [Chuci].  ||  [E] MC d- can derive from an OC T-like or L-like initial. Baxter (1992; also CVST  3:18) relates tà to TB-WT sleb-pa, (b)slebs ‘to arrive, reach, extend’ and sets up an OC initial *l-; he also relates tà to → dài8 逮.  ||  An OC T-like initial would connect the word with MK *bɗap, *bɗaap ‘to touch, adjoin’  ‌(Shorto ɐ1264) with which tà agrees closely in meaning.  The OC and MK vowels are different, but uncertainty of vowels is often encountered in MK (peruse Shorto 2006) and OC. TB items under dié6  輒 partially overlap with tà.
(‘Globe-fish like’:) ‘rounded’ person’s back in old age [Shi] (so Karlgren) brings to mind WT ldir-ba ‘be distended, inflated’.

‘To kill’ in Mǐn: PMin *dʰaiᴬ², *dʰi.   ||  [E] Area word: Tai: S. taaiᴬ¹, Zhuang tʰaiᴬ¹/²  ‘to die’ (< PTai *trai, *prai); PMY *təjH < **pə-təjH ‘to kill’ ᛝ *dəjH < **mətəjH ‘to die’ (M. Ratliff, p.c.).
‘Moss’ [GY].  — [E] <> PTai *glaiᴬ² ‘moss’ (Li 1977: 200).

‘Servant or slave women’ 嬯 [BI], the lowest kind of servant 臺 [Zuo].  ||  [E] AA: OKhmer tai /təj/ ‘woman, wife’ ᛝ tai /Ïəj/ ‘female human, female slave’ ᛝ OKhmer kantai ‘female, wife’, Khasi kynthei ‘girl’ (-> TB-Mikir -kintʰáj); Aslian lgs. on the Malay Peninsula: kəndeh, kəneh, kənah ‘wife’, kenaɁ ‘females of animals’, kanɁ, kena ‘woman’, knaɁ ‘girl’, kəneh, knih, etc. ‘wife’ [S. Lewitz 1976: 761-771]. Some of these items are reminiscent of → n1 女, but they are prob. unrelated. MK *kn-, *k- is a female marker (see → qī3 妻).

‘Be covetous, greedy’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR t'am (平), PR t'an; MGZY tham (平) [t'am]; ONW tʰɑm  ||  [WFE] ST: PTB *d-rum (STC no. 457) > WT drum-pa ‘to long, desire’, WB krum ‘be lean, pine away’ ᛝ kʰyum ‘to pine away’, JP mə³¹-rim³³ ‘to crave to eat’. HST alternatively suggests WT ham-pa ‘avarice, covetousness, greed’ as a cognate, but see → kǎn6 顑.
‘Covetous’ 婪 [Chuci]; ‘covetous, rapacious’ 惏 [Zuo].
‘To stuff (one’s face), be gluttonous’ [Huainan] may belong here.

‘To kill’ is a Han-period Chǔ dialect word [FY 1,16], cognate to lán 惏(lậm) which was a Chén-Chǔ dialect word for ‘kill’ [FY 2, 19]. It is doubtful that this root is connected with → kān4 戡 ‘kill’ (a southern Chǔ-Xiāng dialect word), or with cǎn 慘 (tsʰậmᴮ) ‘to kill’ [FY 1,5], though all these forms could theoretically derive from the same root (so Sagart 1999: 151). The word may be cognate to WB hrumᴮ ‘fail, be defeated’.

‘To reach into with the hand, investigate’ [Lunyu, Yi, Shu]. The initial of the phonet. series is not certain; the word may be related to → shēn3 深 ‘deep’ (provided the initial was OCM *nh-; so Unger Hao-ku 47, 1995). Alternatively, the word agrees with TB-Lushai tʰamR ‘to feel’ (especially with the hand).

‘To dry up’ (of a river) [SW], later ‘beach’. The graph suggests an OC initial *nh-. Yet tān could be compared to PTB *tan > WT tʰan-pa ‘dry weather, heat, drought’, WB tʰanᶜ-tʰanᶜ ‘nearly dry’ (STC: 190 n.; HPTB: 301), if we assume that the word was written with this phonetic only during the Han period (note its first attestation in SW) when OC *nh- and *th- had merged into tʰ-. Syn. → tǎn2 坦.
‘Extend, spread’ [Shi].  ||  [WFE] <> MK: PWa *dɐm ‘spread out a mat’.
‘Bamboo mat’ [Shi] (Karlgren 1956: 16).

‘A pond, pool’ [Chu].  ||  [E] This late OC southern word (Chǔcí) is prob. a foreign loan: PKS *tʰlam¹ (but many KS languages have initial d) <- Malay kolam ‘pond, well, pool’ <- Tamil kulam ‘pond, tank’ (Thurgood 1988: 199). Perh. → táng2 塘 is a variant of this word. Alternatively, tán which is glossed as a ‘deep pond’ could be the same word as tán 潭 ‘deep water, abyss’ [Chuci], and possibly related to → shēn1 深 ‘deep’. TB-WB thumᴮ ‘pond, lake’ differs in initial and vowel.

‘Shoot pellets at’ [Zuo], ‘pluck, play a stringed instrument’ [Li].   ||  [D] PMin *d̯ɑn ~ *dɑnᶜ ‘to pluck’ (a lute).  ||  [E] This etymon is prob. related to PTB *m-dan (STC: 190) or rather *tal > JP n³¹-dan³³ ‘crossbow’, Tiddim tʰalR < tʰalɁ ‘a bow’, Lushai tʰalR < tʰalɁ ‘arrow, dart’.
‘Bow for shooting pellets’ [Guoce, SW]; dàn-wán 彈丸 ‘pellet’ [Hanfei], later dàn also ‘pellet’.    ||  [<] general derivation of tán (§3.5).
‘Brilliant, magnificent’ [Zhuang], ‘aflame, burning’ (of sensation) [Shi]. This is an allofam of the wf under → yán2 炎.

‘To speak’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dam (平), PR dan; MGZY tam (平) [dam]  ||  [WFE] ST: WT gtam < g-lham ‘talk, discourse’ ᛝ gtom-pa ‘to speak’ ᛝ WT gdam-pa < glam  ‘to advise, give counsel’, Mikir -lám ‘word, speech, language’ [Grüßner] (STC 69, 191), Lushai lamR < lamɁ ‘say, pronounce, ask for’ (HST 137). The OC initial is not clear.
‘Talkative’ [Zhuang]; ‘to speak’ 狄 [Xun]. The initial does not agree with the other items.
‘To speak’ [Zhuang] (Pulleyblank 1973: 120; he also includes → dào2 道 ‘to talk about’ in this wf).

(tán10)  □  (dậm)  ||  A Mǐn dial. word for ‘wet’: PMin *dɑm > Fú’ān, Amoy tamᴬ¹. Loan from AA: Viet.  `ăm,  ãm ‘wet, moist’ (Norman / Mei 1976: 298). This etymon occurs also in Tai languages: Lóngmíng tomᴬ² ‘wet’, Lóngzhōu tumᴬ² < *d- (Yue Hashimoto CAAAL  6, 1976: 1).

‘To bare (to the waist)’ 襢 [Shi], 袒 [Zuo].  ||  [WFE] Etymology not certain. (1) Pulleyblank (in Rosemont 1991: 31) adds dàn 但 ‘only’ (under → dān2 單 which also could be related), hence the root means ‘only, bare’. (2) tǎn could be cognate to → dān1 丹 ‘red’ because nakedness is associated with ‘red’ (Lau 1999: 118). (3) ST: WT star-ba ‘to clean, polish’, note also tʰer ‘bald, bare’ (so CVST  2: 122). An allofam may be → tú3 徒 ‘bare’, but see there.
‘To bare, leave open, single, simple’ [Li].
‘Bare, undecorated’ (robe) [Li].
‘Level’ [Yi] (same word as ‘easy-going’ → tǎn3 儃坦 ?); in southern dial. ‘beach’ (~ tān6 灘).
‘Leveled area’ [Shi].
‘At ease’ 坦 [Lunyu] (s. w. as ‘level’ → tǎn2 坦?); ‘easy-going’ 儃 [Zhuang].
‘Let loose, free of care’ [Zhuang].   ||  [C] This wf could belong either to → chǎn2 嘽幝繟 ‘slow’ or to → tǎn2 坦‘level’.

‘Dark’ [Zhuang].  ||  [E] Area word: MK *ɗim, *ɗiim, *ɗəm, *ɗu[ ]m ‘dark’: Khmer ṭaṃ /-dɑm/ ‘be dark’, daṃ /-tum/ ‘be ripe, dark’, PSBahn. dum ‘ripe, red’. It is not clear how the KT items are related, especially since OC could also have had a cluster with *l in the initial: S. damᴬ¹ < *Ɂdl/r- ‘dark’, Saek ramᴬ¹ ‘black’; PKS *Ɂnamᴬ ‘black’, Be lam¹³ ‘black’. Acc. to Thurgood (1994: 358), the KT forms are loans from PAN *qitem ‘black’, Dempwolff 1938 PAN ḍəḍəm ‘be dark’ ᛝ ləmləm ‘be gloomy’ (‘düster sein’); note also AA-Khmer /lým/ ‘be dark, obscure, dim, unclear’, Wa-Lawa-Bulang *ntim ‘dark’ (skies). <> TB-Lushai hlimᴸ ‘shadow, shade’.  ||  The final -m is sound-symbolic for ‘keep in the mouth’ > ‘keep hidden’ > ’dark’, see → shèn4 葚, → gàn2 紺, → qián5 黔, → yīn5 陰 and → àn3 黯. Therefore it is difficult to match the disparate OC syn. with foreign items cited above and under → yīn5 陰.

‘Charcoal’ [Li], ‘lime’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] ST: WT tʰal-ba ‘dust, ashes’ (STC 173 n. 461), Lushai taalR < taalɁ ‘wood ashes, dust’. CH -> Tai: S. tʰaanᴮ¹ and PMY *tʰaanᶜ. The CH word is not related to → rán1 然 ‘burn’.

The earliest occurrence is in the combination kǎn1-tàn 坎窞 (kʰậmᴮ-dậmᴮ) LH kʰəmᴮ-dəmᴮ, *khə̂mɁ-Ɂlə̂mɁ ?  ‘trap pit’ (Shaughnessy 1996) [Yi]. SW says “t`an is a small pit (kǎn) in a pit (kǎn)”.   ||  [D] In some dialects tàn means ‘pit, puddle’ as in shuǐ-tàn ‘puddle’, e.g. Y-Táishān sui⁵⁵-hem²¹  ||  [N] For the irregular aspiration of tàn, see §5.8.5. Except for the above SW entry, tàn occurs by itself only in Post-Han texts and makes therefore the impression of an original reduplicative syllable of *khəmɁ with lateral initial (§2.7); but in light of the Tai connection, tàn has prob. been a full word in OC.   ||  [E] Tàn is of KT origin or an area word (Tai /u/ precludes borrowing from CH): Tai hlum ‘pit, ditch, cavity’, Saek lumᴬ¹ < ˘l- ‘pit, hole’ (as trap), possibly also TB-Lushai humᴴ ‘pitfall’ as trap for elephants etc. Similar CH and foreign comparanda are here tentatively sorted according to connections revealed in Table K-1 → kǎn1 坎埳.  ||  The relationship with PTai *th-: S. thamᶜ¹ ‘cave’, also MK-Wa tha̱m (Dǒng Wéiguāng et al. CAAAL  22, 1984: 110) is not clear.
‘Sound of drum’ [Shi].
‘Sound of drum’ [Shi some versions].

‘Hot water’ for drinking [Meng], for washing oneself [Chuci]; (‘hot’:) ‘reckless’ (of feasting) [Shi].  ||  [D] ‘Warm’ (of a spring) in Mǐn dialects; later ‘soup’.    ||  [E] Bodman (1980: 102) relates this word to WT rlaŋs ‘vapor, steam’.
‘A basin to hold hot water for washing, wash basin’ [SW] (Wáng Lì 1982: 355).
‘To heat, roast’ [Zhuang] > ‘cruel’ [Yi Zhou shu].

‘Path in a temple’ [Shi 142, 2; EY].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR daŋ (平); MGZY tang (平) [daŋ]; ONW dɑŋ  ||  [E] AA or Area word: MK *glɔɔŋ ‘path, road’: Aslian gəløŋ, PMonic *glɔɔŋ ‘road, track, way, direction’; *g-n-lɔɔŋ ‘habitual path’; OKhmer /glɔɔŋ/ ‘way, path, passage > channel, canal, watercourse’ (Jenner / Pou 1982: 289) (-> Tai: S. kʰlɔɔŋᴬ² < gl- ‘canal, watercourse’; TB-Lushai kuaŋᴴ ‘channel of a river’); Note also Viet. duÚòÚng ‘road, way, street’, Muong taːŋ [Pulleyblank JCL 22.1, 1994: 82] (-> PTai *d-: S. tʰaŋᴬ² ‘way, road’).  ||  The PMonic form is also reminiscent of gèng 堩 (kəŋᶜ) [kəŋᶜ] *kləŋh ? ‘road’ [Liji], as well as of → xíng1 行. Wáng Lì (1982: 147) relates this word to → tú2 涂途塗 ‘path’ (along the bank of a canal; paved path)’.

‘Dam, dyke’ [Guoyu]. Later ‘a (round) reservoir, pond’. This could be a variant of → tán3 潭; the word looks like a cognate of → zhàng4 障 ‘dyke, dam’, but the OC initials do not agree (*t- vs. *l-).  ||  [E] <> PYao *glaaŋ² ‘pond, lake’ (Bodman 1980: 112).
‘Envelop’ [Li] prob. does not belong to → zhōu3 周 as we should expect MC tʰieu.
‘To mold, make a mold’ [Shi] > ‘kiln’ 匋 [SW], 陶 [Zuo] > ‘pottery’ [Li]. Possible cognate → yáo1 窯.   ||  [T] Sin S. 掏 SR daw (平); MGZY 掏 taw (平) [daw]; ONW dɑu
‘Peach’ [Shi] < PMY *glaau³ᴬ ‘peach’ (Bodman 1980: 112).

‘To run away’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Etymology not clear, but note MK: PVM *(kə)do ‘to run (away)’ [Ferlus], Bahn. kədəw ‘run away’, PNBahn. *gad`ăw ‘run’, Mon dau (PMon. *d-). -> Tai: Saek theewᴬ² < d- ‘to flee, go away, leave’. However, the initials do not agree.
‘To pour water, wash’ [Shu].  ||  [E] <> PMiao *ɁleuɁᴬ ‘to pour’.
‘To beg, demand’ [Xun].  ||  [WFE] This set is prob. related to the wf → dài1 代 ‘substitute’.
‘To lend’ [Zuo] (Herforth 1984 acc. to Takashima 1996 II: 130).   ||  [<] exoactive of tè (§4.3.1).

‘Male animal, bull’ [OB, Shi, Shu].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR dəj (入), LR dəjɁ; MGZY thiy (入) [dəj]; ONW dək  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. tʰikᴰ¹S < th- (in northern dial. *d-) ‘young male animal’ (Li F. 1976: 43). Note also NNaga *teːk ‘buffalo’ [French 1983: 367].   ||  The graph 特 appears first in a Zhanguo (late Zhou) inscription; zhí, tè (next) seems to be its earlier form (Baxter 1992: 338f):
‘Single’ [Li] =  特 [Yili, Lü], but ‘single’ is not necessarily the same thing as ‘bull’, see → zhí1 直.

‘Evil, wrong’ n. (in ‘do evil’) [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR t'əj (入), LR t’əjɁ; MGZY (chiy > thhiy) (入) [t’əj]  ||  [E] ST: WT nag ‘black, dark’, also in the sense of ‘criminal’ ᛝ gnag ‘black, wicked’ ᛝ snag ‘ink’; PLB *(s-)nak ᛝ *naɁ ‘black’ > WB nak; Nung naɁ; Trung na [Matisoff TSR no. 142], Lahu ná < Ɂnak ‘be deep, thick, dense, steep, hard to understand, profound’ (Matisoff D. of Lahu: 731).
‘To conceal, what is concealed, secluded’ (of plans, lands) [Shu].
‘To hurt’ [GY]. HST keeps this late word (post-classical) in *-uŋ distinct from the one in *-oŋ (→ tōng1 恫).

‘To mount, rise’ [Shi], ‘acend’ [Li] > ‘overcome, oppress’ [Shi]. The phon. series GSR 893 implies that the OC initial was L-like which connects it with → chéng3 乘, but semantically and otherwise, this word appears to agree with the wf → dēng1 登 with an OC T-like initial.

‘Ladder’ [Guoyu].   ||  [E] Etymology not certain. The word appears to be cognate to PTB *s-lay ᛝ *s-ley (so HPTB: 220): WB hle-kaᴮ ‘stairs, ladder’, TGTM *ᴬhli, Chepang hləyɁ (Bodman 1980: 102; 142). <> Tai: S. ban-daiᴬ¹, kraɁᴰ¹-daiᴬ¹ < *Ɂdl/rəiᴬ ‘ladder, stairs’. CH ? -> PWMiaoA ntai³, PYao tʰei¹. However, the foreign initials do not agree with OC (T vs. L); perh. the OC item has been reinterpreted as an allofam of dì 第 ‘sequence’ (under → dì2 弟) (Karlgren 1956: 14). – The elements WB -kaᴮ ᛝ WT skas-ka, skad ‘ladder’ and Lao kʰanᶜ¹-daiᴬ²  ‘stairs’, S. kʰanᶜ¹ ‘steps’ may be related to each other (Manomaivibool 1975: 134).
‘To cut (trees)’ 剔 [Shi]; ‘cut off, cut to pieces’ 鬄 (also read MC tʰieiᶜ)  [Zhouli]; ‘cut hair’. Syn. → tì2 剃.
‘To raise’ [Zhouli], ‘to take, take up’ 提 [Shi] > ‘bank, dyke’ 堤 [Zuo] (the Mand. reading is that of  隄); ‘forehead’ 題 [Li].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR djej (平), PR, LR di; MGZY ti (平) [di]; ONW dėi
‘Bank, dyke’ [Li] (Karlgren 1956: 10).   ||  [C] Possible allofams are → diān1 顛巔, → dìng2 定顁 ‘forehead’, → d`ing3 町 ‘boundary dyke’, → zhěn3 畛 ‘id.’

‘To weep, howl, cry’ [Zuo], later also for animal sounds (crows).   ||  [E] ? ST: Perh. related to Lushai ṭeeR < *tr- ‘to cry out’ (in pain, fear), ‘shriek’, but the OC initial has no trace of an *-r-.
‘Hoof’ [Yi] is prob. cognate to → dì8 踶 ‘to kick’ (so HST: 100).
‘Hoof’ [Shi].

‘Body, form, shape, content’ [Shi].   ||  [<] endoactive tone B derivation from the TB stem (‘the thing which exists’) (§4.5.1).   ||  [E] ST *sri ‘to exist’ (Benedict 1976: 190) > PTB *sri(-t): WT gšis < g-rhyis (?) ‘person, body, natural disposition’ ᛝ WT srid-pa ‘existence, things existing, the world, life, a single being’, also ‘procreate’ (Stein BSOAS 36.2, 1973: 412ff); WB hriᶜ ‘to be (in some place)’.  ||  From the ST root is also derived → shēng2 生 ‘give birth, live’. It is not clear why a hypothetical ST *sr- shows up as a voiceless *rh in tǐ (regular development from ST? or because of a *k-sr- configuration? Note WT), but as a sr-cluster in shēng (*s- re-analyzed as a caustive prefix ? §2.8.1).

‘Tears’ 涕 [Shi]; ‘mucus from nose’ 洟 [Li], the latter may derive from the original meaning ‘tears’ (so Wáng Lì 1958: 551), or both may derive directly from ST ‘water’. The graph 洟 belongs to an OC initial L-phonetic series, but the graph appears late and is prob. only a loan for 涕 (in a T-series).  ||  [E] ST: PTB *ti (STC no. 55) and PTB *tui ‘water’ (STC: 168) > Chepang tiɁ ‘water’, WT mčʰi-ma ‘a tear’ (HST: 146), Chepang ma-tiɁ ‘river’, Kanauri *ti ‘water’. Dhimal hna-thi ‘snot’; or Lushai tuiR ‘water’; both roots, *ti  and *tui occur in JP and Dhimal (STC no. 55; 168).  ||  Wáng Lì (1982: 418) connects tì to → sì2 泗 ‘snivel’ and → lèi1 淚 ‘tears’ (unlikely). Perh. → zhì6 膣 ‘vagina’ is a cognate.

‘To cut hair’ [Huainan, Yupian, JY]. This is perh. a post-Han variant of → tī2 剔鬄 (tʰieiᶜ) in OC the two forms would have been quite different, *lhêk vs. *thə̂i or *thî. It is not clear how the next item relates to these words:
‘To cut off’ [Li].

‘Be distant, far away’ [Shi], ‘remove’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] <> ? PKS *klaːi¹ ‘far’, PTai: S. klaiᴬ¹ ‘far’, but the OC initial was apparently T-like, not L-like. Prob. not related to → zhuō2 卓 ‘distant’ (as proposed by Wáng Lì 1982: 211).
‘Be anxious, to respect, to grieve’ [Shi, Shu].
‘Scared’ [Zhuang]. Acc. to the phonetic series, shì has a T-like initial, though.

‘Sky, heaven, heavenly deity’ [BI, Shi]. The graph shows a person (god) with a head in the shape of a disk like the BI character for dīng 丁 *têŋ ‘a cyclical sign’ which seems to be phonetic. The anthropomorphic graph may or may not indicate that the original meaning was ‘deity’, not ‘sky’. For the *-eŋ ~ *-in variation, see §6.4.1.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR t'jen (平); MGZY then (平) [t'ɛn]; MTang tʰian < tʰian, ONW tʰėn  ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu ⁵³tʰinᴬ¹ ‘sky’, Táishān ³³henᴬ¹; PMin *tʰien, Xiàmén tʰı̃ᴬ¹   ||  An old NW dialect variant QY xien, ONW hėn, is also found in Tang-period Guǎngzhōu, written 祆 ‘Heaven’ (Coblin 1994: 341). An old southern dialect form *tʰɑn survives in Mǐn-Jiānglè tʰãiᴬ¹ ‘sky’ (Norman 1979: 271), which is prob. the same etymon as 坦 tʰɑnᴮ which the Shìmíng records for dialects to the east of the central area (Coblin TP 1994: 155f).  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. Because the deity Tiān came to prominence with the Zhou dynasty (a western state), a Central Asian origin has been suggested, note Mongolian tengri ‘sky, heaven, heavenly deity’ (Shaughnessy Sino-Platonic Papers, July 1989, and others, like Shirakawa Shizuka before him). Alternatively, Bodman (ICSTLL 1987) connects tiān with TB-Adi taleŋ, Lepcha tă-lyaŋ ‘sky’. One could add JP mə⁵⁵-len⁵¹ ‘sky’, yet these items could belong to → líng6 陵 instead.  ||  Most likely, this word is connected with → diān1 顛巔 ‘top’ (so SW) and its TB cognates: WT, OTib. steŋ ‘above, upper part, that which is above’ (Unger Hau-ku 36, 1990: 48), steŋ-lha ‘the upper gods, gods in heaven’ [Hoffmann 1979: 94]; Kachin puŋdiŋ ‘zenith, top’ (STC: 180); Zemi (Naga) tiŋ ‘sky’, Lushai paᴸ-tʰianᴴ ‘god’ (lit. ‘father above’) (French 1983: 157f; 374), perh. also Chepang diŋ ‘(helpful) spirits’. For a similar semantic development ‘top, high’ > ‘sky’, see → líng6 陵, also note the semantic parallel shàngdì 上帝 ‘god on high’ (i.e. in heaven). If MC aspiration should be a reflex of an earlier *s in the initial (§5.8.1), then tiān would agree closely with WT steŋ. A common TB syn. for ’sky’ belongs to the root → mào2 冒 ’cover’.
‘Full’ [Tangshu; JY], but PMin *diemᴮ  ‘full’.  ||  [E] <> PTai *tl- > S. temᴬ¹ ‘full’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 133). Syn. → yíng2 盈嬴.

‘Field’, a general term [BI; Shi].  ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu tʰinᴬ² ‘wet field’. PMin *dzʰən ‘wet field’ is unlikely to be related (Norman 1988: 231), but see → zēng 曾增憎橧.  ||  [WFE] ST: WT žiŋ ‘field’ < lyiŋ or ryiŋ, Bumthang Zha ᴸleŋ, Lep. lyaŋ ‘field, land’ (Forrest JAOS 82, 1962: 332); Cuona Monpa ¹³leŋ; NNaga *ljiːŋ ‘grow(th)’, JP mə³¹-liŋ³³ ‘forest’, Dimasa ha-bliŋ ‘jhum field in 2nd year of cultivation’ (ha ‘earth’) [STC no. 378; French 1983: 254].  ||  Some ST languages have forms with initial r- (related?): Muoto M. Ɂreŋ, Tsangla a-riŋ. Kanauri ri[ŋ] ‘field’; Lushai riŋᴴ ‘jhom, field currently in use’.  ||  Loaned from CH or TB into other languages: PMY *Òinᴬ (Wang Fushi), PYao *riŋᴬ (Therapan) ‘wet field’; Be leŋᴬ (Haudricourt / Strecker TP 77, 1991: 337).

(1) ‘To cultivate, till; hunt’ 田 [Shi 260, 1].  ||  [<] exoact. of tián 田 *lîn (§4.3.2).  ||  [E] ST: WT liŋs ‘hunting or chase’ (HST: 96).   ||  (2) ‘Demesne, royal domain, a type of fief, a feudal title’ 甸 [BI; Shu].   ||  [<] exopass. of tián (§4.4), lit. ‘what is being / has been cultivated’.
‘Be calm, tranquil’ [Shu].   ||  [E] ST: Lepcha glyám ‘be calm, to calm’, Lushai thleemR ‘to comfort, pacify’ (Geilich 1994: 267).
‘Be calm’ 澹 [Lao], 憺 [Chuci]. The phonetic series implies an OC T-like initial.

‘Sweet’ [SW].   ||  [E] ST: PTB *lim > WT ´žim-pa < lyim ‘sweet scented or tasting’, Kanauri im (< yim < lyim; see Schuessler LTBA 22.2, 1999: 73-73 for the initials), Manang lim ‘sweet, delicious’, Thulung lem ‘sweet’, Limbu limma < limt- ‘be sweet’; Lepcha a-klyam; note also WB tsʰimᶜ.   ||  [C] Matisoff (1995: 71) connects this wf with → shí4 食 and → shì16 舐. Words meaning ‘sweet’, ‘lick’, ‘tongue’, ‘flame’ often share to the same roots, see allofams → tiǎn1 舔, → tiǎn2 煔檬, → yán2 炎.
‘Full, to fill, block’ 填 [Guoce], 顛 [Li].
‘To stop up’ [Chuci].
‘Earplug or pendant of jade’ [Shi] (Wáng Lì 1982: 531).   ||  [C] Perh. cognate to → yíng2 盈嬴 ‘full’. Syn. → tiān3 添. The graphs imply a T-like initial in OC.

‘To lick up’ [Tang - Li Bai].  — [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu liːmᴮ¹ < limɁ ‘lick’.  ||  [E] ST or area word: PTB *(s-)lyam > Bahing liam, Khambu, Yakha lem ‘tongue’, Kanauri lem ‘lick’ (STC: 172 n. 458). <> KS: Mulam *ljaːm⁵ ‘lick’.  ||  Words meaning ‘sweet’, ‘lick’, ‘tongue’, ‘flame’ often share the same root, see allofams → tián3 甜, → tiǎn2  煔檬, → yán2 炎.
‘Brightness of fire’ [SW]. Although a dictionary word, it belongs to the wf → yán2 炎. Words meaning ‘sweet’, ‘lick’, ‘tongue’, ‘flame’ often share the same roots, see allofams → tiǎn1 舔, → tián3 甜.
‘Provoke’ [Zuo].  — Etymology not clear.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR t'jew (平), PR t'jaw; MGZY thÿaw (平) [t'jɛw]
‘To perforate, bore a hole’ [Huainanzi] is perh. cognate to → qiào2 竅 ‘a hole’.
‘To jump’ [Zhuang].
‘To leap on to’ [Zuo], ‘leap over’ [Meng].
‘Be jumping’ [Shi].
‘To taste’ [Yupian: Guliang].  ||  [E] ST: WT sñab-pa ‘to taste, savor’ (Bodman 1980: 141).

‘Iron’ [Shu], defined as ‘black metal’ in SW. Wáng Lì (1982: 469) and Sagart (1999: 200) derive tié from an etymon ‘black’, as found in the homophone tiě 驖 (tʰiet, diet) ‘black horse’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Area word: WT lčags < *lhyaks ‘iron’ (HST: 98). Tai: S. lekᴰ¹S < *hl-  ‘iron’, PKS *kʰlit⁷; PVM *khăc ‘iron’ (Bodman 1980: 103). This is perh. ultimately a variant of a foreign etymon which also entered Chinese as → xí4 錫 ‘tin’.

‘To listen, listen to’ [OB, Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR t'iŋ (平); MGZY thing (平) [t'iŋ]; MTang tʰieŋ < tʰiŋ, ONW tʰėŋ  ||  [D] In some dialects such as W-Wēnzhōu the word also means ‘to smell’ and is thus an analog to → wén3 聞 ‘hear, smell’.

‘To listen to’ (person, advice, order) [Shi, Zuo], ‘obey’ [Zuo] (Downer 1959: 284).  ||  [<] exoactive of tīng (§4.3). This may be a late Zhou-period derivation, commentators to some texts read all occurrences in tone A tīng.   ||  [E] This etymon is often considered cognate to → shèng1 聖 ‘wise’. Outside connections are not clear; but note PHlai *ɬiːŋ¹ ‘hear, say’ [Matisoff 1988c, no. 295]; or AA-PNBahn. *tăŋ ‘hear’ ᛝ *tamăŋ ‘listen’, PSBahn. *kətaaŋ ~ *tɔŋ ‘to hear, listen’, Wa-Lawa-Bulang *hm[ɑ]ŋ ‘hear, listen’, PMonic *muŋ ‘listen’ ᛝ *grmɯŋ ‘hear’, but the AA initial *t- does not agree with OC.

‘Settle, regulate’ 亭 [Lao].  ||  [WFE] ST: PTB *diŋ > Lushai diŋᴴ / dinᴸ ‘to stand, stop, halt, stand up, go straight up’ (as smoke) ᛝ ? dinF ‘to erect, build, set up’ (house, image); JP diŋ³³ ‘be perfectly straight’, PLB *Ɂdiŋ¹ ~ *m-diŋ¹ (HPTB: 123) ‘put, place on, set up, establish’ (Lahu gloss) ᛝ *Ndiŋ¹ ‘come to rest, alight’ [Matisoff Lahu D: 642], WB tañ ‘place in position, build’, Lepcha diŋ ‘be erect, to stand’ (Bodman ICSTLL 1987).    ||  [C] This wf could be related to → zhèng1 正政 ‘correct, govern’ (Karlgren 1956: 16).
‘To stop’ [Guanyin], prob. a later meaning.
‘Sit down, settle, establish, determine’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR diŋ (去);  MGZY ting (去) [diŋ]; ONW dėŋ

‘Courtyard, court of a palace, mansion, temple’ [OB, BI, Shi].   ||  [T] MTang dieŋ < diŋ, ONW dėŋ  ||  [D] M-Xiàmén t˜ıãᴬ²  ||  [E] ST: Perh. PTB *gliŋ ‘ground, land, country, region’: NNaga *C/v-khliŋ ‘place’ (e.g. place to sit, abode) [French 1983: 532], WT gliŋ ‘island, continent’. In a round-about way, this etymon might have entered the language of the ancient state of Chǔ during the Han period where we find tīng 汀 (tʰieŋ) LH tʰeŋ ‘island’ [Chuci]; if true, the word must have been written down at a time (Han or later) when OC *hl- and *th- had merged into tʰ-.   ||  [C] This is perhaps related to the wf → tǐng2 挺 in the sense of ‘straight’ > ‘level’.
‘Straight’ [Zuo].

‘Be straight, upright’ (of growing grain, morals) [BI, Shi]; ‘stalk, stem’ 莛 [Zhuang]; ‘small bamboo rods used for divination’ 筳 [Chuci].   ||  [E] ST: PTB: *bleŋ ‘straight’ (STC no. 352). The wf → zhèng1 正政 may belong here, but the initials point to *l- vs. *t- respectively which are difficult to reconcile. Matisoff (1988) combines this wf with → yíng2 盈嬴 ‘full’, → píng1 平 ‘level’ and → zhèng1 正政 ‘straight’. See also → tǐng3 梃.

‘Stick, staff’ tǐng 梃 [Meng]; ‘metal rod inserted in arrow’ dìng 鋌 [Zhouli].  ||  [WFE] Perh. ST *C-liŋ (originally referring to the tibia bone, hence ‘marrow’ as well as the hollowed tube-like piece): PTB *r-kliŋ (STC no. 126) >  Mikir arkleŋ, Lushai tʰliŋR ‘marrow’, Mru kliŋ ‘id.’; WT gliŋ-bu ‘flute’ which is sometimes made of a human femur, lit. bu ‘son’ (i. e. ‘derivative’) of a ‘gliŋ’, PLB *kliŋ > PL *Ɂliŋ¹ ~ *hliŋ¹ ‘flute’, WB kyañ ‘tube’ (Matisoff 1970 no. 98).  ||  This etymon and the wf → kēng2 牼 *khreŋ as well as → xìng3, jìng 脛 *geŋh tend to converge. For an overview, see Table K-2 under → kēng2 牼. Less likely, this wf may be connected with → tǐng2 挺 ‘straight’.
‘Stalk, stem’ 莛 [Zhuang]; ‘small bamboo rods used for divination’ 筳 [Chuci].

‘Pained, grieved’ [Shi].  ||  [WFE] This wf could be related to WT gduŋ-ba (< g-luŋ?) ‘to desire, long for, love, feel pain’, mtʰoŋ-ba ‘to suffer, endure pain, misfortunes’ etc. (HST: 144). HST: 115 keeps this etymon distinct from the one in *-uŋ (→ téng1 疼). It is not clear if the OC / ST initial was of the L or T type.
‘To hurt’ [Zuo].   ||  [<] Tōng + caus. s-suffix (§4.3.2).

‘Penetrate, pass through, communicate’ [Shu], ‘reach everywhere, clearly understand’ [Lunyu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR t'uŋ (平); MGZY thung (平) [t'uŋ]; ONW tʰoŋ  ||  [E] Perh. ST, but an OC initial lateral which is implied by the phonetic series is difficult to reconcile with WT th-, unless the latter derives from *m-lh-: mtʰoŋ-ba ‘to see, perceive, understand’ ᛝ mtʰoŋs ‘smoke hole in a roof’ (HST: 116).

‘Together, join, assemble’ 同 [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR duŋ (平); MGZY tung (平) [duŋ]; ONW doŋ  ||  [E] ? ST: Perh. related to TB-Lushai inᴸ-tɔŋᴴ / inᴸ-tɔnF ‘to meet together, meet, tally, agree, occur at the same time’, WT sdoŋ-pa ‘to unite, join’. Unrelated to cóng 叢 (under → jù7 聚).

‘Bronze, copper’ 銅 [Zuo].  ||  [E] Karlgren (1956: 5) relates this word to → tóng1 同 ‘to join’ (i.e. two metals); but metals are typically associated with color, therefore the word is probably related to tóng 彤 ‘red’ (under → hóng2 紅) (this idea is implied by Benedict MKS 18-19, 1992: 1-13). The word ‘copper’ occurs in some SE Asian languages with initial l-: Tai-Wuming luːŋ², MK-Palaung məlɔŋ ‘copper’ (Sagart 1999: 199).

‘Tube’ 筒 [Lü], 筩 [Hanfei].   ||  [E] Area word: WT doŋ-po ~ ldoŋ-po ‘tube, any hollow cylindrical vessel’ (HST: 153), Chepang tʰoŋ ‘tube’. <> PMK *kɗuŋ ~ *kɗiɲ ‘bamboo tube’ (<> Shorto (1972: 18;  ||  Benedict MKS 18-19, 1992: 9); Khmer klɔːŋ ‘tube’. <> PTai *kl-: S. klɔɔŋᶜ¹ ‘tube, cylinder’; Li loŋ, IN t’luŋ (Benedict AT: 38). The initials are difficult to determine.

‘Be young, young person, fellow; young’ (of animals, i.e. without horns) 童 [Shi]; ‘young person, servant’ [Zuo] > ‘ignorant’ 僮 [Guoyu].    ||  [WFE] Etymology not certain; but note TB-KN-Khami doŋ ‘boy’ (Löffler 1966: 142). <> MY: Mong tuŋ⁵⁵ ‘son, male’ [Strecker LTBA 10.2, 1987: 35]. CVST  (3: 36) relates ‘stupid’ to WT blun ‘stupid, ignorant’.

‘Be inexperienced, ignorant’ 瞳 [Zhuang], 侗 [Shi] (also MC duŋ). The last graph  belongs to an OC L-initial series, the other clearly had initial dental stops; it is not clear how to reconcile these forms.
‘Sorcerer, medium, to dance’ in Mǐn dialects: PMin *doŋᴬ > Amoy col. daŋᴬ²  (lit. doŋᴬ² ‘boy’).   ||  [E] AA: Viet. døong ‘to shamanize’, WrMon doŋ ‘to dance’ (Norman / Mei 1976: 296).

‘Bushel, measure of capacity’ [Lüshi, Shiji], later ‘bucket’.   ||  [E] Etymology not clear, note PTai *thuaŋᶜ¹/ᴬ¹ ‘bucket’ (Luo Yongxian MKS 27, 1997: 274), a CH loan? Or perh. ST: Chepang dʰuŋ ‘container, pot-shaped storage basket.’

‘Reckless, careless’ [Li] > ‘rude’ [Zuo] > tr. ‘to slight, despise’ [Zuo].    ||  This word’s meaning is rather different from the homophone ‘to steal’ (→ tōu2 偷) so that it is prob. directly derived from → yú17 愉 *lo ‘pleasant’ (< ‘relaxed’).
‘Reckless’ [Shi]. This variant might have been influenced by the homophone tāo 滔 ‘overflowing’ (under → yóu4 油).
‘Careless’ [Zuo].    ||  [T] ONW tʰuɑt, duɑt  ||  [C] This group belongs to the root → yú17 愉 *lo ‘pleasant’ (< ‘relaxed’); see there for allofams.
‘To steal’ [Guan]. CVST  (3: 42) relates this word to WB luᶜ ‘take by force’.

‘To rob, take away’ [BI, Shi]. Pulleyblank (ICSTLL 1998: 11) connects this word with dào 盜 (dâuᶜ) LH dɑuh ‘thief, to rob’ [Shi].  ||  [C] This group belongs to the root → yú17 愉 *lo ‘pleasant’ (< ‘relaxed’), see there for allofams.

‘To throw’ [Shu], ‘throw out, eject, throw to, present’ [Shi], ‘reject’ [Li].   ||  [E] ST: WT ’dor-ba ‘to throw or cast away, throw out, eject, decline, reject’ ᛝ gtor-ba   ||  ‘to strew, scatter, throw, waste’ (Unger Hau-ku 35, 1986: 33). For loss of ST final *-r, see §7.7.5.
‘A kind of song’ [Chuci].  ||  [E] ST: WT glu  ‘song’, Mru klö ‘sound, melody’, WB kyuᴮ ‘produce melodious sound’ (Löffler 1966: 130), and / or kruiᴮ ‘kind of song’.

‘Head’ [Eastern Zhou BI, Zuo], replaced earlier → shǒu3 首.     ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dəw (平); MGZY thiw (平) [dəw]; ONW dou   ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu tɐuᴬ²(-hɔkᴰ) 頭(殼); K-Méixiàn tʰɛuᴬ²-naᴬ² 頭那, Dànshuǐ tʰiuᴬ²-naᴬ¹-hɔkᴰ¹ (R. Bauer CAAAL  28, 1987: 60f); PMin *dʰəuᴬ²: Jiānglè tʰəuᴰ¹, Fúzhōu tʰau⁵², Xiàmén tʰauᴬ²-kʰak; W-Wēnzhōu dɦeu²¹  ||  [N] The initial consonant in the phonetic series 豆 could be either *d or *l, but it was prob. *d- as forms for ‘skull’ → dú8-lóu 髑髏 show.  ||  [E] The late appearance of tóu in the 6th cent BC when it began to replace → shǒu3 首 suggests that it is derived from the much earlier attested vessel → dòu2 豆 (Sagart 1999: 156), but dòu (tone C) looks like a derivation from tóu instead which may therefore originally have meant ‘skull’. An allofam may be → dòu3 荳 ‘bean’.  ||  The word tóu has two possible outside connections. (1) ST: Loloish *Ɂdu² ‘head’ [Matisoff LL 1.2, 2000: 168] where u corresponds directly to OC o. Or (2) MK: Khmer -tūla /-dool/ ‘head, to bulge’ which would also be a direct phonological equivalent of OC (for CH loss of final MK consonant, see §6.9). The MK word belongs to a large wf ‘bulge, knoll’ and would thus provide an etymology.

‘To dig through, break through’ [Zuo] > ‘bursting forth > suddenly’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *tu, *du > PL *m-du², WB tuᴮ dig, JP tʰu³¹, Nung du ‘to dig’ [STC no. 258], NNaga*tʰu [French 1983: 334]. Note also Lushai tʰutᴴ ‘suddenly’ (related?).

‘To plaster, mud, plaster’ [Shi], ‘to soil’ [Zhuang].   ||  [D] PMin *dʰo ‘soil, earth’; for a semantic paralell ‘mud’ > ‘earth, soil’ see → ní2 泥.    ||  [E] <> Tai: S. tʰaaᴬ² < *d- ‘to smear, paint’ (Li F. 1976: 40).

‘Path’ (along the bank of a canal; paved path) [Zhouli]; ‘road’ 途 [Lie], 塗 [Lunyu].  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. Perh. related to → táng2 塘 ‘dam, dyke’. Wáng Lì (1982: 147) relates this word to → táng1 唐 ‘path in a temple’, but see there. Or it may be the s. w. as → tú1 途 ‘mud, plaster’.

‘Bare, naked’ [Li], ‘only’ [Meng].  ||  [E] ? AA: Khmer dɑh, Bahn.-Stieng dɔh ‘to take off’ (clothing) [Huffman 1975]. <> Tai: S. taa⁴ ‘only, sole’. This word may have alternative etymological connections, see → tǎn1 袒襢 ‘to bare’ and the items listed there.

‘Land, soil’ [Shi]. The phonetic series GSR 62 implies a dental stop initial.   ||  [D] Y-Guǎngzhōu tʰouᴮ¹, Táishān huᴬ². Some modern dialects have replaced this word with → ní2 泥.  ||  [E] There is no obvious cognate and etymology, unless it may be related to AA-PMon *tiiɁ ‘soil, ground consisting of earth, earth’, Aslian tiɁ ~ tɛɁ; however, this would require the assumption of a shift from front vowel to OC *a (§11.1.3). Prob. related to → shè1 社.

‘To spit out’ [Shi].   ||  [D] Mand. tǔ ‘spit’, tù ‘vomit’; Y-Guǎngzhōu tʰouᶜ¹ (both meanings), Táishān huᴬ¹   ||  [E] ST *twa > PTB *(m-/s-)twa > Kachin mətʰo, Garo stu, Kanauri tʰu ‘spit’. Although tǔ looks like a variant of the syn. → tuò3 唾, the ST sources are quite distinct. For the lack of a Chinese medial w, see §10.2.1; Chinese aspiration is associated with forceful outward motion §5.8.5.
‘To vomit’ Mand. Not all dialects have both these words.

‘Hare, rabbit’ [OB, Shi]. The OC initial *lh- is revealed by the graph’s use as phonetic in a word for ‘tiger’ in Zuǒzhuàn (→ hǔ1 虎).  ||  [E] ST: TB words for ‘rabbit’ include Jiarong kɑ-lɑ, Lolo languages: Hani tʰo³¹-la³³, Lahu tʰɔ⁵⁴-lɑ³¹ and the like [ZM 1992, nos. 292; 758]. Middle Korean twos(ki) ‘hare’ might have been borrowed from CH in connection with the animal cycle (Miyake 1997: 1988).

‘Round, everywhere, plenty’ 團 [Shiwen: Shi]; ‘make round’ [Li], ‘collect’ [Guan], ‘bundle’ 摶 [Zhouli]; ‘rich, plentiful’ (dew) 漙 [Shi]; ‘plentiful’ 敦 [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dwɔn (平); MGZY ton (平) [dɔn]
‘Roll and wrap up’ [Zuo], ‘bundle’ [Zhouli].   ||  [C] Allofam is perh. → zhuǎn1 轉 ‘turn round’ (so Karlgren 1956: 13).
‘To cut’ [Li].
‘Cut meat, slice’ [Huainan].

‘A kind of pig’ [Yi, SW], variant tuān 貒 (tʰuânᴬ) [EY, SW, Chu]; → tún5 豚 is prob. variant of the same etymon.  ||  [E] <> PY *duŋᴮ ‘pig’ (M. Ratliff, p.c.); their first textual occurrence in Chǔcí and Han texts suggests that these words are of MY origin.

‘To push away’ [Shi], ‘push’ [Zuo], ‘extend’ [Meng]. CH aspiration is associated with forceful outward motion §5.8.5. Acc. to Baxter (1992: 231) perh. related to the next:  ||  [WFE] Possibly ST: Chepang dus- ‘to push away, shove’ ᛝ dhus- id.
‘To urge, press’ [SW: Shi].
‘To repress, oppress’ [Shi258, 3].

Xnote: (a hypothetical PCH form corresponding to MC might have been *thul)
Notes: ‘Thigh’, also ‘lower leg’ [Tang: Han Yu; GY].  ||  [E] MK: PMon *dɯl ‘thigh’.

‘Withdraw, retire’ [Shi].   ||  [T] ONW tʰuɑi  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. This may be related to tuì 駾 *l(h)ots ‘withdraw’ (under → tuō3 脫). Perh. related to MK-Mon dui’ ‘to stop, keep quiet, stay put’.

‘To swallow’ [Guoce].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR t'un (平), PR t’ən; MGZY thhin (平) [t'ən]  — [D] PMin *tʰun  ||  [E] <> KT: PT *kl-: S. kliinᴬ¹ ‘to swallow’, Ahom k(l)en, Wuming klwan, Saek tlɯɯnᴬ¹;  PKS Ɂdun; cf. IN təlun, lunlun, Be lun (Benedict AT: 19, but withdrawn in Benedict 1976: 68). Alternatively, CVST  2: 10 relates this word to WT ’tʰuŋ ‘drink’.

‘The rising sun’ [Chuci].   ||  [E] This word has two possible sources, although the first appearance in Chǔcí favors a MK connection; perh. it is a blend of the two: (1) TB: WT ’tʰon-pa, tʰon ‘to come out, go out’, WB pɔ-tʰonᴮ ‘come out’ (e. g. the sun), Monpa Cuona ⁵³tɕʰuŋ, Motuo tʰoŋ ‘to come out’ (sun) (ZM 92 no. 1207). In ST lgs. the notion of sunrise is often associated with ‘to come out, rise’ (cf. WT šar ‘to rise, east’, CH rì chū 日出 ‘the sun comes out’), while ‘west’ → xī2 西棲栖 is associated with ‘to go down, rest, nest’.  ||  (2) MK: PMon *tun ‘go up’ (sun, water level etc.) which is phonologically close to the OC word. In both TB and MK the word is apparently native (for PMonic, see: Diffloth 1984: 206), although their basic meanings differ (TB ‘come out’, MK ‘go up’). An allofam may be → dōng2 東 ‘east’.
‘Hill’ [Zhuang].  ||  [WFE] This etymon seems to represent a variant of → duī 堆 ‘mound’, the MK items cited there could equally apply to this wf.
‘Hill’ [Shi].

T_data: [T] Sin Sukchu 飩 SR dun (平)
Notes: ‘Accumulate’ [Yi] > ‘to mass troops, put pressure on’ [BI, Shi], ‘garrison, station soldiers’ [Zuo], ‘thick’ (as darkness in a grave) 窀 [Zuo] (also read zhūn [ṭun ~ ṭuin]).  ||  [E] ST: WT ’du-ba ‘to assemble’ ᛝ gdu-ba ‘to gather’ ᛝ ’dun-sa ‘meeting place’ ᛝ ’tʰun-pa ‘to gather’ ᛝ sdud-pa ‘to collect, gather’ ᛝ sdud ‘fold of garment’ ᛝ ’du-ba ‘come together’ ᛝ ’dus-pa ‘to unite’ ᛝ gdu-ba ‘to gather’ ᛝ ’tʰu-ba ‘to gather, collect’ ᛝ (m-)dud-pa ‘knot’. Bodman (1969: 340) associates many of these WT items with zú 卒 (under → zāo2 遭). Unger (Hau-ku 35, 1986: 31) relates the CH word to Lepcha tyul ‘to conglomerate, a flock’.   ||  [C] Tún could possibly be related to → tún1 屯.

‘Tie together, envelop’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT tʰul-pa ‘furred coat, cloak; to roll or wind up’; Nung rədul ‘roll, wrap, enwrap’, Angami Naga rətuu < rtul ‘roll’ (STC p. 110; Unger Hau-ku 35, 1986: 30). Perh. related to → tún2 屯窀 ‘accumulate’.
‘Young pig’ [OB, Lun] (see Li Liu EC 21: 1996: 17). Perh. → tuàn 彖 and tuān 貒 are variants of this word.

‘Buttock’ [Guoyu].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *tun > Meithei məthun¹, Abor-Miri ko-dun ‘buttock’, prob. also LB-Lisu khi²¹ du²¹ [Matisoff LTBA 17.2, 1994: 137]. This meaning is connected with ‘heel’: JP lə³¹-tʰin³³ ‘heel’, KN-Naga-Wancho chi-dun ‘heel, LB-Phunoi pi³³ tun¹¹.   ||  The ST etymon may have wider connections: PKS *lun² ‘back, behind’, Tai-Saek tloonᴬ¹ ‘buttocks’. And / or AA items cited under → tún1 屯 ‘hill’ which belong to a wf ‘to bulge’. A variant is → diàn2 殿. A possible allofam is → dùn4 遯遁 ‘withdraw’ (‘go back’).

‘Other, different’ [Bi, Shi], in modern dialects the word has the specialized meaning ‘he, she, it, they’, and is in most places pronounced → tā1 他. Etymology not clear. Perh. cognate to → chǐ2, chí 誃 ‘to separate’; for a semantic parallel, note AA-Khmer -dai /-təj/ ‘be other, different’ ᛝ OKhmer didai /diidəj/ ‘be different, distinct, separate’.

‘Take away’ 脫 [Zuo], 挩 [Lao], ‘peel off’ 脫 [Lie], ‘take off’ (clothes) [Shi, Guoyu]  > ‘let off, let escape’ [Shi], ‘escape’ [Lao], ‘relieve’ [Gongyang].   ||  [D] M-Amoy col. teɁᴰ², lit. toatᴰ², Jiēyáng toɁᴰ² ‘take away forcibly’; Amoy col. tʰuɑɁᴰ¹, lit. tʰuɑtᴰ¹ ‘escape’. We would expect the tr. meanings (‘take away, take off’) to go with LH tʰuɑt, the intr. (‘escape, careless’) with LH duɑt.    ||  [WFE] ST: PTB *g-lwat (STC no. 209) > WT hlod-pa ‘loose, relax’ ᛝ glod-pa ‘loosen, relax, slacken’; PLB *k-lwat > PL *k-lwat⁴ ‘free’, WB hlwat ‘free, relax’ ᛝ lwat ‘be free’ ᛝ kywat < klwat ‘loosed, freed’ ᛝ kʰywat < kʰlwat ‘release, free’; Mru lot, lon ‘loose, let out’; Lushai tʰlɔnᴸ < thlɔns ‘to come / fall off’ [Löffler 1966: 123], Lai lot ‘free’ ᛝ še-lot ‘set free’  ‌[VanBik LTBA 25.2, 2002: 106], JP lat³¹ ‘to escape, get lost’. <> Tai: Shan lɔtᴰ² < *dl- ‘to be free, to free’ is prob. a TB loan.    ||  [C] This group belongs to the root → yú17 愉 *lo ‘pleasant’ (< ‘relaxed’), see there for allofams. Perh. → róng1 容 is related. This wf comes close to → chōu1 抽.
‘Withdraw, flee’ [Shi].   ||  [<] exopass. / reflexive of tuō (§4.4). We would expect the intr. use to correspond to LH duɑs.
‘Wipe off’ [Yili].

‘Fresh-water alligator, Alligator sinensis’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Its mythological meanings and etymological speculations are discussed by Carr (LTBA 13.2, 1990: 131ff). Tuó is distinct from → è5 鱷 (ŋâk) ‘aquatic reptile’ [SW].  ||  Löffler (1966: 140) relates this word tentatively to Mru tam  ‘alligator’, but the final nasals do not agree. The word is also reminiscent of AA: Santali tajan ‘broad-headed crocodile’.
‘Shred sacrificial meat’ [Zhouli].  ||  [E] ST: WB tʰwa ‘mince with a knife’ is prob. unrelated since neither initial nor rime match.
‘Long and narrow, oval’ [Chuci].  ||  [WFE] ST: JP diŋ³¹-loi³³ ‘long and narrow’ (CVST 3: 32).
‘Long and narrow’ (mountain) [Shi].
‘To take up, lift’ [Lie].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu 託 SR t'aw (入); MGZY 託 thaw (入) [t'aw]  ||  [E] TB: perh. a LB loan: note PLB *Ɂtak ‘lift, carry’. For cognates on the ST level, see → zhì15 陟.
‘Noise of pounding earth’ [Shi].  ||  [E] This word is onomatopoetic, but note also AA-Mon tÅk ‘to beat’, Khm ÊɔÊɔk ‘beat (shake) a rattle’ [Pinnow 1959: 318].

‘Spittle’ [SW, Hanshu], ‘to spit’ [Zuo].   ||  [D] PMin *tʰoiᶜ; some dialects in the Yuè area have archaic rimes: Guǎngzhōu col. tʰœᶜ¹ beside tʰɔᶜ¹, Zēngchéng sœyᶜ², Bǎo’ān suiᴮ², Enpíng tsʰuiᴬ²; K-Dōngguān suiᴮ.  ||  [E] ST *tol > WT tʰo-le  (i.e. *tol-e) ’debs-pa ‘to spit’ (’debs-pa ‘to throw’) (HST: 138); WB tʰweᴮ ‘spit’ (STC: 30 n. 95) seems to agree with the WT and CH forms. But alternatively, STC connects WB with PTB *twəy (= *tui) ‘water’. Although tuò looks like a variant of the syn. → tǔ3 吐, the OC and the TB forms are quite distinct. CH aspiration is associated with forceful ejection §5.8.5.

‘To wither, fallen leaves’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Prob. AA: Khmer sla’ka /slɑk/ ‘to fade, wilt, dry up’, from a root -la’ka /-lɑk/ ‘to fall’, acc. to Jenner / Pou 1982: 523. Alternatively, tuò could possibly be related to → luò7 落 *râk ‘fall’ (Unger Hao-ku  39, 1992: 92; Sagart 1999: 18), but then one would need to assume OCM *rhâk for tuò which is not supported by the phonetic series.
‘Frog’ [Zhouli].  ||  [E] Perh. KT: PT *kw-: Boai kwɛɛᶜ¹, Wuming klwe ‘small green frog’; PKS *k-waiᶜ ‘small frog’ (Bodman 1980: 144).
‘Hole, hollow, concave’ 窐 [Lü], 窪 [Lao].
‘Concave, puddle’ [Zhuang].
‘A hollow, cavity’ [Meng], ‘hollow of a tree trunk’ [Yi] is perh. a nominalizing k-prefix derivation (§5.4).

‘Outside, external’ [OB, BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR ŋwaj (去), PR ŋwaj, waj; LR waj; MGZY  xue (去) [ɦuɛ]; ONW ŋuɑC  ||  [N] In the OB, the graph is a vertical line with a stroke on one side 卜, i.e. ‘outside’; the graph is identical to → bǔ1卜. ‘Moon’ yuè 月 LH ŋyɑt  has been added later as phonetic. Bodman (1980: 136) connects this word with WT ŋos ‘side, direction’, see → yù17 禦.
‘To bend’ (a bow) 關 [Meng] > later ‘bent coast line, a bay’ 灣. This word may be connected with → yū1 迂紆, → wēi1-tuó 委佗, → wēi2 逶, or → wěi3 委.
‘A bowl’ [Guan] (written with rad. 木).  ||  [<] ōu 甌 (Ɂəu) with nominalizing n-suffix (§6.4.3).  ||  [WFE] ST: WB uiᴮ ‘pot, jar, chatty’; → wèng 甕 may also be connected.
‘A bowl’ [Xun].

‘Be extending, long, wide’ 曼 [Shi] > ‘creeping plant’ 蔓 [Shi].  ||  [WFE] ST: Lushai muaŋᴴ / muanᴸ ‘be slow and leisurely, to linger’, Lepcha moŋ, mon ‘be quiet, silent’. (Geilich 1994: 139; 159 includes these TB items in the wf → mò15 默嘿 ‘silent’).
‘Distant, unlimited’ [Zhuang] > ‘free, careless’ [Zhuang].
‘Be slow, negligent’ [Shi] > ‘indulgent’ 慢 [Li] > ‘to slight, insolent’ 嫚 [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR man (去); MGZY man (去) [man]

‘Ten thousand’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR vwan (去), LR vwan; MGZY (khan >) wan (去) [van]; ONW muan  ||  [E] ST: WT ’bum < ɴbum ‘hundred thousand’; JP lə³¹-mun³¹ ‘ten thousand’ (CH loan?). As to foreign initial b- for CH m-, see §5.12.2.  ||  CH -> Tai: S. hminᴮ ‘ten thousand’ (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 54).

‘To lose, disappear, flee’ [BI, Shi]; ‘to have none, there is not’ intr. [Lunyu] (Pulleyblank 1995: 109).    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR, LR vaŋ (平);  MGZY wang (平) [vaŋ]; MTang mvuaŋ, ONW muaŋ  ||  [<] ST *ma ‘not’ (→ wú 無) + ST terminative suffix -ŋ (§6.5.1).  ||  [E] TB: Lushai maŋF ‘to die, die out, exterminate’, JP maŋ³³ ‘corpse’.

‘To forget’ [BI, Shi], i.e. ‘to lose’ (from memory) is the s. w. as wáng 亡 in early OC as revealed by Shījīng rimes, tone C emerged later (‘it has disappeared from mind, has escaped me’, a perfective form in *-s / *-h of wáng 亡 (§3.5), acc. to Unger Hao-ku 20, 1983).

‘There is no, not have’ occurs in Shūjīng and the old parts of Shījīng, but is then replaced by its stem → wú4 無 in that meaning. The graph 亡 in the OB, BI may perh. write this word rather than wáng 亡 above.   ||  [<] wáng 亡 *maŋ with the aux. vb. tone B (§3.3.2).
‘To waste’ (of land, time) [BI, Shi] > ‘neglect, reject’ [Shu].  ||  [<] caus. devoicing of wáng 亡 (mjwaŋ) (§5.2.1).

‘Mourning, burial’ [Shi], ‘corpse’ [Shǐj`i] (Pulleyblank 1962: 136; Baxter 1992: 187). For a semantic parallel ‘grave’ ~ ‘corpse’, see → mù5 墓.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR saŋ (平); MGZY sang (平) [saŋ]  ||  [<] wáng 亡 *maŋ + nominal ST s-prefix (§5.2.4).  ||  [E] ST: Chepang hmaŋ ‘corpse’, WB saŋ- ‘grave’.
‘To lose’ (e.g. a country) [OB, Shi], ‘destroy’ [Shu], ‘to die’ [Shu, Liji].   ||  [<] s-caus. of wáng 亡 *maŋ (§5.2.1) + exoactive tone C (§4.3.2).

‘King’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR waŋ (平); MGZY xwang (平) [ɦwaŋ]; ONW uaŋ  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. Prob. ST: WT dbaŋ ‘might, power’ ᛝ dbaŋ-po ‘ruler’, WB aŋ ‘strength, power’, NNaga *waŋ ‘chief’ [French 1983: 389]. The initials present difficulties, though (WT *b- vs. OC *w-), unless one assumes that occasionally WT b- can derive from a *w (db- < *dw-); the WB form seems to support this. Alternatively, wáng may possibly be connected with an AA homophone: OKhmer vaṅ ~ vāṅ(ṅ) ‘royal palace ...’ (-> Tai: S. waŋ ‘palace’), cognate to luəŋ ‘king’ (-> Tai luaŋ ‘royal’); the identification of ‘king’ with his palace is perh. supported by a BI where wáng refers not to the Zhou king but to a place (Shaughnessy 1991: 197). Thus wáng would belong to the complex of stems under → yíng4 營; prob. also cognate to → huáng1 皇 ‘august’. Otherwise, speculations have related wáng to wāng 尪 (Ɂwâŋ) ‘emaciated’ [Zuo] (under → qú4, jù 臞 ) and → kuáng 狂 (gjwaŋ) ‘mad’, based on certain theories on ancient CH kingship and shamanism (see D. Keightley JAS 54.1, 1995: 132).
‘Be king, rule’ [Shi 241,4].  ||  [<] *waŋ + s/h-suffix (§3.5).

‘To go to, gone, past’ 往 [OB, BI, Shi], 迋 [Zuo].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR waŋ (上); MGZY xwang (上) [ɦwaŋ]; ONW uaŋ  ||  [<] yú 于 *wa + ST terminative *-ŋ (§6.5.1) + endoactive (?) tone B (§4.5). Since the terminative implies an end point of the action, the meaning in some languages is ‘go to’ > ‘arrive’ > ‘come’.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *waŋ (STC no. 218) > Chepang waŋ ‘to come’ (Bodman 1980: 81), Barish-Nocte ²vaŋ(Ɂ) (Chepang and Barish (= Bodo) disagree in phonation, Weidert 1987: 30), WT ’oŋ-ba ‘to come’ ᛝ perhaps also WT soŋ < s-waŋ ‘went’, Tamang ¹waŋ ‘enter, go in, come in’;  WB waŋ ‘to enter, go or come in’ ᛝ swaŋᴮ ‘to put into’, PL *waŋ¹ ‘to enter’; Mikir wàŋ ‘to come’ (HST: 86), NN *woŋ ‘come’. It is not clear how Tai luaŋᴮ² ‘to pass time, go beyond’ (Bodman 1980: 107) may relate to this ST stem.
‘To go’ [Zuo].   ||  [<] *waŋɁ + general purpose suffix s/h (§3.5).

‘Net’ 罔[Yi], 網 [Shi]; ‘to catch, snare, entangle’ 罔 [Meng], ‘to tie, interlace’ [Chuci].   ||  [T] MTang mvuaŋ, ONW muaŋ < maŋ  ||  [E] Perh. KT: PTai *mɯaŋᴬ² ‘a type of fishnet’ (Luo Yongxian MKS 27, 1997: 274), Saek mɔɔŋᴬ² ‘long net across the river’. This may be the s. w. as wǎng 罔 ‘deceive’ (under → wū3 誣).
‘Water spirit’ [Zuo]. A variant is prob. wǎng-xiàng 罔象.  ||  [E] Perh. related to Lepcha tə-raŋ ‘water spirit’ (Geilich 1994: 290f).
‘A water dragon which eats people’ [Zhuang, Guoyu, Shiji].
‘Lawless, rude’ [Zuo], ‘reckless’ [Li].    ||  [WFE] This wf converges and overlaps with → wū3 誣 ‘deceive, false’.
‘Excessive, reckless’ [Zhuang]. For the difference in finals, see §6.4.2.

‘Look towards’ [Shi], ‘look into the distance’ [Xun], > ‘hope’ [Meng]. Perh. the s. w. as → wàng5 望. Tone A in older parts of Shījīng (Mattos 1971: 309).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR, LR vaŋ (去); MGZY wang (去) [vaŋ]; MTang mvuaŋ, ONW muaŋ < maŋ  ||  [E] ST: PTB *mraŋ (STC no. 146) > Gurung (Himal.), Thakali mraŋ ‘to see’, PL *mraŋ¹ > WB mraŋ ‘see’ (HST: 129) ᛝ caus. PLB *s-mraŋ or *Ɂmraŋ ‘to show, teach’ [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 1027], Mikir làng ‘to see’, Nung jaŋ (j = palatal glide).

‘Full moon’ [BI, Shu] is considered to be the s. w. as → wàng4 望. If the OC word had the equivalent of later tone C (and the double readings in GY may be a trace of this), ‘full moon’ may be a regular passive derivation from the above, lit. ‘the thing that is gazed at from afar’ (§4.4). Alternatively, Van Auken (JAOS 122.3, 2002: 528) suggests that ‘full moon’ is cognate to → liàng 亮 ‘light’.

‘Graceful, compliant’ [Shi].  ||  [WFE] Qiu Xigui (2000: 374) lists over 20 graphic variants of this sound-symbolic word. The etymology is not clear. The first syllable may be related to TB-Lushai vialᴴ < vial ‘to writhe’, although the item could also be linked to either → wēi3 逶 Lushai vaiF <vaiɁ; or it could be an *-i final cognate of → yāo1 妖 or → yǎo1 夭殀. TB-Lushai cognates show that this etymon is not related to → wēi2 逶 ‘fluttering’.   ||  The second syllable tuó / yí / chí reflects an area etymon: TB-Chepang kloyɁ ‘be winding’ (path or stream). <> MK-Khmer /-lée/ as in  /rlée/ ‘to snake, move sinuously (as through water)’. AA-Khmer final /ē/ corresponds also in other words to OC *-ai.  ||  TB languages have a similar item whose initial t is irreconcilable with OC l: Lushai taalR < taalɁ ‘to struggle, wriggle, writhe’, or Chepang toy- ‘to circle or spiral upwards’.    ||  [C] An allofam of the first syllable is prob. → yuān3 蜎肙 ‘worm’, of the second syllable → shé2 蛇 ‘snake’.
‘Be graceful, compliant, be winding’ (as road) [Shi].
‘Be winding’ (as road) [Shi].

‘Tortuous movement, fluttering’ (of a flag) [Chuci]. TB (Lushai) cognates show that this etymon is not related to → wēi1-tuó 委佗 ‘be winding’.  ||  [WFE] ST: PTB *waːy (STC no. 90; HPTB: 210) > Kachin wai ‘whirl, as a whirlpool, stir, strike out with a sweeping motion’; WB waiᴮ ‘whirlpool, brandish’ a sword..., ‘soar around’ as a bird; Lushai vaiF < vaiɁ ‘to wave’ with the hand, arm, or anything horizontally, ‘brandish’ (a sword) ᛝ huiF ‘to beckon’ with hand. Acc. to Shorto 1972 likely derived from PMK *wa(a)y(-s): Palaung vay ‘to vawe hand, beckon’, Viet. vãy ‘to wave’.   ||  [C] For an overview of synonyms for ‘turn, rotate’, see under → huí 回.
‘To signalize, manifest’ [Yi] is an iterative derivation (§5.2.3) from wēi. A variant or syn. is → huī4 麾.

‘To wither’ [Shi].  ||  [WFE] ST: PTB *hwaːy (HPTB: 214) > Lushai vuaiᴴ ‘to wither, wilt, droop’ ᛝ uaiᴴ ‘to wither, wilt, droop’ ᛝ uaiᴸ ‘to hang on to, hang upon’; Tangkhul Naga hùy ‘fade’, JP waiᴴ ~ woiᴴ, Lahu hwē ‘id.’ [Matisoff D. of Lahu: 1111].   ||  [D] Ancient dialect variants are cited under → yū2 菸.
‘To wither’ [Huainan]. For the final -n, see §6.4.4.
‘To overawe, intimidate’ [Shu], ‘imposing, majestic’ [Shi], ‘intimidating, majesty, dignity’ [BI, Shi, Shu]. Acc. to Sagart, → guǐ1 鬼 ‘ghost’ is a derivation.
‘To fear, be in awe of; to respect’ [Shi, Shu].  ||  [<] *Ɂui + exopass. s/h-suffix, lit. ‘be intimidated’ (§4.4.1).

‘High, precipitous’ [Zhuang, Li, Guoyu], ‘lofty’ [Lunyu], ‘dangerous’ [Meng].  ||  [E] ST: WB ŋwa ‘large, high, project’. CH and WB can be reconciled if a ST final *-l is assumed. This may be a vocalic variant of → wéi9 巍 ‘high’.

‘To be’ 隹 [OB, BI], 惟 [Shu], 維 [Shi]; (‘it is’ > ‘it is only’ >) ‘only’ 唯 [Shi and subsequent classical Chinese]; (‘to consider to be’ >) ‘to think’ [Shi and later] (GSR 575n; Dobson EAC; §2.10). Syn. of ‘to be’: → shì14 是, → yě1 也; syn. of ‘only’: → zhǐ3 只, dàn 但 (under → dān2 單).    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR vi (平); MGZY ywi (平) [yi]; ONW iui  ||  [E] ST: PTB *wəy > PLB *wəy ‘to be’ (Thurgood 1982, CLAO XI. 1: 65-81); Lushai eF < ɁeeɁ, ve, JP we pres. tense particle; perh. WT yin ‘to be’ <*wi-n (?) (earlier *w disappears before i in WT).    ||  [C] The negative copula → fēi1 非 incorporates this word.

‘It should be’ [OB, Shu]. The OC reading is not certain. The usual meaning ‘be kind, compliant’ [BI, Shi] could possibly be a semantic extension (‘should be’ > ‘to consider / treat as it should / ought to be, as expected’ ?) since there is a tendency for copulas to expand to full verbs, note ’to be’ > ‘to think’ above (Dobson EAC; §2.10).   ||  [<] See §6.2.2 for the ‘irrealis’ role of the OC final consonants.

‘To make, do, (function as:) be’ [BI, Shi]. Note that in general words meaning ‘do, make’ also develop the meaning ‘function as, act as, to be’; see → yì6 役, → zuò3 作.   ||  [T] Sin S. SR uj (平); MGZY xue (平) [ɦuɛ]; MTang ui, ONW ue  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. Some languages have similar looking words: TB-Mikir iŋhóy < m-hol ‘to do, make’. <> MK: Khm Ɂaoy (spelled oːy) ‘give’, resultative marker; MK lgs. on the Malay peninsula ‘to make, do’: Semai Ɂuuy, Jah Hut mɁoy, Semelai j-Ɂɔy [Diffloth 1975]. Khmer /-w´əə/ ‘do, make’ ᛝ OKhmer thve ~ tve /t∫əə/ ‘to do, make, perform, act, serve as, carry out funtion of, act as if, pretend to be...’ (Jenner / Pou 1982: 349). The OC and AA vowels are rather different, though. A derivation is perh. → yì6 役.   ||  (wéi4  為  (jwie) OCM *wai or *woi)  ||  ‘Elephant’? [Shang dyn.]. Since the element ‘elephant’ is puzzling in this graph for ‘to do’, it has been suggested that an obsolete area word for this animal had once served as phonetic, note AA-PVM *hwɔyᴬ, PSBahn. *ruəs, PTB *m-gwi(y) > JP gui³¹ ‘elephant’ (Matisoff LTBA 15.1, 1992: 169; HPTB: 200). For lack of initial *r in OC, see §10.1.3.
‘For, on behalf, because’ [BI, Shi].

‘To surround, encircle’ [Li], ‘besiege’ [Zuo] (Yates EC 19, 1994: 112) is prob. cognate to → wèi7 衛 even though the finals differ. The basic meaning of the etymon is ‘to walk around something in order to watch it’.  ||  [E] Area etymon which is widely attested in TB and AA languages. TB-Lushai veelF ‘go round, surround, encircle, around, round about’ ᛝ veelR ‘to keep coming or walking near’ (as those who want to steal, see what one is doing...); Siyin vil ‘watch’ [Stern AM X.2, 1963: 244]; WB weᶜ ‘to run around (an object), veer’. For additional Lushai allofams, see the cognates → wèi7 衛, → xiàn10 縣.  ||  Since both WB and KN languages have MK loan words, the ultimate source of this etymon is prob. AA. PMK *wìəl  basic meaning ‘surround, be around, make rounds’, occurs in Mon and Khmer with many prefixed derivatives (Shorto AA Studies 1976: 1065): PMonic *wiil ‘to go around’ ᛝ *tr-wiil ‘to attend on, surround’ [Diffloth 1984: 239]; Khmer viala /wíiəl/ ‘to turn, move round’ ᛝ /rwíiəl/ ‘make one’s rounds, patrol’. MK -> Tai: S. kra⁴-ween (McFarland: 45: gkra⁴-wane), Saek vianᴬ² ‘go around, make a circuit’. Perh. related is PVM: *veːl ‘return’ ᛝ *k-veːl ‘village’ [Ferlus]; the last word brings to mind → guī3 歸 ‘return to a place where one belongs’.

‘To go against, disobey, oppose; go too far, transgress’ [Shi] > ‘err, fault’ [Zuo].    ||  [WFE] ? ST or AA: TB-Lushai uiᴴ < Ɂui ‘to regret, dissuade, forbid’, both OC and Lushai are perh. connected with AA: Khmer veḥ /wéh/ (written viər) ‘to quit, leave, avoid, shun...’, Stieng wuir ‘avoid’ (Shorto 1973: 378).   ||  [C] Allofam is prob. → huí 回.
‘Avoid, taboo’ [Zuo].

‘It is not that, if it had not been for’ [Shi] is the negative root *m- + → wéi2 惟 OCM *wi ‘to be’ (Pulleyblank 1995: 110). It is often considered the s. w. as → wéi8 微‘small’.  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR vi (平); MGZY wi (平) [vi]; ONW mui

‘Be small, eclipsed’ [Shi].  ||  [E] The etymology is not clear. It is prob. related to PTB *mwəy (STC: 174 n. 463) > WB mweᶜ ‘fine, delicate’, perh. also Chepang mi-Ɂo ~ məy-Ɂo ‘small’. And / or it is often considered the s. w. as → wéi7 微 (Pulleyblank 1995: 110). Finally, it may perh. be a vocalic variant of → mǐ7 靡.
‘High, majestic’ [Lunyu].
‘High’ [Zhouli].   ||  [C] This set may be a vocalic variant of → wéi1 危 ‘high’.

‘Tail’ [Shi] > ‘to copulate, have sexual intercourse’ [Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR vi (上); MGZY wi (上) [vi]; ONW muiᴮ  ||  [E] ST: PTB *r-may ‘tail’ (STC no. 282) > Chepang meɁ ‘tail’, Tamang (¹)meː, PL *Ɂ-mri², WB mriᴮ;  KN-Aimol rəmai; Lushai meiR < meiɁ.

‘To fall’ [Zhuang], ‘to hang down’ 委 [Li]. Perh. the same word as → wěi3 委 ?  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. Gong H. (in W. Wang 1995: 48) relates it to WB lway ‘suspend from the shoulder’. The OC form is similar to words with nearly identical meaning (‘hang down’): → chuí1 垂, → ruǐ 繠蕊.

‘To bend’ 委 [Li], 骫 [Liezi] may be the same word as → wěi2 委. WB kweᴮ ‘bend, curve’ ᛝ kweᶜ ‘bend round, curved’ are perh. MK loans (Shorto 1972): Sre kue ‘bent, crooked’, Biat kwɛː (kwac) ‘winding’. Perh. cognate to → yǎo1 夭殀, → yíng5 縈.
‘Woof’ [Zuo], ‘to weave’ [Zhuang].
‘Woof’ [SW] (Karlgren 1933: 28).  ||  [<] n-nominalization of wěi 緯 (jweiᶜ) (§6.4.3).
‘Be vigorous’ (of persons) [BI, Shi, EY] is cognate to items under → mín4 痻 ‘suffering’ (so Wáng Lì 1982: 410). There may perh. be a connection with → wù11 務 ‘apply oneself, work’.
‘Eagerly’ [Li].

‘Not yet’ [OB, Shi, Mand.], in contrast to → bù1 不, wèi focuses on whether an action occurred or not, without reference to the subject’s intention (Norman 1988: 98). Pulleyblank (1995: 109) considers this word a fusion of the negative root *m- with the perfective particle → jì3 既 ‘already’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR vi (去); MGZY wi (去) [vi]; ONW muiᶜ  ||  [D] W-Wēnzhōu, Y-Guǎngzhōu meiᶜ, M-Fúzhōu muiᶜ, Xiàmén beᶜ

The 8th of the Earthly Branches identified with the sheep / goat [OB]. Acc. to Norman (1985: 88), possibly a loan from AA: note MK: OKhmer-Lao *mamɛɛ ‘goat’ ᛝ Khmer babae ᛝ Mon ba˘be’ [Ferlus MKS 18-19, 1992: 56], also Atayal (AN) miːts ‘goat’.

‘Taste’ [Yili].   ||  [E] This word is perh. of MK origin: PMonic *[Ɂ]məp ‘good tasting, have a pleasant flavor, be pleasant’ (the QY rime can derive from Proto-Chinese *-s, *-ts  and *-ps). Unger (Hao-ku 39, 1992: 89) connects wèi with WT brod ‘taste’. The meaning of KN-Lushai hmuiᴴ ‘savory smelling’, Lai hmuj / hmuɁj  ‘be fragrant’ is somewhat removed from ‘taste’; however, these items are phonologically close to Chinese.   ||  Boltz (JAOS 99, 1979: 432) draws attention to binomes for ‘taste’: zī-wèi 偏味 LH tsiə-mus [Shiji, Lie] and cǎn-wèi 噆味 LH tsʰəmᴮ-mus [Huainan], apparently with two different ways to write the first syllable.

‘Position, place, seat’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR uj (去); MGZY xue (去) [ɦuɛ]; ONW ui  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. Although it is often related to → lì3 立 (so Pulleyblank 1962: 233; Baxter 1992: 446), the role of 立 in the graph wèi is prob. more semantic than phonetic.

‘Gadfly’ [Guoyu, Chuyu].  ||  [E] AA: PAA *ruwaj  [Pinnow 1959: 268], MK *ru[u]y, *ruəy > PVM *m-rɔːj ‘a fly’ [Ferlus], PMon *ruuy  ‘house-fly’ (Norman / Mei 1976: 284-285; Bodman 1980: 92), Khmer /ruj/ ‘a fly’ ᛝ /roj/ ‘dart here and there...’ For lack of initial *r in OC, see  §10.1.3.

‘Kind of monkey-like animal’ [Zhouli].  ||  [E] MK *[s]ryuul, *[s]ryuəl ‘gibbon’ (Shorto 2006 #1784): Wa-Lawa-Bulang *rəyol ‘white-handed gibbon’; in the variant *wih, the AA initial *r- was lost, see  §10.1.3.  ||  Matisoff (1995: 71) suggests that the final *-i in wèi is a ST diminutive suffix added to → yóu8 猶, but wèi and yóu differ in initials as well (*j- vs. *w-).

‘To guard, patrol’ [BI, Shu]. The graph shows feet walking around an enclosure. Wèi is related to → wéi5 圍 ‘surround, encircle’ even though the vowels differ and the final *-s is unusual in an etymon with ST *-l, but note the parallel word Lushai veetF / veɁᴸ (< *wes) ‘to put round or on, cause to encircle; a single encircling’ (under → wéi5 圍). For synonyms, see under → huí 回. See → wéi5 圍 for outside cognates.
‘Stomach’ [Li].  ||  [E] MK *wəc ‘stomach’ (Shorto 2006 #865): Palaung vɛʔ, PWa wɛk ‘entrails, stomach’  ‌(loaned into TB? Note PLB *Ɂwik§ ‘stomach’).
‘To say, call, be called’ [Shi] is thought cognate to → yún2 云 (Wáng Lì 1982: 456). Alternatively, it could possibly a derivation from → yǒu2 有 ‘there is, have’ (§6.2.2; §2.10).

‘Screening’ (of mist) [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu 慰 SR Ɂuj (去); MGZY 慰 'ue (去) [Ɂuɛ]  ||  [WFE] <> KT: This group could be related either to PTai *Ɂu̯opᴰ¹S ‘to shut, cover up’; or to Tai: S. Ɂut⁴ ‘to compress, crowd in together’ (a CH loan?).
‘Be dense’ (forest)  [Shi] > ‘to block up’  [Zuo] > ‘pent up’ (feelings), ‘oppressed’ 苑 [Shi], ‘depressed’  [Chuci], ‘anxious’  [Meng].
‘To screen’ (as mists) [Shi]. For a semantic parallel, see → yuàn1 苑.

‘To feed’ (an animal)’ [Liji, Chuci], Mand. 喂餵 (Wáng Lì 1982: 430).  ||  [E] Area word: PTB *wul (HPTB: 416) > Lushai vulɁᴸ ‘to keep or rear’ (domestic animals), ‘to domesticate’ ᛝ vilR < vilɁ ‘to look after, tend’; Mikir wiᴴ ‘tend animals’ (STC: 83), perh. also WB kyweᴮ ‘give a meal, feed’. PMK *wiir > OMon wir ‘keep, rear’ (domestic animals) (Shorto 1972: 14); Khmer /kwíiəl/ ‘to pasture animals, watch, tend’. The TB items are MK loans acc. to Shorto.

‘Warm’ [Li], ‘mild, gentle’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin  Sukchu SR Ɂun (平); MGZY 'un (平) [Ɂun]; ONW Ɂon  ||  [E] Perhaps ST *ur: TB-Lushai urɁᴸ ‘to burn’ (in cooking), ‘get smoky’, uurᴴ ‘to smoke, to heat, distill; to warm’ ᛝ uutF / uɁ ‘to burn, char, scorch’ ᛝ urᴴ roᴴ ‘to dry’ (at a fire); Mikir ur ‘to dry over the fire’ (Benedict HJAS 5, 1940: 122 no. 62). However, while the TB items tend to imply burning and fire, a homophonous MK etymon is semantically closer to OC: MK *cʔur, *cʔuur (and more variants) ‘warm’ (Shorto 2006 #1559a): Stieng uːr ‘to heat [leaf to soften it]‘, Khasi ur ‘with a warm sensation’. Prob. not (directly?) related to → yù20, yǔ 嫗 ST *Ɂo.

‘Be striped, patterned’ [BI, Shi], ‘written character’ [Zuo] > ‘literature’ [Lunyu] > ‘refined, accomplished, cultured’ [BI, Shi].    ||  [T] Sin  S. SR vun (平), PR, LR vən; MGZY wun (平) [vun]; MTang mvun, ONW mun  ||  [<] Prob. a nominal n-derivation (§6.4.3) from → méi9 煤 *mə ‘soot’, hence lit. ‘black marks, dark patterns’ (as tattoos on body etc.), ‘writing’ (with ink). At least some of the black paints were, like ink, made from soot.

‘Mosquito’ [Zhuang].   ||  [T] MTang mvun, ONW mun  — [D] PMin *≥mun  ||  [E] The identification with → wén1 文 as the insect with ‘patterned markings’ on its wings (Williams 1941 / 1974: 281) is prob. folk etymology. It is not clear if měng 蠓 (muŋ[ᴮ]) LH moŋ ‘midge, mosquito’ [Lie] is related: PMin *moŋᴮ.   ||  MK *muuys, *muə[y]s ‘mosquito, gnat’ (Shorto 2006 #1496): PSBahn., PVM *mɔːs [Ferlus], Khmer muuh, Stieng mɔɔh, Bahnaric *mɔɔs [Diffloth 1976: 223]. CH added the nominal n-suffix (§6.4.3).

‘To hear about, hear’ [BI, Shi], ‘to smell’ [Shu]. Baxter’s (1992: 352f) reconstruction *mjun ‘to hear’ is based on Shījīng rimes and an earlier form of the graph.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR vun (平), PR vən; MGZY wun (平) [vun]; MTang mvun < mun,  ONW mun

(1) ‘Be heard about, renowned, fame’ [Shi].  ||  [<] *mən + passive s-suffix (§4.4).   ||  (2) ‘To ask about, inquire’ [Shi].   ||  [<] *mən + exoactive s-suffix (§4.3), lit. ‘let (me) hear’ (?) (cf. Baxter 1992: 431).  ||  [E] The step from ‘hear’ to ‘ask’ is not easy to understand, but it occurs also in TB languages, e.g. PLB *Ɂna ‘listen’ ᛝ *na ‘ask’ (Matisoff D. of Lahu: 726f), also in Tani (J. Sun LTBA 16.2, 1993: 152). Perh. AA had some paronomastic influence on OC, note PMonic *smaaɲ ‘inquire’ > Mon hman, Wa-Lawa-Bulang *hmaɲ ‘to ask for, ask a question’. -> Tai: Saek maanᶜ² ‘ask for help’.  ||  [E] ST *m-nəm: PTB *m/s-nam ‘smell’ (HPTB: 250f), WT mnam-pa ‘to smell of’ ᛝ snom-pa (> snum-pa) ‘smell’ (Tib. -> Spilo Kanauri mun- ‘to smell’ – recorded by N. C. Bodman); WB nam ‘stink’ ᛝ namᴮ/ᶜ ‘smell’, Mru nam, Lushai namᴴ < nam ‘smell of’, JP mə³¹-nam⁵⁵ ‘to hear, smell’. CH -> PMY *nhoMᴮ ‘to hear, smell’. The meanings hear ~ smell are paralleled by ST *nə ‘ear ~ nose’, see → ěr1 耳. However, in almost all languages, *nəm means only ‘to smell’, while ‘to hear’ is often expressed by the stem for ‘ear’. The inversion of n and m in CH is the result of labial dissimilation or prefix-preemption.

‘Corner of the lips, shut the lips’ [Zhouli].  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. It could either be related to mén 門 (HST: 111); or to TB-Lushai hmuuiᴸ < hmuuih ‘the lips, upper lip’ [Weidert 1987: 204], also MK-PVM hmoyᴬ ‘lip’ [Thompson]; or to TB-WB mut ‘mouth’ (in ‘beard’) ᛝ hmut ‘blow with the mouth’, but see → fú8 弗); also MK-Khmer m`ɔət ‘mouth, edge’ (of water).

‘Tangle, confused’ (net) [Shu]. This word may be cognate to → mén3 悶, but the notions of ‘dark > confused’ and ‘tangled = confused’ are semantically distinct. Wáng Lì (1982: 524f) relates this word to → fēn4 紛 ‘mixed, confused’.

‘Old man’ [FY], ‘father’ [SW].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɂuŋ (平); MGZY 'ung (平) [Ɂuŋ]; ONW Ɂoŋ  ||  [E] Perh. ST: TB-Lushai unᴸ ‘be old, elderly, venerable, ancient’, WB uᴮ ‘uncle’. Unger, (Hao-ku 63, 1999) connects this word with foreign items under → gōng4 公 ‘uncle’.

‘Tub, vat’ 瓮 [Mo], 罋 [Yili] (also QYS Ɂjwoŋ[ᶜ]); ‘swollen’ 甕 [Zhuang].  ||  [E] Perh. ST: PL *Ɂ-loŋ ‘pot’, WT gžoŋ ‘tub’, Lepcha joŋ-mo ‘bucket, tub’ (Unger Hao-ku 63, 1999). <> Tai: S. luŋᶜ² < *l- ‘vessel, utensil for keeping provisions’. The initial l-  in these languages is difficult to reconcile with OC, Unger assumes a Ɂ-prefix; see §5.11.   ||  [C] Allofam → yōng2 癰 ‘ulcer’; → wǎn4 碗 may also be connected.

‘Snail’ [Li]. PMin *˘lɔi.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *kroy (STC no. 311) > WB krwe ‘shellfish, cowry’, JP kʰoi³³ ‘shellfish, shell’ (Bodman 1980: 143). Perh. also related to PMK *gl[o]Ɂ ‘snail’ (Shorto 1972: 16).
‘Be / look glossy’ (of leaves) [Shi], ‘sprinkle, moisten > fertile’ [Zuo], ‘wash’ (hands) [Zhouli].
‘silvery’ [Shi].   ||  [E] Perhaps connected with MK *lʔuk, *lʔuuk ‘wet, soaked’: Mon dɜk ‘be wet, damp, sappy, green’ (Shorto ɐ277b).

‘To lie down, sleep’ [Meng].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋɔ (去), PR, LR ɔ; MGZY o (去) [ɔ]; ONW ŋuɑ  ||  [E] ST has *ŋ(w)al ~ *nwal parallel stems (§5.12.1) for this etymon:  ||   (1) *ŋwal > *ŋwaj: WT ŋal-ba ‘to rest’ ᛝ mŋal ‘womb’ (lit. resting place with body part *m-); Lushai ŋɔiᴴ / ŋɔiɁᴸ < ŋɔis ‘to be quiet, silent, stop, pause’, NNaga *C-ŋuaj ‘easy, gentle, quiet’, Kachin ŋwi ‘gentle, mild’ = JP ŋui³¹ ‘slow, satisfied’, WB ŋweᶜ ‘gentle, moderate’ (STC no. 315) agree phonologically with Chinese.  ||   (2) A ST parallel stem *nwal (§5.12.1) is represented by → suī 綏.  ||  Non-ST languages in the area have words which look similar: AA-PVM t-ŋah ‘(to lie) on the back’, PTai ŋaiᴬ¹ ‘lie on the back looking up’.
‘Pool, stagnant water’ 汙 [Zuo], 洿 [Meng].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɂu (平); MGZY 'u (平) [Ɂu]; ONW Ɂo
‘Pool’ [Zuo] (Pulleyblank 1962: 233).

‘Spirit medium, witch, shaman’ [OB, Yi, Shu, Lunyu], both male and female, but later restricted to females [SW] while the male is called xí 覡 (Ɣiek) [Guoyu]. Wū were associated with chaotic and negative aspects of nature and life, e.g. natural disasters, and often killed in order to eliminate such disasters. They had little to do with ritual. (Boileau BSOAS 65.2, 2002: 350ff).  ||  [E] ST: Western Tib. ’ba-po < ɴba ‘shaman(ess), sorcerer’ (HST: 107). As to foreign initial b- for CH m-, see §5.12.2. However, the usual WT word for ‘shaman’ is gšen. <> Tai: S. mɔɔᴬ¹ < PTai *hmɔᴬ ‘doctor, sorcerer’ is usually considered a CH loan (Li 1976: 40) and has been cited as evidence for an OC voiceless initial. MK-PWa *səmaŋ ‘shaman’ may also be connected.  ||  Several alternative etymologies have been proposed: (1) Perh. → wū3 誣 ‘to deceive’ is the same word. Note a WT semantic parallel ‘deceive’ ~ ‘magical power’: sprul-ba ‘to juggle, make phantoms, miraculous power’ ᛝ ’pʰrul ‘magical deception’. (2) Wū could be cognate to wǔ 舞 ‘to dance’ [Shi] (Lau 1999: 87). (3) Wū could in addition to ‘dance’ be cognate to → mǔ2 母 ‘mother’ as wū were female acc. to late Zhou and Han texts (E. Schafer, see Jensen EC 20, 1995: 422). (4) V. Mair (EC 15, 1990: 27-47) has proposed that wū is a loan from Iranian *maghu or *maguš ‘magician’, i.e. an ‘able one’ (specialist in ritual).

‘To deceive’ [Lunyu], ‘slander, accuse falsely’ [Zuo].   ||  [E] ST: Chepang maɁ- ‘to lie, deceive, pretend, secretly do’.  ||  [WFE] This wf converges and overlaps with → wàng2 妄 ‘reckless, false’. Perh. related to → wū2 巫 ‘spirit medium’.

‘To deceive, confusion, to outwit, wits’ [Shi].  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. pʰraaŋᴬ² < *br- ‘to deceive, cheat’. For foreign initial b- for CH m-, see §5.12.2. The Tai form throws doubt on the possibility that wǎng is the s. w. as → wǎng3 罔網 ‘net, to snare’.
‘To deceive’ [Xun]. For the difference in final nasals, see §6.4.2.

‘Roof’ [Shi, Zuo], ‘house, room’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɂu (入); MGZY 'u (入) [Ɂu]; ONW Ɂok  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. The basic meaning of this word is apparently ‘roof’, yet comparanda all mean ‘house’. It is sometimes associated with Tai: Po’ai lukᴰ²S < *dl- ‘room’ whose initial l- is difficult to reconcile with OC, see §5.11. Alternatively, note PTai *Ɂj-: S. jauᶜ¹ ‘home, house’. But wū may be closer to AA forms: PVM *k-rn-ɔɁ ‘house’ (with infixes and separated initial omitted in CH), and / or Kharia oɁ, Munda oÂaɁ. Wáng Lì (1982: 293) believes that wū was originally the same etymon as wò 幄 (Ɂåk) ‘tent’.
‘How’ [Lun], ‘to what place, where’ [Meng], also wū hu 惡乎. This and the following interrogatives occur before the vb, basically asking ‘at / to which place’ (Dobson LAC: 146f).

‘To / at what place, in what respect?’ [Shi, Zuo] (Dobson). The final -n in this and the next item is probably the same demonstrative morpheme encountered in → rán2 然 and other grammatical words (§6.4.5).
‘To what place, at which place?’ [Shi] (Dobson). Probably a (sandhi?) variant of ān above.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɂjen, jen (平); ONW Ɂan
‘Crow, raven’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɂu (平); MGZY 'u (平) [Ɂu]; ONW Ɂo  ||  [E] This onomatopoetic word could perh. be cognate to PL *ak§/ a³.
‘Crow, raven’ [Zhuang], a later variant of the above which for reasons of sound symbolism preserves the earlier vowel, see §7.2.2 (Pulleyblank AM  n.s. 9.1, 1962: 103; Unger Hao-ku 22, 1983).
‘Should not, don’t!’ Injunctive and imperative negative [OB], already in Zhou time phonetically confused with, and read like, wú 無 (DEZC: 48, 647).

(1)  ‘Should not, don’t!’ Injunctive negative [OB, Shi] (DEZC: 48, 650; §6.2.2).   ||  (2)  ‘Don’t vb. him / her / it!’, fusion of wú with zhī 之 [Meng et al.] (Pulleyblank 1995: 108). The OB graph is distinct from that for → wù5 物 ‘thing’ which was therefore not a graphic loan.

沒 ‘not have, there is no, not yet’ Mand.; MC muət may be a col. (j-less) variant of wú 勿 or wèi 未, which later fused with, or was contaminated by, yǒu 有 (Norman 1988: 126). An alternative etymology derives the meaning ‘not have’ from ‘submerge’ (e.g. Norman: Ohta). The following belong to a different stem *ma: → mǐ6 靡, → mò2 末, → wáng1 亡 (incl. sāŋ 喪), → wú4 無 (incl. mò 莫). Pulleyblank (1973: 121) combines all these words in one large wf.

‘I, my’ [BI, Zuo] is a dependent pronoun and therefore functions as a subject or possessive, not the sentence-final object (§3.3.3). The BI graph is yú 虞 *ŋa, or with yú 魚 *ŋa under the ‘tiger’. During the Nanbeichao and Tang periods, there is no distinction between wǒ and wú, and wú disappears from the col. lg. (Norman 1988: 118). Wú is directly cognate to the TB forms below, even though it is missing in the earliest texts.  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋu (平); MGZY u (平) [u]; ONW ŋo  ||  [E] ST: PTB *ŋa (STC no. 406): WT ŋa; WB ŋa ‘I’ ᛝ ŋaᶜ obj. and poss. of ŋa ‘I’, PL *C-ŋa. Many TB languages have different etyma for this pronoun.

Independent pronoun ‘I, we’ [OB, BI, Shi], in classical texts ‘I (stressed), we’ (§3.3.3). Originally, the graph for wǒ seems to have been created to write the name of a Shang period people / country, ‘sheep’ 羊 was later added 義 (prob. signifying pastoralists) in order to distinguish the name from the pronoun (Sagart TP 81. 4-5, 1995: 328-342).   ||  [T] Sin S. SR ŋɔ (上), PR, LR ɔ; MGZY ngo (上) [ŋɔ]; ONW ŋɑ  ||  [D] Mand. wǒ is a col. archaism, some northern dialects have the expected ě (Demiéville 1950: 5; Stimson 1972: 177); some southern dialects have preserved the OC rime: Y-Fóshān ¹³ŋɔiᴮ²; K-Méixiàn ŋaiᴮ, PMin *ŋɑiᴮ (Norman 1988: 223).   ||  [<] *ŋa + independent marker *-i; this final is also a suffix in TB, see below. The OC glottal element may have resulted from *ŋa + Ɂi > *ŋaɁi > *ŋaiɁ. In OC, wǒ occurs in all sentence positions, unlike the dependent wú 吾, see §3.3.3 for more details.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *ŋai (STC no. 285): JP ŋai³³ ‘I’, WT ŋed (< *ŋai-t), Mikir ne, Chepang ŋi ~ ni ‘we’, Phom (Chang-Tangsa = Konyak) ŋei ‘I’ (Benedict 1995: 31); Lushai ŋeiᴸ ‘self’, JP ŋai³³ ‘I’. The final *-i is a suffix (Matisoff 1995: 76f).
‘I, we’ is perhaps a stressed form [Shi] (Sagart 1999: 135).    ||  [C] For possible wider connections, see → yà2 御迓訝. Syn. → yú5 予余.
‘To shout’ [Shi].   ||  [E] Perh. related to WT ŋar-skad ‘roaring of a tiger’ ᛝ ŋa-ro ‘be loud’. WT does not preserve earlier medial *w (§912.9).

‘There is no, not have’ [later Western Zhou texts and since].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR, LR vu (平); MGZY wu (平) [vu]; MTang mvu < muo, ONW muo  ||  [N] The classical meaning ‘there is no, not have’ emerged only later during the Western Zhou period and eventually replaced earlier forms with this meaning and grammatical function; the OB have only → wáng1 亡 for ‘not have, there is no’, the Shūjīng has both wǎŋ 罔 (under → wáng1 亡) and wú 無, the Shījīng both wú 無 and → mǐ6 靡.  ||  In the OB, negatives with initial *m- negate actions which are controllable by living persons (Takashima 1996: 370ff).  ||  [D] Wú is the common ST negative ‘not’ which has survived as such in southern dialects: W-Shanghai mᴬ², Y-Guǎngzhōu, Kèjiā mᴬ², M-Xiàmén mᶜ² (Norman 1988: 199), also sporadically in Zhou texts as some investigators claim, but the instances are ambiguous.  ||  In many dialects, this etymon fused with → yǒu 有 ‘to have, there is’ for ‘not have, there is no’: G-Nánchāng, Fèngxīn mauᴬﬂ, Línchuān mauᴬ²; X-Chángshā mɑɣᶜ², Shuāngfēng məᶜ²; Y-Guǎngzhōu mouᴮ²  冇(Mand. mǒu), Táishān moᴬ¹; K-Méixiàn moᴬ² (Norman 1988: 213 etc.).   ||  [E] ST *ma: PTB *ma ‘not’, widely represented in TB languages, e.g. WT ma ‘not’, WB maᶜ, PL *ma² ‘not’.
