Notes: ‘To defend, object, oppose, prevent’ [BI, Shi] (yù16 and yù17 blend into each other).  ||  [WFE] ST: WT ŋo ‘face, countenance, air, look’. WT ŋos ‘side, direction’ belongs to CH → wài 外 ‘outside’ (so Bodman 1980: 136). For an overview of related words, see under → yà2 御迓訝.
‘To go against’ 啎 [Lü], 迕 [Lie]; ‘encounter’ 啎迕 [Chuci]; ‘face to face’ 晤 [Shi]; ‘to turn against’ 捂 [Yili]; ‘oppose’ 忤 [Hanfei]; ‘resist’ [Li] (Qiu Xigui 2000: 335).
‘Resist, oppose’ [Zhuang].
‘Go upwards against’ 泝 [Shi]; ‘go up against current’ 泝 [Zuo]; ‘complain’ 愬 [Shi], ‘accuse, inform’ 訴 [Zuo].   ||  [<] perh. intensive of wù 蘁 *ŋâk(h) (§5.2.3) (Baxter / Sagart 1998: 53).
‘To understand, instruct’ [Lun] > ‘example’ 喻 [Meng]; ‘proclaim, understand’ 諭 [Li, Guoce].  ||  [E] ? ST: WT blo ‘mind, intellect’.

(Of birds:) ‘to sit on eggs, incubate’ 嫗伏 [Liji] > ‘to warm with body’ (as mother a child, or the earth all things to make them grow) [Liji].  ||  [E] ST *Ɂo: PLB *Ɂu³ > WB uᴮ (i.e. /Ɂuᴮ/) ‘lay an egg’ ᛝ ə-uᴮ ‘egg’ (HPTB: 180).  ||  [C] This wf coalesces partially with → xù4 旭, perh. they together form a single wf. → wēn 溫 ‘warm’ could be an allofam, but it prob. belongs to a ST root *Ɂur, while the above items belong to ST *Ɂo.
‘Mother’ [SW] > ‘Mrs.’ [Shiji] > ‘(old) woman’ [Guangya].  ||  [<] a late general purpose tone C derivation of yù, yǔ 嫗 (§3.5), lit. ‘the one who is breeding, mothering’.
‘To brood, hatch (eggs)’ is acc. to Guō Pú’s commentary to FY 8, 4 a Jiāngdōng (lower Yangtze) dialect word; it survives today in Mǐn dialects: Jiàn’ōu iuᶜ¹, Chóngān ieuᶜ¹ (Norman 1983: 206).
‘Warm’ (of season, house, clothing) [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WB uik (i.e. Ɂuik) ‘feel warm, close’.
‘To be satiated, full’ (of food, wine) [Shi].  ||  [E] ? ST: Perh. WT myo-ba, myos ~ smyo-ba, smyos ‘insane, mad, drunk’, if Tib. m- is a prefix.
‘To satiate, nourished’ 於 [Shu], 飫 [Shi] seems to be a vocalic variant of the preceding word.
‘Drunk, mad’ (with wine) [BI, Shu].   ||  [<] *Ɂoh + initial MC x- which may represent ‘intensive’ ‘devoicing’ (§5.2.3).
‘Cooked meal’ (for sacrifice to the dead) [Shi], (for banquet) [Meng].   ||  [<] *Ɂoh + terminative -ŋ (§6.5.1), lit. ‘(something for) getting to be full’.

‘To give birth, to rear, breed, nourish’ 育 [Shi, Shu]; ‘produce’ 毓 [OB, BI, Zhouli]; ‘nourish’ [Zhouli], ‘young’ 鬻 [Shi]. Baxter / Sagart (1998: 52) derive → zhōu5 粥鬻 ‘rice gruel’ from this word. → jú5 鞠 ‘nourish’ is a derivation.  ||  [E] ST: JP lu³¹ ‘give birth’ (to a child).
‘To nourish’ [Lao]. The graph 毒 was used in this late Zhou text when *C-l- and *d- had apparently already merged. Or was this graph simply borrowed for yù?
‘To nourish’ [FY 1.5] a Han period Qín dialect word.

‘To nourish’ [Lao] a vocalic variant.     ||  [C] Table C-2 (under → chù4, xù 畜) shows the phonological and semantic connections among similar looking words. This etymon is not related to any of the other stems in that table, nor to → xiū4 羞. Perh. connected with chōu 抽 (under → yóu2 由).

‘To sell’ [BI]. Originally, this graph was distinct from the one for mài ‘sell’, see SW 2776.  ||  [E] MK: OKhmer /lɔk/, Khmer /luk/ ~ /ruk/ ‘to sell, to fine’. Yù looks like a cognate of → shú6 贖 *m-lok ‘ransom’ (Sagart 1999: 82), but the vowels should be identical in a closely related introvert / extrovert pair; also, simultaneous close connections with both TB-WT (→ shú6 贖) as well as MK are difficult to explain, therefore these words may not be related. Syn. → dí6 糴; → gǔ11 賈; → mǎi 買; → shòu2 售.

Supposedly ‘large elephant’ [SWJZGL 4277] (Karlgren GSR 83e). There is prob. no such word. (1) There is no early text in which this word means ‘elephant’; (2) the ancient graph (gǔwén 古文) did not have xiàng 象 ‘elephant’ as a graphic element. SW was guessing at the original meaning of the graph.

‘Slow and deliberate’ [Lao], ‘think beforehand’ [Li], ‘anticipate’ [Zuo].   ||  [E] Karlgren GSR 83e derives this word from the homophone ‘elephant’ → yù24 豫 [SW] (< ‘elephant-like’) which is unlikely. This is prob. the s. w. as → yù8 悆譽豫   ||  ‘pleased’ (both from < ‘relaxed’) (so Wáng Lì 1982: 162). A semantic parallel is → yú17 愉.    ||  [WFE] Three different valence-increasing morphemes are added to the root *la: (1) final s/h: *la-h, (2) causative devoicing *lha, (3) s-prefix: *s-la. A similar profusion of forms is seen in the wf → yì35 繹.
‘Relax, slowly, leisurely, easy’ [Shi], ‘lazy’ [Shu].   ||  [<] *la + devoicing (meaning?) (§5.1)  ||  [E] ST: WT sla-ba ‘easy’ (CVST 3: 1).
‘Be remiss’ [Shi], ‘relax, alleviate, delay’ [Zuo]. If the reading MC dźjwo can be trusted, the initial *m- is prob. inherited from ST.
‘Walk slowly, gently’ [Meng], ‘slow, by and by’ [Zuo], ‘quiet’ [Zhuang].   ||  [<] *la + s-prefix (meaning?) (§5.1.1).

‘Well-rope’ [Li] occurs also in WT: rgyud < r-yut ‘string, cord’. This could possibly be a variant of → l5 繂率, both from PCH *rjut ~ *r-jut (§9.2.1), provided the late OCM form (Liji) was already -uit and had merged with the reflex of -wit.
‘A fragrant herb’ [Li]. Unger (Hao-ku 39, 1992) suggests that this is the s. w. as → wèi10, yù 蔚 ‘a kind of artemisia’.
‘Hawk, kite’ [Shi] is shared with TB-PL: *(k-)dzwan¹ ‘hawk’.
‘Small worm’ 肙 [SW] > ‘be bending, crawling’ (as a caterpillar)  蜎 [Shi]  ||  [<] *-n nominalization (§6.4.3) of a ST etymon: → wēi1(-tuó) 委佗, TB-Lushai vial ‘writhe’.

‘Head’ [Zuo, Xi 33] (Unger Hao-ku 28, 1984: 251; Mei 1985: 335), ‘to be at the head, first, eldest, principal, great’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋyen (平); MGZY xwÿan (平) [ɦyɛn]; ONW ŋuan  ||  Yuán is perh. related to PTB *m-gaw ~ *(s-)gaw (STC no. 490) > WT go ‘headman, beginning, source’ ᛝ mgo ‘head, summit, beginning’ ᛝ mgon-po ‘protector, master, lord’. WT mg-, mb- = CH ŋ-, m- does occur elsewhere, but is rare. Alternatively, the WT etyma could be related to → gāo1 高 (kâu) (so HST: 93), yet yuán’s semantic agreement with WT is significant. Mei Tsu-Lin (in Thurgood etc. 1985: 335f) considers both yuán and → jūn3 君 (kjuən) ‘lord, prince’ variants which are related to WT mgon.
‘Large turtle’ [Zuo] is the same word as 元 (Unger Hao-ku 28, 1984: 251, 260). On the other hand, this word may be related to
‘Turtle’ [Liezi]. If yuán should be the original form, the final nasal has been lost in the process of back formation. Allofams are perh. → hòu1 后, → yuán3 原.
‘Marsh between mountains’ [SW] has perh. a Tai connection: S. leenᴬ² ‘marsh, mire’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 235).
‘A plain, highland’ [Shi], ‘spring, source’ [Meng] is perh. the s. w. as → yuán1 元 ‘head’ (Qiu Xigui 2000: 275).
‘Quiet talk’ [SW: Meng] is perhaps related to PTB *ŋoj ‘mild, quiet’.

‘Circle’ 員 [Shi]; ‘round’ 圜 [Yi], 員 [Meng], 圓 [Hanfei]; ‘return’ 員 [Shu]; yuán ‘circle’ is symbolic for ‘sky, heaven’, fāng 方 ‘square’ for ‘earth’ [Huainan].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR yen (平); MGZY xwÿan (平) [ɦyɛn]; ONW uan  ||  [WFE] Area word: PMK *wail ‘turn around’ (Shorto 1972: 4; 1973: 380) ᛝ *wal ‘bend, return, halo’. <> ST *w(i)al: PTB *wal (STC no. 91) > WB wanᴮ ‘circular’, Kachin wan, Lushai valR ‘be in the form of a ring or circle’ (HST: 55) ᛝ hualᴸ ‘to surround, encircle’. CH -> Tai: S. wianᴬ² ‘revolve, encircle, circle’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 179). MC -jä- suggests that the OC vocalism was not /a/ but frontish (e, ia?), therefore prob. not (directly?) related to → huán1 桓垸. Or this CH wf, or some of its members, belong to → yíng4 營. Most likely, the area roots *weŋ ~ *wen and *wial ~ *wel have converged in OC. For synonyms, see → huí 回.
‘Wall round a courtyard’ 院 [Mo]; ‘ring-shaped jade insignium’ 瑗 [Xun], also MC jwɐnᶜ; Downer (1959: 280) adds caus. ‘encircle oneself > put on’ (a buff coat) 擐 [Zuozhuan].

‘To turn round, to wheel’ 旋 [Zuo], ‘to turn around, return’  還旋 [Shi], ‘turn away, all round’ 旋 [Shi, Yi] > (turning this way and that:) ‘agile’ 還 [Shi]; ‘ring’ 旋 [Zhouli].   ||  [<] caus. of yuán 員圓圜 (jwän) (§5.2.2), lit. ‘make go round’.

‘Monkey’ [Zhuang, Guoce].  ||  [E] ST etymon with the OC nominal final *-n (§6.4.3): PTB *woy ~ *(b)woy (STC no. 314), JP woi³³. Alternatively, the root could be AA: PMK *swaaɁ ‘monkey’ (Shorto 2006 #242): PNBahn. *hwa ‘gibbon’, Wa-Lawa-Bulang *hwaɁ ‘leaf monkey’. For synonyms for ‘monkey’, including possible variants, see → yóu8 猶.

‘Garden, park’ [Shi].  ||  [E] This word is prob. derived from one or other root *wan ‘round, encircle’ (see → huí  回), semantically like yuàn 院瑗 ‘wall round courtyard’ (→ yuán5 員圓圜), see → yíng4 營. Therefore, the following are unrelated: TB-KN-Kom ra-h˘un ‘garden’; AA-Khmer swna /sùuən/ ‘care for, look after > flower / pleasure garden’ (Jenner / Pou 1982: 373) -> KT *swjaan (Li acc. to Benedict AT: 37; 1976: 90) > S. suanᴬ¹ ‘garden’. <> PMY *weŋ² ‘garden’ agrees phonologically with CH (M. Ratliff, p.c.).
‘Be slow’ [Shi]. Acc. to Karlgren (1956: 14), the following is related:
‘Slow, delay’ [Meng] > ‘slack, indulgent’ [Zuo] > ‘negligent’ [Yi], but this word could instead belong to → xuān2 暖 ‘soft, mild’. Gong (1995) relates huǎn to WT ’gor-ba ‘to tarry, linger, loiter’.

‘Far away, distant, far-reaching, extending’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR yen (上); MGZY xwÿan (上) [ɦyɛn]; ONW uan  ||  [WFE] This item has no apparent TB cognate, but may be an unexplained rime *-an variant of the wf → jiǒng2 泂迥 *weŋɁ ‘distant’. Allofam is perh. → jiǒng3 憬 *kwaŋɁ which represents a transitional rime. Baxter / Sagart (1998: 60) relate this etymon to → yuè4 越 ‘pass over’.
‘Keep at a distance, keep away’ [Shi].   ||  [<] *wanɁ + exoactive > caus. s-suffix (§4.3.2).

‘Sleeve’ is an ancient Jiāngdōng (lower Yangtze) dialect word acc. to Guō Pú’s commentary to FY 29.32. It still survives in Mǐn dialects: PMin *Ɂyonᴮ > Fú’ān unᴮ¹, Fúzhōu uoŋᴮ¹, Xiàménen ŋᴮ, Jiànyáng yeŋᴮ¹ (Norman 1983: 206).

‘Trees with rich foliage, umbrageous’ [Guoyu] > ‘pent up’ (feelings) [Shi]. For a semantic parallel, see → wèi10, yù 蔚.  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR Ɂyen (上); MGZY 'wÿan (上) [Ɂyɛn]  ||  [C] An allofam may be → yǐ4 猗 ‘luxuriant foliage’.

(1) (‘Pent up’:) ‘resent, bear resentment’ [Shi].  ||  [<]  perhaps exoactive of yuàn 苑  (Ɂjwɐnᴮ) (§4.3).   ||  (2) (‘Who is resented’:) ‘enemy’ (also read with tone A).  ||  [<]  exopass. of yuàn 苑 (Ɂjwɐnᴮ) (§4.4).
‘To wish’ [Shi]. Prob. not related to Lushai ŋiatF ‘to demand, wish for’.

‘To say’ (usually introducing direct discourse), ‘to be called’ [OB, BI, Shi].  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. This word is cognate to → huà3 話 acc. to Sagart (1999: 113). Syn. → yún2 云.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋye (入); MGZY xwÿa (入) [ɦyɛ]; MTang uar, ONW uat < wat
‘To bind’ [Shi], ‘cord’ [Zuo] > ‘restrain, restrict’ [Lunyu] > ‘abbreviate, condensed, essential’ [Li, Meng].  ||  [E] ST: WB yok ‘wind round, as thread’.
‘Bond, contract, agreement’ [Zuo].

‘Sound of vomiting’ [Li].  ||  [E] This is an onomatopoetic expression, other languages in the area have similar words: PTB *Ɂaw ‘vomit’ (HPTB: 227), PLB *ut ‘to belch’; Lushai uakR; PMonic *tl-ɁɔɔɁ, Mon həɁɔɁ ‘to vomit, regurgitate’ [Diffloth 1984: 151]; also WB an ‘vomit’; WT skyug-pa (< s-Ɂyuk ?) ‘vomit, eject’.
‘To vomit’ [Zuo].

‘Moon > month’ [OB, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR ŋye (入); MGZY xwÿa (入) [ɦyɛ]; MTang ŋuar, ONW ŋuat,   ||  [D] Mand. yuè ‘month’, yuè-liáng 月亮 ‘moon’; Gàn ŋyœɁᴰ²-kwɔŋᴬ¹ 月光 ‘moon’ (in Mand. ‘moonlight’); Y-Guǎngzhōu jytᴰ²-kuɔŋᴬ¹ 月光 ‘moon’, Táishān ŋgutᴰ²-kɔŋᴬ¹; PMin *ŋyot: Xiàmén col. geɁᴰ², lit. guatᴰ²  ||  [E] ST: Unger (Hao-ku 39, 1992) proposes as cognate WT ŋo(s) ‘waxing and waning moon, half moon’, Lepcha ñóm. These belong to PTB *ŋow (STC no. 296) > WT sŋo ‘blue-green’, Lushai ŋoᴴ ‘white, fair’, Thado ŋou ‘clean’, Lepcha ta-ŋot ‘white hair, old’ ᛝ ŋo ‘old’ (Bodman 1980: 136). The widespread semantic association of ‘moon’ with ‘white’ would support this etymology; see → bái1 白, → pò4 魄 , → pò5 霸魄 for a parallel. There may possibly be a connection with → ài1 艾 ‘white-haired’, but that is phonologically problematic. Matisoff sets up PTB *s-ŋᵂ(y)at ‘moon, star’ (HPTB: 24; 85). <> Tai ŋuatᴰ² ‘recurring period’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 330) would be a CH loan if the ST etymology is correct. Alternatively, HPTB (24; 26) reconstruct PTB *s-ŋwa-t ‘star / moon’ (from the above root?).

‘Battle-ax’ [BI, Shu, Shi]. Mahdi (1994: 177) points out that the yuè type ax has been found in archeological sites south of the Yangtze and in the Austronesian speaking areas (Chang Kwang-chih 1963; Chén Zhōngmǐn LTBA 22.2: 42) where the word for ‘iron’, in places ‘ax’, is reconstructed PAN *bari > *basi, in some languages wasi and the like. Yuè < *wat could therefore perh. be an AN loan. The etymon also occurs in AA: MK *wac, *waac ‘knife, sword’ (Shorto 2006 #864), PWa *wac ‘knife, sickle, sword’, OMon rwas /rwɔs/ ‘weapon’, perhaps -> TB-JP n³¹-waɁ⁵⁵ < n³¹-wak⁵⁵ notched knife.  ||  Curiously, some Taiwanese tribes have the tradition that they originally came from ‘Vasai’ across the Taiwan straits on the mainland, i.e. the area which has been known as Yuè 越 < *wat since mid-Zhou times.

‘To go on, go beyond, transgress’ [Shi, Shu] > ‘furthermore, and now, later on’ [BI, Shi, Shu], ‘far away’ [Guoyu].   ||  [<] yuè may be derived from → yú1 于 ‘to go’ with a t-suffix of unknown function.   ||  [C] A derivation is prob. → suì1 歲 ‘year’. Baxter / Sagart (1998: 60) relate yuè to → yuǎn1 遠 ‘far away’; Matisoff (ICSTLL 1978: 16) relates kuò 闊 ‘far apart’ (under → kuān 寬 ) to this word.
The ancient state of Yuè, earlier Yú-yuè 於越 *Ɂa-wat; see → yuè3 戉鉞.

‘Mountain, peak’ 嶽 [Shi], 岳 [Shu].  ||  [E] ? AA: PNBahn. *ŋŏk ‘mountain’. Note also PHlai *hŋwɁo³ ‘mountain’. Perh. also connected with WB ŋok, ŋok-ŋak < PLB *Ɂŋokᴸ ‘project, stick up or out’ and WB ŋroŋᶜ ‘any sharp thing sticking out, sharp stump or thorn’, WT rŋog ‘hump’ (of an animal); for a semantic parallel, note Khmer kóok ‘knoll, hillock’ ᛝ Lao ‘hump, bump’ of ox).

‘Music’ [Shi].  ||  [E] The etymological relationship with → lè3 樂 ‘joy’ has been much debated, extensively by K. Wulff (Det Kgl. Danske Videnskabernes Selskab, historisk-filologiske meddelelser XXI,2,1935, København), more recently by Unger (Hao-ku 19, 1983) who suggests something like OCM *grak ‘joy’ from which is derived *ɴ-grak ‘music’. For the semantics Unger draws attention to WT rol-ba ‘to enjoy’ vs. rol-mo ‘music’. On the other hand, there is no other example of QY initial ŋ- ~ l- in a wf. In the popular mind, the concept ‘music’ can easily be connected with ‘joy’, hence perh. the same graph for these near homophones. The graph 樂 originally wrote ‘oak’ lì 櫟 (liek), OCM *riâuk which is therefore the actual phonetic.
‘Bamboo flute’ [Shi]. Baxter (1992: 535) suggests that the following item is from the same root:
‘Flute’ [SW, Fengsu tong].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR di (入); MGZY ti (入) [di]
‘Even, uniform’ [JY] is cognate to → jūn1 均鈞.
‘To say it’ [Lunyu], ‘is called’, ‘to speak’ intr. with the final pronominal -n (Pulleyblank 1995: 81f; see §6.4.5). Perh. cognate to → wèi9 謂 (so Wáng Lì 1982: 456). Syn. → yuē1 曰.
‘To weed’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT yur-ma ‘the act of weeding’, for the initial correspondence, see §12.9 WT. Note also yǒu 莠 (jiəuᴮ) LH juᴮ OCM  *juɁ (< *wuɁ ?) ‘weeds’ [Shi] which may be connected.

‘Cloud’ [OB, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR yn (平); MGZY xwin (平) [ɦwin]  ||  [D] PMin *hiun, W-Wēnzhōu ɦyoŋᴬ², Guǎngzhōu wanᴬ²  ||  [E] This word has no obvious outside connection, except possibly TB-Mikir iŋhùn < m-hùn ‘clouds’; or alternatively KN vaan > Lushai vaanᴸ < vaanh ‘sky’ (in some languages, ‘sky’ and ‘cloud’ are the same word).  ||  However, ‘cloud’ is possibly cognate to → yùn2 運暈 ‘revolve’, thus yún was lit. a ‘whorl’ or ‘swirl’ in the sky (the OB graph for yún shows a whorl). Therefore one or other of the numerous synonymous and similar-looking roots in the area (see under → huí 回) is probably represented here. Closest is perh. AA-Khmer /wul/ ‘to turn (around), revolve, rotate, spin, whirl, eddy, swirl’. From *wul to *wun is only one phonological step; an equally appropriate root PTB *wir would instead require two steps, in addition to -r > -n also the change u > i (§11.5.1): TB-Lushai virR < virɁ ‘rotate, revolve, spin’ ᛝ virᴸ < virh (< -s) ‘a whorl’, Mru wir ‘rotate, spin’, WT ’kʰyir-ba ‘to turn round in a circular course’, JP-Hkauri kə-wīn ‘rotate’ [Matisoff 1974: 166]; WB ə-kʰyin ‘a time period, season’ (for semantics, note xún 旬 under → jūn2 鈞).

‘To trust, be true, sincere’ [Shi] seems to be related to → xìn1 信 ‘believe, trust’; if so, OC should be expected to be *winɁ (not *junɁ). On the other hand, the word may be related to TB-WB yum ‘believe, trust’ (for the final nasal, see §6.7).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR yn (上); MGZY yÿun (上) [jyn]

‘To drop, fall’ 隕 [Shi]; ‘fall to the ground’ [Zuo], ‘to rain, fall down like rain’ 霣 [Gongyang];  ‘to drop, lose’ (one’s life) 殞 [Guoyu]; ‘lose’ 隕 [Zuo] > caus. ‘to overthrow’ 隕 [Zuo], ‘destroy’ 殞 [Xun].  ||  [WFE] ST *(r)we is a rare parallel stem of ST *(r)wa ‘rain’ (→ yǔ3 雨): TB-Mikir arwè ~ ruwè < r-weᴸ ‘rain’, also in Lolo lgs. *we (?) (but HPTB: 128 derives these forms from *r-wa). For CH final -n, see §6.4.4. Syn. include → yǔ3 雨, → líng8 霝零 ‘rain, fall’.
‘To drip, tears falling’ [Guoyu].   ||  [<] iterative derivation of yǔn (§5.2.3).

‘Pregnant’ [Zuo, GY] is prob. the s. w. as yìng 繩 ‘full’ (of ears of grain)  [Zhouli].   ||  [D] Medieval dictionaries and non-Mandarin modern dialects reflect a reading which is the equivalent of QY jiəŋᶜ: W-Wēnzhōu ɦiaŋᶜ², M-Xiàmén lit. jiŋᶜ², Fúzhōu eiŋᶜ², Cháozhōu eŋᴬ. Occasional forms with the equivalent of QYS rime -jen prob. represent secondary developments: Guǎngzhōu janᶜ² (but northern Yuè dialects point to -jəŋ), M-Xiàmén col. jinᶜ². Mand. dialects have forms riming in -un which may possibly reflect the ancient (LH and OC) form jun as opposed to LH win. Many modern dialects have replaced this word with other expressions.    ||  [WFE] This etymon is perh. related to → yíng2 盈贏 (jiäŋ) ‘full’ because the two words differ only in the vowels (as can occasionally be observed within wfs), and because the phrase 孕育 ‘to conceive and give birth’ is rendered as 贏育 (*-eŋ) in Guǎnzǐ. More tenuous would be identification with the WT dictionary word liŋs-pa ‘quite round or globular’.
‘Pregnant’ [Guanzi; GY] (GY 432; GYSX 884).

‘Revolve, turn round’ [Yi], ‘move’ [Zhuang], ‘longitudinal’ 運 [Guoyu]; ‘bring supply of food to’ [Zuo]; ‘vapor, halo’ 暈 [Lü].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR yn (去); MGZY xwin (去) [ɦwin]; ONW un  ||  [E] → yún5 雲 ‘cloud’ is prob. related. Karlgren (1933: 28) relates this etymon to → wéi5 圍, Wáng Lì (1982: 398) to → huí 回, but see there.

‘To block, accumulate’ (pent-up feelings) 蘊 [Shi] > ‘to hoard, accumulate’ 薀 [Zuo].  ||  [WFE] This wf may perh. be related to → yōng1 邕; for the difference in final nasal, see §6.4.2. The wf → yīn4 湮堙闉 ‘to obstruct’ is probably not related. We have prob. these developments:  ||  PCH *Ɂuŋ >  LH  Ɂoŋ (→ yōng1 邕)  ||  >  LH  Ɂun  (yùn 蘊薀)
‘To pack, store up’ [Lunyu].
‘To hate’ [Shi] (note  蘊薀 ‘pent-up feelings’), ‘grieved’ [Li].

‘To bite, sting and suck’ (as a mosquito) [Zhuang].  ||  [E] Sound symbolic area word: PTB *dzoːp (STC no. 69) > PLB *Ɂcup ~ Ɂɉup ~ *C-cup ‘suck, milk’; Thado tsop, Siyin tuop, Dimasa dźop; Lushai fɔɔpF (Lorrain fâwp) / fɔɁᴸ ‘to kiss, suck’; WT ’ǰo-ba, bžos ‘to milk’ derives from a form with medial *j (PTib. *-op > WT *-o, see §12.9); JP mə³¹-sup³¹ ‘to suck’, tʃup³¹ ‘suck’. HPTB: 382 list many TB variants. Note also AA: Kharia jo’b ‘to suck’, Munda cɛpɔ’d, Khmer -jāpa /-cíiəp/ ‘to take in, suck’.    ||  Foreign words with the rime -op, -up usually become MC -əp (via earlier -wəp, with the medial w lost due to dissimilation); occasionally, such words appear in OC as *-ot, *-ut, thus → chuò2 啜歠 ‘drink’ may be related. Karlgren (1956: 18) relates this word to → cǎn 噆 ‘hold in the mouth’.

‘Natural disaster’ (fire, drought, flood, locusts, eclipse, pestilence etc.), ‘accident, injury’ 災 [OB, Shi], 憧 [Li], ‘conflagration’ [Zuo, SW, Hanshu].  ||  [E] ? ST *tsə > TB: JP tsa³¹ ‘be damaged’ ᛝ ʃə³¹-tsa³¹ ‘to destroy’. This root blends into a homophone meaning ‘warm, heat, fever, pain’: PTB *tsa ‘be hot’ (STC no. 62) > WT tsʰa-ba ‘hot, heat, sharp (spices), illness’ ᛝ tsʰad-pa ‘heat, fever’ ᛝ tsʰan-ma ‘hot, warm’; TGTM *¹tshawa ‘fever’, ²tsha ‘be in pain’; Chepang ca ‘sore, wound’ ᛝ ca- ‘have sores’, Mikir sò- ‘hot, excessive, be ill, sore’; NNaga dzat ‘suffer’ [French 1983: 223], Garo sa ‘ache, pain’; WB ə-cha ‘hunger, something faulty or hurtful’, Lahu cha ‘to shine, be bright’ (of the sun). STC (170 n. 455) relates PTB *tsa ‘hot, pain’ to → jí6 疾, but see there.   ||  [C] Prob. cognate to → zī8 菑 ‘slash and burn’, and possibly to → zéi 賊.

‘To plant’ 栽 [Li]; ‘to begin’ 哉 [Shu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tsaj (平); MGZY dzay (平) [tsaj]; ONW tsɑi  ||  [WFE] The basic meaning of this wf is ‘to be at a place > to put at a place > put into place > plant / initiate’. The word → zài1 在 ‘to be in, at’ is prob. related; this wf belongs perh. to ST *tsə ‘come forth’ from which → zǐ1 子 (tsiᴮ) is derived.
‘To initiate, start work, undertaking, achievement; at first’ [Shi, Shu].
‘To board, erect building frames’ [Shi, Zuo].

‘Be in, at, to exist’ [OB, BI, Shi] appears to be the endoactive form of the items under → zāi2 栽哉 (§4.5). On the other hand, Matisoff  (ICSTLL, Bangkok 2000: 8) compares zài to Lahu ch»ə ᛝ j»ə ‘stop, cease, come to rest’ *N-dzay² (JAM) or *cya² ᛝ *jya² (Bradley 1979). Allofam → cún 存.   ||  [T] Sin S. SR dzaj (上去); MGZY tsay (上去) [dzaj]; ONW dzɑi
‘To load, carry, pour, fill, conveyance’ [Shi].  ||  [WFE] This wf could possibly be part of → zāi2 栽哉, here in the sense of ‘to put into place > put on, place onto, load’.
‘To load, a load’ [Shi]
‘A burden’ [Shi].
‘Twice, again and again’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tsaj (去); MGZY dzay (去) [tsaj]; ONW tsɑiᶜ
‘A turn’ (as in: ‘it is his turn to...’), ‘a year’ [Shu].   ||  [<] endoactive / tr. of zài.
‘Year’ [Guoce], as in jīn zī 今茲 ‘this year’, lái zī 來茲 ‘next year’.
‘Repeat, repeatedly’ 薦 [Shi], ‘repeat, a second time’ 洊 [Yi], ‘repeat, increase’ 荐 [Zuozhuan].

‘Hairpin’ [Xun].  ||  [D] PMin *±tsɑm (> Jiānglè tsoŋᴬ¹, Fúzhōu tsaŋᴬ¹) ~ *tsem (> Amoy tsiamᴬ¹); Y-Guǎngzhōu ⁵⁵tsamᴬ¹    ||  [E] Area word *C-rum ~ *C-rim ‘needle’; the OC word is phonetically closest to languages which are farthest afield (this is also the case with ‘weave’ → rén5 紝): AN-PCham *jurŭm, IN daƔum ‘needle’ (Benedict AT: 113); AA-PNBahn. jar≠ùm, PSBahn. ɉərum, Sre jurum -> TB-Lepcha ryŭm, Mikir iŋprìm ‘needle’; IST: 237 lists prum ~ prim > ṭim for Kuki-Chin languages. OC can be derived from a form *jrum or *crum. The history of PKS *tsʰomᴬ ‘needle’ is not clear.
‘To slander’ tr. [Shi]. For semantics, see → zhēn8 箴鍼, → cì2 朿.
‘Be good’ (of quality of persons, horses, state) [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WT bzaŋ-po ‘good’ (HST: 87).
‘Meet, encounter’ [Shi].  ||  [WFE] Bodman (1969) combines zú 卒, cuì 萃 with → tún2 屯窀, zuì 最 (under → jù7 聚) and other items into a large ST wf ‘to collect, accumulate’.
‘Come together’ [Guoyu], ‘crowd’ [Zuo].  ||  [T] MGZY tsaw (平) [dzaw]; Sin Sukchu SR dzaw (平)  ||  [<] endopass. / intr. of zāo 遭 (tsâu) (§4.6).
‘To collect, bring together’ (blessings, states) [Shi].
‘Bring together, collect, sum up’ [Yi].  ||  [E] ST: WB cuiŋ ‘cohere’; Lushai čhuŋᴴ (Lorrain chhung) ‘family, household’.

‘Group’ (of men, families, states) [Li], ‘soldier, army’ [Zuo].   ||  [T] MTang tsur < tsuir, ONW tsuit  ||  [<] derived from zāo 遭 above with the nominal t-suffix (§6.2.1).   ||  [C] Karlgren (1956: 13) considers this word a cognate of → zú1 卒 ‘to die’ (unlikely).
‘To collect, assemble’ [Shi], ‘assemblage, crowd’ [Meng]. Bodman links this word to → zú1 卒; Baxter (1992: 350) considers this word a tone C derivation from → jí13 集輯 (dzjəp) ‘collect’.

‘Early’ [Shu]. Acc. to Norman (1986: 382) the Northern Mǐn ‘softened initial’ *±ts- indicates OC prenasalization which is supported by Yao dzjou³ < *ntz- ‘early’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tsaw (上); MGZY dzaw (上) [tsaw]; ONW tsɑu,   ||  [E] Zǎo is prob. derived from → zào3 造 ‘do, make, begin’ and thus semantically similar to other words for ‘morning’ (→ chén5 晨, → sù3 夙). WB coᴮ ‘early, pre-mature’ ᛝ cʰoᶜ ‘be early’ (as rains), JP tʃau³³ are prob. Tai loans (Matisoff 1974: 178): PTai *zauᴮ² ‘time of cock crowing’ (Luo Yongxian MKS 27, 1997: 293) or *ɉauᶜ² [Li Fang Kuei].
‘Flea’ [Zhuang]. Unger (Hao-ku 39, 1992) suggests cognation with → sāo1 搔 ‘scratch’, hence lit. ‘itcher’.
‘To wash’ [Li].  ||  [E] <> PMY *nts¹aau³ ᴮ/ᶜ ‘to wash (bathe)’. Note also TB-Lushai suᴸ / suukF < tsuɁ/h ‘to wash’, but the vocalism does not agree with OC.
‘An acorn, black-dying fruit’ [Zhouli]. CVST (4: 13) relates this word to WT tsʰos ‘paint, dye’ which, however, could phonologically also agree with → cǎi2 采 *tshəɁ ‘full of colour, colour’ [Shi].
‘To proceed to’ [Shi, Meng], ‘reach to’ (mountains the sky) [Hou Hanshu].
‘To proceed, achieve’ [Shi] (Wáng Lì 1982: 311).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dziw (去); MGZY tsiw (去) [dziw]; MTang dzeu < dziu, ONW dzu  ||  [N] This wf is perh. related to → zào3 造, → zú1 卒.

‘To do, make, build’ (boats, bridges), ‘be active, begin’ [Shi]; ‘to achieve’ [Shi], ‘perfected’ [Shu].   ||  [N] The element → gào0 告 ‘report’ with initial k- is not phonetic, it was part of the original word 造 *tshûh ‘to go and offer’ (a sacrifice), ‘go and appear in court’ which usually would involve some announcement or report. Therefore, there is no need to postulate an *sk-like initial.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *tsuk > WT ’tsʰugs-pa ‘go into, commence, take root’ ᛝ ’dzugs-pa ~ zug-pa ‘to stick into, set, erect, put down, begin’ ᛝ ’tsʰud-pa ‘be put into, enter’, PLB *tsukᴴ ‘build’ (a house). An allofam is prob. → zǎo1 早 ‘early’. This wf is perh. related to → zào2 造, → zú1 卒.

‘Consequently, thereupon, otherwise’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin S. SR tsəj (入), LR tsəjɁ; MGZY dzhiy (入) [tsəj]; ONW tsək  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. Unger (see Geilich 1994: 289) suggests that this is zī 茲 LH tziə, *tsə ‘this’ [Shi] with the distributive k-suffix (§6.1.2). If true, the meaning ‘a norm’ [BI, Shi] would prob. represent a different word.
‘Request, reprove, hold responsible’ [Shu].
‘Debt’ [Shu]. Acc. to Baxter (1992: 231). → zhé8 謫 is possibly related.

‘To choose’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐəj (入); MGZY cay (入) [dʐaj]; MTang ḍëk, ONW dëk  ||  [E] <> KT: PKS *laːiﬂ ‘to pick, select’, Tai: S. liakᴰ² ‘to choose’. QY div. II ḍɐk results from the same OC L-like initial which with all other rimes has yielded QY div. III initial ḍj-. Final -k added to *-ai yields *-ak in a few other words as well.
‘A quiver’ [Yili].  ||  [E] MK: Khmer /crɑɑk/  ‘insert, introduce, shove into...’

‘To spear’ (fish) [Guoyu].  ||  [E] This word is a variant of → chuō 政  and → cè5 簎 whose OC vowel may be due to interference from either → chā1 叉 *tshrai ‘fork’ (incl. ‘tree fork for spearing fish’) or cì 刺 (tsʰjäk) [tsʰiek] *tshek ‘stab’ (under → cì2 朿), semantically parallel to → cè5 簎.

‘To injure, damage; robber’ [BI, Shi] may possibly be related to → zāi1 災 ‘disaster, injury’.  ||  [E] ? ST: WT ǰag < ? ‘robbery’ (HST: 127) looks like a cognate, but a WT palatalized initial usually does not correspond to an unpalatalized one in Chinese. On the other hand, a MK palatal initial may; note Khmer /chak/ ‘to snatch’ ᛝ /cmak/ ‘thief’ [Jenner / Pou 1982: xlvii].

‘To add’ [Meng] > ‘to double, to rise high’ 曾 [Chuci]; ‘increase, numerous’ 增 [Shi]; ‘bundles of branches’ 橧 [Li] > ‘to hate’ 憎 [BI, Shi] may be the same word (i.e. emotional increase, accumulation).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tsəjŋ (平), PR tsəŋ; MGZY dzhing (平) [tsəŋ]; ONW tsəŋ  ||  [WFE] Prob. ST: WT ’tsʰeŋ-ba ‘increase, improve’ (CVST 4: 4). Alternatively, this group may be derived from → dēng1 登 (HST: 126) in which case it would be an iterative s-prefix derivation (§5.7).

‘In two stories, double’ [Chuci].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dzəjŋ (平), PR, LR dzəŋ; MGZY tshing (平) [dzəŋ]  ||  [D] Perh. this (i.e. MC dzəŋ) is the s. w. as PMin *tsʰənᴬ² ‘wet rice field’ (J. Norman, p.c.); note also zěng 與 (tsəŋᴮ) ‘wet field’ [JY], but initial and tone don’t agree with PMin. Chen and Li (1991: 24) identify the Mǐn word with chéng 塍 (dźjəŋ) ‘raised path between fields’ [SW].   ||  [<] endopass. of zēng (tsəŋ) (§4.6), lit. ‘what is increased, raised’.

‘To open’ (a door) [Zhuang], the graph shows a person with the legs opened.  ||  This word’s final -k variant is → zhé6 磔. OC rimes *-e  and *-ai do occasionally mix in wfs, the initial OC *tr-  could derive from some consonant + medial r as is also seen in the allofam → bò3 擘 and its Tai cognates. Therefore this word may be cognate to → bǎi2 捭 OC *breɁ ‘to open’. For an overview of similar items, see Table P-1 under → pī3 披.  →  For a listing of similar words and possible allofams, see → lí10 離.

‘To die (i.e., in an epidemic)’ [Zuo], ‘pestilence’ [Zhouli].  ||  [WFE] MK: Zhèng Xuán (commentary to Zhōulǐ) says that zhá means ‘to die’ in the ancient Yuè (Viet) language (Pulleyblank 1983: 438), which however does not necessarily mean that zhá is a loan from PVM. MK *kc[ə]t ‘to die’ (Shorto 2006 #987): PVM *k-ceːt > Viet. chêt ‘to die’ (Norman / Mei 1976: 277); PMonic kcət ‘to die’ ᛝ k-r-cet ‘to kill’; Khmer /s`ət/ ‘to die’ ᛝ /bɑnsìiət/ ‘to kill’ (ban- is caus. prefix). For the initials, see §10.5.2.
‘To suffer, hurt’ [Shi].

‘To inhabit, reside, dwell, settle, residence’ [Shi, Shu], ‘homestead, farmstead’ [Meng];  Mand. ‘residence, house’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐəj (入), LR dʐəjɁ; MGZY cay (入) [dʐaj]; MTang ḍëk, ONW dëk  ||  [E] MK: Khmer dak ‘put down, settle, lodge...’ ᛝ dɔmnak (i.e. d-mn-ak) ‘residence’. As in many words, OC has an assumed *r in the initial which is absent in other languages (§7.6.2). Alternatively, it has been suggested that zhái may be connected with Tai: S. riakᴰ² (perh. ‘field’?) (Manomaivibool 1975: 150-153).

(‘To look at, gaze, look at omens, dreams’:) ‘prognosticate, interpret’ [OB, BI, Shi].    ||  [WFE] ? MK: OKhmer /cam/ ‘to watch over, watch for, keep in mind’ [Jenner / Pou 1982: 67], Viet xem [sem] < *tśʰj- (and also *ṭʰj-?) ‘to see, look at, watch’. The initial correspondance is not clear, though.
‘To look at, gaze’ [Shi]. The OC vacillation between *-em and *-am points to an actual *-iam (§11.3.2).   ||  [T] ONW tśam
‘To look, observe’ 佔 [Li] > ‘to spy’ 覘 (also read ṭʰjämᶜ) [Zuo].

‘To moisten, soak through’ 霑 [Shi], 沾 [Chuci]. Perh. cognate to → jiān8 漸瀸湛 (so Karlgren 1949: 80).  ||  [E] MK *ram, *raam ‘to be in, under water’ (Shorto 2006 #1384): Khmer /tram/ ‘to soak, steep’ ᛝ /tɑmram/  ‘soaking, immersion, anything soaked in water / brine’, PNBahn. *trăm, PSBahn. *təram ‘soak’, *kəram ‘sink’; Katuic *tərh[ə/a]m ‘soak’.
‘Sandalwood’ <- Indic: Skt. candana. The earlier word consists of just the second syllable [Shi] where the connection with Skt. is doubtful.

‘Roll over’ 輾 [Shi], ‘unfold, open’ 展 [Yili] > ‘develop, set forth’ [Zuozhuan] > ‘examine’ [Liji].  ||  [E] ST: WT rdal-ba, brdal ‘to spread, unfold, extend over’ (HST: 139), WB tanᴮ ‘extend in a line, stretch out straight’ ᛝ ə-tanᴮ ‘line, row, duration, length’.
‘A ritual robe’ [Shi] is perhaps a derivation (i.e. ‘rolled = draped around’?).

‘To cut off, cut down’ [Shi].  ||  [WFE] MK: PVM *cɛmᴮ ‘to chop’ [Thompson]; Khmer cram ‘to hack’ (a learned r-infix from a col. form without, Khmer càm ‘cop up, cut’; a CH loan acc. to Pou / Jenner J. of Oriental Studies 11, 1973: 1-90; however, OC already had this medial*-r-). <>  PTai *thr-: S. hamᶜ¹ ‘chop, hack’ (Luo Yongxian ICSTLL 2002).
‘Sharp’ [Mo].  ||  [<] endopass. of zhǎn (§4.6), lit. ‘be cutting’ intr..
‘To slander’ [Zuo]. For semantics, compare items under → zān 簪, from which zèn 譖 (tṣjəmᶜ) ‘slander’ is derived.
‘Be soaking’ (as dew) [Shi]; ‘deep’ [Chuci].  ||  [E] <> PYao *rjɛm ‘to water, soak’ [Purnell]. Prob. related to → chén2 沈.

‘War, battle’ [Lunyu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂjen (去); MGZY jÿan (去) [tʂjɛn]; ONW tśan  ||  [E] This word is commonly thought to be cognate to WT ral ‘fight, war’ (so STC: 155 n. 419; p. 173 n. 461), Lushai raalᴴ ‘enemy’, or to rgyal ‘victory, victorious’. However, TB initial *r for OC *t- is unlikely.  ||  As in many languages, the word for ‘war, battle’ zhàn may be a semantic extension zhàn 戰 ‘tremble, fear’ (under → dàn7 憚) (Geilich 1994: 238). The semantics are identical to Greek pólemos ‘war’ which is derived from a root ‘tremble, fear’ (Buck 1949; §20.13). The TB word *raːl belongs to the root ‘separate’ which is cognate to CH → lí10 離 ‘depart from, divide’ which has a semantic parallel in Skt. vigraha- ‘strife, war’ (Buck ibid.). The word is probably unrelated to MK *jəl ‘to charge, fight’ (Shorto 2006 #1728): Old Khmer jɑl, because MC initial tś- (< *t-) is otherwise not known to correspond to a foreign affricate.

‘A shed made of intertwined branches’ [Zhuang], ‘carriage box made of lath or bamboo’ [Shi].  ||  [E] Manomaivibool (1975: 157) relates zhàn to Tai: S. raanᶜ² ‘machan, booth, stall, shop’. For the initials, see §7.1.5.
‘Make long, to string a bow’ [Shījīng], ‘string an instrument’ [Guoce], ‘stretch, extend’ [Laozi].
‘Be swollen, conceited; wanting to go to stool’ 張 [Zuo]; ‘a tent’ (< ‘something stretched’) 帳 [Shiji], ‘a curtain’ [Chuci].   ||  [<] exopass. of *traŋ (§4.4), lit. ‘be stretched’.
‘To grow tall’ [Meng], ‘increase, elder’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂjaŋ (上); MGZY jang (上) [tʂaŋ]  — [D] PMin *tɔŋᴮ  ||  [<] endoactive of *traŋ 張 (§4.5).

‘Be long, tall, long-lasting’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [D] PMin *d̯ɔŋ  ||  [<] endopass. (§4.6) of *traŋ 張, lit. ‘be extended, stretched’ (intr. voicing; Baxter and Sagart 1998: 46). The lack of TB cognates indicates that this word is a CH innovation.

‘Length, measure of length’ [Li].  ||  [<] LOC general derivation *draŋ (§3.5.2) (Baxter / Sagart 1998: 55: a noun derived from a ‘gradable adjective’).  ||  [E] ST: WT ’dren-ba, draŋ(s)  ‘to draw, drag, pull, draw tight’ (a rope), PLB *raŋ ‘draw, pull, drag’; Lushai ṭaŋᴴ / ṭanᴸ ‘be distented’ (as breasts w. milk), ṭʰaŋᴴ / ṭʰanᴸ ‘to grow’, perh. also WB kraŋᶜ ‘tense, tight’ (see §12.9 WT (5) for the TB initial correspondences).  ||  Several languages in the area have a syn. with simple initial t-, MK * taaŋ ‘extend, stretch’ (Shorto 2006 #544a): Khmer /-daaŋ/ ᛝ /trɑdaaŋ/ ‘stretch out, extend’ ᛝ /taaŋ/ ‘draw out, prolong, lengthen’; Mon dāŋ, Bahnar tăŋ ‘stretch out’. AA -> TB-Lepcha daŋ (Forrest JAOS 82, 1962: 334); WB taŋᴮ ‘tighten, become tense, stiff’ (from *tr-?); WT tʰaŋ-po ‘hardy, strong, tense’ (HST: 150). Table Z-1 provides an overview of the ST items.  See Table  Z-1   Tight, tense for zhāng1 張  →

‘Be splendid, distinguishing, distinction’ [Shi, Shu], ‘to display’ [Shu] > ‘emblem, insignium, jade tablet’ [Shi, Shu].  ||  [E] ST: KC-Tiddim ta:ŋM / taːnF ‘be bright, shining’ ᛝ taːnF ᛝ taːt ‘to illuminate’.
‘River deer’ [Lü].   ||  [D] In Mǐn the word has initial k-: Xiàmén kiũᴬ¹, hence perh. OCM *kiaŋ?

‘Old man’ 丈 [Lunyu], 杖 [Yi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐjaŋ (上); MGZY cang (上) [dʐaŋ]; MTang ḍaŋ, ONW daŋ  ||  [E] ST: PTB *źraŋ (STC no. 205) (or rather *ryaŋ ?) > WT žaŋ an honorific: žaŋ-žaŋ ‘chief uncle’, WB ə-hraŋ ‘master, lord’, Kuki *r(j)aŋ ~ *traŋ ‘father’s sister’s husband’, Mru taraŋ ‘uncle’ (Löffler 1966: 140). This may be an old area word: PAN guDaŋ ‘adult, grown up’ (Sagart JCL 21.1, 1993: 32 associates AN with items under → zhāng1 張). This word is sometimes thought to be the same as → zhàng3 杖 ‘staff’, i.e. someone who walks with, or leans on, a staff (unlikely).
‘A length measure of ten chǐ [Zuo].  ||  [D] PMin *dɔŋᴮ  ||  [E] ST: Lushai ṭaaŋᴴ-kaiᴴ a measure as much as the distance from the tip of the middle finger to ... breast bone...’.

‘Stick, staff’ [Lunyu].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐjaŋ (上); MGZY cang (上) [dʐaŋ]; MTang  ḍaŋ, ONW daŋ   ||  [D] PMin *dʰɔŋᴮ  ||  [E] Area word: TB-Lushai: tiaŋR ‘a walking stick, a staff’. <> Benedict (1976: 171) relates zhàng to a Proto-Austro-Tai *(n)ti(y)aŋ ‘stick, handle, post, tree’: Javanese tiyaŋ, Malay tiaŋ ‘post’, Fiji ndia ‘stick, handle’. <> PTai *deeŋ ~ *tʰeeŋ ‘stick, bar’. <> MK: Khmer ṭaṅa /dɑɑŋ/ OKhmer toŋ /Ïɔɔŋ/ ‘shaft, stock, shank’ ᛝ -toṅa /-taaoŋ/ ‘stock, stem, stick’.
‘To lean on’ [Zuo].
‘Dyke, dam up’ [Zuo], ‘obstacle’ [Li]; Mand. ‘hinder, obstruct, barrier, block’. The word looks like a cognate of → táng2 塘, but the OC initials do not agree (*t- vs. *l-).

‘To cut’ 釗 [SW]; ‘a big sickle’ 鉊 (MC tśjäu only) [Guan]; 鉊 is a Han period dialect word from the eastern Huái-Yangtze region, in Chǔ and Chén [FY 5,30].  ||  [E] KT: Prob. a Tai word: Lao kiauᴮ¹ ‘to reap, sickle’, S. kiauᴮ¹ ‘to cut with a sickle’ ᛝ khiauᴬ² < *g- ‘a sickle’ (Li 1976: 47).

‘Be bright, illustrious, glorious, enlighten’ [Shi, Shu].  ||  Acc. to SW zhāo 釗 (tśjäu, kieu) is a loan graph for 昭, therefore the OC stem in this wf was prob. *kiau (not *tiau); note also the allofams jiǎo 皎皦 and qiāo.   below.

‘To shine, be brilliant, visible’ 炤 [BI, Shi]; ‘shine, shine on’ (of sun, moon) 照 [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂjew (去); MGZY jew (去) [tʂɛw]; ONW tśau  ||  [<] exoactive / tr. of zhāo 昭 (tśjäu) (§4.3).
‘Glorious’ [Shi].
‘Bright’ 皎皦 [Shi], 柾 [Chuci]; ‘distinct’ 皦 [Lunyu].   ||  [D] Amoy kiauᴬ¹ col. ‘bright and decided’ / lit. ‘beautiful’.
‘Bleached white (of bones)’ [Zhuang].   ||  [<] Probably a tone A noun of jiǎo 皎皦 (§3.1).

‘Morning’ [BI, Shi]. A labial initial may be assumed for OC because zhāo serves as phonetic for → miào2 廟 ‘temple’, note also Tai. See also §7.1.4.  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. pʰrauᴬ² < *br- ‘morning’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 302).
(‘Perform the morning ceremony’:) ‘go / come to court, to an audience’ intr. 朝 [Shi]; ‘morning tide’ 潮 [Chuci], opp. ‘evening tide’ → xī1 夕汐.
‘Claw’ 爪 [Shi], 叉 [SW]. This is the s. w. as, or cognate to, → zhuā 抓 ‘grasp’; it may perh. also be related to → sāo1 搔 ‘scratch’.
‘To search for’. The word first appears in the Ming dynasty, etymology unknown (Norman 1988: 76).
‘To call, summon’ [BI, Shi].  ||  Prob. related to Tai: S. riakᴬ² ‘summon, call’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 152), for the initials see §7.1.4, for the finals §6.9.
‘To beckon, summon’ [Shi] > ‘signalize’ [Guoyu].
‘To tell, declare’ [BI, Shu] is perh. related.
‘To prognosticate omen, symptom’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] Perh. ST: Chepang hrawɁ- ‘forebode, portend ill fortune, be ill’.

[T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂjaw, dʐjaw (入), LR tʂjawɁ; MGZY jew, cew  (入) [tʂɛw ~ dʐɛw]  ||  A Mand. progressive suffix, first appears in the 9th cent. AD; in Wú dial.: tsi (< Southern MC ṭjɣ), it has now also assumed the function of the perfective aspect marker (Mei Tsu-Lin CAAAL 9, 1978: 39ff.).

‘Hanging ears’ [Zuo, N. Pr.], also dā 耷 (tâp) LH tɑp ‘ears long and hanging down’ [GY] is acc. to JY the common graph for zhé.  ||  [E] Perh. connected with Tai *tuːp ‘hanging ears’ (of dog) (STC: 181 n. 479).

‘To break off’ tr. [Shi], ‘destroy’ [Yi], ‘decide’ [Shu].    ||  [WFE] ST *tet ~ *tjat (for the vowels, see §11.3.2): Chepang tet- ‘break or snap a rope, tear cloth’. PTB *tsyat (STC no. 185), or rather *tyat (Baxter / Sagart 1998: 43f): PLB *tsat ~ *C-tsat ‘break in two, cut through, conclude’; WT ’čʰad-pa, čʰad ‘to cut, explain’ ᛝ gčod-pa, bčad ‘to cut’. Lushai čatᴸ / čaɁᴸ (Lorr. chat) ‘to break or snap’ (as rope, string), ‘asunder, apart’ ᛝ čʰatᴸ / čʰaɁᴸ ‘to fetch or cut’ (long pieces of cane etc.).   ||  [C] Karlgren 1956: 16 relates → zhé3 哲 ‘wise’ (< ‘penetrating’) to this wf.
‘To bend’ intr. [Li], ‘be cut off, broken off > to die prematurely’ [Shu].  ||  [<] endopass. of zhé 折 (tśjät) (§4.6) (Baxter and Sagart 1998: 43). For a semantic parallel, see → yǎo1 夭殀.
‘Fever’ [Shi], ‘suffer’ [Shi] is perh. a MK word: Khmer krùn vb. ‘have a fever’, the OC vowel *ə after an initial with *r could correspond to foreign *u as in → chén6 塵 ‘dust’.
‘Path between fields’ [BI, Shi], ‘boundary dykes’ [Zhuang] is perh. cognate to the synonymous → dìng3 町.
‘My, our’ [BI, Shi, Shu], etymology not clear.

‘To shake, rouse, quake’ 振 [Shi] > ‘to alarm, fear’ 震 [OB, Shi], ‘scared’ 振 [Guoce]; > ‘move’ [Li], ‘lift’ 振 [Guoyu] > ‘save, help’ 振 [Yi], ‘endow, succor’ 賑 [Mo].   ||  [D] M-Xiàmén col. tǐnᴮ¹, lit. tsinᴮ¹ ‘to shake’ (neither the col. initial nor tone agree with the QYS).

‘Majestic’ [Shi] is prob. related because of the frequent semantic connection between ‘shake’ and ‘fear, fearsome’.  ||  [E] The semantic field of this wf is parallel to → sōu3, sǒu 搜: ‘move / stir > pregnant, morning’. Therefore → chén5 晨 ‘morning’ belongs also to this root, perh. also → zhèn, shēn 娠 ‘pregnant’. Perhaps zhèn2a  震 ‘thunder’ belongs to this wf.  ||  Probably connected with MK *gt1ar (ɛ *gt1ər ?) ‘to shiver’ (Shorto 2006 #1623): Bahnar tar-[war] ‘to shake with fear’, Central Nicobarese kətɤə ‘to tremble, vibrate’, Mon hətɔ ‘to shiver’, Khasi kynther ‘to shake off, shed, flutter’.
‘Thunder’ [Shi].  ||  [E] MK *[g]tiər, *gtər ‘(to) thunder’ (Shorto 2006 #1622). Perhaps related to zhèn2 振震.

‘Pregnant’ 娠 [Zuo], ‘become pregnant’ 震 [Shi]. The reading shēn has prob. been transferred from → shēn2 身 ‘body’ with which it is unrelated.   ||  [E] The etymology is not certain. It is prob. the s. w. as → zhèn 振震 and therefore semantically derived from ‘to shake, rouse, excite’ (e.g. a grasshopper from hibernation, i.e. coming to life), hence lit. ‘start stirring, moving’ (of an embryo). Alternatively, this could be the s. w. as zhèn 侲娠 (tśjenᶜ) LH tśienᶜ, OCM *təns ‘child, boy or girl’ [Han texts]; in the ancient Yān-Qí region (NE and eastern China) the word meant ‘someone who raises horses’ (stable boy / girl?), 娠 also refers to a ‘maid’ of an official’s wife [FY 3,3]. Zhèn ‘pregnant’ means then lit. ‘with child’.
‘To fight, quarrel’ [Shi].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂəjŋ (平), PR, LR tʂəŋ; MGZY jhing (平) [tʂəŋ]; ONW tṣëŋ  ||  [E] ST: WT ’dziŋ-ba ‘quarrel, contend, fight’ (HST: 122), WB cac ‘war, battle’.
‘To steam’ (food) [Shi]. Sagart (1999: 73) derived the following from this word:
‘Boiler, earthenware pot for steaming rice’ [Meng].
‘Brushwood’ (as firewood) [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *taŋ (STC no. 320) > WT tʰaŋ ‘pine, fir, evergreen tree’, WB tʰaŋᴮ ‘fuel, firewood’, in compounds also ‘pine, fir’ (HST: 79).

‘Elbow, heel’ occurs in southern dialects: PMin *taŋ ~ *tiaŋ: Yǒng’ān tı̃ᴬ¹, Jiàn’ōu tiaŋᴬ¹, Fúzhōu taŋᴬ¹, Fú’ān naŋᴬ¹, Amoy tı̃ᴬ¹, Jiēyáng tẽᴬ¹; Y-Guǎngzhōu sauᴮ¹-tsaaŋᴬ¹ ‘elbow’, kœkᴰ¹m?-tsaaŋᴬ¹ ‘heel’. Etymology not clear.

‘Be straight, correct > govern, determine’ 正 [Shi, Shu]; ‘to govern, government’ 政 [BI, Shi, Shu], ‘remonstrate’ 証 [Guoce].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂiŋ (去); MGZY jing (去) [tʂiŋ]; ONW tśeŋ  ||  [<] exoact. / tr. derivation of zhēng (§4.3.2).

‘Center of target; first (month)’ [BI, Shi] > (‘to target, make straight for’:) ‘to march on / against, campaign’ 征 [BI, Shi]. Contrary to traditional belief (GSR 833o), the basic meaning is not ‘to correct’ > ‘punish by military expedition’, although the (royal, imperial) attacker likes to see his action thus morally justified.

‘Be orderly’ [Zuo] > causative ‘to arrange, dispose’ (troops) [Shi] (Unger Hao-ku 36, 1990: 50)  ||  [<] endoactive of zhēng 正征 (tśjäŋ) (§4.5).  ||  [WFE] ST or area word: TB-Lushai diiŋF ‘to go straight or direct, go straight through without breaking the journey’ etc.; Chepang dʰeŋ- ‘be straight’; JP teŋ³¹ ‘right, correct’, Lepcha atʰáŋ ‘right, correct’, WB tañᶜ ‘straightforward, direct’. <> MK: Khmer diaṅa /tíiəŋ/ ‘be true, accurate, correct, right’.   ||  This wf could be related to → tíng1 亭 (so Karlgren 1956: 16), but prob. not to → tǐng2 挺 because the initials are different (*l- vs. *t-). Matisoff (1988) combines this wf with → yíng2 盈嬴 ‘full’, → píng1 平 ‘level’, → tǐng2 挺 ‘straight’.
‘Testify, prove’ [Lunyu]. The wf → zhēn4 貞 is similar to this one.  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂiŋ (去); MGZY jing (去) [tʂiŋ]; ONW tśiŋ
‘To examine, verify, summon’ [Shu], ‘test, testify, prove’ [Zuo].

[T] Sin S. SR tʂi (平), PR, LR tʂʅ; MGZY ji (平) [tʂi]; ONW tśə  ||  (1) Demonstrative pronoun ‘this, he, she, it’. As a subject it is common in OB, sporadic in Shījīng and subsequent classical texts, but it is everywhere the normal object pronoun ‘him, her, it’. Placed after the negatives bù 不 and wú 毋, the obj. pronoun is reduced to its initial t- and fused with the preceding negatives yielding fú 弗 (pjuət) ‘not it’ and wù 勿 (mjuət) ‘don’t... it’, see under → bù1 不 and → wú1 毋.   ||  (2) Derived from the pronoun is the use as the common genitive marker. A medieval colloquial genitive marker was written → dǐ2 底; subsequently → de3 的 appears for the first time in a Song document (Coblin p.c.) and later in a Yuan inscription of 1238 (Mei Tsu-Lin BIHP 59.1, 1988). However, these forms may be unrelated to zhī because they imply a final -k.  ||  [WFE] ST: WT da ‘there’.

Demonstrative pronoun ‘this, now, then’ [Shi]. Pulleyblank (1995: 89) considers shí a relatively unemphatic form of → shì14 是. See also §3.3.3.   ||  [T] Sin S. SR ʐi (平), PR, LR ʐʅ; MGZY zhi (平) [ʐi]; ONW dźə

‘To go, proceed’ [Shi].    ||  [T] Sin S. SR tʂi (平), PR, LR tʂʅ; MGZY ji (平) [tʂi]; ONW tśə  ||  [E] ST *tjə ?: WT čʰa-ba ‘to go, become, be going to’; WB caᶜ ‘begin, at first’ ᛝ ə-caᶜ  ‘beginning’. These TB items do not belong to → chū3 初 as has been suggested.
‘Time, season’ [BI, Shi]. OC -> Tai: S. tii¹ < d- ‘time, favorable occasion’.   ||  [<] *tə + endopassive devoicing (§4.6) + endoactive tone B (§4.5) forming an introvert noun, ‘what is proceeding’.

‘Goal, purpose, will, wish’ [Shu] > ‘spirit, mind, record, treatise’ [Zuo]. Note the semantic proximity with the root in the phrase 不如我所之 ‘[My thoughts] are not equal to (where I am going:) my purpose’ [Shi 54, 5].   ||  [<] *tə + exopass. s/h-suffix (§4.4), lit. ‘what is being proceeded to’. This word is unrelated to → shì32 識 (suggested by Wáng Lì 1982: 95).
‘Foot > heel’ [BI, Shi]; > ‘to settle, stop’ 止 [Shi].   ||  [<] *tə + endoactive tone B noun derivation (§4.5). This word is not related to the TB items under → jǐ1 几机.

‘Date, point in time, season, planet’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [<] *də 時 + the nominal n-suffix (§6.4.3), lit. ‘what is proceeding’. This is a near synonym of shí 時, the word from which it is derived. In southern dialects the word for ‘time’ is a composite which includes this word rather than the standard shí (as in Mand. shí-hòu 時候): M-Fúzhōu seiŋᴬ²-ŋauᶜ² 辰候, Y-Guǎngzhōu siᴬ²-sɐnᴬ² 時辰.

‘Juice, sap, melting snow’ [Li].   ||  [D] PMin *tšep  ||  [WFE] Etymology not certain. Perh. related is PLB *Ɂgrip ‘lac, pine resin’: WB kʰrip, kʰyip [STC: 38] (CVST 5: 65); or to Kachin məgyep ‘liquor’ (STC: 38); or HST: 99 relates zhī to WT čʰab ‘water’, but initial velars do not palatalize in WT. Prob. not related to → chěn2 瀋沈 ‘a liquid’.
‘Juice’ [Yili] is perh. a cognate of zhī (Unger Hao-ku 47, 1995: 141); the dialect word from East of the Passes xié 協 (Ɣiep) [gep] [FY 3.7] is prob. related.

‘Limb, branch’ 支枝 [Shi, Yi], ‘body limb’ 肢 [Meng]; ‘to separate’ 支, ‘go astray’ 枝 [Xun] (OC -> Tai: S. keeᴬ¹ ‘go astray’), ‘branch of a tree, go astray’ 枝.  ||  [WFE] ST: Chepang gweɁ ‘finger’ ᛝ keŋ ‘twig, branch’, hluŋ keŋ- ‘be distracted’ (hluŋ ‘mind’), Lushai keᴸ ‘leg’ [Weidert 1975: 28], Tani *ke(ŋ) ‘finger’; WT ’gyed-pa, bgyes, bkye ‘to divide’ (Bodman 1980: 182).  → qí6 騎 ‘to ride’ may be related.
‘Bifurcating, forked (road)’ 歧 [Lie]; ‘to stride’ 岐 [Shi] (HST p. 65).

‘To know, understand’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂi (平); MGZY ji (平) [tʂi]; ONW te  ||  [WFE] Prob. ST: Lushai hriaR / hreᴴ / hriatF ‘to know’ (CVST 2: 73), JP tʃe³³ < rje³³ ‘to know’, perh. WT rig-pa ‘to know’.
‘Knowledge, wisdom’ [BI, Shu, Meng] > ‘be wise’ [Zuo] (Downer 1959: 287).  ||  [<] exopass. of zhī  知 (ṭje) *tre, lit. ‘what is known’ (§4.4).

‘Single’ [Gongyang], measure word for individual birds, animals and things that occur naturally in pairs, eventually extended to include other objects (Norman 1988: 116).  ||  [E] ST *tjak: PTB *tyik ~ *tyak (STC p. 94; HPTB: 346) > PLB *C-tik§, *ti² ‘one’ > WB tac ᛝ PLB *Ɂdik ‘only’ (Matisoff 1997a: 81) > Lahu tí ‘only’; Limbu thik ‘a little, only’; WT gčig ‘one’; JR kətiag (Beyer 1992: 83). Vowel e as in OC (from *-ja-): Bumthang t(h)ek, Cuona Monpa tʰeɁ⁵⁴ (Matisoff 1997a: 20; HPTB: 507).  ||  [WFE] ST: PLB *day² ᛝ tí ‘only’ > WB tʰiᴮ ‘single, alone’ (Matisoff 1997a: 21), JP tai³³ ‘single’.
‘Only’ [Meng]. Acc. to the phonetic series, shì has a T-like initial, and other meanings of shì had the alternate MC reading tśjäk.

‘Only’ [Post-Han]. The ONW and earlier readings with initial velar (kieᴮ) belong to a different word; by the time this word appears in the literature, earlier tśie and kie type syllables had already merged into the palatal.
‘Peace, happiness’ [SW: Yi].  ||  [E] ST: WT bde-ba ‘happy’ (HST: 91).
‘Foot fetters’ [Zhouli]. The final *t is prob. a nominal suffix (§6.2.1).  ||  [E] ST: WB tʰit ‘stocks for confinement’.
‘Foot shackle for criminals’ 鈦 [Guan]; (‘shackle for axle’:) ‘wheel-axle cap’ 犇 [Chuci] (Unger Hao-ku 39, 1992). The vowel correspondence is unusual, perh. these two CH words are unrelated.
‘Be reverent, revere, respect’ [BI, Shu]. CVST (2: 126) relates this word to WT sti-ba ‘honor, respect, reverence’.

‘Grease’ (for lubrication) [Shi]. SW says that zhī belongs to animals with horns, → gāo3 膏 ‘grease, fat’ to animals without horns (e.g. pigs). The OC initial is not certain, the phonetic implies an OC *k-, but palatalization of 旨 may have occurred so early in the Zhou period that it could also be used for words with original dental initials.   ||  [E] The TB area has words for ‘grease, fat’ with the final -il, but with initial consonants which are difficult to reconcile with the CH word: PTB *tsil (STC: 168f.) > WT tsʰil ‘fat’ n.; Kanauri tsil ‘marrow’; PL *tsi¹ ‘fat’, WB cʰi ‘oil’, kʰraŋ-cʰi ‘marrow’ [Matisoff 1978: 183f] (STC: 169 n. 452). Also, note AA: Santali itil ‘be fat’, Khmer kɔn-Êul.
‘To tarry, slow’ [Shi].   ||  [E] <> ? AA: Semai /kərdiɁ/,  Temiar /kədiɁ/  ‘to cease from activity, wait’, Mon /tÆəɁ/, WMon dui’ ‘to stop, keep quiet, stay put’.
‘To wait’ 遲 [Xun]; ‘to sow late, unripe’ 晃困 [Shi].

‘To weave’ vb. [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *tak (STC no. 17) > WT ’tʰag-pa ‘to weave’ ᛝ tʰags ‘texture, web’; PLB *tak / *dak ‘weave, spin’.    ||  [WFE] Some TB languages have a variant, or different etymon, with initial *r: PLB *rak, *k-rak, also Mutwang (Rawang - Nung) raɁ ‘weave’ [Matisoff TSR: 70]; Lushai ṭahᴸ < traɁ or trah ‘to weave, woven’. There is another word with *t- ~ *r- variants: PTB *ti ~ *ri ‘water’ (PTB *tap ‘fireplace’ and *rap ‘shelf over fire-place’ (STC: 19) are apparently different words). Tibetan and Chinese (where applicable) have the T-variant, Burmese the R-variant.

‘Woven cloth, be woven’ [Shi].    ||  [<] exopass. of zhī  織 (tśjək) (§4.4), lit. ‘what is woven’.  ||  [E] ST: WT btags pf. of ’tʰag- ‘woven’ ᛝ tʰags ‘texture, web’, JP daɁ³¹ < dak³¹ ‘woven material’.

‘Simply, only’ [Meng]. Karlgren GSR 919a believes that the homophone ‘straight, right’ [Shi] is the same word (see under → zhì22 置).  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐi (入); MGZY ci (入) [dʐi]; ONW dik  ||  [WFE] ? ST: tak ‘one’ in several Western Himalayan lgs., e.g. Darmiya taku ‘one’.
‘Simple, only’ [Shi].

‘Single’ 犆 [Li], ‘single, an only one’ 特 [Yili], ‘only’ [Lü]; ‘a mate, a match for’ 特 [Shi]. The meaning ‘male animal, bull’ 特 (see → tè2 特) could be derived from the meaning ‘a mate, match’, but this is speculation.

‘Straight, right’ [Shi] could either belong to → zhì22 置 ‘set up’, or to → zhí1 直 ‘single’ (so Karlgren GSR 919a). Probable allofam → dé2 德.  ||  [E] ST: PLB *N-d(y)ak§ ‘truely, very’, WB tyak-tyak ‘very’; Lushai takᴸ ‘real, true, genuine, very’. It is not clear if / how the following may be related: Lushai dikᴸ ‘right, accurate, true, proper, correct’; JP tik⁵⁵ ‘always 一直’.

‘Nephew, niece’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *b-ləy ‘nephew, grandchild’ (STC no. 448; Matisoff 1995a: 52), OBurm. mliy, WB mreᴮ ‘grandchild’ [IST: 337]. For the initials, see §8.1.1; §8.1.5; for the final *-t, see §6.2.
‘To hold, seize, take’ [BI, Shi]. → zhí6 縶馽 ‘bind’ etc. is perh. cognate.

‘To catch, seize’ 摯 [Shujing]; ‘bird of prey’ 鷙 [Chuci], ‘seize a prey’ [Li] (Baxter / Sagart 1998: 57); ‘ceremonial gift’ 贄 [Shujing] is thought to be cognate (Wáng Lì 1982: 591f).  ||  [WFE] ? ST: Perh. WT čʰab ‘power, authority’ (HST: 120). MK: Khmer and OKhmer /cap/ ‘hold, grasp’ is thought to be related, but the initials and vowels do not match very closely, see → jié2 捷.

‘Rope, tether’ [Shi], ‘to bind’ 縶 [Zuo]; ‘to hobble, bind the front feet of a horse’ 馽 [Zhuang].  ||  [E] Note Lushai čepᴸ / čeɁᴸ (Lorrain chep, cheh) ‘to nip, clip, clamp, fasten, bind, pinch’, to which the CH word may be related. Perh. cognate to → zhí5 執 ‘hold’.
‘Be hibernating, clustering’ (of insects, snakes) [Shi, Yi] may belong to → jì10 揖.
‘Duty, attend to, manage’ [Zuo], ‘duties of office’ [Shi]. This word could belong to the wf → zhì22 置.

‘Be fine tasting, excellent’ [Shi] > (flavor:) ‘basic idea’ [Yi] (so Karlgren GSR 552a).   ||  [T] Sin S. SR tʂi (上), PR, LR tʂʅ; MGZY ji (上) [tʂi]; ONW  tśi   ||  [E] ST: dgyes-pa ‘rejoice’ ᛝ dge-ba ‘happiness, virtue’ (Bodman 1980: 182; HST: 73).
‘Enjoy’ (food) [Shi] > ‘enjoy, like very much’ [Chu].

‘Paper’ [Hou Hanshu].  ||  [E] Bodman (1980: 184) relates this to Viet. giâ´y, PVM *k-cajɁ [Ferlus] ‘paper’ which, like the PMin form *tšiɑiᴮ, presupposes an OC rime *-ai rather than the QY’s *-e. When this word was committed to writing, the rimes OC *-ai and *e had already merged in some dialects, a process which is observed already in late Zhou texts (Pulleyblank 1962: 216).

‘Embroidery’ [BI, Zhouli].  ||  [WFE] Etymology not certain. Possibly from ST *C-rwi: Lushai ṭʰuiᴴ ‘to sew’, JP ri³¹ ‘thread’; for absence of the medial w in CH, see §10.2.1. Alternatively, this wf could be related to MK: Khmer tir ‘to sew clothes or tree-leaves’ [S. Lewitz AA Studies 2, 1976: 742]; the metathesis of the MK final *-r may have been occasioned by the final consonant forms in this wf (-irt > -rit), but can also occur in words with simple final *-r, see §7.7.3 and §6.1.
‘Embroidered cloth, fine cloth’ [Shi].   ||  [<] Tone A noun of zhǐ 黹 (ṭiᴮ) (§3.1).
‘To sew’ [GY].
‘To mend (old clothes)’ [Yupian] was a Han period Qín dialect word for zhì 紩 ‘to sew’ (above) [FY 4].

‘To come to, get to, arrive at, reach to’ [BI, Shi]. See §8.1.5 on GSR 413.   ||  [T] Sin S. SR tʂi (去), PR, LR tʂʅ; MGZY ji (去) [tʂi]; ONW tśi  ||  [E] ST: WT mčʰis-pa (to have arrived): ‘to be, be there, exist’.  ||  [WFE] ST: WT mčʰi-ba ᛝ mčʰis-pa, see above; Tiddim cì ‘to say’, Bodo mitiɁ, Garo maɁ-si-a   ||  (Weidert 1987: 25). Lushai tiᴸ / tiɁᴸ < tiih / tiɁ/h ‘to do, perform, treat, think, say’ ᛝ tiɁ ‘cause to be, cause, make’, WB te ‘make sthg and do sthg with it’, Lahu te.
‘To bring, bring about, effect’ [BI, Shi].  ||  [E] caus. of zhì 至 by *r in the initial (Pulleyblank 1973: 118; §7.5).   ||  [T] Sin S. SR tʂi (去), PR, LR tʂʅ; MGZY ji (去) [tʂi]; ONW ti

‘To come to, bring about, effect, accomplish, achieve’ [Shi]; ‘come to’ [Chuci]; ‘to bring about, establish, settle’ 耆 [Shi]. The root initial is a dental, the graph 耆 which had an OC velar initial was perh. borrowed after palatalization.   ||  [E] ST: WT mčʰi-ba ‘come, go, say’.

‘Water leech’ [SW, GY].   ||  [E] ST etymon, although the correspondence of the initial consonants is unusual (§8.1.5): PTB *m/s-liːt ‘water leech’ (STC no. 396; HPTB: 350), but KN *m-hliit (IST: 27) Lushai hliit < C-lit; Lepcha hlet-bŭ, Karen Pho *səli, Chepang lit. TB cognates to words in GSR 413 have pre-initial *m- (§8.1.5). The unrelated Mand. word for ‘leech’ also has the *m-prefix: mǎ-huáng 螞蟥, so do old dialect words mǎ-qí 馬蜞, mǎ-qí 馬耆. Alternatively, CVST 2: 129 connects zhì with WT sdig ‘scorpion’.   ||  [C] The word may possibly be related to → dié2 咥 *lit ‘to bite’.

‘Be weighed down’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: PTB *s-ləy-t ~ *s-rəy-t ‘heavy’ (HPTB: 49) > WT lči-ba < lhyi, lǰi-ba < lyi; Kanauri li-ko ‘heavy’, Lepcha lí, lím, PL *C-li² > WB leᴮ, JP li³³; KN *rit > Lushai ritᴸ / riɁᴸ < rit / rih ‘be heavy’. ‘Leech’ → zhì2 蛭 with the same phonetic points to an initial *l  (§8.1.5); Qiang-Queyu qa⁵⁵-rlə⁵⁵ ‘heavy’ may or may not support an original initial *rl- for OC and KN; a prefix OC *r- for PTB *s- would not be unusual; see §5.3.

‘Sickle, cut with a sickle’ [Shi] > ‘ears of grain’ [Shu]  ||  [E] Perh. ST: WT gri ‘knife’, WB kreᴮ ‘copper’, JP mə³¹-gri³³ ‘brass’, Lushai hreiᴸ < hreih ‘axe, hatchet’; for the initial correspondence see §7.1.4; §8.1.5; for final *-t see §6.2.1. Alternatively, Luo Yongxian (ICSTLL 2002) suggests that zhì is related to Tai: Po-ai liipᴰ¹ᴸ < *tʰr- ‘small knife used to cut or reap glutinous rice’, Wu-ming rep, Yay (Dioi) tʰep, but the Tai and CH final consonants do not agree. Alternatively, the TB items may belong to → qí14 鰭鬐 ‘fin’ (semantically less likely).
‘To stop up’ [Shi], ‘block-headed [Lunyu].  ||  [E] ST: WT ’dig-pa ‘to stop up’ ᛝ ’dig ‘a stopper’ (HST: 142).

Xnote: [Yupian 6th cent. AD] (the reading may simply be that of the phonetic)
Notes: ‘Vagina’ (ZWDCD), ‘vulva’ (Sino-Japanese acc. to Benedict); the meaning is only later attested (Benedict LTBA 14.1, 1991: 143).  ||  [E] ST *tey (Benedict): PTB *teyᴮ, PKaren *Ɂteᴮ (Benedict LTBA 5.1, 1979:22). The CH form goes back to a hypothetical OC *tit which brings it close to the TB / ST etymon *ti ‘water’ as in → tì1 涕 *thiɁ/h ‘tears’: JP mə³¹-di³³ ‘be moist, be wet’ ᛝ mə³¹-dit³¹ ‘to moisten, be wet’; PLoloish *Ntit ‘soak in water’ ᛝ *Ɂtit ‘to immerse’ (or *Ntik ᛝ Ɂtik) ᛝ Lahu dì (< *Ndi) ‘ejaculate’ (of a man), ‘moisten due to sexual excitement’ (of a woman) (Matisoff 1978: 33; 2002: 53 no. 109). Apparently zhì has the nominal t-suffix for natural objects, lit. ‘the moist thing’ (§6.2.1). The etymon is also reminiscent of MK-PVM *k-cɛːɁ ‘vagina’. Syn. → bī1 屄.

‘To fall down’ 陊 [SW]; ‘fall down, collapse’ 阤 [Guoyu].  ||  [WFE] ST: WB laiᴮ ‘fall down from an erect posture’ (< lañ) ᛝ hlaiᴮ ‘throw down from an erect posture’ (< hlañᴮ). Note also PKS *lai⁴ ‘to fall’.
‘To destroy’ (e.g. a house) [Guoyu].
‘Wicked, malignant’ [Shi].  ||  [E] <> Tai: S. keekᴰ¹ ‘wicked, perverted’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 160).

‘To work, make, regulate, govern’ [Shi] > ‘well-governed, in good order’ [Yi], ‘punish’ [Zuo]. Downer (1959: 287) reads ‘well-governed’ [Liji] in tone C, the other meanings in tone A. Sagart (1999: 127) relates this word to → lí4 釐 ‘regulate’. If related, zhì may possibly belong to an AA wf, related to → lǐ5  理.   ||  [T] Sin S. SR dʐi (去); MGZY ci (去) [dʐi]; MTang ḍi, ONW diə
‘Black mole’ [Shiji 誌, GY].   ||  [D] A commentary to Shǐjì says that zhì 誌 is the ordinary word for ‘black mole’ in the southern Wú and Chǔ dialects. PMin *kiᶜ.
‘To roast’ [Shi].

‘Be roasted’ [Shi], ‘a roast meat’ [Zuo] (Downer 1959: 274).  ||  [<] *tak + pass. (§4.4) < ‘what has been roasted’.  ||  [E] ? ST: PLB *kyik > Lahu chîɁ ‘be hot (enough to burn)’, WB kʰyac ‘be burnt’ (as food); if related the OC form was probably *k(i)ek or *kiak.

‘To ascend, die’ [Shi], ‘promote’ [Shu].   ||  [E] ST: PLB *ɴtak ‘ascend’ > WB tak ‘go up, ascend, advance, increase’, ~ *Ɂtak ‘lift, carry’, ~ *tak ‘upper part, top surface’: WB ə-tʰak ‘upper part, prior time’ [Matisoff TSR: 48]; WT ltag-pa ‘the upper part / place’, and / or tʰeg-pa ‘lift, raise’ (so HST: 110), JP (lə³¹-) tʰaɁ³¹ ‘above’. HST: 154 associates WT ltag-pa with → tuò1 拓 (tʰâk) ‘to take up, lift’ [Lie] which may perh. be a loan from a TB language. Wáng Lì (1982: 253) and Matisoff (BSOAS 63.3, 2000: 363) relate this word to → dēng1 登 ‘ascend’.
‘To slip, trip’ [Shi]. This etymon is apparently parallel to, but distinct from, the syn. → dié3 跌, see there for more.  ||  [WFE] ST: WT ’dred-pa ‘to slip, slide, glide’; Kanauri *bret (HST: 135).
‘To stumble’ [Zuo] which writes prob. the s. w. as  疐 above (so Duàn Yùcái).
‘Be angry’ 懥 [Shi], 懫 [Shu]. As in → zhì16 疐, the two graphs for this word are MC homophones but placed in different OC rime categories.

‘Natural qualities’ [Li], ‘substance’ [Yi], ‘essential’ [Lunyu].   ||  [E] Unger (Hao-ku 39, 1992: 88) relates this word to WT gšis ‘nature, temper, natural disposition’ (the correspondence of the initials is unusual), while Baxter / Sagart (1998: 52) derive this word by t-prefix from → shí12 實 ‘fruit, solid, really’. Karlgren (1956: 16) connects this word with zhì 質 (ṭiᶜ) LH ṭis, *trəts ‘pledge, security give, hostage’ [Zuozhuan].

T_data: [T] ONW dźik  ‘Aim will’ [Chuci] could belong either to

Notes: ‘To set, place, arrange’ [Shi].   ||  [E] ST: WT ’ǰog-pa, bžag  ‘to put, place, arrange’.
‘To sow or plant early’ [Shi].
‘Hold upright’ 值 [Shi], 植 [Shu], ‘a pole’ 植 [Li] (植 has also the MC reading źjək).
‘To plant, cultivate’ 殖 [Shu], 植 [Zhouli], ‘raise, establish’ 殖 [Guoyu], 植 [Zhouli]; ‘to place’ 植 [Lun]; ‘grow, flourish’ 植 [Huainan] (has also the MC reading ḍiᶜ).
‘A pole’ [Zhouli].   ||  [C] Possible allofams: → zhí8 職 ‘duty’, → zhì21 植 ‘aim, will’. Syn. → shǔ7 樹.
‘Wild boar, pig’ [OB, Li].  ||  [E] KT: PKS *Ɂdlaaiᴮ ‘wild pig’, PHlai *lat ‘wild boar’.

‘Some kind of small deer’ [OB, SW]. When hunting, Shang dynasty kings would often kill this animal in great numbers [OB], but later its identity was mostly forgotten. SW has the variant xiè-zhì  解廌 or 解豸 LH gɛɁ-ḍɛɁ. This riming binome makes it likely that the LH reading was ḍɛɁ rather than ḍieɁ. Curiously, in a passage in Zuǒzhuàn (Xuan 17) 豸 is supposedly a graphic loan for 解 which raises the suspicion that the latter ended up as a pre-syllable in the animal name due to a misunderstood gloss. Be that as it may, the element xiè 解 ‘distinguish, understand’ may be responsible for the belief that this animal could tell straight from crooked, right from wrong.  ||  [E] MK *draay ‘kind of deer’ (Shorto 2006 #1508) > OMon *drāy ‘hog deer’ (-> WB darai ‘hog deer’), Biat Ïraai ‘swamp deer’, PVM *k-Ïeː ‘deer’ [Ferlus], Khm. trìəːy ‘stag’. <> PYao *djai² ‘deer’ [Purnell].

‘Pheasant’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WB rac ‘pheasant’, WT sreg-pa ‘partridge’, Lushai vaᴸ-hritᴸ, SChin-Areng tari’ (Löffler Anthropos 55, 1960: 529), Mru rik, Garo grit ‘pheasant’ (STC no. 403; HPTB: 507), perh. also Chepang rut-waɁ. OC *-Ɂ for PTB *-k is regular, see §3.2.2; for the initials, see §7.1.4.

‘To cut out’ (as clothes) 制 [Shi], 製 [Zuo] > ‘robe, cloak’ 製 [Zuo] > ‘regulate > institution, law’ 制 [Zuo], sometimes thought to be related to → zhé2 折 (tśjät).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂi (去); MGZY ji (去) [tʂi]; ONW tśei

‘Be in the middle, middle, inside’ 中 [BI, Shi]; ‘inner garment, middle, medium’ 衷 [Zuo]. Baxter (1992: 233) reconstructs *k-l- on the basis of a Han sound gloss (Coblin 1983: 156) and WT. This may be the same word as → zhōng2 忠 ‘sincere’.   ||  [T] Sin S. SR tʂjuŋ (平), PR, LR tʂuŋ; MGZY jung (平) [tʂuŋ]; MTang ṭuŋ, ONW tuŋ
‘Hit the center, hit, attain’ [Zuo].  ||  [<] exoactive of zhōng 中 *truŋ (§4.3).  ||  [E] OC -> Tai: S. troŋᴬ¹ ‘hit the point’ (<> Manomaivibool 1975: 148).

‘The 2nd (middle) of three or more brothers’ [Shi], ‘second of the month’ [Shu].  ||  [E] The etymology is not certain. PMiao *ntrɔŋᴬ ‘middle’ is close to the OC form. Perh. related to TB-WT gžuŋ < glyuŋ or gryuŋ (?) ‘middle’ (<> HST: 53). But other etyma may be related instead: STC: (182 n. 479) relates zhōng to PTB *tuːŋ ‘inside’ (STC no. 390) > Manchati toŋ(-riŋ) ‘inside’, Chepang duŋ ‘inside’ (esp. of a dwelling) ᛝ duŋɁ- ‘push to the center’; WB ə-twaŋᴮ ‘inside, inner part of a thing’, Lushai čʰuŋᴴ ‘inside of anything’ (<> CVST 2: 3); Rawang ă-duŋ ‘middle’ (IST: 55). The basic meaning of both these TB etyma is ‘inside’, not ‘middle’, however. Finally, there is yet another root meaning ‘inside’ < ‘excavate’ in AA, see under → chuán1 船 ‘boat’.

‘Sincere, loyal, integrity’ [Lunyu]. Perh. this is the s. w. as → zhōng1 中.  ||  [E] ST: WT gžuŋ ‘to attend to, sincere’ (<> Bodman 1980: 123; HST: 107). CH -> Tai: S. troŋᴬ¹ ‘faithful, loyal’ (<> Manomaivibool 1975: 148).
‘Father-in-law’ [Lüshi].  ||  [E] ST: Lepcha (a-)jóŋ ‘uncle’, Stod əjəŋ ‘maternal uncle, father-in-law’ (<> Unger Hao-ku 63, 1999: 246). The root initial was probably *j-, see §9.3.

‘To end, terminate, complete, completely’ [Shi]. Wáng Lì (1982: 608) derives → dōng1 冬 ‘winter’ from this word.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂjuŋ (平), PR, LR tʂuŋ; MGZY jung (平) [tʂuŋ]; ONW tśuŋ  ||  [E] ST: Chepang doŋɁ- to end, cease’ (period of time, spell of weather, speech), KN-Lai doŋ / doɁŋ ‘to end’ [LTBA 21.1: 210]. The connection with the following is not clear (for the difference in final consonants, see §6.7): WB tumᶜ ? ‘be ended’ (season) (CVST 2: 4), JP tʰum³¹ ‘be ended, terminated’, Lushai čʰumF < čʰumɁ ‘finish reaping’, also Lai tʰum ‘be ended’ ᛝ džə-tʰum ‘end something’ [Van Bik LTBA 25.2, 2002: 106].
‘Locust, grasshopper’ [Shi].  ||  [E] ST: WB kjuiŋᴮ ~ gjuiŋᴮ ‘locust’ (HST: 104). The root initial was prob. *j-, see §9.3.

‘A mound, peak; be great’ 冢 [Shi]; ‘a mound, tomb’ 塚. This is still the word for ‘tomb’ in some dialects, e.g. Mǐn-Jiàn’ōu tœyŋ²¹; in most modern dialects, the word for ‘tomb’ is → fén4 墳. A possible Han period dialect variant is → lǒng 壟隴.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *m/r-duŋ (<> HPTB: 310) > WT rduŋ ‘a small mound, hillock’, WB toŋ ‘hill, mountain’. Note also PMY *tr²ɔŋ¹ ‘mountain’ [Purnell].

‘Seeds, cereals’ [Shi] > ‘descendants’ [Guoce].  ||  [E] <> AA-PVM *k-coːŋɁ ‘seed’ [Ferlus].  ||  [WFE] ST: Chepang tuŋɁ- ‘to plant’ ᛝ duŋ ‘shoot, sprout’ (growing) ᛝ duŋ- ‘to sprout, grow’ (esp. plant), Tangsa (Barish) ¹toŋ(Ɂ) (Weidert 1987: 22).

‘To sow’ [Shi], later also ‘to plant’ (a tree).   ||  [<] exoactive of zhǒng 種 (tśjwoŋᴮ) (§4.3).   ||  [E] This may possibly be the same word as → zhǒng3 腫踵 ‘to swell’, a seed then being something that first swells before growing sprouts.

‘Swell, swollen’ 腫 [Zuo] > ‘tumor’ 腫 [Zhouli] > ‘heel’ [Li] > ‘follow in the footsteps of’ 踵 [Zuo]. For the semantic link between ‘swollen’ and ‘heel’ (< * ‘swelling’), see Matisoff (LTBA 17.2, 1994: 144). There are other etyma for ‘swollen’ with the same rime: → yōng2 癰 and → wèng 瓮甕罋 ‘jar, swollen’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂjuŋ (上); MGZY jung (上) [tʂuŋ]  ||  [E] ST: Limbu thɔŋt- ‘to swell’.
‘Be swollen, inflated’ [Shi].  ||  [<] endopass. of zhǒng 腫踵 (tśjwoŋᴮ) (§4.6).
‘Heavy’ [Shi] > ‘important’ [BI, Zuo], ‘increase, to honor’ [Zuo].  ||  [E] Etymology not certain, but note TB-WB cum ‘double, form a pair’ (for the final nasal, see §6.7).
‘Double, two, accumulate’ [Shi] > ‘twice, repeat’ [Zuo].  ||  [<] exoactive of zhòng 重 (ḍjwoŋᴮ) (§4.3).   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐjuŋ (平), PR dʐuŋ; MGZY cÿung (平) [dʐjuŋ]; ONW duoŋ

‘Milk (of cows and mares)’ [Mu tianzi zhuan], ‘milk-like fluid’ [SW] is a loan from some ancient Central Asian language (Pulleyblank 1962: 250ff). LH was probably toŋᶜ because it is the simpler reading and MC ṭioŋᶜ is the reading of the phonetic element.

‘Be numerous, all, the multitude (i.e. common people) [OB, BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂjuŋ (去), PR, LR tʂuŋ; MGZY jung (去) [tʂuŋ]; ONW tśuŋ  ||  [E] Prob. ST: WT yoŋs ‘all, whole’ (incl. multitude of people) ᛝ OTib. yoŋ ‘in all, at all times, ever before’; for the initials, see §9.3.

‘Boat’ [OB, Shi]. Acc. to the Yìjīng, a zhōu was originally a hollowed tree trunk (canoe) (Huáng Jīnguì, Shěn Xíróng YYWZX 1987.8: 41ff) like → yú14 俞.  ||  [WFE] MK *ɗuuk, *ɗuk ‘boat, canoe’ (Shorto 2006 #336): Khmer duːk, Bahn. *duːk ‘boat’, PVM *Ïoːk -> Tai-S. tuːkᴰ¹ ‘boat’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 159). For the lack of final consonant in CH, see §6.9. Syn. → chuán1 船.
‘Carriage pole’ [Shi] may perh. be cognate (‘trunk’ > ‘pole’ / ‘canoe’?).
‘Island in a river’ [BI, Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂiw (平); MGZY jiw (平) [tʂiw]  ||  Several synonyms with different vowels may be related: zhǔ 渚, zhǐ 沚, chí 坻.
‘Islet’ [Shi], smaller than zhōu [EY 12.2].
‘Islet’ [Shi], smaller than zhǔ [EY 12.2].
‘Iislet’ [Shi], smaller than zhǐ [EY 12.2].

‘To surround, encircle, circle, everywhere, curve (in the road)’ [Shi].    ||  [WFE] Etymology not certain. Perh. connected with TB-WT gču-ba ~ lču-ba ‘screw’ ᛝ gčud-pa ~ lčud-pa ‘to turn, twist, plait, braid’. Alternative: Tai: S. diw³ ‘strips of rattan or bamboo bent in a circle to which ribs of a cage are fastened’ (McFarland: 330). Other alternative: note AA: Khmer jwta /cúuət/ ‘to encircle or wrap (the head) in a length of cloth’, the final -t would be lost in OC after a long vowel (§6.9); the initials could be reconciled if the source had tj- or tšj- (as opposed to ts-); a parallel case may be → zhōu4 周. A doubtful comparandum is → tāo1 綢.
‘To be wrapped round, pressed tightly together, dense’ [BI, Shi], ‘bind round’ [Shi]; ‘nightgown’ 裯 [Shi] (Karlgren 1956: 17).
‘Be tied round’ [Shi] (Baxter 1992: 513).

‘To have aid, help’ [Shi], ‘relieve, succour’ 賙 [Zhouli].  ||  [E] Etymology not clear. Perh. the s. w. as → zhōu3 周 ‘surround’ as words for ‘help, aid’ are often derived from the notion ‘next to, or around, a person’ (see under → zuǒ 左 and → yòu2 右). Alternatively, note AA: Khmer jwya [ɉuuj] /cúuəj/ ‘to aid, help, succour, rescue, save’, the final -j would be lost in OC after the long vowel (§6.9). For the initials, see the comment under → zhōu3 周.
‘Rice gruel’ [Zuo, Li].  ||  [E] ST: Association with WT tʰug-pa ‘soup, broth’ (Bodman 1980: 172; HST: 137) is more straightforward than Karlgren’s (1956: 17) derivation from → yù22 育毓鬻 ‘produce’.
‘Wrinkles, furrows; to frown’ [Tang: Han Yu] (Unger Hao-ku 35, 1986: 34).  ||  [E] ? ST: Lepcha a-sŭr ‘wrinkle’. Prob. related to → sù8 肅蒋 ‘shrivel, contract’.
‘To crinkle, crape’ [Shi].  ||  [<] exoactive of zhōu 皺 (tṣjəu) (§4.4).

‘Wrist, elbow’ [OB, Zuo].   ||  [<] This is a tone B endoactive body part derivation (§3.3.2) from a root *tru which also underlies → chù2 絀, hence lit. ‘the thing that is bending’. The phonetic in the latter may indicate some sort of velar in the complex initial, hence the word may be related to TB-WB kruiᶜ ‘bow down, stoop’, and perh. also to WT gru-mo ‘elbow’ (HST: 70) is related, which lit. means ‘corner, angle’, however. Note also PTai *x-: S. kʰɔɔᶜ¹ (loan?). The Lushai word for ‘elbow’ kiuᴸ < kiuɁ/h may belong to the root → jiǔ3 糾. For a semantic parallel, see wàn 腕 (under → yū1 迂紆).

‘Time of daylight, daytime, morning, day’ [BI, Shi].    ||  [D] PMin *təuᶜ > Xiàmén, Fú’ān tauᶜ ‘afternoon’.  ||  [E] ST: WT gdugs  elegant sp. ‘midday, noon’ (Bodman 1980: 172; HST: 61).  ||  OC -> Tai: S. truuᴮ¹ ‘early morning’ (Manomaivibool 1975: 148).
‘Helmet’ [Shi].
‘Full dress’ [Shi].
‘Sleeve’ 褎 [Shi], 袖 [Zuo]. The role of *s- is not clear, perhaps iterative because sleeves come in pairs.
‘To wrap, cover’ 韜 [ Yili]; ‘conceal, doubtful’ 慆 [Zuo]. This word may be unrelated.  This wf means any kind of ‘cover’ one slips over something.
‘Be red, scarlet’ [BI, Shi] may be an old basic word for ‘red’, rivaling → chì3 赤 (Baxter 1983).   ||  [E] <> MK: PVM *tɔh ‘red’ [Ferlus]. → zhě 赭 may perh. be cognate.

‘Pig’ [Zuo].    ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂy (平); MGZY jÿu (平) [tʂy]  ||  [D] CDC cieᴬ¹; more archaic forms are preserved in southern dialects: M-Fúzhōu tyᴬ¹, Cháozhōu tɯᴬ¹, Xiàmén tiᴬ¹; X-Chángshā tyᴬ¹; W-Kāihuà tɑᴬ¹   ||  [E] Perh. a ST word: Mru tia ‘(wild) pig’ (Löffler 1966: 146). Alternatively, → jiā8 豭 is said to be a dialect form of zhū [FY]; but since jiā appears to be much older than zhū, the latter could have developed *Cr- > tr- > ṭ which seems to be associated with rural words (§1.3.1; §7.1.4).

‘Bamboo’ [Shi].  ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂy (入), PR tʂuɁ; MGZY jÿu (入) [tʂy]; ONW tuk  ||  [E] <> PTai: S. tɔɔkᴰ¹ᴸ < *proɔk, PKS *tʰruk ‘bamboo strip’; or PTai *Ɂdrok ‘a kind of bamboo’ (Luo Yongxian MKS. 27, 1997: 293). <> PMiao *Îəuᴰ.
‘To pursue’ (animals, not men) [OB, Shu] (Schuessler 1987: 851; Qiu Xigui 2000: 213). See → zhuī2 追 for a near synonym which may be related in spite of the difference in finals.

‘Torch’ [Li].  ||  [E] ST: PLB *duk ‘burn, be blazing’ ᛝ *Ɂduk ‘kindle, set on fire’ [Matisoff TSR: 39] > WB tok ‘blaze, flame, shine, glitter’; WT dugs-pa ‘to make warm, to light, kindle’; Lushai dukᴸ ‘be glowing with heat’ (like ashes) (HST: 151). This word may have a wider distribution, note MK: Bahnar tōk, Stieng dúk ‘to burn’.
‘To check the foot, stop walking’ [Yi], ‘stamp the foot’ [Xun].  ||  [WFE] ST: WT ’dug-pa ‘to sit, dwell, stay, remain’ (HST: 141); or WT rdog-pa ‘step, kick, walk’; JP tʰoŋ³¹ ‘stop’.
‘To stop’ [Lie] > ‘dwell’ in a place [Nan Qishu].
‘To stop, dwell, stay’ [Hou Hanshu], perhaps a variant of zhù 住 (ḍjuᶜ).

‘To stamp earth, earth up’ (earth into walls) > ‘build’ [Shi]; ‘beat, strike’ [Zhouli].  ||  [E] ST *truk: WT rdug-pa ‘to strike against, to stumble at’; WB tuik ‘strike against, engage in combat’. For more ST cognates and / or parallel stems, see under → chù1 觸.

‘Master’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂy (上); MGZY jÿu (上) [tʂy]; ONW tśuoᴮ  ||  [E] Etymology not clear; note these comparanda: (1) ST: WT ǰo-bo ‘elder brother, lord, nobleman’ ᛝ ǰo-mo ‘mistress, lady, goddess’. (2) WT tʰu ‘chief’ (Peiros and Starostin CAAAL 22, 1984: 125). (3) MK: PMon *[d]ndooɁ  Nyah Kur ‘headman’, Mon ‘to teach, instruct’. (4) Tai: S. čok⁴ ‘a leader, chief’ (for final -k, see §3.2.2).

‘A large deer living in the mountains’ [YiZhoushu]; its tail was used as a duster.  ||  [E] This word is perh. connected to MK: PMonic *-truus ‘boy, man’, OKhmer *trus ‘strong male of animals’; Kha Boloven truy ‘male of deer’, but we should expect an *r in the OC initial.

‘To boil, cook’ [Li].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂy (上); MGZY jÿu (上) [tʂy]  — [D] PMin *tšyᴮ  ||  [E] Bodman (1980: 134) compares this word with WB kyak, Lushai tlakᴸ < klak ‘to boil’ (vegetables). If related, an OC *kiaɁ needs to be assumed which had palatalized by the time of the Lǐjì, but this would leave Lushai still unexplained.
‘To store away, bag for clothes’ 褚 [Zuo] (Mand. chǔ); ‘to store, supplies, storehouse, ownership’ [BI], ‘to heap’ 貯 [Guliang].
‘To collect, store up’ [Guiyu]. Karlgren (1956: 17) connects this word with zhū 諸 ‘all’ (under → duō 多).

‘To cut’ 斸 [Guoyu], ‘cut out, eradicate’ 鐲 (zhuó) [Xun].  ||  [WFE] TB parallel stem: Lushai tśuᴸ / tśukᴸ (Lorr. chu) ‘to bite’ (as snake), ‘peck, strike with a pecking motion, knock against, injure’, WT mčʰu ‘lip, bill or beak of birds’ (the WT word is not related to → chún1 脣漘).   ||  [C] For ST cognate and / or parallel stems, see under → chù1 觸 for an overview.

‘To hew, chop, carve’ (trees, wood) 斲 [Shi], ‘to carve, chisel’ 琢 [Shi], ‘break open’  斲 [Zuo]; ‘to castrate’ 斀 [SW: Shu], ‘to beat, strike’ 椓 [Shi].   ||  [D] In some Yuè dialects this is the word for ‘to chop, cut’ (written → duò4 剁): HK col. tœkᴰ, Jiāngmén tiœkᴮ¹, Dòumén (Zhen) tiɔkᴰ¹, Bǎo’ān tiɔᴮ². The late word Mand. duò 剁 (tuâᴮ) [GY] ‘cop, cut’ may be related.  ||  [E] ST *trok: Mikir artòk < r-tò/uk  ‘chop off’.
[D] Mǐn: Amoy col. teɁᴰ¹, lit. tokᴰ¹, Zhāngzhōu tøɁ   ||  ‘To peck up’ [Shi].
‘Beak’ 咮 [Shi], 啄 [Han texts]. In MC, there is no div. II in the QY rime -əu.  ||  [E] ST *trok: PLB *tok ‘peck, strike with a curved instrument, hook onto’, WB tok-hra ‘woodpecker’.

‘To attach, connect’ [Li], ‘copulate’ [Mozi]. The meanings ‘touch’ [Zuo], ‘to apply’ (e.g. ear to wall) [Shijing] may have been influenced by → zhù7 注 ‘touch’.  ||  [E] AA, MK *tɔ[ɔ]k ‘to copulate (with)’ (Shorto 2006 #310) appears to be the same word.  ||  [WFE] ST: WT gtogs-pa ‘to belong to, be part of’ ᛝ tʰog-pa ‘to gather’ (HST: 52), rdogs-pa ‘to bind, fasten, tie’.  ||  TB has a parallel stem *dzoːk, *tsoːk (STC note 178): Chang suːk ‘vulva’, JP məc´ɔɁ ‘socket, vagina’, PLB *ɉok > WB cok. Lushai čʰuF (Lorr. chhu) < čʰuuɁ ‘vulva’ (Benedict LTBA 5.1, 1979).

‘Be connected, attached to’ [Shi], ‘belong to’ [Shu]; (‘fit’: ‘socket’ and related items:) ‘vulva, penis, to copulate’ (the SW radical of shǔ is ‘tail’ – GSR 1224s).   ||  [<] endopass. voicing of zhǔ 屬 (§4.6).
‘Vulva, penis’ [GY], lit. ‘socket’ acc. to Mei Tsu-Lin 1979.  ||  [E] ST: PTB *s-tu ‘vagina’ (HPTB: 247), WT stu, Chepang tuɁ ‘female genitals’ (Weidert 1987: 27).

‘To bind, attach’ [Shi]. This word may perhaps be the base for → zhù10 祝 ‘prayer’, i.e. ‘binder’.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂy (入); MGZY jÿu (入) [tʂy]  ||  [C] It is not yet clear how the different outside etyma may be related to one or other member of this large CH word family — if these CH words should indeed all be related. For further alternatives, see → dào1 倒.
‘Space between gate and gate-screen’ [Liji]. Perh. related to → cháng5 場 [ḍɑŋ].
‘Lamb’ [Shi] (syn. tà 羍 (tʰât)  LH tʰɑt ‘lamb’ [OB, SW]).  ||  [E] Etymology not certain; perh. ST: WT ra-ma ‘goat’, Kanauri la. For the initial correspondence, see §7.1.4; §12.9 WT (6).

‘Ramie’ 苧, 紵 [Shi], ‘cloth’ or ‘rope’ made thereof [Hanshu], 苧 [Shiji].   ||  [D] M-Xiàmén tɯᴮ²;  Zhōngbǎo kyɁᴰ² (common in Kè-Mǐn, Branner 1995: 268).  ||  [E] ? ST: WT ras ‘cotton cloth’; Lushai laᴸ < laɁ/h ‘cotton’. For the initial correspondence, see §7.1.4; §12.9 WT (6). <> PMiao *ndoᶜ ‘hemp’ (discussed by Strecker LTBA 10.2, 1987: 49).

‘To pour’ [Shi].    ||  [WFE] Bodman (1980: 172) compares WT čʰu ‘water’ ᛝ ’čʰu-ba, bčus ‘to ladle or scoop water, irrigate’ and also includes dǒu in this wf. TB *lu ‘to pour, cast’ has initial *l and belongs to → yù4 浴 ‘to pour, bathe’.
‘To cast’ (metal) [BI, Zuo].
‘Ladle’ [Zhouli] is a tone B noun derived from zhù, lit. ‘the thing which does the pouring’.
‘Bushel, ladle, name of a constellation’ [Shi].

‘To flow into, join, meet’ intr. (as a river flows into another / the ocean) [Meng 3A, 4; Shanhaijing 5]. ‘To conduct water’ [Shi] may be this word or belong to → zhù5 注 ‘to pour’.  ||  [E] Etymology not certain. On the one hand, this word seems to be the cognate of WT mdo ‘point where two valleys / rivers meet’, i.e. ‘confluence, lower part of valley’; it could be the s. w. as → zhù7 注 ‘be touched’. On the other hand, this may be the same word as → zhù5 注 ‘to pour’ which, however, has a different WT cognate.

‘To apply’ [Zuo], ‘be touched’ [Zhuang], ‘bring together’ [Zhouli].  ||  [WFE] ST: WB tuiᶜ ‘touch lightly’, Lushai tuukF ‘to touch’ (as in a game). This stem may be related to → zhǔ8 屬 ‘attach, connect’.
‘To come in contact with, meet, next following day’ [OB].

‘Pillar’ [Yili].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐy (上); MGZY cÿu (上) [dʐy]  ||  [WFE] ST: TB-WB tuiŋ ‘post, column’; SChin Daai ktuŋ ‘post’ [Hartmann ICSTLL 1999: 6], JP toɁ³¹ < tok³¹ ᛝ ʃə⁵⁵-to⁵⁵ ‘pillar’. For the TB final -ŋ, see §3.2.4). Perh. related to → zhuó9 梲.
‘To prop up, support’ [Guoce] (Karlgren 1956: 9).

‘Prayer; invoker’ [BI, Shi], ‘to pray’ [Zuo]. This word may perh. be the same etymon as ‘to bind, attach’ (i.e. ‘a binder’), see → zhǔ7 屬.   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR tʂy (入); MGZY jÿu (入) [tʂy]  ||  [WFE] There is no outside etymological connection, similarity with AA-Pearic troː ‘to pray’ is prob. coincidence.
‘To curse’ [Shi] (Karlgren 1956: 12).  ||  [<] perh. extrovert (§4.3).
‘To pray’ 禱 [Shi]; ‘a horse sacrifice consisting of a prayer 禂 promising a sacrificial animal offering’ [SW; Zhōulǐ] (Sterckx EC 21, 1996: 64).
‘Cut off’ [Gongyang].  ||  [E] ST *tu(k): Lushai tukᴸ ‘cut, chop’, JP tʰu³³ ‘cut’.  ||  For ST cognate and / or parallel stems, see under → chù1 觸 for an overview.
‘Aid’ [Shi].   ||  [T] Sin Sukchu SR dʐu (上); MGZY cu (上) [dʐu]
‘To help’ [SW] (Gong Hwang-cherng 1999: 9).

‘To place, order of place, position’ [Zuo].   ||  [E] ST: PTB *ta (STC no. 19) > WT sta-gon ‘preparation’ ᛝ stad-pa ‘to put on, lay on’, Tsangla tʰa ‘to put, place’, Kanauri ta ‘place, set, appoint’, Kachin da ‘put, place’, PLB *ta², WB thaᴮ < Ɂta² ‘put, place’, Lushai daɁᴸ ‘to put, place, set, put aside’ (Comparative Vocabulary of Five ST Languages 2: 5).
‘To place, put, apply’ [Li].
‘To attach, come in contact with’ [Li], ‘be attached to’ [Guangyun] (Baxter and Sagart 1998: 46)  ||  [<] endopass. voicing of zhuó 著 (§4.6).
‘To place, position’ [Guoyu].
‘To stand in attendance’ 佇 [Shi]; ‘to stand’ 囃 [Chuci].

‘Chopsticks’ [Li]. Norman (1988: 76): “Acc. to a Mǐng work by Lù Róng, the word zhù was tabooed on boats because it was homophonous with zhù 住 ‘stop’; it was replaced by a word of opposite meaning kuài 快 ‘(go) fast’,” hence kuàizi 筷子.
